1.prez_name: 3D Graphene for Dye-sensitized Solar Cells and Supercapacitors
1.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
1.prez_authors: Yun Hang Hu, Wei   Wei, Liang  Chang
1.prez_abstract: We invented a novel process to synthesize three dimensional graphene directly from CO2, which possesses high conductivity and large accessible surface area. The 3D graphene exhibited excellent performance as a counter electrode for the dye-sensitized solar cell (DSSC). The efficiency is even better than that of a DSSC with an expensive Pt counter electrode. Furthermore, the 3D graphene electrode showed ultrahigh areal capacitance of 1.16 F/cm2 at current density of 1 A/g in a symmetric capacitor cell with 2M KOH aqueous solution as an electrolyte. In addition, the 3D electrode can reach a very large efficient-mass-loading of 11.2 mg/cm2, which meets the current commercial requirement (about 10mg/cm2) for super-capacitors. This would provide a novel approach not only to synthesize free-standing 3D graphene for energy devices, but also to control CO2 emission.

2.prez_name: Beyond Graphene Foam, a New Form of Three-dimensional Graphene for Supercapacitor Electrode
2.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
2.prez_authors: Lu  Zhang, Derek  DeArmond, Noe  Alvarez, Vesselin  Shanov
2.prez_abstract: Graphene foam (GF) is a three-dimensional (3D) graphene structure that has been intensively studied as electrode materials for energy storage applications.  However, the electrical conductivity of GF is still unsatisfactory due to the lack of macropore size (~300 µm) control that hinders its applications.  Here we demonstrated that the obtained 3D graphene structure and its assemblies are promising electrode materials for sueprcapacitors, flexible supercapacitor, lithium-sulfur battery and structure energy storage systems.

3.prez_name: Chemical Bonding in Graphene and Newly Predicted Two-dimensional Materials
3.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
3.prez_abstract: The adaptive natural density partitioning (AdNDP) algorithm combines the compactness and intuitive simplicity of Lewis theory with the flexibility and generality of canonical molecular orbital theory. The objects of chemical bonding in this method are n-center 2-electron bonds, where n goes from 1 (lone-pair) to the maximum number of atoms in the system (completely delocalized bonding). Solid state AdNDP program (SSAdNDP) allows us to elucidate the bonding in bulk materials and interfaces in a natural, chemically intuitive fashion, yielding insight into the fundamental origins of their structure and properties. In my talk, I will demonstrate the versatility of both methods by applying the concepts of localized and multicenter bonds towards the following 2D sheets and solids as well as several polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons: graphene, BC3 honeycomb epitaxial sheet, C4F fluorinated graphene sheet, Cu2Si/Cu2Ge and Ni2Si/Ni2Ge   monolayers, 2D magnetic boron, and molecules of coronene, isocoronene, and circumcoronene.

4.prez_name: Crystalline Three Dimensional Molybdenum Disulfides for Energy Generation and Storage Applications
4.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
4.prez_abstract:
This talk will highlight the potential of inexpensive and earth-abundant transition metal dichalcogenide materials as electocatalysts for a broad range of electrochemical applications. In particular, I will overview our recent progress on synthesizing highly crystalline and layered three dimensional (3D) molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) catalysts with Mo edge atoms. The growth mechanism of 3D MoS2 structure will be discussed in more details where abrupt and localized transitions from 2D to 3D take place during the growth process, which resemble the Stranski-Krastanov (SK) growth mechanism of thin films. 
I will also overview our recent discovery on MoS2/ionic liquid based co-catalyst systems that exhibit outstanding catalytic performance far exceeding that of noble metals for oxygen reduction reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, lithium-air battery and CO2 reduction system. This remarkable performance has been observed for a wide range of pH levels including acidic conditions via different reaction driving forces than that of noble metal catalysts.

5.prez_name: CVD Assembly of 3D Graphene and their Contribution for Lithium-sulfur Batteries with High Energy Density and Long Lifespan
5.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
5.prez_abstract:
Among various promising candidates with high energy densities, lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries with a high theoretical capacity and energy density are highly attractive; while the commercial application of Li-S batteries still faces some persistent obstacles, such as the low electrical conductivity of sulfur and lithium sulfide and the dissolution of polysulfides. The introduction of 3D graphene into the field of Li-S batteries sheds a light on the efficient utilization of sulfur by improving the conductivity of the composites and restraining the shuttle of polysulfides. In this presentation, the concept for the rational design of 3D graphene is explained. The advances in the use of 3D graphene in the cathode, separator, and anode is explained.1-3 New insights on the relationship between the 3D graphene structure and the electrochemical performance are presented.

References
1)Nature Commun 2014, 5, 3410. 
2)Energy Environ Sci 2014, 7, 347.
3)ACS Nano 2015, 9, 1506.

6.prez_name: Fuel Cell and Lithium Battery Membranes from the Assembly of Polymer Brush Nanoparticles
6.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
6.prez_abstract:
This talk will describe a novel approach for the preparation of proton and lithium conducting membranes using “hairy” nanoparticles (HNPs). HNPs are prepared by surface-initiated atom transfer radical polymerization (SI-ATRP). In both cases, ion-conducting channels are formed in the interstitial spaces between the nanoparticles.

Proton conducting membranes were prepared using silica nanoparticles (SNPs) surface-grafted with sulfonated polymer brushes, poly(3-sulfopropylmethacrylate), pSPM, and poly(4-styrenesulfonic acid), pSSA. Proton conducting pore-filled membranes were prepared from nanoporous colloidal crystals first assembled from unmodified SNPs, followed by filling the pores with pSPM or pSSA brushes. A sigmoidal dependence of the proton conductivity on the amount of sulfonic acid groups was found for pSPM pore-filled membranes.

Lithium conducting membranes were prepared using SNPs surface-grafted with PEO-containing polymer brushes, poly(ethylene glycol) monomethyl ether methacrylate and with poly(ethyl methacrylate). There materials showed high ionic conductivity and unusual conductivity temperature dependence.

7.prez_name: High Power High Safety Battery with Li3V2(PO4)3 Cathode and Li4Ti5O12 Anode with 95% Energy Efficiency
7.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
7.prez_abstract: Li3V2(PO4)3 (LVP) and Li4Ti5O12 (LTO) possess excellent lithium ion storage properties when properly when forming nanocomposites with graphene or other carbon. LVP cathode and LTO anode can deliver reversible specific capacities of 108 and 149 mAh/g at a rate of 5 C, respectively. No appreciable degradation can be perceived in both electrodes over 500 cycles. A full battery with LVP cathode and LTO anode delivers a maximum power density of 12,046 W/kg, reaching the strength of supercapacitors, while offers a high energy density of 90 Wh/kg at a power density of 1350 W/kg with a charging or discharge time of 7 min. This battery demonstrates an energy storage efficiency close to 95% at a rate of 2C and maintains >90% efficiency at 20 C.

8.prez_name: Ionic Interactions to Tune Mechanical and Electrical Properties of Hydrated Liquid Crystal Graphene Oxide Films
8.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
8.prez_abstract: Considerable improvements has been obtained in physical and mechanical properties of free standing liquid crystal graphene oxide (LCGO) films in their hydrated state , by modification of LCGO dispersions with a low quantity of chloride salts. Addition of salts to LCGO dispersions result in an increase of the storage and loss moduli and viscosity through the interaction between cations and functional groups of LCGO. Free standing films is made from the salt treated LCGO dispersions  significantly improved mechanical (2× to 5× increase) and electrical properties (decreased surface resistance up to approximately 670×). The influence of the salts on properties of LCGO dispersions and their hydrated free standing films is postulated as a complex interplay of many factors such as the size of cations, the valency of positive charge of the cations, ratio of charge and cations size, as well as the hygroscopicity of the salts.

9.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
9.prez_abstract: Covalently grown 3D graphenes such as foams and honeycombs are typically closed-cell structures with a characteristic length scale of the order of microns or more. In contrast, we have grown 3D graphenes [1-2] made of 5 nm tubes covalently bonded into a tetrahedrally connected open structure  of various cell sizes. Such tubular graphene can be further nitrogen doped to endow outstanding redox activity while maintaining excellent electrical conductivity. The resultant 3D graphene with low density, high surface area, facile fluid permeability and variable hydrophilicity can serve as bipolar electrodes for supercapacitors and as feather-weight aerogels for load bearing and other energy/environmental uses. In such applications, they exhibit unprecedented figures of merits in specific capacitance and modulus, with remarkable endurance. 1. “A New Tubular Graphene Form of a Tetrahedrally-Connected Cellular Structure,” Advanced Materials, 27, 5943 (2015). 2. “Nitrogen-doped Mesoporous Carbon of Extraordinary Capacitance for Electrochemical Energy Storage,” Science, 350, 1508 (2015).

10.prez_name: Nanomorphology and Optical Characteristics of Wrinkled Graphene
10.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
10.prez_abstract: There is tremendous need for the graphite-like single and multiple layered carbon materials since they can be very useful as electrodes in high charge density lithium batteries. In addition, these materials have great potential for applications in aerospace industries, carbon brushes, graphite electrodes for electric arc furnaces for metallurgical processing and moderator rods in nuclear power plants. Based on the number of layers and structures, many properties change significantly. We describe the preparation and morphology of wrinkled graphene. During the annealing as well as physical vapor transport growth of silicon carbide in certain conditions produces ultrathin carbonaceous film. The characterization of observed standing fibrous film indicates behavior similar to graphene. Compositional analysis showed traces of oxygen impurities in some cases.  The material was free from water and does not have any sign of hygroscopic nature.

11.prez_name: Nanostructured Materials Grown on 3D Graphene for High-rate Batteries and Pseudocapacitors
11.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage

12.prez_name: Peanut Shell Hybrid Sodium Ion Capacitor with Extreme Energy: Power Rivals Lithium Ion Capacitors
12.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
12.prez_abstract: This is the first report of a hybrid sodium ion capacitor (NIC) with the active materials in both the anode and the cathode being derived entirely from a single precursor: peanut shells, which are a green and highly economical waste globally generated at over 6 million tons per year. The electrodes push the envelope of performance, delivering among the most promising sodiation capacity - rate capability - cycling retention combinations reported in literature for each materials class. Hence the resultant NIC also offers a state-of-the-art cyclically stable combination of energy and power, not only in respect to previously published NICs but also as compared to Li ion capacitors (LICs). The ion adsorption cathode based on Peanut Shell Nanosheet Carbon (PSNC) displays a hierarchically porous architecture, a sheet-like morphology down to 15 nm in thickness, a surface area on par with graphene materials and high levels of oxygen doping.

13.prez_name: Perylene Diimide Modified Graphitic Carbon Nitride as Photocatalyst for Hydrogen Production from Water
13.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
13.prez_abstract: Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) has been explored as metal-free photocatalyst for hydrogen production from water, an ideal way to convert solar energy. However, the photocatalytic efficiency of bulk g-C3N4 powders remains low due to the poor visible absorption and difficulty in control of the charge recombination. In this talk, we will present a new approach to improve the photocatalysis of g-C3N4 by surface modification with perylene tetracarboxylic diimides (PTCDIs).  Self-assembly of PTCDIs not only enhances the light absorption in the range of 500-700 nm, but also improves the charge separation by creating interfacial heterojunction. The electronic energy levels of PTCDIs match the band structure of g-C3N4, enabling cooperative charge separation between the two materials. When dispersed in aqueous solutions the PTCDI/g-C3N4 composites demonstrate efficient hydrogen production (∼0.375 μmol h−1) under visible irradiation (≥ 420 nm), which represents about ten times improvement compared to the unmodified g-C3N4 catalyst.

14.prez_name: Self-assembly of Chemically Modified Graphenes for Electrochemical Capacitors
14.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
14.prez_abstract: Chemically modified graphenes (CMG; e.g., graphene oxide (GO) and reduced graphene oxide (rGO)) can be cheaply and conveniently prepared from graphite via modified Hummers methods. CMG sheets have an atom-thick two-dimensional structure; thus they are unique building blocks for self-assembling to macroscopic films, fibers, hydrogels and aerogels. In this talk, I will describe the preparation of graphene-based functional gels for electrochemical capacitors (EC).  For example, an EC with electrodes of porous graphene “pottery” showed high gravimetric and volumetric capacitances. Graphene films with oriented micropores can be prepared through electrochemically induced or template guided self-assembly. These films were applied as the electrodes of ultrahigh-rate ECs for ac line-filtering.

15.prez_name: Tailoring In-plane Pores in 3D Graphene for Highly Efficient Energy Storage
15.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
15.prez_abstract: With high specific surface, high electron conductivity and mechanical robustness, 3D graphene offers an excellent material for electrochemical devices. Here I will discuss our recent effort in creating and tailoring in-plane pores in 3D graphene to create 3D holey graphene (3DHG) with simultaneously optimized electron conductivity, ion transport and electrochemical active surface area. We will first discuss the exploration of such 3DHG as supercapacitor electrodes with exceptional specific capacitances, rate capabilities, and cycling stabilities, to enable a fully packaged device stack with energy density approaching that of traditional lead acid batteries. I will then discuss the use of 3DHG as a high surface conductive scaffold for the efficient integration of electrochemical active nanostructures, to create a variety of electrochemical energy storage devices with unprecedented combination of high energy density and high power density.

16.prez_name: Three-dimensional Architecture of Lithium-anodes Made from Graphite Fibers Coated with Thin-films of Silicon Oxycarbide: Design, Performance and Manufacturability
16.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
16.prez_abstract: Silicon oxycarbide (SiCO) is an amorphous molecular network of Si-C-O tetrahedra anchored to graphene-like carbon. We grow these films on a bed of commercially available graphite fibers that serve the dual function of a current collector. The electrochemical behavior of the composite is measured as a function of the thickness of the SiCO films. Thick films approach the typical behavior of bulk SiCO (which has three times the capacity of graphite, but suffers from poor first cycle efficiency). However, films, approximately 100 nm thick, show high first cycle efficiency as well as high capacity. The composite performs better than the prediction from the rule-of-mixtures, which further substantiates the unusual behavior of the thin-film architecture.

17.prez_name: Three-dimensional Graphene-based Materials for Flexible Electrochemical Supercapacitors
17.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage

18.prez_name: Transport Properties of Metal-organic Graphene Analogues
18.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
18.prez_abstract: Metal-organic graphene analogues are new materials with graphene-like structure and pi-conjugation but widely different properties due to the metal atoms bridging organic ligands. These properties include high conductivity, electron mobility and theoretically predicted topological insulator behavior. However, electrical transport in these materials has not been explored carefully. In this talk, I will describe our recent efforts to characterize two different families of these materials with Ni, Cu and Pt metals. Some of these materials show high conductivity and ambipolar transport behavior at room temperature. I will discuss the temperature dependence of conductivity in these compounds to elucidate the transport mechanism of this class of potentially technologically important materials.

19.prez_name: Well-defined Graphene-based Hybrids for Energy Storage Applications
19.symp_name: 3D Graphene for Energy Conversion and Storage
19.prez_authors: Linjie  Zhi, Xianglong  Li, Bin  Luo, Bin  Wang
19.prez_abstract: The preparation of high performance electrode materials is critically important for the development of powerful batteries. Graphene-based materials have attracted great attention recently as electrode in various energy storage devices, including lithium ion batteries and supercapacitors. However, the rational design and constructionl of the structures and functions of the material is always a big challenge. In this work, graphene-based materials with well-defined structures and functions, such as the graphene/SnXn nanocomposites with rationallly desinged interfaces, the graphene/Si nanocomposites with systematic structure control, have been developed by the rational design of various chemical approaches. Interestingly, the rational design of structures and functions of the electrode material provides efficient strategies for the development of high performance materials in lithium ion batteries.

20.prez_name: Advanced Thermo-mechanical Simulation Coupled with Synchrotron X-ray Scattering
20.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
20.prez_authors: Antonio J Ramirez, Guilherme A. Faria, Leonardo  Wu
20.prez_abstract: The development and optimization of advanced materials and processes involves nowadays the use of diverse characterization and modelling techniques. Among those, intense x-ray synchrotron experimental stations made possible to study materials performance and evolution in real time. When such installations are equipped with powerful thermo-mechanical physical simulators, the possibilities to study fundamental phenomena and rapidly develop and optimize materials and processes are expanded. This was the strategy while designing and building the unique x-ray scattering and thermo-mechanical simulation-XTMS installation at LNNano. The possibility to simultaneously subject materials to well-controlled and reproducible strain/stress and temperature conditions while approaching its crystallographic characteristics by x-ray diffraction and tracking phase transformations through dilatometry, have made possible to explore phase transformations fundamentals and to optimize processing conditions for conventional and advanced materials. Thus, the capabilities of such unique installation will be presented along with selected examples of fundamental studies on metallic alloys.

21.prez_name: Analysis of Short-range Order in Alloys
21.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
21.prez_authors: Lewis  Owen, Helen  Playford, Matthew  Tucker, Howard  Stone
21.prez_abstract: As early as the 1950s, Short-Range order (SRO) has been recognised as a real and important effect in metal alloy systems. However, mainly due to experimental difficulties the study of this field has been largely abandoned. Recently, however, there have been many developments in the analysis of total scattering (Bragg and diffuse), particularly the use of pair distribution functions (PDFs) for analysis. The development of reverse Monte-Carlo (RMC) techniques has created a new method by which to analyse and determine local structure in a host of compounds. In this work a combination of RMC and PDF is used as a novel analysis technique for the study of crystalline alloys. This will allow the development and adaptation of theory as to the effect of short-range order on the physical properties of an alloy, and ultimately direct the creation of new alloy systems, required to meet the ever-increasing demands of industry.

22.prez_name: Dynamic Response of Nanocrystalline and Ultrafine Grained Microstructures to Ion Irradiation
22.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
22.prez_authors: Mert  Efe, Osman  El-Atwani, Jonathan  Hinks, Jean Paul  Allain
22.prez_abstract: Tungsten walls of future fusion reactors will suffer from irradiation damage due to H and He ions escaping from the plasma. Damage in the form of defect clusters, dislocations, and especially He bubbles, result in eroded surfaces. One approach to mitigate this kind of damage is to refine the microstructure to ultrafine or nanocrystalline grain sizes, as grain boundaries may act as sinks for irradiation-induced defects and bubbles. This study provides an understanding of the defect-grain boundary interactions by direct observations of the in-situ dynamic response of the microstructure during particle-beam exposure of 2 keV He+ ions at 950°C within a TEM.  We complement the in-situ results with lower energy (< 200 eV), ex-situ irradiation experiments to show that ultrafine grained tungsten can tolerate higher fluences (up to one order of magnitude) before the formation of severe surface damage at high temperatures.

23.prez_name: Imaging of Hydrogen in Steels with Neutrons
23.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
23.prez_authors: Axel  Griesche, Eitan  Dabah, Thomas  Schaupp, Beate  Pfretzschner, Thomas  Kannengiesser
23.prez_abstract: Cold neutrons are predominantly scattered at hydrogen when penetrating hydrogen-charged samples, resulting in a high image contrast between hydrogen and e.g. iron. The used radiographic set-ups consist of a neutron source, state-of-the-art scintillator screens and digital cameras. This allows monitoring diffusive hydrogen fluxes two-dimensionally with 20s temporal resolution. Such hydrogen fluxes can be quantified by using standards with known hydrogen content and similar sample thickness.Neutron tomography generates three-dimensional models of the hydrogen distribution in steel. Such models gain new insight for damage analysis by showing the hydrogen accumulations around cracks and by enabling the hydrogen gas pressure estimation inside cracks.The capabilities and limitations, as well as perspectives of this method will be discussed and illustrated with help of selected examples.

24.prez_name: In-situ 3D Observation of Slip Events in a Zirconium Polycrystal
24.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
24.prez_authors: Rulin  Chen, Jonathan  Lind, Robert  Suter
24.prez_abstract: We use the near-field High Energy Diffraction Microscopy (nf-HEDM) with Forward Modeling Method(FMM) reconstructions to spatially resolve slip events in a zirconium polycrystal undergoing tensile strain. Both well annealed and deformed states of the same volume were measured [J. Lind et al, Acta Mat. {\bf 76}, 213-220 (2014)] so that direct comparisons could be made. We use an automated script that searches the measured volume of material for small angle rotations about the c-axis; such rotations are associated with prismatic slip events. With the observed texture (most c-axes close to the plane perpendicular to the loading axis), we expect, and see, many slip events generated by the macroscopically applied load. The three dimensional slip planes are visualized in the analysis and the variation of rotation axes and extents are presented.

25.prez_name: In-situ Characterization of Binary Marginal Glass Forming Alloys during Isochronal Crystallization
25.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
25.prez_abstract: Marginal glass formers are known to exhibit an abnormal devitrification behavior by having nanocrystal densities orders of magnitude higher as compared to the predictions according to the classical nucleation theory. In this study, we have investigated this enigmatic behavior by revealing the crystallization pathway of as-quenched solid amorphous Al-RE binary metallic glasses using in-situ high-energy XRD (at ALBA synchrotron lightsource) in combination with in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM), 3D atom probe tomography (3D-APT), and thermal analysis. Results have revealed a clear correlation between the amorphous structural features, namely short-to-medium range ordered structures, and the phase selection mechanisms in devitrification of these glasses. Origin of chemical and topological order is attributed to be inherited from molten state according to HEXRD studies. The corresponding isochronal crystallization mechanism will be discussed in detail in the light of HEXRD, TEM and 3D-APT results.

26.prez_name: In-situ Polarised Neutron Reflectometry during Thin Film Growth
26.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
26.prez_abstract: The performance of magneto-electronic devices relies on the properties of the layers they consist of. Since the morphology, microstructure or the coupling of layers can change during growth, it is important for the understanding and optimisation of devices to accurately monitor the structural and magnetic properties. While the structural characterisation of thin films is common practice (e.g. by RHEED/LEED, STM or synchrotron radiation), the in-situ measurement of the magnetic properties using polarised neutron reflectometry (PNR) is challenging. Within a collaboration of TU München, University Augsburg and MPI Stuttgart, we operate a mobile sputtering-facility for the growth of magnetic multilayers, which can be installed at suitable neutron beamlines. First proof of principle in-situ PNR measurements on Fe/Cr carried out at the ToF reflectometers REFSANS @ FRM II and at AMOR @ PSI, where the Selene neutron optics allows PNR to be performed within only 15min per spin direction, will be presented.

27.prez_name: In-situ Raman Monitoring of Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) Solar Absorber Material at Elevated Temperatures
27.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
27.prez_abstract: Development of new techniques for characterizing copper zinc tin sulfide Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) is a critical to the production of low cost CZTS thin films for solar cell applications.   In this present work, we report the results of in situ Raman monitoring of CZTS thin film prepared from sol-gel/sulfurization method under relevant processing conditions at elevated temperatures.  In situ Raman experiments showed that CZTS phase is Raman active at elevated temperatures up to ~600°C.  In addition, important information regarding CZTS phase decomposition and oxidation at high temperatures are also revealed.  For example, it is shown the CZTS oxidation starts quickly at ~400°C in air. The study demonstrates that in situ Raman, when combined with other carefully planned ex situ characterization techniques, could provide valuable insights that help understand the complex processes involving phase formation, transformation, and degradation for CZTS and other related multi-component chalcogenides phase as solar absorber materials.

28.prez_name:
In-situ study of Austenite Formation and Decomposition in Ti-stabilized Supermartensitic 

Stainless Steel
28.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
28.prez_authors: Julian David Escobar, Guilherme  Faria, Paulo Roberto Mei, Antonio  Ramirez
28.prez_abstract: A time-resolved study on the kinetics of phase transformations on Ti-stabilized 12Cr-6Ni-2Mo supermartensitic stainless steel was carried out using coupled physical simulation and synchrotron x-ray diffraction at the XTMS experimental station at LNNano-Brazil. The material was heated at 500 °C/s, held for 9000 s at 580, 625, 650 and 700 °C, and cooled down to room temperature at 5 °C/s, while the austenite fraction was measured. The martensite to austenite reversion kinetics, and the austenite to martensite transformation were obtained during the isothermal stages and cooling, respectively. The diffraction data was complemented with  coupled laser dilatometry, which allowed also to track the As, Ms and Mf transformation temperatures. For intercritical tempering above 625 °C, reversed austenite was partially unstable, and martensitic transformation occured during cooling. On the other hand, intercritical tempering at 625 °C or below, resulted on sluggish reversion kinetics, but the formed austenite was stable upon cooling.

29.prez_name: In-situ X-ray Characterization of the Thermal Stability of Expanded Austenite in a 316L Austenitic Stainless Steel
29.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
29.prez_authors: Andre  Tschiptschin, Carlos Eduardo Pinedo, Arthur Seiji Nishikawa, Luis Bernardo Varela
29.prez_abstract: Metastable expanded austenite, formed by DC plasma nitriding austenitic stainless steels may degrade by exposure to high temperatures. Time-resolved X-ray diffraction experiments were undertaken at the Brazilian National Synchrotron Light Source, by heating nitrided 316L specimens up to 700ºC, to investigate the stability of the 14 µm thick expanded austenite layer.  A continuous heating experiment (12ºC/min) showed that expanded austenite remained stable up to 500ºC, without losing nitrogen and maintaining unchanged the expanded austenite lattice parameter. For T > 550 ºC, a continuous decrease in expanded austenite lattice parameter occurred and CrN nitride precipitated. For T > 625ºC bcc ferrite precipitated accompanied by precipitation of CrN/Cr2N and Fe2-3N nitrides.  Isothermal treatments conducted at 400ºC and 550ºC for 30 min showed that expanded austenite remained stable at 400ºC for at least 30 min, while at 550ºC it lost stability and decomposed to fcc austenite and CrN after 15 min of exposure.

30.prez_name: Industrial Applications in the Fields of Materials Science at SPring-8 Today
30.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
30.prez_abstract: SPring-8 is a large synchrotron radiation facility which delivers the most powerful synchrotron radiation currently available. Consisting of narrow, powerful beams of electromagnetic radiation, synchrotron radiation is produced when electron beams, accelerated to nearly the speed of light, are forced to travel in a curved path by a magnetic field. The research conducted at SPring-8 includes nanotechnology, biotechnology and industrial applications. SPring-8 was opened in 1997 to industrial, academic and government users, domestic and international. Any user whose application is accepted may use the facility. Collaborations between academia and industry at SPring-8 have been performed successfully in the fields of materials science. Some of the outstanding works recently achieved in SPring-8 is introduced here.

31.prez_name: Investigating the Effect of Stress on the α → σ + γ’ Transformation in UNS32750 Super Duplex Stainless Steel
31.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
31.prez_authors: Guilherme Abreu Faria, Leonardo  Wu, Antonio J. Ramirez
31.prez_abstract: Superduplex stainless steels are widely used in chemical and petrochemical industries due to their interesting combination of mechanical and environmental performance. Their microstructure is the result of careful chemical formulation and thermo-mechanical processing. However, the elevated addition of Cr, Mo and potentially W to provide the required corrosion resistance leads to the potential precipitation of undesirable phases, particularly sigma phase, which forms within the temperature range from 650 °C to 950 °C through the diffusive transformation α → σ + γ’. In this work, we report a series of in situ X-ray diffraction measurements taken in isothermal plateaus in this transformation temperature range. The study was performed on samples subjected to no stress and elevated elastic stresses. An analysis of the effect of stress in the transformation kinetics is presented with a deep consideration on how the driving forces and mobility mechanisms are affected by the application of stress.

32.prez_name:
Macroscopic Fronts of Localized Deformation in Tensioned Superelastic NiTi Wire
 Studied by In-situ 3D-XRD and FE Modelling
32.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering

33.prez_name: Multi-scale and Multi-modal Studies of Phase Transformation and Microstructural Evolution Dynamics in Metal Alloys
33.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
33.prez_authors: Amy  Clarke, Seth  Imhoff, Damien  Tourret, John  Gibbs, James  Mertens, Younggil  Song, Alain  Karma, Kamel  Fezzaa, Joseph  McKeown, John  Roehling, Kevin  Bladwin, Theron  Rodgers, Jonathan  Madison, Frank  Merrill, pRad  Team, Michelle  Espy, James  Hunter, Terry  Holesinger
33.prez_abstract: State-of-the-art characterization techniques available at U.S. DOE User Facilities and in the laboratory are enabling unprecedented studies of phase transformations and microstructural evolution dynamics in metal alloys.  In particular, solidification is spatially and temporally multi-scale and is critical to processes like casting and additive manufacturing.  Heterogeneities that develop during solidification may even influence subsequent solid-state phase transformations and microstructural evolution and translate throughout downstream processing.  We use 800 MeV proton radiography (pRad) at Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL), synchrotron x-rays at Argonne National Laboratory’s Advanced Photon Source, high-energy micro-focused x-rays at LANL, and dynamic transmission electron microscopy to image metal alloy solidification dynamics at different length and time scales.  Our results are used to inform, develop, and validate computational models at the same scales.  Here we highlight example results and a recent multi-modal experiment.  Electron microscopy and diffraction after selected dynamic experiments also reveal a wealth of complementary information.

34.prez_name: Neutron Imaging of Lithium Distribution in LiNi0.33Mn0.33Co0.33O2 Cathode
34.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering

35.prez_name: Observation of Martensite Formation by Combined Use of Synchrotron Diffraction and Dilatometry
35.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
35.prez_abstract: Welding residual stress engineering by means of an adjusted martensite phase transformation would be highly attractive as detrimental tensile residual stresses may be prevented already during welding without time and cost intensive post processing. The present study shows a synchrotron diffraction analysis of a martensitic steel subjected to thermo-mechanical load cycles. Experiments were conducted regarding the microstructural strain response during the austenite to martensite transformation. The strains are a function of the temperature and the specific loads applied during cooling. The relation between the transformation plasticity of the material, the amount of martensite formed and the arising strains can thus be assessed. The lattice plane specific strains were compared to experimental findings from (macro) dilatation tests. It is shown that the microscopic material behavior differs remarkably from the one observed on the macroscopic scale, what leads to characteristic residual stresses in the material.

36.prez_name: Real-time X-ray Radiography for Hot Crack Detection during Welding
36.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
36.prez_authors: Axel  Griesche, Francis   Twumasi Boateng, Arne  Kromm, Thomas  Kannengiesser, Uwe  Zscherpel, Uwe  Ewert
36.prez_abstract: Fast digital radiography was used to observe the crack development during single pass bead-on-plate gas tungsten arc welding with a minifocus X-ray source and a digital detector array with 75-micrometer pixel size. The sample material were 5 mm thick AlMgSi plates. An acquisition rate of 12 frames per second and an exposure time of 40 ms per frame were used for real-time observation of the hot crack propagation during welding. The basic spatial resolution of the images is about 80 µm. A 3D laminographic reconstruction of the acquired 2D radiographic images gives access to the volumetric extent of the cracks in the welded sample. The parallel use of a high-speed camera during welding allows the real-time inspection of surface cracks. The development of surface cracks was compared with the crack’s distribution in the sample volume and these results were correlated to the used welding parameters.

37.prez_name: Study of a Novel Combination of Hot Stamping with Quenching and Partitioning Processing on High Strength Steels
37.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
37.prez_authors: Edwan Anderson  Ariza, Arthur  Seiji Nishikawa, André Paulo  Tschiptschin
37.prez_abstract: A novel combined process of Hot Stamping (HS) and Quenching and Partitioning (Q&P) treatment applied to a TRIP-assisted steel has been conducted by thermo-mechanical simulation. The aim is to compare the Q&P process with the same process when previous hot deformation is included. With this purpose, HS and Q&P cycles were designed in order to obtain ferrite, martensite and, the maximum retained austenite (RA) fraction after the process. Time-resolved X-ray diffraction experiments were undertaken in a thermomechanical simulator coupled to the Brazilian National Synchrotron Light Source, to understand the influence of time, temperature and strain on the level of carbon enrichment in austenite. The in-situ austenite transformation kinetics and lattice parameter evolution were tracked, making possible to optimize the RA fraction at room temperature after HSQ&P processes. The newly developed combined process is promising as the transformation induced plasticity phenomenon during deformation can contribute to the formability and energy absorption.

38.prez_name: Study of Phase Transformations in the ICHAZ of Grade 91 Weldment Using In-situ Synchrotron X-ray Diffraction
38.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
38.prez_authors: Kyle  Stritch, Guilherme  Abreu Faria, Boian  Alexandrov, Antonio  Ramirez
38.prez_abstract: From previous dilatometry measurements of simulated ICHAZ samples, volume changes on cooling suggesting austenite and ferrite transformations have been observed.   Presence of ferrite in the ICHAZ may be detrimental to the creep strength of Grade 91 welds and could be a factor for the high susceptibility to Type IV cracking.  The ferrite transformation kinetics needs to be better understood in order to find a way to reduce or eliminate its presence in the final microstructure.  The presence of ferrite cannot be positively identified in cooled samples by using typical characterization methods.  However, the existence and the fraction of such ferrite can be observed with in-situ X-ray diffraction measurements during thermal simulation of the HAZ.  In this work, a sequence of measurements during simulations of different regions of the HAZ in P91 steels is presented.

39.prez_name: Surface Effects on Cooling Induced Martensitic Transformation Temperatures Observed by Medium Energy (12KeV) In Situ X-ray Diffraction
39.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
39.prez_authors: Guilherme Abreu Faria, Julian David Escobar, Antonio J. Ramirez
39.prez_abstract: In this work we report a set of experiments performed with a Super Cr 13 supermartensitic stainless steel in which the martensitic transformation Ms temperature was measured through in situ X-ray diffraction. Experiments were performed at the XTMS experimental station at the Brazilian National Nanotechnology Laboratory. Collected results consistently show a transformation temperature up to 100 ºC above the expected transformation temperature measured by dilatometry. By performing a stress partition analysis based on diffraction peak shifts, and combining results with dilatometry and residual stress measurements, it is shown that the high temperature observed transformation happens only at the surface of the samples. A model based on the thermodynamics of nucleation for martensite is proposed to explain the higher transformation temperatures.

40.prez_name: Time-resolved WAXS Studies on the Formation and Dissolution of Polynuclear Aluminium Sulfates
40.symp_name: 3rd International Workshop of In-situ Studies with Photons, Neutrons and Electrons Scattering
40.prez_abstract: Polynuclear aluminium species (Al13) find application in different areas like water purification[1], contaminant transport[2], and as pilling clays with high specific surface areas[3], due to their strong binding ability to aggregates and high positive charge. In the present contribution, we report on the in situ investigation of the Al13 sulfate synthesis and dissolution by synchrotron wide-angle X-ray scattering (WAXS). Al13 sulfates were crystallized by precipitating hydrolyzed aluminum solutions by the addition of sodium sulfate. Dissolution of the formed Al13 species was carried out by adding hydrochloric acid. The measurements were performed using a custom-made acoustic levitator as sample holder. The study provides information about the intermediates during the crystallization and dissolution processes. From the data, a mechanism was derived indicating the influence of the crystallization process.[1] G. Furrer, Science 297 (2002) 2245. [2] J. C-T. Lin, Desalination 284 (2012) 349.[3] F. Gonzalez, Inorganic Chemistry 31 (1992) 727.

41.prez_name: A Regulatory Perspective on ICME and Model-enabled Certification

42.prez_name: Accelerated Insertion of Materials (AIM): 15 Years Later:

43.prez_name: Accelerated Materials and Processing in Defense in 2016

44.prez_name: AIM Qualification of Additively Manufactured Components

45.prez_name: FDA’s perspective on 3D Printing of Medical Devices

46.prez_name: Ferrium S53, an AIM Case Study

47.prez_name: Materials Innovation Case Study: QuesTek’s Ferrium® M54® Steel for Hook Shank Application

48.prez_name: Probabilistic Property Prediction: Strategic Data Fusion with Science Based Modeling

49.prez_name: A Review on Direct Laser Deposition of Nickel Base Superalloy for Surface Coating
49.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials

50.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing for AV-8B Engine Repair at FRC East
50.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
50.prez_abstract: Additive Manufacturing (AM) is recognized by NAVAIR as a means to bring a revolution in how they sustain systems.  This technology has clear potential to benefit Navy sustainment activities, including:  direct part replacement, fabrication of repair parts, and/or refurbishment of worn or corroded parts.  ARL Penn State is advancing AM technology for both manufacturing/fabrication and repair by developing a qualification test plan, a suitable repair process, and a technical data package to support the qualification, repair, and implementation of AM repair procedures at FRC East.  These procedures address a high-priority repair need within the AV-8B F402 engine--fretting wear on the Low Pressure Compressor (LPC) 2nd Stage Rear Seal Ring.  A key payoff for the Navy will be the reduction in time associated with placing components and systems back into service, resulting in reductions in cost and addressing critical, improved readiness needs.

51.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing of Al-Si Alloy Coating on AZ91 Magnesium Alloy Using Cold Metal Transfer Welding
51.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
51.prez_authors: Tanmay  Waghmare, Rajeev P G, Viswanathan  R, Lakshman  Neelakantan, Srinivasa Rao Bakshi
51.prez_abstract: Application of magnesium alloys requires the use of protective coatings due to their poor corrosion resistance. Thick surface coatings (> 1mm) can be developed on Mg alloys by additive manufacturing using weld deposition. Cold metal transfer (CMT) welding is an attractive technique due to its low heat input and energy efficiency. In this work, weld cladding on AZ91 using Al, Al, Al-3Si, Al-5Si and Al-12Si wires has been carried out by CMT. It is shown that Si is necessary for deposition of adherent coatings. SEM images revealed the presence of intermetallics like Mg2Si and γ-phase (Al12Mg17) at the interface which were confirmed by the XRD studies. Micro-hardness suggested high hardness of these intermetallic phases increasing the hardness to 450 HV at the interface. No cracks were observed at the interface. Local corrosion tests at the interface shows an increase in the corrosion resistance compared to the AZ91.

52.prez_name: Automatic Finishing of Metal AM Components
52.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
52.prez_authors: Ola L A  Harrysson, Richard  Wysk, Matt  Frank, Harshad  Srinivasan, Carter  Keough
52.prez_abstract: Finishing of direct metal AM components to achieve required surface finish and tolerances can be both time consuming and costly. This is particularly true for low-volume production or for one-off components. To reduce the time and cost, a software package has been developed that connects the AM process with the subtractive finishing process. The software is independent of the AM and subtractive processes used and is handling pre-processing and post-processing of the build file. The software is using an extended version of the new AMF format and is automatically adding machining allowances to selected features or surfaces and adding fixturing features that will make the finishing more automated. Once the component has been fabricated in an AM process the part is scanned in the subtractive machine setup and the tool path is automatically generated. A second scanning can be used to verify the dimensional tolerances of the component.

53.prez_name: Build Surface Analysis and Process Effects in Powder-bed Electron Beam Additive Manufacturing
53.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
53.prez_abstract: In this study, the build surfaces of parts made by powder-bed electron beam additive manufacturing (EBAM) were investigated. Simple blocks were fabricated using an Arcam S12 system with Ti-6Al-4V powder. The system parameter setting, speed function (SF), was varied, from 20 to 65, to examine the process effect. A white-light interferometer was used to measure and analyze the build surface morphology including roughness and defects, which were compared for different process conditions. The results show the following. (1) Typical EBAM build surfaces show a thin fish-scale feature resulted from the raster scanning. (2) Averaged surface roughness (Ra) values are mostly in the range of 2.5 to 6.0 microns, except for the highest SF case. (3) A higher scanning speed (about 0.7 m/s associated with SF 65) results in not only a much rougher surface, over 15-micron Ra, but also hole formations, on the order of 0.5 mm diameter.

54.prez_name: Cold Spray Coating as a Tool for Additive Repair/Refurbishment of Al Alloy Components
54.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
54.prez_abstract: Cold Spray (CS) coating technology is well established for obtaining thick metallic coatings.  However, the applicability of CS coating technology for rebuilding and refurbishing of worn out components and for building new components/parts is not fully established.  In this presentation, the feasibility of refurbishment and repair of Al alloy components by depositing thick Al alloy coatings using cold spray will be examined.  Towards the above purpose, tensile specimen of Al alloys will be coated with Al alloy and heat treated at different temperatures and subject to tensile testing.  In conclusion, optimum heat treatment conditions to obtain the best properties for the refurbished/repaired Al alloy samples will be presented.

55.prez_name: Development of 3D Printing Process for Engineering Graphene Reinforced Poly (Lactic Acid) Composite with Superior Surface Wear Resistance
55.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
55.prez_authors: Pranjal  Nautiyal, Jenniffer  Bustillos , Daniela Montero Zambrano, Benjamin  Boesl , Arvind  Agarwal
55.prez_abstract: In the view of excellent biocompatibility and mechanical strength of Poly Lactic Acid (PLA) for orthopedic applications, 3D printing processing technique for fabricating PLA and graphene reinforced PLA (Gr-PLA) implants is explored to engineer implant surfaces with superior tribological performance. Surface performance was evaluated by ball-on-disk tribology test, for 30 minutes duration. Graphene reinforced PLA exhibited drop in coefficient of friction (COF) value (0.1-0.4) as compared to pure PLA (0.5-0.58) for first 15 minutes of the test. This is ascribed to the lubrication effect of graphene. However, after 15 minutes, rapid progressive increase in COF was noticed. This is related to the breakage of graphene layers after extended sliding, which was observed in sub-surface scanning electron microscopy (SEM) of wear tracks. Size of wear debris was smaller in Gr-PLA as compared to pure PLA, signifying improved surface integrity due to graphene addition.

56.prez_name: Effect of Cobalt Binder on the Hardness and Wear Properties of Low-pressure Cold-sprayed WC-Co and WC-based Metal Matrix Composite Coatings
56.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials

57.prez_name: Laser-aided Additively Manufactured Transition Metal Intermetallic Coating on Aluminum to Enhance Functional Properties
57.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
57.prez_authors: Hitesh D. Vora, Ravi Shanker  Rajamure, Anurag  Roy, Srinivasan G. Srivilliputhur, G.  Sundararajan, Rajarshi  Banerjee, Narendra B. Dahotre
57.prez_abstract: The various physical and chemical properties of surface and subsurface regions of aluminum (Al) can be substantially improved by the formation of transition metal intermetallic phases (AlxTMy) via coating of transition metal (TM) on aluminum. However, lower equilibrium solid solubility of TM in Al (<1 at. %) is a major obstacle to the formation of solid solutions using conventional alloying methods. In light of this, surface engineering via a laser-aided additive manufacturing (SELAAM) approach can effectively produce transition metal intermetallic coatings on the surface of Al with enhance functional properties. The focus of the present work included an integrated experimental and computational methodologies for SELAAM based approach to establish the required process control to achieve thermodynamic and kinetic conditions necessary for desirable physical, microstructural and compositional features. A multiphysics finite element model was developed to predict temperature profile, cooling rate, melt depth, and resultant dilution of W in Al matrix.

58.prez_name: Microstructural Effect on Corrosion and Tribological Properties of Fe Based Metallic Glass Coating Synthesized by Air Plasma Spraying
58.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
58.prez_authors: Swadipta  Roy, Atanu  Banerjee, Pavan K. Bijalwan, Monojit  Dutta, Tapas  Laha
58.prez_abstract: Fe-based metallic glasses possess great potential as surface protective coatings owing to the excellent corrosion and wear resistance attributed to the amorphous nature of the material. In the present work, a lean composition of Fe based (Fe-0.7C-2.5B-6.7Si-2.5Cr in wt%) alloy powder was used as precursor material to synthesize amorphous coating on steel substrate through air plasma spraying with varying process parameters (e.g. plasma power and coating thickness). The effect of splat morphology and phase composition i.e. degree of retained amorphous structure on corrosion and wear properties were investigated. The coatings exhibited very high degree of amorphization with dense layered structure without significant change in pore density with varying power. The coatings showed significantly lower wear rate than the bare steel substrate and the wear rate decreased with increasing plasma current from 200-500A. Corrosion resistance of the coated substrate showed 40-70% improvement over bare, as well as galvanized steel substrate.

59.prez_name: Microstructural Observation of Inconel 718 Cladding Fabricated by Pulsed Laser Additive Manufacturing
59.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
59.prez_authors: Mathieu  Brochu, Yuan  Tian, Alberto  Muniz
59.prez_abstract: Fully dense and crack-free Inconel 718 cladding was fabricated by pulsed laser additive manufacturing process. In the as-deposited condition, columnar dendritic structure with average dendrite arm spacing of 0.25 ± 0.04 μm was observed, and the cooling rate in the magnitude of around 106 m/s could be calculated. This high cooling rate yielded the precipitation of both γ’ and γ”, and broke down the continuous feature of eutectic phases formed from the residual liquid phase during final solidification stage. The eutectic phases were found to be composed by mainly Laves phase and a small portion of NbC. The non-continuously distributed eutectic phases contributed to the good solidification of Inconel 718 clads.

60.prez_name: New Technology Increased Metal Fatigue Life 20-Times in Lab Tests
60.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
60.prez_abstract: Metal Fatigue results from cyclic stresses that exceed the metal’s yield point. Sometimes it’s used for under-design trade-offs. For example, aircraft, vehicles, bridges, dance halls, or other structures may be under-designed to save weight or money. Nevertheless, the Cost of Metal Fatigue, estimated as much as seventy percent of all metal failures is huge. Alas, Battelle, on contract with the USAF, fatigue-life tested a newly patented surface treatment technology applied before environmental exposure to 2024T6 aircraft quality aluminum dog-bones for stress testing that increased fatigue life twenty times in contrast with controls resulting in opportunities to save more weight, more money, or increase structural life; in the case of medical prostheses extending lives.    This technology extended fatigue life three times as long as controls for dog-bones that were stress tested without the surface treatment until a crack appeared then surface treated and tested to failure.

61.prez_name: Ni Based Alloy Additive Manufacturing with CMT Welding
61.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
61.prez_authors: Ana Sofia C. M. D´Oliveira, Henrique  Zenere, Bernhard  Guimarães, Luiz Felipe  Beltzac, Paulo C. Okimoto
61.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing, or 3D printing, of metallic parts is accomplished with a welding process. This study used cold metal transfer welding process known by the controlled stability of metal transfer. Layer by layer linear and circular walls of IN625 Ni based alloy were processed. Post-deposition heat treatment was carried out on parts with both geometries. Microstructure characterization of parts before and after heat treatment aimed to assess the role of the processed geometry.  X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscopy were the main tools used. The initial layer was deposited on an AISI 304 stainless steel substrate, at least 7 more layers were deposited for each geometry. An austenitic dendritic microstructure with epitaxial growth at the interface between layers is observed. Correlation between the observed microstructures and those obtained following processing with Plasma transferred arc is presented. Discussion also includes the potential of CMT welding to repair damaged parts.

62.prez_name: Obtaining Ultimate Functionalities in 3D-printed Cellular Ti-6Al-4V Mesh Structures
62.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
62.prez_authors: Krishna Chaitanya  Nune, Devesh   Misra, Li  SJ, Hao  YL, Yang  R
62.prez_abstract: Titanium and its alloys with open cellular structures are characterized by low Young’s modulus similar to that of human bone and provide the space required for bone tissue in-growth. However, to ensure long-term endurance and ability to withstand abrupt impact fracture, the cellular materials must possess adequate strength in conjunction with high energy absorption capability. By optimizing the unit cell structure, shape, distribution of pore size, pore morphology, and relative density, the aforementioned properties were attained in a single material, during fabrication of Ti–6Al–4V alloy mesh structures by EBM. The effects of cell shape on the mechanical properties of these samples were studied. The compressive strength and deformation behavior of these meshes were studied by combining buckling and bending deformation of struts. Meshes dominated by buckling deformation indicated relatively high collapse strength and exhibited brittle characteristics, while, meshes dominated by bending deformation, showed ductile behavior.

63.prez_name: Robust, HF Free, and Water Based Polishing and Finishing Process for Complex Shapes
63.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
63.prez_authors: Timothy D Hall, Stephen  T Snyder, Heather  McCrabb, Holly  Garich, E. Jennings  Taylor
63.prez_abstract: This paper will discuss recent developments toward the demonstration of electrochemical processing conditions and tooling that enable a wide range of complex components to be finished, deburred, radiused, or polished. Unlike conventional electrochemical surface finishing processes, the pulse reverse process does not require low conductivity/high viscosity electrolytes or the addition of chemical species (like HF) to remove the passive film associated with electropolishing of passive and strongly passive materials like Ti alloys. This paper will focuses on pulse/pulse reverse electrofinishing processes developed by Faraday Technology of various material groups including but not limited to titanium alloys, tantalum alloys, nickel alloys, stainless steels, niobium, and molybdenum alloys. In particular, this talk will discuss techniques in electrofinishing AM / HIPped parts and the design of tooling that enables complex components / passages to be finished to meet the required specifications.

64.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing for Surface Engineering of Materials
64.prez_abstract: The presentation will cover advances made in thermal spray and how thermal spray is being used to provide engineered surfaces for power plants, aircraft, drilling equipment and art.  Component repair is also included.  Systems include powder and wire using flame, arc, plasma, HVOF and HVAF.

65.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
65.prez_authors: Joseph  Muth, Patrick  Dixon, Logan  Woish, Lorna  Gibson, Jennifer  Lewis
65.prez_abstract: By controlling structure across multiple length scales, new architected ceramics with unique properties can be created. Specifically, we explore the ability to fabricate ultra-lightweight ceramics via 3D printing. We will first describe the development of novel ceramic inks that enable printing of hierarchically designed materials. We will then demonstrate the fabrication of architected ceramics over a broad range of densities with hierarchical features. Finally, we will characterize their mechanical properties and establish a correlation between their composition, geometry, and characteristic feature/cell sizes.

66.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites with Anisotropic Heterogeneities
66.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
66.prez_authors: Neal R Brodnik, Katherine T Faber
66.prez_abstract: We report the fabrication of composite systems with anisotropic heterogeneities designed to directionally alter fracture toughness.  Brittle polymer composites are fabricated using ultraviolet stereolithography, which allows for the precise positioning of directionally textured, uniformly spaced inclusions with cross-sectional areas that are asymmetrical along the direction of crack propagation.  The heterogeneities investigated, which are either voids or polymer of differing effective modulus, are arranged as parallel channels so that crack propagation can be studied in a two-dimensional stress state.  The directional alignment of these heterogeneities results in fracture toughness that varies based on how their asymmetrical cross-section is oriented with respect to the direction of crack propagation.  Demonstration of analogous behavior in ceramic systems is also possible through the use of gelcasting and stereolithography of preceramic photopolymers.

67.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing of High-entropy Alloy Reinforced Aluminum Matrix Composites
67.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
67.prez_authors: G.M.  Karthik, G.D. Janaki  Ram, Ravi Sankar  Kottada
67.prez_abstract: Friction deposition is a promising solid-state technique for additive part fabrication in novel composite materials. In the current study, an aluminum (alloy AA5083) matrix composite reinforced with 12 vol.% NiCoCrFe high-entropy alloy (HEA) particles was successfully friction deposited in multiple layers. The composite friction deposits showed a dynamically recrystallized fine-grained aluminum matrix with uniformly distributed HEA particulate reinforcements without any bonding defects at the layer interfaces as well as any intermetallic formation at the reinforcement/matrix interfaces. The HEA particles were found to retain their nanocrystalline structure. In Z-direction tensile tests, the composite friction deposits showed significantly higher strength when compared to standard wrought- processed alloy AA5083-H112. The composite friction deposits showed a better combination of strength and ductility as compared to conventional ceramic particle reinforced aluminum matrix composites.

68.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing of Polymer Composites for Multifunctional Applications
68.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
68.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) allows excellent control of material placement over length scale such that complex geometry, function, and composition can be widely tailored. Additively manufactured, light weight polymer composites are being developed with secondary phase additions to improve the strength and multi-functionality of components for use in aerospace applications. Pure PLA and ABS, and composite specimens with different reinforcements (nanotube, carbon fiber, and powder additions of copper, bronze, tungsten, iron, and bismuth) were 3D printed at incremental layer heights and resulting microstructures and properties were characterized. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) behavior of filaments with different reinforcements were studied. Tensile strength and fracture toughness tests were conducted on specimens as a function of print layer height. These results will be presented and discussed in detail.

69.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing of SiCN Ceramic Matrix for SiC Fiber Composites by Flash Pyrolysis of Nanoscale Polymer Films
69.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
69.prez_abstract: The potential of polymer-derived ceramic matrices for silicon-carbide fiber composites is demonstrated by additive layering of thin films on SiC fiber bundles. The thin liquid films, which naturally wet the fiber surfaces, are cross-linked and pyrolyzed in-situ into the silicon carbonitride ceramic in just a few seconds to yield defect free layers that are 10 nm to 100 nm thick. The infiltration is completed by repeating the cycles. A nearly fully dense and defect free SiCN matrix could be obtained. Room temperature tensile tests show a tensile strength of ~1200 MPa. Good matrix-fiber interface behavior is seen with pull-out character which is most likely responsible for the apparent ductility. The SiC fibers were uncoated.

70.prez_name: Alloy Design Multicomponent Hardmetal Alloy for Additive Manufacturing
70.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
70.prez_authors: Kai-Chun  Chang, An-Chou  Yeh, Chen-Wei  Li, Jien-Wei  Yeh, Su-Jien  Lin, Che-Wei  Tsai
70.prez_abstract: Novel multicomponent hardmetal alloy WC/Al0.5CoCrCuFeNi can provide exceptional combination of hardness and toughness. In this research, 3D laser printing method has been employed to fabricate samples of WC/Al0.5CoCrCuFeNi and several new compositions. Alloy design has been conducted by CALPHAD-based simulations in order to control the phase constituents. Microstructure and mechanical properties have been analyzed and compared with conventional WC/Co alloy. The potential of 3D laser printing multicomponent hardmetal alloys will be discussed.

71.prez_name: Binder Jetting of Si3N4-based Composite Ceramics with Different Porosity
71.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
71.prez_authors: L.N.  Rabinsky, A.V.  Ripetsky, S.A.  Sitnikov, Yury  Solyaev, R.M.  Kahramanov, Arseniy  Babaitsev
71.prez_abstract: We present the results of the binder jetting technology application in the processing of the Si3N4-based composite ceramics. The difference of the developed technology between analogues, which used for additive manufacturing of silicon nitride ceramics, is a method of the separate deposition of the mineral powder and binder without direct injection of suspensions/slurries. It is assumed that such approach allow to reduce the technology complexity and simplify the process of the feedstock preparation, including the simplification of the composite materials production. The binders based on methyl ester of acrylic acid with polyurethane and modified starch were studied. The technology of green body’s fabrication is implemented using a standard HP cartridge and specially developed software. Obtained green bodies of silicon powder with silicon carbide and alumina additives used to produce the ceramic samples via reaction sintering. The results of a study of ceramics samples microstructure, composition and mechanical properties are presented.

72.prez_name: Developing Additive Manufacturing Processes for Radome Fabrication
72.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials

73.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
73.prez_abstract: While Additive Manufacturing (AM) is beginning to deliver on the promise of revolutionizing the aerospace manufacturing industry, one of the largest barriers to broader adoption of AM for producing aerospace parts is the lack of a standardized qualification process.  By leveraging investments with industry driven consortia such as the Metals Affordability Initiative and America Makes, the Air Force Research Laboratory is supporting research that enables the transition from slow and costly point qualifications to more general qualification and certification approaches. Key areas of targeted research that inform the qualification of additive materials and processes include: enabling fully characterized process definition, developing in-situ process monitoring and sensing, identifying the limits of AM part inspectability, and quantifying of the drivers of manufacturing variability in AM production parts.  Recent progress made in three representative programs will be presented.

74.prez_name: Engineered and Low Cost Filler Based Lightweight Composites
74.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
74.prez_authors: Vasanth Chakravarthy  Shunmugasamy, Yasser  Al-Hamidi, Bilal  Mansoor
74.prez_abstract: Foams are lightweight materials possessing high specific mechanical properties and good thermal properties. Due to these properties they find applications in aerospace, automotive, marine and oil and gas sectors as heat exchangers, energy absorbing crash structures and weight saving structural members. One class of closed cell foam composites called syntactic foams formed by dispersing hollow filler particles inside a matrix medium is used in the present work. The study is performed to evaluate the mechanical properties of composites filled with engineered and low cost filler materials. The goal was to investigate the effect of size and wall thickness of metallic and polymeric filler materials as it effects the over-all energy absorption capabilities of the foam composites. The prepared composites are subjected to compression and flexural tests at room and elevated temperatures. We also considered fatigue properties to study the material behavior under cyclic loading.

75.prez_name: Establishment, Vision, and Success Stories from America Makes - The National Additive Manufacturing Innovation Institute
75.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
75.prez_abstract:
As part of the vision to catalyze a nationwide network of manufacturing innovation institutes, America Makes was launched as the first institute with the topic of additive manufacturing (3D printing). This public-private partnership is based on an industry, membership-based consortium and open collaboration with over 170 organizations. America Makes has developed a national strategy for additive manufacturing focusing on exploiting potential benefits of additive manufacturing such as enabling shorter lead times, mass customization, reduced part count, complex part geometry, and less material waste. America Makes is focused on addressing key challenges to widespread adoption of additive manufacturing. These challenges include the need for improved process controls, design tools, reliability, non-destructive evaluation techniques and standards.  America Makes is leading over 50 collaborative project teams addressing these challenges.
This presentation will focus on the technical vision, project results to date, and success stories.

76.prez_name: Fabrication and Thermal Properties of Aluminum Matrix Composites Reinforced with Molybdenum Carbide-coated Graphite Fibers
76.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials

77.prez_name: Functional Graded Titanium Matrix Composites Reinforced by Submicron TiC or TiB2 Inclusions under SLM
77.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials

78.prez_name: Functionally Graded Material from Ti-6Al-4V to Invar: Experimental Characterization and CALPHAD Modeling
78.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
78.prez_authors: Lourdes D. Bobbio, Richard A. Otis, John Paul Borgonia, R. Peter Dillon, Bryan  McEnerney, Andrew  Shapiro, Zi-Kui  Liu, Allison M. Beese
78.prez_abstract: Functionally graded materials (FGMs) can be made through directed energy deposition additive manufacturing, which allows the gradual change in elemental composition as a function of position within a component.  As the composition is graded from one well-understood alloy to another, new alloys are deposited in the gradient region, which may present secondary phases leading to cracking or morphological defects.  This work investigates a material graded from Ti-6Al-4V to Invar.  The component was characterized using optical and scanning electron microscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, and micro-indentation in order to qualify variations in local microstructure morphology, elemental composition, microstructural phases, and micro-hardness.  Various new phases formed in the gradient region, including a low melting point alloy that resulted in the material overflowing the prescribed boundaries and regions with cracks that formed as a result of brittle phases.  These were further investigated using CALPHAD (Calculation of Phase Diagrams) modeling.

79.prez_name: Hierarchically Reinforced Epoxy Based Functional Nanocomposites
79.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
79.prez_abstract: The effective reinforcement of structural matrices such as epoxy resins are benefitted, for example, by the individualization of filler material typically at the nanoscale through promoting enhanced stress transfer. Assembling of the molecular constituents or their aggregates over a wide range of length scales in hierarchical fashion from nanoscale to macroscale is an important factor in achieving structural and functional integrity. 3-D direct write assembly offers a multiscale approach to materials manufacturing through control of microscale features while the composition and structure of the material filament can be tuned at the nanoscale. For one-part epoxy based systems that rely on thermal energy for cure, rheological modification is necessary for the deposition of self-supporting filaments at room temperature. Here, a one-part epoxy based formulation is developed for use in 3-D direct write assembly that takes advantage of low loadings required for effective nano-reinforcement and functionality with the requisite self-supporting viscoelastic properties.

80.prez_name: Inkjet Printing of Three Dimensional Structures Using Metal Nanoparticles
80.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
80.prez_authors: Jayasheelan  Vaithilingam, Ehab  Saleh, Ricky D Wildman, Richard J.M. Hague, Christopher John Tuck
80.prez_abstract: The use of metal based additive manufacturing (AM) techniques such as selective laser melting and electron beam melting has been in use for fabricating complex three dimensional (3D) structures. This study will discuss the use of metal nanoparticles (MNPs) to inkjet-print 3D structures. Besides the advantages offered by AM, inkjet-printing of MNPs to fabricate 3D structures can be useful for a number of reasons including precise position of the ink droplets within the build, fabrication of high-aspect ratio parts, possibilities to print dissimilar metals, efficient use of materials and less wastage. Much of the previous research concentrated on using MNPs to print circuits for electronics application and a limited work on printing 3D structures. In this study, several layers of an ink containing silver nanoparticles were inkjet-printed and subsequently sintered using an infra-red source to obtain a 3D structure. The surface and mechanical properties of the part will be discussed.

81.prez_name: Interlaminar Strengthening of Multidirectional Laminates Using Additive Manufacturing
81.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
81.prez_abstract: Interlaminar regions in carbon fiber reinforced polymer matrix composites are critical regions that are most susceptible to delamination under static and dynamic loading. A generalized plane strain model is developed to determine critical interlaminar regions most susceptible to delamination in multidirectional laminates under static and thermal loading, and is implemented within the finite element framework. The hypothesis is that the interface strength and toughness can be improved significantly by introducing interlaminar micro-reinforcements using polymer additive manufacturing. Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) will be used to print micro structures on critical interfaces determined from the computational analysis. Flexural tests will be conducted on both FDM modified and pristine laminates (no modification) to validate the improved effect of optimized interlaminar reinforcement on the residual strength of layered composites.

82.prez_name: Investigation of Interfacial Bonding Strength and Fracture Behavior of Laser Deposited FV520B Steel
82.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
82.prez_authors: Shaopeng  Wei, Gang  Wang, Yiming  Rong
82.prez_abstract: The interfacial tensile strength of laser deposited FV520B material was quantified by using a uniaxial tension testing approach. Specially designed T-shape samples were fabricated by laser hot-wire deposition process. The fracture morphology of the deposited samples were obtained to investigate the fracture behavior. Microstructural investigations of the deposition sample were carried out for a better understanding of the fracture mechanism. The effect of laser heating on the microstructure and fracture behavior was also discussed. Results show that the tested bonding strength of laser deposited material was approximately 1055 MPa. The tensile failure of the deposited samples results from the competition between crack propagation in the interface and micro-void coalescence in the heat affected zone.

83.prez_name: Investigations on Additively Generated Micro-scale, Open-pore Components Based on a Multi-material
83.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
83.prez_authors: Florian  Hengsbach, Peter  Koppa, Madison  Burns, Martin   Holzweißig, Kay-Peter  Hoyer, Thomas  Tröster, Mirko  Schaper
83.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) enables the creation of highly complex metallic structures with approximately similar mechanical properties as their conventionally-processed counterparts. One established metal, powder-based additive manufacturing technique is laser beam melting (LBM). Recently, additive technologies have begun to segue from rapid prototyping to rapid manufacturing as machine technology has improved and the range of processable materials has expanded. To date, however, few steels have been processed via LBM.
