The aim of the presenter’s research is to further expand the material range by investigating gas atomized duplex stainless steel processed with LBM. In this research, heat treatments are developed to improve resulting LBM duplex stainless steel phase distribution, and the microstructural evolution, as well as the mechanical performance is compared between the as-built and heat treated conditions.

84.prez_name: Knowns and Unknowns of the Current State, Future Trends, and Associated Implications of Additive Manufacturing
84.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
84.prez_authors: Runze  Huang, Diane  Graziano, Matthew  Riddle, Joe  Cresko, Eric   Masanet
84.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) has been developed rapidly and adopted in many industries. The lack of good understanding of the present state and future potentials of AM is inhibiting robust engineering and policy decisions today that reaches the greatest benefits tomorrow. In order to fill the knowledge gap, we analyzed over 350 AM machines and 270 AM materials covering both polymeric and metallic AM processes available in the market. In addition, based on these datasets we developed a dynamic systems model that analyzes the life-cycle energy/environmental/economic implications of AM associated with AM technology evolvement. The analysis offers a high-level understanding of present performance and future trends of AM processes. It also helps identify the most actionable opportunities related to AM that bring the largest potential of cost saving, energy reduction and carbon mitigation, which can guide R&D progress down the most cost effective and efficient pathways.

85.prez_name: Laser Deposited In Situ TiC Reinforced Nickel Matrix Composites: 3D Microstructure and Tribological Properties
85.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
85.prez_authors: Tushar M. Borkar, Prashanth Reddy  Yennm, John  Sosa, Thomas  Scharf, Jaimie  Tiley, Hamish  Fraser, Rajarshi  Banerjee
85.prez_abstract: A new class of Ni-Ti-C based metal matrix composites has been developed using the laser engineered net shaping (LENSTM) process. These composites consist of an in situ formed and homogeneously distributed titanium carbide (TiC) phase reinforcing the nickel matrix. Additionally, by tailoring the Ti/C ratio in these composites, an additional graphitic phase can also be engineered into the microstructure. The microstructure of these composites has been characterized in detail in three dimensions, via serial-sectioning in a dual-beam focused ion beam instrument followed by appropriate 3D reconstructions, to determine the true morphology and spatial distribution of the TiC and graphite phases as well as the phase evolution sequence. These three-phase Ni-TiC-C composites exhibit excellent tribological properties, in terms of extremely low coefficient of friction while maintaining a relatively high hardness, and these will be discussed in the presentation.

86.prez_name:
Laser Deposition of Zr/Alumina Composites and Functionally Graded Zr/Stainless Materials 
by Powder Injected Melting
86.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
86.prez_authors: Mehrdad   Iravani, Arshad   Harooni, Adrian  Gerlich, Amir   Khajepour, Ahmed  Khalifa, J.M. (Mitch)   King
86.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing methods for Zr-based components in the nuclear industry holds great potential for synthesis of high value components.  The present work examines the feasibility of fabricating novel materials using laser deposition by powder injected melting.  This process involves side injection of a powder using a specially designed nozzle with only local shielding, and directing the powder stream into a melt pool maintained by a 1kW laser.  Zr/alumina composite which was produced by pre-mixing commercially pure Zr powder with alumina, with potential applications in areas demanding high wear and corrosion resistance.  Deposition of commercially pure Zr deposit on a stainless substrate was also examined, with potential to produce functionally graded components.  The microstructures and phase constituents of the laser deposited materials are studied, and the microhardness results are explained based on the observed microstructures and compounds detected using SEM and XRD analysis.

87.prez_name: Metal Powders and Powder Mixtures for Additive Manufacturing: Assessing their Processing Characteristics
87.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
87.prez_authors: Claus  Aumund-Kopp, Dirk  Lehmhus, Hong Ngoc  Le, Frank  Petzoldt, Matthias  Busse
87.prez_abstract: Several additive manufacturing processes especially among the metal-based ones rely on transport and spreading of powders: Powder bed fusion processes like laser beam melting and binder jetting techniques such as 3D printing are prominent examples in this respect. Thus a major factor determining processing results is the suitability of powders chosen for the process employed. While powder metallurgy in general has developed several methods for assessing process-related properties of particles and powders, not all of these provide the necessary support for the aforementioned AM processes. The present contribution evaluates classical and advanced particle and powder characterization approaches in this respect, including techniques like flowability analysis by means of the powder revolution analyzer. The related findings extend from powder handling itself to final part production and part properties achieved and are supported by experimental results obtained on standard metal powders as well as powder mixtures containing non-metallic additions.

88.prez_name: Metallic Additive Manufacturing at the Army Research Laboratory
88.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
88.prez_authors: Brandon  McWilliams, Andrew  Gaynor, Larry  Holmes
88.prez_abstract: An overview of the Army Research Laboratory’s (ARL) Center for Advanced Manufacturing Science is provided, showcasing the actively expanding research activities in additive manufacturing (AM) of metallic components.  ARL is pursuing an integrated approach to metallic AM linking materials, manufacturing, and design development concurrently.  This framework seeks to link next-generation alloy development for optimized feedstocks, AM process modeling development, and advanced topology optimization (TO) algorithm development to design for AM through incorporation of manufacturing capabilities and constraints into the design process.  Disruptive improvements in metallic AM which meet property requirements for in-service use necessitate the development and integration of advanced modeling and simulation tools in the manufacturing approach in order to understand the fundamental manufacturing science related to processing parameters, including their effect on the resulting microstructures and the properties of AM parts.

89.prez_name: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of Stainless Steel Specimen Manufactured by Selectively Laser Sintering
89.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
89.prez_authors: Fei  Chen, Nikhil  Gupta, Khaled  Shahin
89.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing has expanded to fabrication of end-use products in aircraft, dental and medical implants, and automobiles. In this study, selective laser sintering (SLS) is used to produce a series of tensile specimens of stainless steel. The specimens are printed in two different orientations, where the printing direction is maintaining parallel and perpendicular to the specimen length. These specimens are subjected to non-destructive and destructive tests to understand their microstructure and properties. Grain size and shape analysis and porosity measurement are performed first to understand the effect of printing direction. Next, density and hardness of are investigated. Ultrasonic imaging is also conducted on the as-printed and surface machined specimens. Finally, tensile test is conducted to understand the effects of different printing orientations on mechanical properties. The results are compared with the corresponding properties of cast stainless steel specimens reported in the literature and against results from finite element models.

90.prez_name: Microstructure and Residual Stress of a Selective Laser Melting Produced Al-50Si Alloy: Effect of Heat Treatments
90.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
90.prez_authors: Nan  Kang, Pierre  Coddet, Hanlin  Liao, Christian  Coddet
90.prez_abstract: Due to high heating/cooling rates involved in selective laser melting (SLM) process, SLM produced samples always present high residual stress levels, which affect significantly their mechanical properties. Previous study indicated that almost dense hypereutectic Al- high Si alloys could be in-situ manufactured by SLM under argon environment. In this paper the effect of heat treatments on the microstructure and residual stress level of an Al50Si alloy prepared by SLM was investigated. Heat treatments were performed under air condition at temperatures ranged from 573 K to 873 K for 2 h with a subsequent water quenching. Results show that both the density and microhardness are improved by the heat treatment with the highest values being reached after heat treated at 723 K. Above this temperature, the primary silicon particles size increases dramatically. The residual stress, which is detected by Raman spectroscopy, could also be released after heat treatment.

91.prez_name: Microstructure Design of Novel Composite Lanthanum Zirconate-yttria Stabilized Zirconia Based Thermal Barrier Coatings
91.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
91.prez_authors: Xingye  Guo, Zhe  Lu, Sung-Hoon  Jung, Yeon-Gil  Jung, Li  Li, James  Knapp, Jing  Zhang
91.prez_abstract: La2Zr2O7 is one of the proposed next generation thermal barrier coating materials with low thermal conductivity and superior high temperature stability. To overcome the residual stresses due to thermal expansion disparity between La2Zr2O7 and nickel super alloy substrate, composite coatings composed of La2Zr2O7 and conventional 8wt% yttria stabilized zirconia (8YSZ) were designed and deposited using plasma spray technique, an additive manufacturing process to create coatings made of ceramic and metallic powders.  Coating architectures with selected volume ratios of La2Zr2O7 and 8YSZ (25:75, 50:50, and 75:25) were designed in the matrix for evaluation. Coating’s thermal and mechanical properties were characterized. Thermal exposure tests, such as furnace cycle test and jet engine thermal shock test, were implemented to evaluate thermal durability of the newly designed coating systems. The mechanical properties were measured using indentation methods. Compared with previous multilayered coating architectures, the new composite coatings have greatly improved the thermal cycle performance.

92.prez_name: Nanocrystalline TiC/316L Stainless Steel Matrix Nanocomposites Fabricated by Selective Laser Melting: Densification, Microstructure Evolution and Mechanical Properties
92.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
92.prez_authors: Bandar  AlMangour, Dariusz  Grzesiak, Jenn-Ming  Yang
92.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) has a strong potential for the formation of a new class of multifunctional nanocomposites. In this study, 316L stainless steel was mixed with 15% (by volume)TiC powder. The nanocomposite powders were then prepared by a mechanical alloying method based on high-energy ball milling. Selective laser melting (SLM), a promising AM fabrication technique, was applied to produce nanoscale TiC-reinforced 316L stainless steel matrix nanocomposites. In this study, the relative density, microstructure and mechanical properties were investigated with four different laser energy density. The relative density, microstrcuture and mechanical properties were all affected by the laser energy density. In general,the improvements in the mechanical properties are attributed to the combined effects of grain refinement and grain boundary strengthening.

93.prez_name: On the Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of Al-Cu-Fe-Cr Quasicrystal and Al-Cu-Fe-Cr/Al Composite Materials Prepared by Selective Laser Melting
93.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
93.prez_authors: Nan  Kang, Yingqing  Fu, Pierre  Coddet, Hanlin  Liao, Christian  Coddet
93.prez_abstract: In this study, the effect of processing parameters on the microstructure and mechanical properties of Al65Cu20Fe10Cr5 and Al65Cu20Fe10Cr5/Al composite materials produced by selective laser melting (SLM) are investigated. After processing, Al65Cu20Fe10Cr5 samples present already a composite structure consisting of quasicrystals and some á-Al. This material is prone to cracking and presents a very narrow process window, due to its low ductility. Microcracks and fracture appear as the sample thickness (number of layers) increases during the build procedure. Therefore, Al65Cu20Fe10Cr5/Al composite materials were also considered. They present a higher relative density and a wider process window, because the addition of Al improves their ductility. Dry sliding tests were carried out to determine the effect of the process parameters on the wear and friction properties.

94.prez_name: Passive Multi-feed Mixing of Complex Fluids for 3-D Direct Write Assembly
94.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
94.prez_abstract: Filamentary-based approaches for materials fabrication at the microscale typically rely on the production of single composition feedstock; or if a multi-material fabrication is desired, individual feedstock has to be sequentially deposited through multiple nozzles. Progress towards enhancing form and function during materials fabrication, through dynamic control of local composition or reactive processing, requires a multi-feed mechanism where deposition occurs from a single nozzle. The laminar flow conditions of 3-D direct write assembly makes efficient, homogeneous mixing of complex fluids a critical yet challenging component of the multi-feed deposition process. Passive mixing requires no energy input or moving parts; as such, mixing under static conditions can only be controlled by manipulating flow (deposition) rate and geometry of the mixing environment. Here, novel enhanced geometric designs and facile fabrication methods of passive multi-feed mixers are explored for the intended application of on-the-fly production of thermosetting polymeric composite filaments with locally controlled composition.

95.prez_name: Potential of Geometrically Defined Internal Structuring in Multi-material Additive Manufacturing Parts
95.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
95.prez_authors: Dirk  Lehmhus, Axel  von Hehl, Matthias  Busse, Hans-Werner  Zoch
95.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) is rapidly developing towards full spatial control of material deposition in multi-material parts. This provides the basis for considerations on benefits that may be derived from tailored internal structuring of AM parts. In the present study, such potentials are investigated using Finite Element methods, the starting point being the assumption of a matrix material in which a secondary, reinforcing phase is embedded and supposing full freedom of design regarding the latter phase’s geometry. Three different scenarios have been studied in this respect on the basis of simplified representative volume elements, namely implementation of reinforcements tailored to match loading, modification of residual stresses through tailored second phases and introduction of uncommon mechanical characteristics through second phase integration of structure based effects (e. g. auxetic behavior). Results are revisited regarding alternative processes including in-situ formation of the reinforcing phase and experimental program to validate the theoretical results is proposed.

96.prez_name: Securing the Cloud Based Additive Manufacturing Chain
96.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
96.prez_authors: Fei  Chen, Gary  Mac, Nikhil  Gupta
96.prez_abstract: This work explores the additive manufacturing supply chain, especially in the CAD design phase and G-code generation, with the aim of identifying vulnerabilities and developing effective and innovative security strategies. Our hypothesis is that a unique combination of innovative design features in CAD models and settings in 3D printer can lead to the desired quality parts, whereas all other combinations would print a defective part. Several such strategies are examined and their impact is demonstrated to provide the high quality parts in the right settings. Modification on G-code level such as printing temperature, extruder head moving speed or printing orientation are proved to be easily conducted in this work. Advanced encryption methods such as signature security service are in demand of development for additive manufacturing. Standards for additive manufacturing are still evolving, which should be sensitive to the security needs.

97.prez_name: Selective Electron Beam Melting as AM Method for Complex Materials
97.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
97.prez_abstract: Selective electron beam melting (SEBM) is a powder-bed based additive manufacturing (AM) method which uses an electron beam as energy source. The high beam powder and the extremely high beam movement speeds of up to 10.000 m/s allow both for novel scanning strategies and for preheating the powder bed to temperatures above 1000°C. Together with the processes’ vacuum conditions, SEBM is as if predestined for AM of complex materials which exhibit high melting temperatures, solidify in complex microstructures (like intermetallics), are prone to atmospheric contamination etc. This presentation shows an overview of SEBM for complex materials. Three examples where SEBM can take full advantage of its process conditions are to be discussed in detail. Microstructure tailoring of two high-temperature materials (titaniumaluminide and nickelbase-superalloy) is one way for defined locally heterogeneous properties. Finally a third material example will show that SEBM is not only a very high temperature AM process.

98.prez_name: Selective Laser Melting of FeCr24Ni7Si2 Steel: Processing
98.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
98.prez_authors: Zhao  Xiao, Yi  Xin, Liu  Jie, Song  Bo, Wei Qing Song, Shi Yu Sheng
98.prez_abstract: Austenitic heat resistant steels have good mechanical properties, promising a great potential in thermal treatment plants, aerospace and nuclear power fields. However, they are usually difficult to fabricate complex parts by machining techniques. In this study, FeCr24Ni7Si2, a kind of austenitic heat resistant steels, was processed by selective laser melting aiming at the fabrication of complex hot forging steel mould. The Orthogonal design was used to study the effects of laser power, scanning speed and layer thickness on the density, microstructure and hardness. The optimized processing parameters are as follows: laser power of 140 W, scanning speed of 400 mm/s and layer thickness of 0.15 mm. The highest density of parts is 96.09%, while the highest hardness is 328.7 HV3. The microstructure of the parts shows a fine grain, with lots of microcracks. The microcracks could be attributed to the large residual stress and the formation of the brittle phase.

99.prez_name: Spatially Tailored Stimulus Response in Shape Memory Alloys
99.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
99.prez_authors: Ji  Ma, Brian  Franco, Kubra  Karayagiz, Gustavo  Tapia, Alaa  Elwany, Raymundo  Arroyave, Ibrahim  Karaman
99.prez_abstract: We demonstrate a smart material with controlled spatial variations in its stimulus-response characteristics, caused by location-dependent microstructure created from adjustments of the processing parameters during additive manufacturing.  A nickel-titanium shape memory alloy part was created with multiple shape recovery stages activated at different temperatures using the selective laser melting technique.  The multi-stage transformation is caused by differences in the precipitate structure and morphology created from controlled variations in the laser power, scan speed, and hatch distance within the same part, which result in differences in the thermal history at various spatial locations.  This is an example of using additive manufacturing techniques as a tool to create materials with novel functional response that is difficult to achieve through conventional methods.

100.prez_name: Tandem Arc Welding Based Wire+Arc Additive Manufacturing for Ternary Aluminum Alloys
100.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials

101.prez_name: Thermoset Cross-linking Effects on Interlayer Bond Strength of Fused Filament Fabrication Parts
101.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials
101.prez_authors: Andrew C. Abbott, Robyn L. Bradford, Gyaneshwar P. Tandon, Hilmar  Koerner, Katie  Thorp, Patricia  Hubbard, Roger  Avakian
101.prez_abstract: Weak interlayer bond strength in thermoplastic parts processed by fused filament fabrication (FFF) limit their mechanical performance.  High use-temperature thermosetting polymers have the potential to enhance interlayer bond strength by leveraging the cross-linking reaction.  Interlayer cross-linking is initiated during extrusion of thermoset filaments and completed during post-cure cycles.  The goal of this research is to characterize the degree to which cross-linking enhances interlayer bond strength in FFF parts.  Interlayer bond strength is measured for high molecular weight thermosetting EXP5010 polyimide filament developed by PolyOne Corp. and compared to thermoplastic Ultem 9085 both with and without chopped carbon fiber loading.  Average bond strength is measured by tensile testing specimens printed vertically with all roads in the same orientation such that load is applied to bonds between layers.  Mesostructural features including interlayer bond contact length and porosity are characterized via optical microscopy image analysis.

102.prez_name: Topological Design for Additive Manufacturing of Cellular Material: Application to Energy Absorption Applications
102.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials

103.prez_name: Ultrasonic Filament Modeling: Metal Additive Manufacturing of Fully-Dense Materials at Room Temperature with In-process Tailoring of Microstructure Capability
103.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Composites and Complex Materials

104.prez_name: A Combinatorial Assessment of Complex Concentrated Alloys / High Entropy Alloys
104.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance

105.prez_name: A Composable Simulation Framework for Microstructure and Mechanical Properties Prediction for Metallic Additive Manufacturing Processes
105.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
105.prez_authors: Nachiket  Patil, Deepankar  Pal, Pradeep  Chalavadi, Chong    Teng, Kai  Zeng, Brent  Stucker
105.prez_abstract: Metal powder-bed fusion additive manufacturing (AM) techniques involve rapid melting and solidification of the surface of a powder bed using either laser or electron beam energy sources. These processes are increasingly being used for the production of geometrically complex and high-performance components for various industries. Unfortunately, metal powder bed AM processes rely heavily on empirical testing of coupons to ensure reliability and quality, which is time-consuming and costly. A flexible, efficient and composable simulation tool is developed to capture the essential information needed to enable process optimization. Desirable characteristics of a composable simulation framework include the ability to reuse the simulation models for different build geometries, materials and process environments. The submodules developed for this purpose includes a real-time thermal solver, fluid mechanics solver, structural solver and a predictive microstructural solver. In this work, various case studies with experimental validations were performed to demonstrate composability of the 3DSIM simulation framework.

106.prez_name:
A Partial Solution to Modeling the Anisotropic 
Material Properties of Fused Deposition Modeling  ABS - Part 1 of 2
106.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
106.prez_authors: Ross  Fischer, Keenan  Jewkes, Scott  Kessler
106.prez_abstract: Many printing parameters are available for use during the fused deposition modeling (FDM) process. In general, this paper will explore the effects these parameters have on the mechanical properties of the resultant prototypes. This study presents the baseline data that will be later used with an ANN to investigate these effects. This paper makes broad correlations between printing parameters and mechanical properties. Three printing parameters were chosen and methodically varied while printing tensile specimens. The prototypes’ mechanical properties were determined through tensile testing. Results suggest that layer height, infill pattern and density have significant effects on FDM parts' strength, stiffness, ductility, and toughness. However, only general connections can be made between a specific printing parameter and material property. Additionally, ambient temperature was found to be essential to the final properties, however it was not recorded and will not be presented herein or used in the ANN.

107.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Differing Microstructures with Varying Builds
107.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
107.prez_authors: Roberta  Beal, Veronica  Livescu, George  Gray, Manny  Lovato
107.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) of metals is attractive due to its customizability, energy efficiency, and lower cost compared with conventional manufacturing methods. AM materials impose a new complexity through the build pattern of the particular additive process used, in addition to the polycrystalline microstructure within that pattern.Significant microstructural differences may be obtained for changes in the deposition process or the shape of the deposited material.This project is aimed at comparing microstructures of stainless steel built using three different deposition methods starting from the same stock powder material. There are several differing possible parameters used in each build process from each site and build direction. Steel samples deposited using LENS, electron beam powder bed, and laser powder bed are used to evaluate microstructural changes depending on deposition process and direction. Post-mortem metallographic analysis will be used to compare each sample microstructure and unveil connections between differing microstructures.

108.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing of Stainless Steel and Aluminum Alloy: Processing, Microstructure, and Material Properties
108.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
108.prez_authors: Sudhakar  Vadiraja, Penn  Rawn, Bryce  Abstetar, Ronda  Coguill, Bruce  Madigan
108.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing is one of the modern innovative technologies used for producing automotive, aerospace, bio-medical and many other engineering products. The basic objective of this investigation is to examine the processing-microstructure-mechanical property characteristics of 316L stainless steel. 3D-printing process was used to produce this alloy. Tension tests were performed on MTS Landmark servohydraulic Test System. Leica DM750P optical microscope, paired with Leica application suite software was used to characterize the microstructure and SEM (LEO 1430 VP model)for determining the mode/s of fracture. Tensile test results of 3D-printed samples were almost on par with those of wrought metal alloy samples. Fracture characteristics of stainless steel demonstrated typical ductile fracture features demonstrating good levels of toughness properties.

109.prez_name: Advanced Characterization of Additively Manufactured Materials Including Synchrotron–based 3D X-rays
109.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
109.prez_authors: Anthony  Rollett, Ross  Cunningham, Tugce  Ozturk, Sneha  Narra, Jack  Beuth
109.prez_abstract: It is important to understand the microstructure and, in particular, porosity in additively manufactured metallic parts as well as the powders used in many of the machines. Absent manufacturing defects, pores are the primary origin of fatigue failures under cyclic loading.  The characteristics of these pores can help indicate their cause; lack of fusion or keyholing pores with irregular shapes can usually be linked to incorrect processing parameters, while spherical pores suggest trapped gas. Synchrotron-based 3D X-ray microtomography was performed at the APS on additively manufactured samples of various metals using both electron beam and laser powder bed.  The spatial and size distributions of the porosity over a range of processing conditions were determined. Marked variations in the type and amount of porosity were observed as a function of the melt pool area.  Tomography was also performed on the unmelted powders themselves to measure size, shape and internal porosity.

110.prez_name: An Alternative Processing Route for Historically Process Incompatible Metal Alloys
110.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
110.prez_abstract: Aluminum 6061 is of great commercial and military interest due to its ubiquitous use in manufacturing, advantageous mechanical properties, and its successful certification in military applications. However, due to its off eutectic nature and the accompanying large freezing range, attempts to process the material by additive manufacturing have resulted in parts hampered by cracking and diminished mechanical properties. We have developed a unique approach to processing this historically difficult-to-process material.  Expansion of this technique to other systems not typically compatible with additive manufacturing may be achievable. Through the use of this approach, dense parts with few cracks have been produced by the SLM process. SEM, EDX, and hardness testing have been performed to verify successful processing of the alloy. An overview of this approach and the theoretical reasoning will be presented along with test results using an AL-Si-Mg mixture.

111.prez_name: An Experimental Investigation of Support Structure for Selective Laser Melting of Ti-6Al-4V
111.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
111.prez_authors: Kai  Zeng, J.J.S  Dilip, Haijun  Gong, Deepankar  Pal, Brent  Stucker
111.prez_abstract: Many Additive Manufacturing processes, such as polymer laser sintering or sheet lamination technologies, can be self-supporting and do not require support structures to withstand thermal stresses and gravitational forces. However, several other AM processes, such as direct laser deposition, material extrusion and direct printing are not self-supporting. They require secondary supports structures so that overhanging structures do not sag or distort due to gravitational forces or thermal stresses. In this study, the support structure of selective laser melting (SLM) has been investigated to understand how different support structures withstand the thermal stresses produced by the very high spatiotemporal thermal gradients induced during Ti-6Al-4V part fabrication. Experiments were conducted to study the influence of support structures on distortion and microstructure of parts fabricated using EOS M270 machine. Multiple support structure designs and strategies were explored experimentally to inform a model which predicts effective process parameters and support layouts to resist delamination of the part from the build plate.

112.prez_name: Analysis of Residual Stress Formation in Additive Manufacturing of Ti-6Al-4V
112.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
112.prez_authors: Mauritz  Möller, Dirk   Herzog, Tim  Wischeropp, Claus   Emmelmann, Christina   Krywka, Peter   Staron, Maximilian   Munsch
112.prez_abstract:
Laser Beam Melting (LBM) and Additive Metal Deposition (AMD) offers many advantages such as high freedom in design and short lead times. Although Ti-6Al-4V is one of the most widely used materials in powder bed-based LBM and the nozzle-fed powder-based AMD, the occurrence of residual stresses is still a common cause for failure of parts or even the entire build job.
In this paper, the influence of different exposure patterns on the residual stresses in both technologies is shown. A simulation-based approach is chosen to develop a strategy for further optimization of the exposure. The influence of the local geometry, e.g. in terms of overhangs or at the part edge, is taken into account. For validation, X-ray diffraction has successfully been used in first experiments to determine the local distribution of residual stresses in a laser beam melted specimen. The results show a significant variation of the residual stresses.

113.prez_name: Anisotropic Spall Strength in Additively Manufactured Ti-6Al-4V
113.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
113.prez_authors: David R Jones, Roberta A Beal, Olivia  Dippo, Veronica  Livescu, George T Gray
113.prez_abstract: We present a study on the spall strength or resistance to dynamic tensile damage of additively manufactured (AM) Ti-6Al-4V.  Samples were sectioned from plates of AM Ti-6Al-4V such that the effects of having the tensile loading parallel or normal to the build plane could be investigated.  A sample of wrought Ti-6Al-4V was used as a control.  Gas gun plate impact experiments with velocimetry and soft-capture of the samples allowed calculation of the spall strength and quantitative analysis of the internal damage.  When loaded so that the tensile stress was parallel to the build layers the AM material had a very similar response to the wrought control.  However, when the tensile stress was normal to the build planes the spall strength was reduced by up to 40%.  An increase in damage was also observed, with many large fractures occurring instead of the typical void nucleation and coalescence expected with spall failure.

114.prez_name: Anisotropic Thermal Expansion Behavior of Ti-6Al-4V Components Fabricated by Lased Based Directed Energy Deposition Additive Manufacturing
114.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
114.prez_authors: Jay S. Keist, Todd A. Palmer
114.prez_abstract: The thermal expansion behavior was analyzed by dilatometry on a series of Ti-6Al-4V wall structures that were fabricated by a laser based directed energy deposition (DED) additive manufacturing (AM) process.  The average thermal expansion from the AM wall structures was near values expected for forged Ti-6Al-4V components.  In addition, the observed beta transus temperature of the AM wall structures was slightly higher than forged Ti-6Al-4V components which was attributed differences of the measured oxygen content.  Significant anisotropy, however, was observed within the dilatometry results depending on the orientation of the sample in relation to the build substrate.  Samples oriented with the long dimension perpendicular to the substrate exhibited significantly higher thermal expansion values than samples oriented with the long dimension parallel to the substrate.  The thermal expansion anisotropy may be linked prior beta grain morphology observed microstructural and the strong grain texturing observed by XRD within the wall structures.

115.prez_name: Application of Digital Thread to Additive Manufacturing Systems
115.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
115.prez_abstract: R&D investments in Additive Manufacturing (AM) is yielding huge amounts of data on materials, process parameters, testing, and part qualification.  In parallel, companies are responding to competitive pressures by 'digitizing' their supply chain, manufacturing processes, part and in-service data.  Data captured throughout the product lifecycle is analysed to reduce tooling costs and lead times, improve efficiency and drive innovation.  The phrase ‘Digital Thread’ describes this process.  AM, a digitally-driven technology, represents an ideal application for Digital Thread concepts.  Data, captured dynamically, is available to integrated discovery, data mining, and physics-based simulation tools, enabling timely response to in-process variability that affects part quality and predict in-service performance.  This paper reports on an informatics system tested against the challenges of the Digital Thread to drive production of high-fidelity AM parts while reducing the costs of physical testing, repair and in-service liability.

116.prez_name: Assessing the Tensile and Fatigue Properties of Ti-6Al-4V Produced from Electron Beam Melting
116.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
116.prez_authors: Brian J. Hayes, John  Porter, Tim  Hall, Ken  Davis
116.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) of metallic components has received increasing attention as an emerging technology in recent years. The ability for AM to produce complex geometries using lightweight alloys, such as Ti-6Al-4V, is of primary interest to the aerospace industry. However, before this technology is fully realized as a viable manufacturing method for structural components, the mechanical behavior needs to be fully assessed. This study evaluates the tensile and fatigue properties of Ti-6Al-4V produced from a powder-bed electron beam melting system. The properties of specimens in the as-built condition are compared to those that have undergone post-processing, including hot isostatic pressing and electrochemical finishing. The effect of specimen orientation relative to the build direction is also evaluated using both samples built for test as well as samples excised from AM parts. Additionally, fractography was performed to characterize the fractured surface morphology and detect the presence of potential defects such as porosity.

117.prez_name: Assessment of Residual Stress in Selective Laser Melted 17-4 PH Stainless Steel via Numerical Modeling and Neutron Diffraction
117.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
117.prez_authors: Mohammad  Masoomi, Aref  Yadollahi, Scott M Thompson, Nima  Shamsaei, Robert Andrew Winholtz, Justin L. Milner
117.prez_abstract: The residual stress within 17-4 PH stainless steel parts fabricated via Selective Laser Melting was investigated experimentally and numerically. A three-dimensional finite element model was employed for predicting the thermal history and internal stress distribution within the SLM part.  Using neutron diffraction, a continuum-scale numerical model was validated and used to determine effects of SLM process/design parameters on residual stress formation.  The relationships between residual stress distribution and laser scan direction, part thickness, heat transfer and thermomechanical properties were investigated.  In addition, the effects of powder bed properties and post-SLM heat treatment on residual stress were studied.  Results indicate that residual stress is higher along the boundary of SLM 17-4 PH stainless steel parts relative to more central locations and that heat treatment reduces such residual stress.

118.prez_name: Carbide Formation in Additive Manufacturing of Single-crystal Superalloy René N5 Processed through Scanning Laser Epitaxy
118.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
118.prez_abstract: Carbon is added to single-crystal nickel-base superalloys to reduce the formation of grain defects. C and a carbide former drive precipitation of carbides at grain boundaries reducing grain boundary sliding. In this paper, carbide formation in nickel-base superalloy René N5 was studied using optical microscopy (OM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). Samples of René N5 were fabricated using scanning laser epitaxy (SLE), a powder bed fusion based additive manufacturing (AM) technique. The carbides formed in these alloys were mostly Chinese script-type carbides which formed discrete networks in the interdendritic region. In addition, blocky and elongated carbides were also observed. EDX analysis showed the carbides to be Ta rich. The findings also showed the presence of rhenium carbide which was not reported in earlier literature concering AM of carbon-containing nickel-base superalloys. This work is sponsored by the Office of Naval Research through grants N00014-11-1-0670 and N00014-14-1-0658.

119.prez_name: Characterisation of Additive Manufactured Aluminum-based alloy Periodic Cellular Structures (PCS)
119.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
119.prez_authors: Florian Thibaut Gallien, Adriaan  Spierings, Andrew  Norman, Andreas  Mortensen, Volker  Gass
119.prez_abstract: Periodic structures are stronger by one order of magnitude compared to stochastic microcellular metal structures, and feature also a reduced spread in values of mechanical properties if the sample to cell size ratio is small. The rapid development of additive manufacturing processes has greatly facilitated the production of such materials. In this work, four different types of PCS were manufactured in aluminum-silicon alloy (AlSi12) by selective laser melting to have 30% relative density. Porosity and inclusions defects introduced by the process are identified and quantified using 3D-Tomography recordings. Mechanical properties are measured through quasi-static compression tests and are correlated to finite element analysis. The influence of the defects on the compressive modulus is investigated and the failure modes of the structures are determined using stereo cameras allowing 3D in-situ strain mapping, to assess the importance of the PCS design on the mechanical properties.

120.prez_name: Characterization of MAR-M247 Fabricated by Electron Beam Melting
120.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
120.prez_authors: Kinga A. Unocic, Alfred O Okello, Michael  Massey, Michael  M Kirka, Ryan  Dehoff
120.prez_abstract: The persistent demand for increased efficiency, performance, and reduction in cost and CO2 emission in power generation applications requires materials that exhibit high temperature strength and oxidation resistance.  Materials such as Ni-base superalloys can fulfill this role better than ferritic and austenitic steels since they have unique microstructure owing to their complex composition, which often comprises a dozen elements selected carefully to target particular issue. Ni-base alloys can display excellent properties such as creep resistance, fatigue strength, and fracture toughness in aggressive environments of high temperatures and stresses. The new challenge is to produce these alloys with additive manufacturing (AM), which will allow for cost reduction and complex-shaped structures with retained exact composition. Therefore, this study will focus on detail and advanced characterization of MAR-M247 fabricated by electron beam melting using scanning electron microscopy and scanning transmission electron microscopy. The results will be compared with those for traditionally cast MAR-M247.

121.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
121.prez_authors: Wes  Everhart, Paul S Korinko, Marissa   Reigel, Michael  Morgan, John   Bobbitt
121.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing is being considered for a wide variety of applications.  To be successful, understanding interactions of process variables on reproducibility of mechanical properties and microstructure is needed.  The primary variables of interest in this study include the build location, nearest neighbor spacing, and build group in addition to the influences of manufacturing process noise such as operator and powder lot.  Samples from three different builds were used to determine a variety of properties.  Preliminary results indicate the properties are influenced by many variables that one might consider secondary, tertiary, or even higher order.  The results indicate that SLM technology is viable for fabricating some structures, however, the opportunities for high value added applications are still in the future and research such as that reported here will enable designers to tailor the build to the strengths and weaknesses of the process.

122.prez_name: Comparison of the Processing Space for Laser-deposited Inconel 625 and 17-4 Stainless Steel
122.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
122.prez_authors: Colt  Montgomery, Jack  Beuth, Shawn  Moylan
122.prez_abstract: Melt pool geometry prediction is important for reliable and efficient part production utilizing additive manufacturing. In this research Inconel 625 and 17-4 stainless steel are investigated to determine optimal regions of processing space within the laser powder bed operating range. Various geometries and the addition of powder are explored utilizing a process mapping approach. Insights are obtained by comparing results from experiments and simulations. Furthermore, comparisons between the results of the individual alloy systems can provide deeper understanding of the laser powder bed processing of high strength corrosion resistant alloys.

123.prez_name: Computed Tomography as a Tool for the Inspection of Metallic Additively Manufactured Components: A Review
123.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
123.prez_authors: Griffin T Jones, Todd A Palmer
123.prez_abstract: Several non-destructive testing (NDT) methods have been shown to be viable options for the interrogation of metallic additively manufactured components.  Many of these tools, though, are limited by the unique characteristics and geometries of additively manufactured (AM) components.  One of the more promising NDT methods is micro-x-ray computed tomography (CT).  This tool combines the complex volumetric inspection capabilities of radiographic tomography with the relatively recent advent of microfocus technology, allowing for the simultaneous three dimensional evaluation of both internal and surface features. A review of the application of CT to the interrogation of metallic AM components is presented for a range of alloy types and part geometries along with the challenges in obtaining data of sufficient quality for adequate inspection and identification of defects. Opportunities for further investigation and advancement of the field of CT as an enabling technology for the inspection of additively manufactured components are identified.

124.prez_name: Constitutive Property and Modeling of Additive Manufactured Stainless Steels
124.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
124.prez_authors: Shuh Rong  Chen, G. T.  Gray, Carl M Cady, Veronica  Livescu, Cameron M Knapp, John S Carpenter
124.prez_abstract: Utilization of AM materials to meet engineering applications requires quantification of the constitutive properties of these evolving materials in comparison to conventionally-manufactured metals and alloys. Cylinders of 316L and 304L SS were produced using a LENS MR-7 laser additive manufacturing system from Optomec (Albuquerque, NM) equipped with a 1kW Yb-fiber laser. The microstructure of both SS is detailed in the as-built condition and following heat-treatments designed to obtain full recrystallization. The constitutive behavior as a function of strain rate and temperature is presented and compared to that of nominal annealed wrought SS plate. Material parameters for an advanced constitutive model were derived and validated using Taylor cylinder impact tests. The deformation mechanisms of the AM materials will be investigated.

125.prez_name: Continuum Modelling of Solidification during Additive Manufacturing
125.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
125.prez_abstract: Compared to traditional manufacturing routes, recent technological developments have made additive manufacturing(AM) a viable alternative or even superior when addressing specific goals, such as optimized material use, controlled local microstructure and complex shapes of the finished product. To realize such an end, AM needs extreme control of the process parameters. This talk focuses on computational modelling of the solidification process relevant to metals and alloy systems, pertaining to AM process involving partial or complete melting of the powder such as laser melting, laser deposition and laser sintering. The talk would discuss the phase field model developed to address solidification, which takes into account the thermodynamics and kinetics of material of relevance to AM process to simulate the microstructural outcome due to specific processing conditions. The aim of this work is to develop strategies of altering the processing conditions in order to have a better control on the final polycrystalline microstructure.

126.prez_name: Damage Development in Thin Walled Selective Laser Melted Structures
126.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
126.prez_authors: Jonas  Saarimäki, Johan J Moverare, Håkan  Brodin
126.prez_abstract: Microstructure of additive manufactured alloys are usually complex and difficult to characterize. One method to reveal the true morphology is by performing an (EBSD) analysis of the material. An analysis of the SLM material is reported. The microstructure contains large grains with multiple low angle grain boundaries together with small grains that approach nanometer size, in the smallest size range. Grains are to a large extent, not equiaxed, but rather elongated.Mechanical testing has been conducted and the results clearly indicate a situation where the additive manufactured material is stronger compared to material manufactured by traditional routes. The impact of anisotropy is discussed and the role of heat treatment is addressed.The processes yield microstructures that are characteristic for the manufacturing process in question, even though a common heat treatment has been applied. In all cases, carbides are present. How grain morphology influences the mechanical properties are discussed.

127.prez_name: Defect Characterization in Powder Bed AM Aluminum
127.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
127.prez_authors: Lisa  Deibler, Jeff  Rodelas , Jay  Carroll
127.prez_abstract: Mechanical testing of laser powder bed manufactured AlSi10Mg has revealed large scatter in properties, particularly in ductility measurements during tensile tests.  The observed behavior is indicative of flaw-dominated failure.  The microstructural characteristics and the defect distribution in post-failure tensile bars has been characterized using fractographic and metallographic techniques.  The defect data has been statistically treated and linked to the mechanical properties of each particular sample.  The desired outcome of this research is to have the ability to determine the characteristics of the most detrimental flaws.  That information will then be used to focus development of the powder bed process to avoid those particular flaws.

128.prez_name: Defect Detection and Distribution Analysis for Metal Additive Manufacturing using micro CT: Opportunities and Challenges
128.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
128.prez_abstract: Additive Manufacturing (AM) has made significant progress/growth over the past years, enabling complex parts to be manufactured layer by layer, with excellent material properties. However, these parts may contain defects at various size and length scales which affect mechanical properties of the components. X-ray micro-computed tomography (microCT) is a non-destructive testing method which has in recent years changed from a qualitative imaging to a quantitative measurement method. In this work microCT is used for non-destructive testing of industrial components that were additively manufactured from a titanium alloy. Various types of defects have been detected using microCT. These defects would have been very difficult/impossible to detect by other non-destructive testing methods due to the object complexity, defect size, shape and location within the component. Visualization/quantification of the pore size distribution/changes before and after the scan is accomplished by alignment of the volumes. The application of microCT to AM is thus demonstrated.

129.prez_name: DEM Modeling of Powder Spreading in the Powder Bed Fusion Process and Empirical Correlations
129.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
129.prez_authors: Justin  Whiting, Michelle  Bernhardt, Stephen R. Geer
129.prez_abstract: The modeling work done over the past two decades in additive manufacturing (AM) has undoubtedly increased the rate of progress.  While much of the modeling work present in AM research is aimed to create representations of the melt pool, rate of solidification and the final part’s mechanical properties, very little has been done to investigate the spreading procedure in the powder bed fusion process.  Limited focus has been placed on describing the particulates that are actually incorporated into the final part.  Characteristics of these particles, including morphology, size distribution, and surface roughness alter the final part’s properties.  Discrepancies based on the location of the particles in the powder bed have been previously found.  Discrete element method simulations are used to model the interaction between the recoating blade and the AM powder.  Powder from deposited layers is extracted and evaluated to serve as a comparison and calibration tool for the model.

130.prez_name: Design of an ODS-TiAl Alloy for Additive Manufacturing Technologies
130.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
130.prez_authors: Christoph  Kenel, Karl  Dawson, Georgia  Dasargyri, Thomas  Bauer, Alberto  Colella, Adriaan B Spierings, Gordon J Tatlock, Christian  Leinenbach
130.prez_abstract: In this work, a novel oxide dispersion strengthened (ODS) titanium aluminide (Ti-45Al-3Nb ODS) was developed for additive manufacturing (AM) technologies. Titanium aluminides are promising structural intermetallics for weight reduction and increased performance of high temperature components. The introduction of ODS particles using AM provides a new route for processing complex high-temperature resistant parts. The alloy design and selection process was supported by computational thermodynamics, taking into account requirements for processing as well as long term alloy behavior under service conditions. Laser metal deposition and selective laser melting trials were conducted to study the microstructure formation and distribution of the ODS particles. Conventional duplex and near lamellar microstructures with homogeneously distributed ODS particles in the alloy matrix were obtained. The novel alloy was compared to the established GE48-2-2 alloy in terms of phases, microstructure and texture after processing. A significantly reduced texture formation was observed with the novel alloy.

131.prez_name: Developing Fundamental Scaling Relationships for Size and Geometry in Directed Energy Deposition Processes
131.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
131.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) processes utilizing high energy density laser and electron beam energy sources are used to fabricate a range of metallic components with varying complexity and sizes.  As the sizes of fabricated components increase, changes in the processing conditions impact the complex thermal histories experienced at each location and the corresponding process-structure-property relationships.  By altering the processing conditions, unexpected challenges in the prediction of microstructures, mechanical properties, as well as residual stress states and distortion, are introduced with higher deposition rates as well as longer dwell times.  The development of fundamental scaling relationships that can be used to predict the mechanical properties is an important area of research as part geometries increase in both size and complexity.  A review of recent work in this area and a path for the integration of these scaling relationships in future modeling and simulation tools are provided.

132.prez_name: Development of a Diffusion Mobility Description and Its Implications for Additive Manufactured Titanium Alloys
132.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
132.prez_authors: Greta  Lindwall, Kil-Won  Moon, Nikolas  Hrabe , Carelyn   Campbell
132.prez_abstract: Electron beam melting, one specific additive manufacturing (AM) process, shows promise for making medical devices and aerospace components of Ti-6Al-4V through unique shape control.  An essential to the success of this AM process is control of the microstructure evolution during post-processing of the as-built parts (e.g. hot isostatic pressing). To better understand and control the microstructure evolution during these processes CALPHAD-based diffusion and thermodynamics are employed. A diffusion description is developed for the Ti-6Al-4V alloy system using diffusion couple experiments and a CALPHAD-based approach to model atomic mobilities. Various diffusion couple experiments are designed to enable evaluation of diffusion in the α and β phases including the constitutional binary systems, Ti-Al and Ti-V, and the ternary Ti-Al-V system. Using the developed mobility description, post-processing of Ti-6Al-4V is evaluated with the aim to guide in the selecting processing conditions that avoids detrimental phases.

133.prez_name: Drop-weight Impact Properties of an Additively Manufactured Re-entrant Auxetic Cellular Structure: Geometrical and Material Effects
133.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
133.prez_authors: Amer  Beharic, Rafael  Rodriguez Egui, Li  Yang
133.prez_abstract: Auxetic cellular structures are expected to exhibit attractive energy absorption properties that may be ideal for many applications. The design of performance for these structures includes the design of geometries and the consideration of material properties. In this study, different geometrical design variations of a re-entrant auxetic cellular structure were fabricated by both Ti6Al4V and nylon-12 using powder bed fusion processes, and consequently subjected to quasi-static compressive testing as well as drop weight testing under various testing conditions. The results were normalized by solid material properties and quasi-static mechanical properties in order to provide a direct comparison of the impact energy absorption property dependency on both geometrical designs and material properties.

134.prez_name: Effect of Hall Flow Characterization on Built Properties of SLM Part
134.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance

135.prez_name: Effect of Heat Treatment on the Microstructure of MAR-M247 Fabricated through Scanning Laser Epitaxy
135.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
135.prez_abstract: Engineered components made of superalloys routinely undergo heat treatment to tailor their microstructure and properties. In this study, the effect of heat treatment on the microstructure and hardness of polycrystalline nickel-base superalloy MAR-M247 was investigated. Samples of MAR-M247 were fabricated using scanning laser epitaxy (SLE); a powder bed fusion based additive manufacturing technique. Microstructural characterization of as-deposited and heat treated samples was performed using optical microscopy (OM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), and X-ray diffraction (XRD), while microhardness of the samples was determined using Vickers’s micro hardness measurements. The results showed that the heat treated samples were free from cracking. The average grain size of the heat-treated samples was slightly larger than that of the as-deposited sample and the microstructure became homogeneous with reduction in the eutectic volume fraction. This work is sponsored by the Office of Naval Research through grants N00014-11-1-0670 and N00014-14-1-0658.

136.prez_name: Effect of Hot Isostatic Pressing on Mechanical Properties and Dimensional Accuracy of Intentionally Porous Ti6Al4V Parts Made by Selective Laser Melting
136.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
136.prez_authors: Raya  Mertens, Bart  Boeckmans, Lore  Thijs, Jan  Van Humbeeck, Jean-Pierre  Kruth
136.prez_abstract: This work attempts to improve the production rate of Ti6Al4V parts via selective laser melting (SLM) and determines the optimum trade-off between quality and productivity. In this respect, cylinders with dense shells are produced with varying core densities at high SLM speeds (up to 5 times faster) and then densified by hot isostatic pressing (HIP) post treatment. After examining porosity levels prior to HIP, it is found that compressive yield strengths comparable to a dense part can be achieved if porosity is gradually increased towards the core regions. HIP application results in fully dense parts (>99.5%), which is partly attributed to the well-designed dense shell that enables effective compaction/shrinkage of porous parts. The inevitable part shrinkage is, however, undesirable and can be extensive (up to 400µm on a diameter of 10mm). Lastly, the findings are discussed to form guidelines to determine suitable SLM production strategies depending on the desired requirements.

137.prez_name: Effect of Microstructure on the Creep Behavior of Inconel 718 Manufactured via Electron Beam Melting
137.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
137.prez_authors: Alfred Ogola Okello, Michael M. Kirka, Kinga A Unocic, Ryan R. Dehoff
137.prez_abstract: The nickel-iron-base superalloy Inconel 718 is the most widely used superalloy in the aerospace community due its weldability, corrosion and oxidation resistance, and high-temperature creep strength. Additive manufacturing (AM) with electron beam melting (EBM) uses an electron beam as a heat source to melt successive powder layers, and provides an alternative for fabrication of complex near-net shape Inconel 718 parts that are impossible through traditional forging and casting processes. Additionally, EBM offers the added benefit of site-specific control of columnar or equiax grains within the material. The current research presents preliminary observations on the influence of microstructure (columnar/equiax grains) on the creep deformation mechanisms of EBM Inconel 718 at 650°C in comparison to the traditionally worked Inconel 718.

138.prez_name: Effect of Process Parameters on the Melt Pool Geometry and Evolution of Porosity in Selective Laser Melting of Alloy IN625
138.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
138.prez_authors: John Samuel Dilip  Jangam,  Ashabul Anam  Md, Pal  Deepankar, Stucker  Brent
138.prez_abstract: Alloy IN625 is a solid solution strengthened Nickel base superalloy possessing high strength and good corrosion and oxidation resistance even at elevated temperatures. In this study IN625 was processed using selective laser melting (SLM). The current work focuses on the effects of process parameters on the melt pool geometry, and the evolution of porosity in SLM-fabricated parts. Initially, single bead experiments were carried out by varying the laser power and scan speed with a constant layer thickness. In addition, parts with dimensions of 10 mm×10 mm×5 mm were fabricated with the same process parameter combinations used for fabricating single beads. The single bead and as-built parts were examined using optical and scanning electron microscopy. This study presents the effect of each process parameter on resulting porosity and microstructures.

139.prez_name: Effect of Welding Speed and Post Weld Heat Treatments in Laser Wire Deposition of Thin Ti-6Al-4V Deposits: Microstructure Characterization
139.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
139.prez_authors: Nejib  Chekir, Raynald  Gauvin, Nicolas  Brodusch, JJ  Sixsmith, Alexandre  Gontcharov, Mathieu  Brochu
139.prez_abstract: The effect of two welding speeds on thin Ti-6Al-4V plates produced by Laser Wire Deposition (LWD) has first been investigated. A slow travel speed promotes recrystallization of columnar prior β grains into horizontal prior β grains and coarsening of the α+β basket weave microstructure. It is then shown that by increasing the welding speed, sufficiently high cooling rates are produced in order to create a fine α+β basket weave structure. No recrystallization of the prior β grains has been observed at high speed. Effects of two Post Weld Heat Treatments (PWHT) groups have been investigated in a second part. A stress relief operation keeps the effect of welding parameters on material properties. Annealing or HIP below the β transus temperature, followed or not by aging, homogenize the microstructure but coarsens the previously developed α+β basket weave structure.

140.prez_name: Effects of Nickel Superalloy Composition and Geometry in EBM on Microstructure
140.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
140.prez_authors: Curtis Lee Frederick, Suresh  Babu, Michael  Kirka
140.prez_abstract: The control of micro-structure in electron beam additive manufacturing has been previously demonstrated with Nickel-base superalloy Inconel 718. However, the effects of the composition used, and the size and complexity of the geometry on microstructure have not been understood.  In an ARCAM EBM machine,both bulk parts and thin walled structures are fabircated using nickel based superalloys of different compositions.  The resulting microstructure will be discussed in the context of both grain structure and precipitate formation and compared to results derived from alloy solidification and phase precipitation models. The intent of this work is to provide alloy design principles for future Ni-base superalloys in the EBM process.

141.prez_name: Effects of Powder Feedstock Quality on γ-TiAl Parts Fabricated via Electron Beam Melting
141.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
141.prez_authors: Peeyush  Nandwana, Ryan R Dehoff, William H Peter
141.prez_abstract: γ-TiAl alloys are candidate materials for high temperature applications, but they have found limited use because of their poor machinability. Near-net shape processes avoid these machinability issues, and are therefore a promising approach for fabricating γ-TiAl parts. This study focuses on two aspects of the electron beam additive manufacturing of γ-TiAl: (1) the effect of the particle size distribution on part quality, and (2) changes in the powder feedstock’s chemistry, size distribution and morphology as it is recycled over several build cycles.  Changes in build quality will be correlated with changes in the powder feedstock’s properties.  The study will identify the optimal particle size distribution for fabricating high quality parts and the maximum time the feedstock can be used to achieve builds with consistent chemistries and properties.

142.prez_name: Establishing Post-build Heat Treatment for Age-hardened Additive-manufactured Alloys
142.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
142.prez_authors: Benjamin  Seitz, Michael M. Kirka, Richard W. Neu
142.prez_abstract: The success of fabricating and qualifying additive-manufactured structural components requires comprehensive understanding of the processing-structure-property relationships.  Most focus has been on the primary solidification occurring in the build itself to minimize gross defects such as delamination between layers and porosity.  The next critical processing step for age-hardened alloys is the post-build heat treatment.  Since diffusivity depends on the spatial distribution of the elements, the optimal solution treatment and age parameters established for conventionally forged or cast components of similar composition will likely not be optimal for additive-manufactured components.  This study specifically focuses on developing methods to rapidly establish the post-build heat treatment for Inconel 718 fabricated by electron beam melting (EBM) using a design of experiments approach.  A library consisting of several test volumes is designed, built, and then characterized using relevant microscopy and mechanical property tests.

143.prez_name: Evaluating the Effect of Processing Parameter on Porosity in SLM Ti-6Al-4V via Synchrotron–based 3D X-ray Microtomography
143.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
143.prez_authors: Ross  Cunningham, Sneha P. Narra, Jack  Beuth, Anthony  Rollett
143.prez_abstract: The porosity frequently observed in additively manufactured parts is a concern for components intended to undergo high-cycle fatigue. The morphology and location of pores can help identify their cause; irregular shaped lack of fusion or key-holing pores can usually be linked to incorrect processing parameters, while spherical pores suggest trapped gas. Synchrotron-based 3D X-ray microtomography was performed on SLM Ti-6Al-4V samples fabricated on an EOS M290 Laser Sintering machine over a range of processing conditions. The process mapping technique was used to control melt pool size between samples. Tomography was also performed on the powder to measure powder porosity. This work builds off the authors' previous experiments with the ARCAM Electron Beam Melting technology, which displayed significant variations in porosity with changes to processing parameters. These results give insight into the source of porosity in SLM parts, and add information related to inherent defect populations to existing process maps.

144.prez_name: Evaluation of Structure and Properties of 4340 Steel Produced by the DMLS Process
144.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
144.prez_authors: Elias  Jelis, Rajendra  Sadangi, Michael  Hespos, Jamal   White, Matthew   Clemente, Nuggehalli  Ravindra
144.prez_abstract: Direct Metal Laser Sintering (DMLS) involves the consolidation of metal powder layer by layer through laser melting and solidification.  In this study, process parameters were optimized for 4340 steel to control melt pool characteristics and their interactions to produce dense and homogeneous structures. The resulting mechanical properties at the center of the build plate were found to be comparable to wrought counterparts in the vertical and horizontal orientations after heat treatment. The subsequent build was scaled up to evaluate the mechanical behavior as a function of location as well. The build was then repeated several times. Significant variations in mechanical properties were observed at different build plate locations and orientations likely due to variations in powder coverage and gas flow.  The reliability and reproducibility of the process will be highlighted in this paper.

145.prez_name: Experiments with a Thermal Model for Selective Laser Melting of IN718
145.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
145.prez_authors: R Mark  Ward, Miren  Aristizabal, Moataz  Attallah
145.prez_abstract: An explicit 3d finite volume thermal model was used to simulate the temperature and solidification parameters for objects made by selective laser melting of IN718 on a Concept Laser M2 machine. The model formulation is discussed and predictions are compared with measurements of pool shape, porosity and microstructure for both “simple” and “island” scan strategies. The strengths (high computational speed when running on a GPU) and weaknesses (no residual stress, no fluid flow) are discussed, along with the effects of the material properties and the representation of the laser/metal interaction.

146.prez_name: Fabricating and Characterizing Additively Manufactured Heat Exchanger Tubing
146.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
146.prez_authors: Paul S Korinko, Haley  KcKee, John  Bobbitt, Sudarsanam Suresh  Babu, Frederick  List
146.prez_abstract: Additive Manufacturing brings unique opportunities to the fabrication world, especially for complex, high value added components that are challenging if not impossible to fabricate using traditional technologies.  This project was developed to design, build and test a variety of shapes, internal geometries, and lengths of process tubing for a specialized heat exchanger that operates from nominally 140°C to -40°C.  A preliminary design was fabricated and based on the knowledge gained from this component, several design iterations were made to optimize the heat transfer while not adversely affecting the thermal strains.  Several additional components were prepared and the parts were characterized for burst strength, tensile properties, microstructure, and chemistry.  In addition, the build data were analyzed to determine if a correlation could be made with the properties.  This presentation will describe the application for the heat exchanger, the goals of the project, the results for the optimization, fabrication, and characterization.

147.prez_name: Fatigue Crack Initiation and Growth Behavior of EBM Ti-6Al-4V before and after Hot Isostatic Pressing
147.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
147.prez_authors: Mohsen  Seifi, Aref  Yadollahi, Nima  Shamsaei, John J Lewandowski
147.prez_abstract: The fatigue behavior and damage tolerance of additively manufactured (AM) materials must be assessed and understood in order to utilize them in structural application. Titanium alloys are of particular interest to the aerospace and biomedical community. While microstructure evaluations and quasi-static tensile properties of EBM Ti-6Al-4V have been reported, fatigue properties are not widely available. This work examines the fatigue crack initiation and crack growth behavior of Ti-6Al-4V specimens fabricated in the as-deposited and post-processed via Hot Isostatic Pressing (HIP) conditions. The microstructures, fatigue and crack growth properties were measured in vertical and horizontal directions while the orientation dependence of the fatigue properties determined to utilize the evolving ASTM/ISO standards for AM materials. SEM fractography has been performed to determine failure mechanisms and the results compared to previous results obtained with earlier generations of Arcam machines.

148.prez_name: Fe – Al Intermetallic Cellular Structures Produced by Laser Engineered Net Shaping (LENS)
148.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
148.prez_authors: Krzysztof  Karczewski, Marek  Polański, Zbigniew  Bojar
148.prez_abstract: Laser Engineered Net Shaping (LENS) technique was used to produce Fe-Al intermetallic cellular structures from a FeAl15.8Cr5.4 prealloyed powder. To obtain samples with low porosity and a satisfactory shape and size congruency, suitable technological parameters of the LENS manufacturing process were selected. X-Ray Computed Tomography (CT) was used to analyze shape and size of obtained cellular structures. The phase analysis and microstructure analysis were examined by X-ray diffraction and optical and scanning electron microscopy. Mechanical properties were investigated to validate the metallurgical quality of obtained samples. Directly fabricated Fe-Al cellular structures were found to possess high metallurgical quality, and satisfactory mechanical properties.

149.prez_name: Grain Refinement in Electron Beam Melt Fabricated Ti-6Al-4V via Hypoeutectic Boron Addition
149.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
149.prez_authors: Zaynab  Mahbooba, Timothy  Horn, Harvey  West, Peeyush   Nandwana, Andrzej  Wojcieszynski, Ola  Harrysson
149.prez_abstract: Hypoeutectic boron additions have demonstrated grain refinement in Ti-6Al-4V castings with minimal reduction in ductility.  This work examines the effect of hypoeutectic boron addition on the microstructure of Arcam Electron Beam Melt (EBM) fabricated Ti-6Al-4V.  Microstructural changes resulting from boron addition to Ti-6Al-4V are examined using electron backscatter diffraction, electron microprobe analysis and scanning electron microscopy.  A transition from a highly columnar microstructure to an equiaxed grain structure is observed.  In addition, thermodynamic models are used to predict the solidification process of boron modified Ti-6Al-4V during EBM fabrication.  This study introduces the use of compositional modification to tailor microstructure for Additive Manufacturing.

150.prez_name:
High Density Monolithic Alloy Parts via Additive Manufacturing 
Using the Binder Jetting Process
150.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
150.prez_abstract: Recent advances have enabled the transition of binder jetting processes from infiltrated metal functional prototypes to production of parts in conventional, high-performance monolithic alloys.  Because the printed parts consist of, at most, 60 volume percent metal powder, liquid-phase sintering must be applied to increase the part to near-full density with usable mechanical and thermal properties.
