This sequential printing/ thermal process has been developed to form complex shapes in 316L stainless steel, Inconel 625, and Hastelloy 282.  Density in excess of 97% is achieved with properties approximating those of the alloys in cast form.  Hipping is used to reach full density and even greater mechanical properties.  This presentation will describe the process development, resulting properties, and some applications of the process in energy, thermo-fluid handling, and aerospace.

151.prez_name: ICME Approach to the Materials Challenges in Additive Manufacturing of Metals
151.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
151.prez_authors: Jiadong  Gong, David  Snyder, Gregory  Olson
151.prez_abstract: The emerging additive technology has advanced with unique manufacturing capabilities that cannot be attained with conventional manufacturing technologies. However, the complexity during the additive forming process, such as the rapid temperature change and transient phase transformation, brings increased uncertainty to the microstructure and material properties of the components. Furthermore, the standard post treatment developed for the traditionally formed material often fall short for the additively processed material. Integrated Computational Materials Engineering methods and tools have been developed and applied to additive manufacturing to optimize the process and the resulting properties. A few case studies of additive manufacturing of various alloy systems highlight the application of the ICME methods to design and develop the material and post processing for tailored microstructure and optimized material properties of the component.

152.prez_name: Impact of Atomization and Processing Conditions on the Heat Treatment Response of Additively Manufactured 17-4 Stainless Steel
152.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
152.prez_authors: Scott  Meredith, Jared  Blecher, Todd  Palmer, Rich  Martukanitz
152.prez_abstract: Following the processing of additively manufactured (AM) components, heat treatments are sometimes used to alter the microstructure and improve mechanical properties of the finished parts. However, different processing conditions may influence the heat treatment response.  The heat treatment response for additively manufactured 17-4 PH grade stainless steel fabricated in two different powder bed systems has been studied, employing two different powder feedstock atomization conditions (nitrogen versus argon) as well as different processing conditions (nitrogen versus argon).  The impact of these differing conditions on the chemistry of deposits and microstructure in as-deposited, solutionized, and aged conditions has been examined.  The microstructure produced under these different conditions are correlated to the mechanical response for a range of solution and aged conditions, allowing the kinetics of the heat treat response to be quantified.

153.prez_name: Impact of Fe content and Post Processing on Properties of Additively Manufactured Solid Solution Strengthened Nickel Based Alloys
153.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
153.prez_abstract: Solid solution strengthened nickel base alloys, such as, Inconel® 625, are widely used in cladding and additive manufacturing (AM) processes. However, the formation of carbides and intermetallic compounds (i.e. laves phase) can have detrimental impacts on mechanical, primarily elongation and corrosion properties. Inconel® 625 has a wide range of allowable Fe contents in the wrought condition (from 0 to 5.5 wt. %) that can impact corrosion and mechanical properties, but the magnitude of this impact is unknown. Based on microstructural, mechanical property, and corrosion performance results. Process-structure-property relations for Inconel® 625 directed energy deposition builds with Fe contents at the allowable extremes are developed. The impact of Fe content on this alloy’s structure and performance are quantified in both the as-deposited and hot isostatically pressed (HIP) conditions.

154.prez_name: Improved Parameters for Hot Isostatic Pressing of Ti-6Al-4V Additively Manufactured by Electron Beam Melting
154.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
154.prez_abstract: It is known that hot isostatic pressing (HIP) closes microporosity and improves the fatigue performance of AM Ti-6Al-4V. The ASTM standards F2924 and F3001 define the following HIP parameters: Argon pressure >100 MPa, temperature 895-955°C and time 2-4 hours. These parameters originate from experience with Ti-6Al-4V castings and PM material, and few attempts have been made to optimize HIP parameters for AM material.In this work, we have tested HIP parameters for Ti-6Al-4V made by Electron Beam Melting (EBM). Test specimens were built with intentional porosity and investigated before and after HIP. Full densification was observed at HIP temperatures as low as 800°C, with improved retainment of the fine microstructure and the high tensile strength observed in as-built Ti-6Al-4V material. This is attributed to the EBM vacuum environment. In contrast to AM processes operating at atmospheric pressure, porosity created under vacuum will not contain gas, resulting in better HIP efficiency.

155.prez_name: Influence of Directed Energy Deposition Parameters on the Geometry, Distortion, Porosity, and Microstructure of Ti-6Al-4V
155.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance

156.prez_name: Influence of Grain Structure on the Mechanical Properties of Electron Beam Melted Inconel 718
156.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
156.prez_authors: Michael M. Kirka, Kinga  Unocic, Alfred  Okello, Ryan  Dehoff, Ralph  Dinwiddie, Yousub  Lee, Naren  Raghavan
156.prez_abstract: Electron beam melting (EBM) represents one of the many maturing additive manufacturing technologies for fabrication of advanced high temperature turbine components. EBM is unique from the standpoint that the heat source can be transitioned between a point, line, and area heat source in a near instantaneous manner to promote the formation of equiax grains over columnar ones and control grain size. The power of this ability is to be able to dictate the local grain structure within EBM derived components. However, little information exists on the mechanical performance (tensile, creep, and fatigue) of EBM Inconel 718 comprised of a columnar grain structure let alone an equiax one. To be discussed are the microstructure property relationships and associated effects of mircostructure (columnar/equiax) upon the tensile, creep, and low cycle fatigue behavior of Inconel 718 manufactured through EBM.

157.prez_name: Influence of Powder Characteristics on the Structural Integrity of High Purity Tungsten Produced via Selective Laser Melting
157.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
157.prez_authors: Amanda C Field, Luke N Carter, Nicholas J. E. Adkins, M  Gorley, Moataz M Attallah
157.prez_abstract: Tungsten is a candidate material for nuclear fusion applications given the high operating temperatures (2000 oC) required. Conventionally, only solid-state forming techniques have been possible. Selective Laser Melting (SLM) offers a potential processing route for the net-shape manufacturing of the material, allowing greater flexibility in alloying and component geometries. Powder characterisation, to determine size, composition and impurity levels, was carried out on two powders with spherical and faceted morphology. Both powders were SLM processed using similar parameters range, and were were then analysed to determine the prevalence of defects and to investigate the effect of powder characteristics on the oxygen pick-up of samples during processing. The influence of the powder morphology on the laser-material interaction was further analysed.

158.prez_name: Investigation of the Solidification Effects of Microstructures of Laser Melted Stainless Steel
158.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
158.prez_authors: Emre Firat Özel, Hadi  Mozaffari-Jovein, Class  Müller
158.prez_abstract:
Currently, stainless steel is one of the most used metallic materials in selective laser melting process (SLM). For a better understanding of the microstructures formation during the solidification process, interaction at the solid/liquid interface of melting pool requires further research.
This work focuses on the thermodynamic properties of laser melted stainless steel samples. The diffusion processes which occur specifically during solidification of a single melting point can have a significant influence in the formation of inhomogeneous microstructures in the sample. At the interface between solid and liquid phases, the constitutional undercooling effect can be observed, possibly resulting in the formation of dendritic solid structures and local shifts of alloying composition. The uneven solidification of the liquid phase can lead to inhomogeneous residual stress distribution.

159.prez_name: Laser Additive Manufacturing Processing of a Mixture of Iron and Nickel Powders
159.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
159.prez_abstract: Laser-based powder bed additive manufacturing of metal powders uses pre-alloyed powder. This limits the alloys available for processing. Following the methodology used in traditional powder metallurgy (PM) processes such as press and sinter and MIM (Metal Injection Molding), which can use elemental powder mixtures to produce a wide variety of alloy compositions, this study tests the ability of laser AM to produce a homogeneous alloy from a mixture of powders.

160.prez_name: Laser Additive Processing of Magnetic Alloys from Elemental Blends
160.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
160.prez_authors: Calvin Vijay Mikler, Tushar  Borkar, Srinivas  Mantri, Varun  Chaudhury, Rodrigo  Contieri, Chen  Xi, Raju  Ramanujan, Rajarshi   Banerjee
160.prez_abstract: While there have been a substantial amount of activities on additive manufacturing (AM) of structural alloys, there have been rather limited efforts on AM of functional alloys, such as magnetic materials. The present study will focus on preliminary investigations on laser additive processing of magnetic alloys using the laser engineered shaping (LENS) process from a feedstock consisting of a blend of elemental powders. Soft and semi-hard magnetic alloys of different types have been processed using LENS. These include those of the permalloy type, based on Ni-Fe-V and Ni-Fe-Mo compositions, as well as compositions based on Finemet, Fe73.5Si13.5B9Nb3Cu1, as well as magneto-caloric compositions based on Fe-Mn-Ni. The scale of this microstructure in these LENS processed alloys can be varied via the laser deposition parameters and this, in turn, influences coercivity (Hc) and saturation magnetization (Ms) of these laser-deposited magnetic alloys. This work shows the feasibility of AM processing of magnetic materials.

161.prez_name: Low-cost Spherical Ti Alloy Powders for Additive Manufacturing
161.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
161.prez_authors: Pei  Sun, Z. Zak  Fang, Yang  Xia, Ying  Zhang, Chengshang   Zhou
161.prez_abstract: A novel method is developed to produce spherical Ti alloy powders for advanced near-net-shape manufacturing processes including additive manufacturing (AM). The new process synergistically integrates a few common low-cost steps including granulation, sintering, and deoxygenation to produce spherical Ti alloy powders without relying on costly melting and atomizing techniques. This granulation-sintering-deoxygenation (GSD) process uses low-cost source materials, such as hydrogenated Ti sponge and Ti scrap as raw materials. The spherical Ti-6Al-4V powder produced by the GSD method has controlled particle size distribution and low oxygen content (<0.15%), which meets physical and chemical requirements for AM applications. The GSD method is also applicable for producing other spherical Ti alloy powders or other metal alloy powders at a fraction of the cost of equivalent powders that are available today.

162.prez_name: Manufacturing of W-band Vacuum Electronic Devices with Electron Beam Melting
162.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
162.prez_authors: John Christopher Ledford, Harvey  West, Timothy  Horn
162.prez_abstract: As the need for higher power and more efficient RF sources grows, so does the need for technologies to create low cost, advanced millimeter wave electronics without sacrificing quality or performance. Recently, direct metal additive manufacturing has been projected to fabricate complex, high power, radio frequency (RF) components.  Compared to other, existing additive manufacturing processes, EBM is ideal for OFHC Cu due to the relatively high vacuum conditions to maintain purity, high ambient temperature to eliminate thermally induced stresses, and the high efficiency of EB over laser based technologies. However, the EBM process is typically associated with lower resolutions and higher surface roughness. This suggests that further research may be able to reduce surface roughness by utilizing a smaller powder size fraction and layer thickness while retaining the necessary benefits of EBM, advancing results previously demonstrated at CAMAL for fully dense, high purity OFHC copper components in RF applications.

163.prez_name: Materials Based Spatio-temporal Decoupling for the Prediction of Non-linear Thermomechanical Phenomenon in Metal Additive Manufacturing Processes
163.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
163.prez_authors: Deepankar  Pal, Sally  Xu, Samuel   Dilip Jangam, Chong   Teng, Brent  Stucker
163.prez_abstract: Many commercial simulation tools can predict aspects of the thermo-mechanical evolution in metal melting based Additive Manufacturing processes, but they generally assume the coupling between the microstructure and process evolutions expressed as constant handbook values or not taken into account at all. In this study, a systematic step-by-step development of a continuum level process model was carried out with fully coupled microstructure and macrostructural evolutions followed by spatio-temporal decoupling to efficiently and accurately predict the thermo-mechanical phenomenon.  The thermal field, grain morphology, phase and defect evolution for an AM grade Cobalt-Chromium-Molybdenum-Carbon (CoCrMoC) based alloy has been demonstrated using this model. Various aspects of the formulation and validations along with an extension of the current results towards solving the obstacles such as inability to fabricate flawless parts and unreliable mechanical property evolutions for mainstream adoption of metals based AM will be also discussed.

164.prez_name: Mechanical Properties and Microstructural Evaluation of Direct Metal Laser Sintered Inconel 625
164.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
164.prez_authors: Michael  Brand, Don  Bucholz, Cameron   Knapp, John   Carpenter, TD  Burleigh
164.prez_abstract: Inconel 625 samples, fabricated via Powder Bed Fusion (PBF), will be compared with conventionally cast and wrought samples. Tensile and hardness testing comparisons were made in the as-deposited PBF condition and after heat treatments typically used for wrought Inconel 625. Stress relieving and solutionizing heat treatments were used to promote solid solution strengthening and precipitation hardening for the as-processed PBF, cast, and wrought specimens. Optical microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and energy dispersive spectroscopy were used to quantify the distribution, size and morphology of precipitates in Inconel 625 for PBF, cast, and wrought specimens. Despite the processing differences, all specimens exhibited similar distributions, sizes and morphologies of precipitates. The PBF (both prior to and after heat treatment) samples exhibited higher strength and toughness than cast and wrought counterparts.

165.prez_name: Mechanical Properties of Hastelloy X Fabricated by Electron Beam Melting
165.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
165.prez_authors: Sebastien  Dryepondt, Mike  Kirka, Ryan  Dehoff
165.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing allows for the fabrication of complex near net shape components, and could change drastically parts production in numerous industries. Powder melting results, however, in specific microstructures and material defects that can affect the component mechanical properties. Alloy Hastelloy X (HX, Ni-22Cr-18Fe-9Mo) was fabricated by electron beam melting and tensile, creep and fatigue testing were conducted on the as-fabricated material. The grain microstructure was elongated along the build direction, and most of the grain boundaries were decorated with large (Mo, Si)-rich carbides.  Small voids and sub-micron precipitates were observed in the grains. The tensile strength was above the cast HX minimum requirement in the 20-816ºC temperature range, and excellent ductility was measured at all temperatures. Outstanding fatigue performance was observed at 427ºC, but the creep lifetime at 816ºC was quite low. Finally, the effect of powder quality and post heat treatment will be discussed.

166.prez_name: Mechanical Properties of IN738LC Processed by Direct Metal Laser Melting (DMLM)
166.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
166.prez_authors: Thomas  Etter, Fabian  Geiger, Felix  Roerig
166.prez_abstract: Direct Metal Laser Melting (DMLM) is an additive manufacturing technology used to produce metallic parts from thin powder layers. So far, limited knowledge exists with respect to the DMLM-processing of γ’ precipitation-strengthened Ni-base superalloys, as widely used in industrial gas turbines. In this work, tensile test specimens of the Ni-base alloy IN738LC were tested at room temperature and 850°C with the loading direction oriented parallel (z-specimens) and perpendicular to the building direction (xy-specimens). In order to reduce crystallographic anisotropy and eliminate metallurgical defects observed in the “as-built” condition, specimens were recrystallized, hot isostatic pressed, and exposed to a two-step precipitation heat treatment. DMLM-manufactured and heat-treated IN738LC specimens have comparable or even better tensile mechanical properties compared to cast ones. Furthermore, the recrystallization heat treatment improves the relaxation behaviour and creep properties are comparable to cast samples. The characterisation of microstructural anisotropy was done by Electron Back Scatter Diffraction (EBSD) analysis.

167.prez_name: Mechanical Properties of Selective Laser Melted Al-12Si Alloy
167.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
167.prez_authors: Jyoti Balaji Suryawanshi, K. G.  Prashanth, J.  Eckert, U.  Ramamurty
167.prez_abstract: Selective laser melting (SLM) is a layered additive manufacturing process (3D printing technique) consisting of direct fabrication of functional parts by successive melting of powder layers by means of high-energy laser beam. It offers many advantages vis-à-vis conventional cast route, like ability to produce near net shape component and variety of material with almost full density, geometrical freedom, mass customization, etc. However, it imparts unique macro- and micro-structures to the processed components, whose influence on the mechanical properties require detailed investigation, which is attempted in this study with particular emphasis on fatigue and fracture characteristics. Experimental results obtained on a SLM produced Al-12Si (wt.%) alloy will be presented in this paper, which will be utilized to discuss design strategies for optimally processed SLM components.

168.prez_name: Microstructural and Surface Defects Found in Additive Manufactured Titanium Components
168.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
168.prez_authors: Julius  Bonini, Joan  Morra, Kaitlyn Calaluca Mazza
168.prez_abstract: The Additive Manufacture (AM) of Ti-6-4 and Ti-6-4 ELI components presents significant challenges to the medical implant and aerospace industries.  These unique manufacturing methods involving the electron beam and laser melting of titanium can produce a range of unusual microstructures.  In addition, AM may produce a number of solidification anomalies related to the starting powder material, the melting process itself, and post processing heat treatments such as HIPing.  Microstructural characterization has been performed on both as-fabricated and HIP’ed AM Ti-6-4 ELI material.  Microstructural and surface anomalies will be presented related to prior-beta grain structure, stabilized alpha regions, porosity, powder precondition, disbond regions, and possible micro alloy segregation.  Optical micrographs, Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) images, Electron Backscatter Diffraction (EBSD) analysis, and element maps generated from both X-ray Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) analysis and Dynamic Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (DSIMS) will be presented.

169.prez_name: Microstructural Characterization of As-Manufactured and Heat Treated Electron Beam Melted Inconel 718
169.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
169.prez_authors: Dunyong  Deng, Jonas  Saarimäki, Hans  Söderberg, Ru  Lin Peng, Håkan  Brodin, Johan J. Moverare
169.prez_abstract: As manufactured and heat treated electron beam melted Inconel 718 exhibit inhomogeneous grain morphologies, mainly equiaxed close to the surface and more elongated columnar grains in the bulk. Different processing settings i.e., contouring in the surface region and hatching in the bulk region are responsible for differences in grain morphologies and textures, which are characterized using the SEM techniques electron contrast channeling imagine (ECCI) and electron backscattering diffraction (EBSD). Niobium carbides prefer to nucleate at TiN and are found to be in the grain growth direction. Regarding processing conditions, defects, such as porosities and segregations are discussed, as well as differences in microstructure emphasizing on grain morphologies and precipitates with regards to heat treatment and hardness indentation.

170.prez_name: Microstructural Characterization of ExOne-printed and Liquid Phase Sintered Stainless Steel
170.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
170.prez_abstract: Binder-based additive manufacturing of 316 stainless steel allows for the rapid prototyping of complex parts for which traditional methods of production would be prohibitive due to cost, lead time, or complexity. Current AM techniques struggle to achieve full density while preserving net shape during sintering. The addition of boron has been shown to assist in PM-part densification through the promotion of liquid phase sintering. However, the effects of boron and alloying elements on the secondary phases of additively manufactured 316SS, which does not undergo the compression typical of conventional PM, have not been fully investigated. In this study, various chemistries of SS 316 were printed using an ExOne binder jet printer, sintered, and analyzed.  A combination of nanoindentation, TEM, and SEM-EBSD characterization has been applied to analyze the role of boron in the microstructural evolution during sintering, and how this affects mechanical stability of printed parts.

171.prez_name: Microstructural Evolution and Defect Control in 316L SS Components Fabricated via Laser Additive Manufacturing
171.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
171.prez_authors: Baolong  Zheng, James C. Haley, Nancy  Y.C. Yang, Joshua  K. Yee, Yizhang  Zhou, Enrique   J. Lavernia, Julie   Schoenung
171.prez_abstract: The influence of processing parameters on microstructure, defects, and mechanical properties in 316L stainless steel (SS) components, fabricated using laser engineering net shaping (LENS<SUP>®</SUP>), a powder injection based additive manufacturing (AM) technique, were investigated.  The microstructure developed in the fabricated 316L SS components is complex and dominated by rapid solidification behavior of the molten-pool.  A columnar grain structure due to epitaxial growth from the prior solid interface was observed within each layer.  Observed defects included un-melted powder particles and porosity that resulted from lack-of-fusion and entrapped gas.   Both microstructure and defects were tailored and controlled by optimizing processing parameters to improve the mechanical properties of deposited 316L SS.  SEM/EDS, TEM, and X-ray computed tomography were used to visualize internal inclusions and pores.  The microstructure, defects, as well as the related thermal behavior during AM processing are discussed to provide insight into fundamental phenomena in the powder injection based AM processes.

172.prez_name: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of WC-Co/FeCoNi Manufactured by Selective Laser Sintering
172.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
172.prez_authors: Chi  Peng Chiang, An-Chou   Yeh, Su-Jien   Lin, Jien-Wei   Yeh, Che-Wei   Tsai
172.prez_abstract: Tungsten carbides are widely used as cutting, drilling and machining tools, due to their excellent mechanical properties, such as high hardness and strength, good fracture toughness and great wear resistance over a wide range of temperatures. In this study, not only Co is used as the main binder, Fe-Co-Ni multi-element alloy is also considered as a new binder because Co has several disadvantages, including its high cost, low corrosion resistance and environmental toxicity. Selective laser sintering(SLS) is a rapid prototyping process with flexibility to produce complex 3D objects. The recent research presents preliminary results on the microstructure, hardness, fracture toughness and abrasive wear resistance of the SLS specimens. This study aims to optimize the above mechanical properties through utilizing different powder size, binder contents and SLS parameters.

173.prez_name: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of WC/Co Hardmetal Fabricated by SLM 3D Printing with Spray Granulated Powders
173.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
173.prez_authors: Chao-Jung  Chen, Che-Wei   Tsai, An-Chou   Yeh, Su-Jien  Lin, Jien-Wei   Yeh
173.prez_abstract: WC/Co hard metals are widely used as the primary material for making cutting tools, drills and molds. In this research, WC/Co powder was processed through spray granulation after milling. The granulated particles are spherical and exhibit suitable carr index for powder-bed 3D printing process. By optimizing the laser scanning parameters, bulk samples fabricated by laser 3D printing can exhibit high density, high hardness, good toughness, and wear resistance.

174.prez_name: Microstructure Characterization and Monotonic Properties of Inconel 718 Manufactured Through Electron Beam Melting in the As-built and Post-processed States
174.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
174.prez_authors: Michael M. Kirka, Kinga  Unocic, Ryan  Dehoff, Suresh  Babu, Alfred  Okello
174.prez_abstract: Electron beam melting (EBM) is a powder bed additive manufacturing process that is becoming increasingly more utilized as a means for manufacturing high value, high temperature components for gas turbine engines. During the EBM process, the nickel-base (Ni-base) superalloy Inconel 718 is processed at temperatures in excess of 900°C. Due to this thermal exposure during the build process, as-built Inconel 718 exhibits spatially dependent microstructures. Further, due to Inconel 718 being a precipitate strengthened Ni-base superalloy, the monotonic properties exhibit a high sensitivity to microstructure. To be presented is a characterization of the spatially dependent as-built microstructure in relation to tensile behavior at room temperature and 650C. Additionally, the ability to homogenize the spatially dependent microstructure through post-processing (hot isostatic pressing and heat-treatment) and the resultant effects on the tensile behavior at 20 and 650C will be discussed.

175.prez_name: Microstructure Control in Additive Manufacturing of Aluminum Alloys
175.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
175.prez_authors: Hunter  Martin, Brennan  Yahata, Eric  Clough, Jacob  Hundley, Tobias   Schaedler, Tresa  Pollock
175.prez_abstract: Additive Manufacturing of aluminum alloys has been limited to a select group of weldable Al-Si alloys, however many applications require materials with significantly higher strength.  Standard high strength aluminum alloys, 2000 and 7000 series, suffer from hot tearing during solidification making them unsuitable for processing in additive manufacturing.  We have developed modeling techniques to identify alloys susceptible to hot tearing and mechanisms to reduce this tendency in the unique solidification conditions during direct laser melting.  By modifying material feedstock and controlling processing parameters, the hot tear susceptibility can be reduced. In addition, the microstructure and mechanical properties of additively manufactured aluminum alloys can be optimized. Through simulations, the optimum solidification path can be identified and parameters are tailored to control solidification of the melt pool accordingly.  We will show that application of this process can be used to enable additive manufacturing of new high strength aluminum alloy systems.

176.prez_name: Microstructure Evolution, Tensile Properties, and Fatigue Crack Growth Mechanisms in Ti-6Al-4V Fabricated by Electron Beam Melting
176.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
176.prez_authors: Yuwei  Zhai, Haize  Galarraga, Diana  Lados, Ryan R Dehoff, Michael  M.  Kirka, Peeyush   Nandwana
176.prez_abstract: Electron Beam Melting (EBM) is an additive manufacturing technique that selectively fuses powder particles on a powder bed using electron beam as a power source. The unique thermal history of EBM process leads to directional microstructure and consequently, anisotropy in mechanical properties. In this study, Ti-6Al-4V fabricated by EBM was systematically investigated. As-fabricated microstructure was first characterized, and altered through various heat treatments. Room temperature tensile and fatigue crack growth (FCG) properties were then evaluated and compared in different orientations with respect to the deposition direction. The effects of heat treatment on the tensile and FCG properties of the material were determined. Fatigue crack growth mechanisms at the microstructural scale were also established. These results will be systematically presented.

177.prez_name: Microstructure Informatics Cloud Computing for Data Analytics of Titanium Additive Manufacturing
177.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
177.prez_authors: Ayman A. Salem, Daniel  Satko, Joshua  Shaffer, Richard  Kublik, Mohsen   Seifi, John   Lewandowski
177.prez_abstract:
Enabling manufacturers and designers to efficiently use parts made by additive manufacturing (AM) of titanium alloys (e.g Ti-6Al-4V and 𝛾-TiAl) requires quantification and prediction of location-specific mechanical performance, which is directly related to location and orientation specific microstructure. The spatial variability of microstructure constituents due to the inherent variability in AM processing parameters requires the use of microstructure recording and quantification methods that account for spatial distribution and correlation of microstructure features.  
This talk will summarize the use of higher order statistics to quantify microstructure constituents of Ti-6Al-4V and 𝛾-TiAl produced by powder-bed-fusion (PBF). In addition, techniques for recording large area microstructure data using electron microscopy will be discussed. The results of data analysis methods for calculating higher temperature beta orientations from room temperature alpha orientations will be discussed for Ti-6Al-4V. The implementation of various techniques via cloud computing (MiCloud.AM) will be demonstrated.

178.prez_name: Microstructure of Additively Manufactured 304L and 316L Stainless Steel Materials and Powder Feedstock
178.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
178.prez_authors: Benjamin M. Morrow, Veronica  Livescu, Cameron M. Knapp, John S. Carpenter, George T. Gray
178.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing is a powerful technique capable of producing near net shape parts in complex geometries. Recent work in both 304L and 316L stainless steel has shown that in addition to the unique, characteristic microstructures formed during the process, a fine dispersion of sub-micron particles are evident in the final microstructure. These particles are believed to have an effect on the subsequent mechanical behavior during deformation of AM parts. Such fine-scale features can only be resolved using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) or similar techniques. The present work uses electron microscopy to study both the initial powder feedstock and final AM parts. Special attention is paid to the chemistry and origin of these nanoscale particles in several different metal alloys, and their impact on the final build. Comparisons to traditional, wrought material will be made.

179.prez_name: Microstructures of Low-C and Medium-C Steel Powders Additively Deposited on Cast Iron Using Directed Energy Deposition (DED) Technique
179.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
179.prez_authors: Seulbi  Lee, Yoon Suk  Choi, Jae Hyun  Yu, Sang Hu  Park, Do-Sik  Shim, Dae-Geun  Nam
179.prez_abstract: Multi-layers of low-C steel (AISI P21) and medium-C steel (AISI H13) powders were additively deposited on cast iron using a directed energy deposition (DED) technique. In order to understand the microstructure evolution during the multi-layer DED process, the layer-by-layer microstructural change and chemistry variation were investigated using an electron microscopy and an electron probe micro-analyzer (EPMA). In particular, the microstructure variation across the interface was intensively analyzed to understand the deposition mechanism of laser-heated low or medium C steel powders on a (high C) cast iron substrate, in which a conventional welding technique is not applicable for joining or part-repairing. Thermodynamic calculations were also utilized to understand the through-thickness microstructural change caused by the chemistry variation and heat cycles during the DED process. Experimental results will be discussed along with some suggestions to better control interfacial microstructures and properties.

180.prez_name: Microstructure, Tensile Properties, and Fatigue Crack Growth Behavior in Inconel 718 Manufactured by Laser Engineered Net Shaping
180.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
180.prez_abstract: Laser Engineered Net Shaping (LENS) is a selective deposition based Additive Manufacturing technique developed for fabricating metallic materials. Applying LENS to critical fields such as aerospace, defense and medical requires thorough understanding of the LENS fabricated materials. In this study, Inconel 718 builds were fabricated at two laser power levels, and were investigated in both as-fabricated and heat treated conditions. The effects of processing parameters and heat treatment on microstructure and room temperature tensile properties were systematically studied. Room temperature fatigue crack growth (FCG) tests were also performed to investigate the FCG behavior, as well as to establish the crack propagation mechanisms at the microstructural scale in this alloy. The results generated contributes towards a better understanding of the processing – microstructure – mechanical properties relationship in LENS fabricated Inconel 718.

181.prez_name: Multiple Testing Techniques and Multiple Conclusions in AM Metals
181.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
181.prez_authors: Jay D. Carroll, Jeffrey M Rodelas, Lisa A Deibler, Bradley H Jared, Brad L Boyce, Bradley  Salzbrenner, John  Laing, Thomas  Crenshaw, David P Adams, Benjamin  Reedlunn, Bo  Song, Jack L Wise, Joseph E Bishop, Michael C Maguire
181.prez_abstract:
As additive manufacturing gains widespread popularity for use in structural applications, the impact of variability in material properties will increase. There are a number of testing techniques used to characterize different and often related material properties that are associated with strength and ductility. Some considered for this work are tension dogbones, fracture toughness specimens, Charpy impact specimens, and hardness measurements. Each of these tests provides a different measure of strength, each with its own variability and sensitivity to microstructural features. In this talk, we will examine test results from these multiple techniques on additive manufactured 304L stainless steel and aluminum alloy AlSi10Mg. We will also discuss the implications of the variability observed in each technique.

Sandia National Laboratories is a multi-program laboratory managed and operated by Sandia Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Lockheed Martin Corporation, for the U.S. Department of Energy’s National Nuclear Security Administration under contract DE-AC04-94AL85000.

182.prez_name: NiCr-Alloy Powder Reuse and Testing Results in Additive Manufacturing
182.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
182.prez_authors: Larry  Somrack, Melissa  Gorris, William  Jarosinski
182.prez_abstract:
In order to obtain the material savings associated with utilizing the powder bed process for additive manufacturing (AM), it is important to understand and optimize the number of times powder can be reused to understand the relationship between reuse and properties.

The results of the ongoing research will discuss the critical characteristics of the powder and the effects of the microstructure and mechanical properties of the printed parts that are compared to the function of the number of times the powder has been used to build metallic alloy parts.

These findings are an important step as standards are being developed by ASTM, AMS, and ISO to specify the physical and chemical characteristics for this powder material in the building of quality production parts for industry.

183.prez_name: On the Effect of Metal Powder Recyclability for Build Quality and Process Optimization in SLM 3D Printing
183.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
183.prez_authors: Vicki A Barbur, Juan J Valencia, Kenneth M Sabo
183.prez_abstract: Most 3D printing technologies rely on the use of a newly deposited layer of ‘virgin’ metal powder for each successive build, leading potentially to an expensive waste stream, thus costly printed parts. This approach is used to maintain consistency, reliability and integrity in output part performance. We will discuss an investigation into the recycling of the discarded metal powder stream, its impact on the overall quality of parts and the subsequent contribution to process optimization. We will discuss results directly for Inconel 625 in relation to the use of an SLM machine, and outline the resulting impact on quality characteristics of not only the powder stream due to several iterative recycles, but also the influence of the recycled powder stream on part build performance features and appearance. In conclusion, we will provide a recommendation for managing powder recyclability in order to preserve the integrity of a 3D printed part.

184.prez_name: On the Limitations of Volumetric Energy Density as a Key Parameter to Describe Selective Laser Melting of 316L Stainless Steel
184.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
184.prez_authors: Umberto  Scipioni Bertoli, Alexander  Wolfer, Manyalibo  Matthews, Andrew  Anderson, Rose  McCallen, Kevin  Wheeler, Dogan  Timucin, Enrique J Lavernia, Jean-Pierre  Delplanque, Julie  Schoenung
184.prez_abstract: Energy density is often used as a metric to compare parts manufactured with Selective Laser Melting (SLM) under different sets of deposition parameters (e.g. laser power, scan speed, layer thickness, etc). We present a brief review of the current literature on additive manufacturing of 316L stainless steel. From other authors we identified a range of Volumetric Energy Density (VED) able to lead to successful deposition. In order to corroborate this data, we designed a series of experiments to investigate the reliability of VED by comparing single tracks deposited varying multiple parameters. We found that, outside of a narrow band of applicability, VED fails to predict correct deposition conditions and therefore cannot be used as the only metric for determination of a process window.

185.prez_name: On the Role of Microstructure on the Fatigue Performance of Additively Manufactured Components
185.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
185.prez_authors: Thomas  Niendorf, Stefan  Leuders, Andre  Riemer, Johannes  Guenther, Florian  Brenne
185.prez_abstract: Components designed for additive manufacturing (AM) will have to withstand cyclic loadings in numerous applications, e.g. brackets employed in aerospace industry. In order to be able to predict the fatigue performance and durability of such components, the role of microstructural features imposed by AM on crack initiation and crack growth has to be fully understood. Not only residual porosity but also grain morphology, embrittlement, residual stresses and surface treatment proved to be highly influential.In order to reveal the impact of those features on the fatigue properties of components manufactured by powder bed techniques, i.e. laser melting and electron-beam melting, fatigue experiments have been conducted in the low-cycle to very high-cycle fatigue regimes and under crack growth conditions. Materials under consideration were Ti-6Al-4V, stainless steel and Ni-base alloys. Microstructure analyses employing electron backscatter diffraction and post-mortem analyses of crack surfaces allowed for establishing solid process-structure-property relationships.

186.prez_name: Open Material Database for Additive Manufacturing (AM)
186.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
186.prez_authors: Yan  Lu, Paul  Witherell, Alkan  Donmez
186.prez_abstract: As additive manufacturing (AM) continues to mature as a production technology, the limiting factors that have hindered its adoption in the past continue to evolve.  Overcoming these hurdles requires further understanding of geometry-material-process–structure-property relationships for AM materials. Empirical approaches that seek to harness data have proven to be effective in identifying material process-structure-property relationships.  In this paper we will present a proof-of-concept implementation of an open Additive Manufacturing Materials Database (AMMD) developed at NIST. This database is built using the NIST Material Data Curation System as a backend with structure provided by NIST’s AM schema. Providing a collaboration platform, the database will evolve through the open data access and material data sharing among the AM community.  As data sets continue to accumulate, it becomes possible to establish new correlations between processes, materials, and parts. The functionality of the AMMD is demonstrated through the curation and querying of several AM datasets.

187.prez_name: Partitioning of Laser Energy during Directed Energy Deposition
187.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
187.prez_authors: Frederick  Lia, Joshua  Z Park, Jay  F Tressler, Richard  P Martukanitz
187.prez_abstract: An energy balance equation that describes the transfer of energy is proposed and experimentally validated for a laser-based directed energy deposition process.  The partitioning of the laser energy was experimentally validated and accurately measured through special substrate calorimetry measurements for Ti-6Al-4V and Inconel 625.  The total energy provided by the laser was evaluated as; the energy directly absorbed by the substrate, the energy absorbed by the powder stream and deposited onto the substrate, the energy reflected from the substrate surface, and the energy reflected or scattered from the powder stream.  Processing with powder had lower absorption coefficient than without powder, due to the “shadowing” effect of the powder stream within the beam.  At the same powder flow rate, the absorption coefficient of deposited Ti-6Al-4V powder decreased 30% as the laser energy increased 93%.  The energy lost due to powder stream was estimated during laser additive manufacture technique.

188.prez_name: Phase Field Modeling of Solidification Microstructure during Laser Sintering of Inconel 625
188.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
188.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing via direct metal laser sintering (DMLS) is a relatively recent technology in which metallic parts are produced in a layer by layer fashion by melting (or sintering) and fusing the metallic powders. The microstructure evolution in this process primarily depends on the melt pool characteristics as well as the processing conditions. In order to study this, we employ a phase field model for directional solidification of a dilute binary alloy approximating Inconel 625. The effects of melt pool convection is incorporated in the present work and is expected to be significant in this process. The resulting morphologies may range from columnar-dendritic to equiaxed depending on the solidification parameters, notably temperature gradient and the solidification velocity. Precipitation and coarsening effects during this process are also considered which can influence the properties of the metallic product. Finally, we compare our results with analytical predictions as well as with experimental findings.

189.prez_name: Post Processing of Electron Beam Fabricated Ti-6Al-4V via Hot Isostatic Pressing
189.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
189.prez_authors: Peeyush  Nandwana, William H Peter, Ryan R Dehoff, Anders  Eklund, Magnus  Ahlfors, Sudarsanam S Babu
189.prez_abstract: Electron beam melting is a powder bed additive manufacturing technique that allows for fabrication of complex geometries from CAD files. The fabricated parts have a columnar grain structure. In case of titanium alloys like Ti-6Al-4V, the properties are governed by the size, distribution and texture of α phase that nucleates from β phase at lower temperatures. In the current work, it was found that EBM fabricated Ti-6Al-4V parts subjected to fatigue tests have a higher endurance limit in the direction perpendicular to build direction. The cracks initiated from pores, thus highlighting the need for Hot Isostatic Pressing.  The parts were subjected to HIP treatments at 1120 0C for 2 hours at a pressure of 100 MPa. It was observed that holding the parts above the β-transus, resulted in transformation of β grains from columnar to equiaxed morphology and resulted in a homogenous microstructure. Significant change in α-texture was observed.

190.prez_name: Predictive Modeling of Grain Growth in Laser-based Additive Manufacturing of Austenitic Stainless Steel
190.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
190.prez_abstract: In this work a multi-scale model is developed for in laser-based additive manufacturing processes of Austenitic stainless steel. A macro-scale model is used to predict the fluid flow and heat transfer in the printed geometry, and a micro-scale model based on the Cellular Automata method is used to predict the grain growth during the solidification of molten pool. The effects of laser power and scanning speed on the grain growth will be studied, and moreover, the effect of the line-by-line and layer-by-layer scanning strategy in additive manufacturing on the grain growth will be investigated.

191.prez_name: Process-structure-property Relationships for Selective Laser Melted 17-4 PH Stainless Steel
191.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
191.prez_authors: Aref  Yadollahi, Mohammad  Masoomi, Scott M Thompson, Nima  Shamsaei
191.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) offers the ability to fabricate complex, metallic objects via a layer-wise production process. Quantifying the fatigue performance of manufactured parts is critical for ensuring their reliability in the field.  In this study, the effects of thermal response on the microstructure and fatigue behavior of 17-4 precipitation hardening (PH) stainless steel (SS), fabricated via Selective Laser Melting (SLM), is investigated. A three dimensional, continuum-scale finite element model and high performance computing are utilized for predicting the entire thermal history of fabricated parts. Two sets of rods were made via SLM and their build orientation was varied between horizontal and vertical.  The cooling rate was found to be lower for vertical samples as compared to horizontal ones, resulting in a higher percentage of austenite in horizontal samples. Finally, effects of different microstructures on fatigue and behavior were investigated.

192.prez_name: Process-structure-property Relationships in 304L Stainless Steel Produced by Directed Energy Deposition: Experimental Characterization and Modeling
192.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
192.prez_authors: Zhuqing  Wang, Todd  Palmer, Allison  Beese
192.prez_abstract: To study the effect of processing parameters on the microstructure and mechanical properties of additively manufactured materials, two stainless steel 304L walls were fabricated by directed energy deposition (DED) using different linear heat inputs. The yield strength, tensile strength, and ductility, as a function of location, direction, and heat input, were measured by uniaxial tension tests. The grain size and morphology as a function of location and processing conditions were determined using optical microscope and electron backscatter diffraction . A model developed to describe grain growth in welding was used to interpret experimental data and quantitatively correlate grain size with heat input and location within the walls. The Hall-Petch relationship was applied to demonstrate the effect of grain size and morphology on yield strength within the walls. This work describes an approach to determine the quantitative relationship between processing, microstructure, and mechanical properties in stainless steel 304L deposited by DED.

193.prez_name: Properties of 316L Austenitic Stainless Steel Additively Manufactured Using Laser Metal Deposition Method
193.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
193.prez_authors: Kosuke  Sasaki, Tomokazu  Sano, Akio  Hirose, Go  Obara, Takashi  Obara, Naotada  Okada, Miki  Mori
193.prez_abstract: Aiming to achieve a sound additively manufactured-structure of 316L stainless steel, effects of processing parameters such as laser power, scan speed, laser scanning direction and powder feed rate on microstructure, mechanical properties and corrosion were investigated. 316L stainless steel powders which were fed onto a 316L stainless steel substrate were melted by a CW laser beam with a wavelength of 1030 nm to form a three-dimensional structure. The mass density of the structure fabricated under an optimal condition was 99.31% of the theoretical density. The microstructural observations showed delta ferrite precipitated in austenite existed in the structure. Micro tensile tests of the structure resulted in the tensile strength along the laser scanning direction was 660 MPa, which was higher than the strength for other two perpendicular directions.

194.prez_name: Relationship between Porosity Size and Fatigue Life Distributions of AlSi10Mg Parts Produced by Selective Laser Melting
194.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
194.prez_abstract: The fatigue resistance of the metal parts produced by selective laser melting is dictated by the internal residual porosity. However, there seems to be limited studies on the characteristics of the pores inside the product and correlations between defect size and fatigue life. In this work, porosity inside the AlSi10Mg parts produced by selective laser melting was characterized and analyzed by three techniques: Archimedes method, 2D metallography and 3D x-ray tomographic study. In addition, pore size and its distribution on the fracture surface of samples after fatigue test were measured by SEM. Major characteristics of porosity include volume fraction, average size, size distribution, shape, aspect ratio, and distance to the sample surface. The results show that the maximum pore size on fracture surfaces is much larger than that on the metallographic planes. The correlation between largest possible pore size and fatigue life is established and good agreement is achieved.

195.prez_name: Reliability Estimation of Additive Manufacturing Process Parameters Using Surrogate Modeling
195.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
195.prez_authors: Azadeh  Keshtgar, Kelvin  Leung, Nagaraja  Iyyer
195.prez_abstract: The primary goal of this paper is to develop a probabilistic physics-based numerical prediction approach to characterize the propagation of uncertainties due to powder and process variabilities of Selective Laser Melting (SLM) into the performance of manufactured components. A heat transfer finite element (FE) model is implemented to predict temperature distribution in a multi-layer multi-track SLM process deterministically. Subsequently, uncertainties in the parameters such as layer thickness, laser power and scan speed are utilized to predict a range of temperature distribution by developing a probabilistic kriging-based surrogate meta-model. The probabilistic kriging approach presented here propagates the uncertainties of powder properties and SLM process parameters to manufactured component properties through the heat transfer FE model and assesses the reliability of the process.

196.prez_name: Residual Stress in Direct Metal Laser Sintered Steel powders
196.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
196.prez_authors: Elias  Jelis, Rajendra  Sadangi, Michael   Hespos, Nuggehalli  Ravindra
196.prez_abstract: Direct Metal Laser Sintering (DMLS) is a laser powder bed fusion process in which a laser consolidates metal powder incrementally. The material is subjected to complex time-dependent temperature profile with repeated solid state and liquid-solid phase transformations due to incremental melting.  Thus, process parameters need to be optimized for porosity, texture, and residual stress for alloy composition and part geometry. Residual stress can lead to shape distortions and in extreme cases, can lead to cracking. Shape distortions can result in uneven powder distribution during recoating process, altering melt pool characteristics and poor layer-to-layer bonding. Under extreme conditions, this can lead to formation of cracks and inferior tensile properties. In this paper, we will describe the influence of stripe width on DMLS of 4140 and 4340 steels. Distortion and surface residual stress will be evaluated and correlated to the structure and tensile properties.

197.prez_name: Role of Composition on the Microstructure and Texture Evolution of Additively Manufactured Beta-Ti Alloys
197.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
197.prez_authors: Srinivas Aditya  Mantri, Calvin  Mikler, Vishal  Soni, Deep  Choudhuri, Chris  Yannetta , Rajarshi  Banerjee
197.prez_abstract: Laser-assisted manufacturing processes like, laser engineered net shaping (LENS™), a near-net shape processing technology, are increasingly being used as additive manufacturing processes. The inherent flexibility of LENS™ is well suited for examining the evolution of microstructure and texture along the build direction as function of composition, i.e. combinatorial approach. With regard to titanium alloys, the use of LENS™ technology has been well established; but the evolution of microstructure and texture, and their consequent influence on properties has yet to be fully understood. Thus, model beta-stabilized alloys; Ti-Mo, Ti-V, Ti-Nb, were deposited using LENS™, and we examined the evolution of microstructure and micro-texture analysis along, as well as across the build length, using SEM, EBSD and TEM analyses. These results allowed us to probe the influence of alloy composition on both micro-structure and texture, and link those variables to the mechanical properties.

198.prez_name: Selective Laser Melting of Alloy IN625: Effect of Build orientation on Microstructures and Mechanical Properties
198.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
198.prez_authors: Ashabul Anam  Md, John Samuel Dilip  Jangam, Pal  Deepankar, Stucker  Brent
198.prez_abstract: In the present investigation, microstructural evolution and mechanical properties of alloy IN625 processed using selective laser melting (SLM) was investigated. Samples were fabricated in three orientations, namely horizontal, vertical and inclined (45°) w.r.t. the base plate using an EOS M270 machine. The as-built specimens were characterized using optical microscopy, SEM, EBSD, XRD and TEM. As-deposited microstructures exhibited columnar coarse γ grains which appear to have grown preferentially in the build direction. EBSD of the as-built samples showed a considerable amount of texture in the microstructures. Uniaxial tensile tests were carried out on specimens built in different orientations. The test results show variation in the mechanical properties where the principal stress orientations correlated strongly with the build orientation. Overall, the present study provides insight into how macroscopic anisotropy is formed in IN625 parts fabricated using SLM.

199.prez_name: Simulating Metal Additive Manufacturing Microstructures with Kinetic Monte Carlo
199.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
199.prez_authors: Theron  Rodgers, Jonathan D Madison, Veena  Tikare
199.prez_abstract:
Additive Manufacturing processes create structures with complex, non-uniform thermal histories. Resulting microstructures are often anisotropic and vary by location within a build. These microstructures are often difficult to predict with traditional solidification simulations or current synthetic microstructure generation tools. Here, a modified Potts Kinetic Monte Carlo model is presented which is shown to produce very reasonable computational surrogate microstructures for a wide variety of AM processing conditions and scan patterns. The method is capable of reproducing grain anisotropy and appropriate grain morphologies as a direct function of processing parameters. Results derived from traditional and advanced data science techniques for microstructural interrogation will also be presented.

Sandia National Laboratories is a multi-program laboratory managed and operated by Sandia Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Lockheed Martin Corporation, for the U.S. Department of Energy’s National Nuclear Security Administration under contract DE-AC04-94AL85000.

200.prez_name: Site Specific Texture Control In EBAM Process Using Numerical Modeling and Optimization Techniques Aided by High Performance Computing
200.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
200.prez_authors: Narendran  Raghavan, Ryan  Dehoff, John  Turner, Srdjan  Simunovic, Michael  Kirka, Neil  Carlson, Sudarsanam Suresh Babu
200.prez_abstract: Additive Manufacturing, widely known as 3D printing is the fabrication of functional 3D component from CAD model. Effect of solidification microstructure on the mechanical properties of the engineering components has been well understood. Columnar/epitaxial grain growth is a common phenomenon observed and rationalized in all additive manufacturing processes. Understanding the transient phenomena of repeated melting and solidification is vital to achieve site specific solidification microstructure control. For a given alloy composition, evolution of solidification microstructure during rapid solidification conditions is primarily determined by the temperature gradient (G) and velocity (R) at the liquid-solid interface. In this study, TRUCHAS code compatible of running in parallel is used to simulate the transient thermal model and understand the spatiotemporal variation of solidification parameters of G an R as a function of process parameters. The modeling results are validated by demonstrating the feasibility of columnar to equiaxed transition (CET) in electron beam additive manufacturing.

201.prez_name: Solidification Microstructure and Mechanical Properties Development due to Selective Laser Melting of AlSi10Mg Alloy
201.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
201.prez_authors: Moataz M Attallah, Michael H. Loretto, Noriko  Read, Uriel  Tradowsky, Wei  Wang, Jan  White
201.prez_abstract: This study investigates the microstructural development due to Selective Laser Melting of AlSi10Mg alloy focusing on the solidification structure, as well as the impact of post-process heat treatment on the microstructural and mechanical properties development. The builds generally show fine columnar microstructure, with a fine Si-enriched cellular dendritic network, resulting in tensile strengths superior to the castings in the as-fabricated conditions. Investigations using Transmission Electron Microscopy revealed that the as-fabricated microstructure demonstrates fine sub-micron cells that are separated from adjacent cells by fine Si-rich regions. Post-processing using T6 and/or HIP treatments resulted in the removal of the fine Si-rich regions, replacing them with coarse Si precipitates. This development results in a reduction in strength. The study also looks into the impact of other build parameters (e.g. surface condition and build orientation), combined with the post-process thermal treatments, on the mechanical properties, exploring the utility of post-process HIP on defect mitigation.

202.prez_name: Spatial Control of AM Solidification Microstructure across Multiple Alloys and Processes
202.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
202.prez_abstract: In this work, previous results for solidification microstructure control in Ti-6Al-4V(Ti64) for single bead and thin wall geometries are extended to solid build geometries for multiple alloy systems and two processes. Location- specific microstructure control via additive manufacturing has been demonstrated by the authors for Arcam deposits of Ti64 but has not been explored in detail.  Also, it is important to understand relationship between process variables and microstructure while minimizing part porosity, optimizing the build rate or controlling other process outcomes. Toward this goal, solid test blocks of Ti64, IN718 and AlSi10Mg are built by varying process variables.  Results show a fundamental relationship between melt pool geometry and solidification microstructure across different alloys and different processes. The result is applied to achieve location specific microstructure control in a target component.

203.prez_name: Strengthening Weld-based Additive Manufacturing Through Age-hardened Supersaturated Alloys
203.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
203.prez_abstract: As additive manufacturing (AM) with metals rapidly matures, there is greater demand for inexpensive feedstock and processes. Powder-based AM enables rapid cooling and therefore finer microstructures and greater control of properties, but at a significantly higher cost and lower deposition rate than weld-based AM methods. Previous research in weld-based AM has focused on characterizing existing alloys and not on the development of new alloys and processes to approach the rapidly solidified microstructures observed in powder-based AM. This study explores achieving enhanced properties through either in situ or post age hardening of the supersaturated welds. Supersaturated welds can be achieved through increasing cooling rate on a water-chilled copper plate and by designing alloys that trap the solute in solution more effectively. Improving the performance of weld-based AM products greatly strengthens weld-based AM’s viability as a manufacturing and engineering solution over more expensive powder-based AM and traditional subtractive manufacturing methods.

204.prez_name: Structure / Property (Constitutive and Dynamic Strength / Damage) Characterization of Additively Manufactured (AM) 304L SS Produced Using Four Different AM Build Methods
204.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
204.prez_authors: George Thompson Gray, John  Carpenter, Cameron  Knapp, Veronica  Livescu, Carl  Trujillo, David  Jones
204.prez_abstract: Certification requirements generally involve meeting engineering and physics requirements tied to the functional requirements of the engineering component and finally process and product qualification. In this presentation, the results of a study quantifying the constitutive behavior of 304L SS fabricated using Optomec, EOS, Rhenishaw and ARCAM additive manufacturing (AM) platforms is presented.  The microstructure of the AM-304L SS is detailed for each of the AM processes.  The mechanical behavior of the four AM build methods was characterized using compression testing as a function of strain rate. The dynamic damage evolution and failure response of all three materials was probed using flyer-plate impact driven spallation experiments.  The damage evolution as a function of AM fabrication method was characterized using optical metallography and electron-back-scatter diffraction (EBSD).

205.prez_name: Supersolidus Liquid Phase Sintering of Inconel 718
205.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
205.prez_authors: Peeyush  Nandwana, Amy M Elliott, William H Peter, Sudarsanam S Babu
205.prez_abstract: Binder jetting is a versatile powder-bed based additive manufacturing process that can be used for depositing powders with different chemistries and size distributions. The versatility offered in terms of powder size distribution is unique to binder jet process. Currently, full densification is achieved via infiltration that results in inhomogeneous chemistries and properties. For specialty alloys like Inconel 718, sintering is the preferred route. Sintering also serves to homogenize the chemistry unlike casting where segregation is a problem. The work presents the parameters for achieving full densification in Inconel 718 pellets processed by binder jet printing. It was found that the powder size distribution and chemistry has a dominant effect on the choice of sintering temperature. It has been identified that the samples can be sintered to full densification in 5hrs at between 1280C-1325C depending on the solidus temperature, which depends on feedstock chemistry. The results have been presented.

206.prez_name: Surface Finish Effects on Tensile Properties of EBM Manufactured Ti6Al4V
206.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
206.prez_abstract: The first objective of this research was to identify the mechanical properties HIPed Ti6Al4V fabricated by EBM in three conditions: as-deposited, surface treated using the Extreme ISF® Process, and machined. A statistical analysis shows that the parts treated with the extreme ISF® show the best performance, while the machined part and the as-deposited parts do not exhibit a significant performance difference in most of the cases. The second objective studied in this research was a study to identify variations in mechanical properties due to the location of specimens within the fabrication envelope. Overall, the results obtained indicate a consistency of mechanical properties for parts fabricated using the EBM process regardless of location.

207.prez_name: Surface Texture and Microstructure of Overhanging Structures in Laser Powder Bed Fusion Additive Manufacturing
207.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
207.prez_authors: Jason  Fox, Shawn  Moylan, Brandon  Lane, Mark  Stoudt, Thien  Phan, Lyle  Levine
207.prez_abstract: The development of additive manufacturing has allowed for increased flexibility and complexity of designs over formative and subtractive manufacturing. However, increased design complexity leads to difficulty in maintaining consistent or desired as-built surface texture and microstructure. A difficulty that can be seen in the downward facing surface of overhanging structures. To better understand the relationship between the as-built surface texture, microstructure, process parameters, and geometry, samples covering a range of overhang angles and process parameters were built in a laser powder bed fusion system, surface texture was characterized, and samples were sectioned for microstructural analysis. It was found that surface roughness metrics, such as Rpc, RSm, and Rc, indicate a shift between surfaces dominated by partially melted powder particles and surfaces dominated by material from the re-solidified melt track. Through these relationships, measured surface texture has the potential as a process signature to help determine the cause of defects.

208.prez_name: Tensile Property of the AISI H13 Tool Steel Deposited by the Direct Energy Deposition Process
208.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
208.prez_authors: Jun Seok  Park, Yoon-Sun  Lee, Ji Hyun   Sung, Sang-Kon  Lee, Yong-Jae  Cho, Da Hye  Kim
208.prez_abstract: The Direct energy deposition (DED) process has attracted wide attention because it can directly manufacture the desired metal products. The DED process also applies to making or restoring a die and developing the die with the internal cooling channel by using tool steel materials. Many studies have produced some successful results in forming the desired shape. However, further research for verification the performance and durability of the product is needed. The mechanical properties of the deposited steel by the DED process is dissimilar to that of the wrought steel despite the chemical compositions are insignificantly different in both steels. Here, we investigated the tensile property of the AISI H13 tool steel deposited by using a direct metal tooling process based on the DED process. From tensile tests, we found that the deposited H13 steel has the brittle fracture behavior. We will discuss the tensile property based on the microstructure.

209.prez_name: The Effect of Aging Treatment on Mechanical Properties of Powder-bed Binder-jet Printed Alloy 625 Nickel Superalloy Parts
209.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
209.prez_authors: Erica  Stevens, Amir  Mostafaei, Markus  Chmielus
209.prez_abstract: The effect of aging treatment on the mechanical properties of alloy 625 superalloy fabricated by using the powder-bed binder-jet printing (BJP) method is examined. Samples printed with Ar gas-atomized powder were cured at 175 °C for 8 h, then sintered at 1280 °C for 4 h. After solutionizing, an aging treatment was conducted at 745 °C for 60 h. A variety of tests were performed to study the mechanical properties of sintered and aged samples. Microstructure, phase formation, and composition were characterized using optical microscopy, scanning/transmission electron microscopy, electron dispersive spectroscopy, and X-ray diffraction. The results indicated that aging treatment resulted in carbide formation, and intermetallic phases in the microstructure which directly affected tensile, yield and shear strength, fracture toughness, and microhardness. With optimized heat treatment, mechanical properties similar to cast alloy 625 were achieved for BJP samples.

210.prez_name: The Effect of Beam Spot Size on Melt Pool Geometry in Direct Metal Additive Manufacturing Processes
210.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
210.prez_abstract: In laser or electron beam direct metal additive manufacturing, characteristics of the individual melt pool and therefore final parts are a product of a variety of process parameters.  The spot size or beam diameter of the heat source is a geometric parameter that directly impacts melt pool dimensions and part quality. A finite element model was developed to simulate the effects of various spot sizes on melt pool dimensions across different processes and alloys. Changes in melt pool geometries for different spot sizes are related across the alloys and processes. Experiments support the simulations and give insight into optimal spot sizes needed to yield consistent deposition results.

211.prez_name: The Effect of Post Processing Heat Treatment on Improving Mechanical Properties of 17-4 PH Stainless Steel Additively Manufactured via Laser Powder Bed Fusion
211.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
211.prez_authors: Somayeh  Pasebani, Sunil  Badwea, Harish  Irrinki, Sundar V. Atreb
211.prez_abstract: Water atomized and Gas powder 17-4 PH powder with D50= 17 mm and D50= 13 mm, respectively have been additively manufactured via laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) using a 3D Systems ProX 200 machine in Ar atmosphere. Printed ASTM E8 parts were heat treated thereafter, and mechanical properties of the parts were evaluated at room temperature. While mechanical properties of gas atomized powder were comparable with that of wrought, parts printed from water atomized powder exhibited significantly weaker mechanical properties even at highest laser energy density. Cooling rate during atomization of powder, carbon content and optimized heat treatment condition could potentially improve mechanical properties in water atomized powder. Adjusting the chemical composition especially the carbon content of the water atomized powder and designing high temperature heat treatment were implemented and improved mechanical properties (UTS and elongation) in water atomized powder to compete with that of gas powder.

212.prez_name: The Effect of Processing Parameters on Surface Finish and Mechanical Behavior Of Additively Manufactured Metals
212.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
212.prez_authors: Joy  Gockel, Chigozie  Obidigbo, Eric   Tatman, Jim   Webster
212.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) is revolutionizing the way products are designed and manufactured in the aerospace, medical, automotive and across many other industries. Direct metal additive manufacturing is used not only for prototyping, but also to produce final production parts. Due to the inherent layered nature of the process, a rough surface is present which provides many potential fatigue crack initiation sites. This work uses modeling to show the effect of processing parameters on surface topology due to stacking of melt pools. The effect of surface features on fatigue properties is determined by relating surface notches to a fatigue modifying factor. Additional sources of variation causing deviation from the ideal stacked surface finish will be discussed. An understanding of the effect of as built surface conditions on the mechanical properties is important to take advantage of complex geometries with un-machined internal surfaces.

213.prez_name: The Influence of Laser Engineered Net Shaping Parameters on the Metallurgical Quality and Mechanical Properites of the Fe – Al Intermetallic Products
213.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
213.prez_abstract: In this paper we employed laser engineered net shaping (LENS) to produce Fe-Al intermetallics. To obtain samples with insignificant porosity and a satisfactory shape and size congruency, suitable technological parameters of the LENS manufacturing process were selected. To analyze metallurgical quality of obtained samples X-Ray Computed Tomography (CT) was used. The microstructures were examined by optical and scanning electron microscopy.The identification of phases formed during the process was carried out by X-ray phase analysis. Microhardness measurements and tensile tests were sued to validate the effect of process parameters on the sample mechanical properties.

214.prez_name: The Influence of Post-build Microstructure on the Electrochemical Behavior of Additively Manufactured 17-4 Stainless Steel
214.symp_name: Additive Manufacturing of Metals: Microstructure, Material Properties, and Product Performance
214.prez_authors: Mark R. Stoudt, Richard Edmond Ricker, Eric A. Lass, Carelyn E Campbell, Lyle  Levine
