555.prez_name: Nanosheets of MgB2 as a New Class of 2D Semiconductor
555.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
555.prez_abstract: It is shown here that unlike the transition metal diborides, MgB<sub>2</sub>, when thinned to a nanosheet, has a band gap. Bulk MgB<sub>2</sub> has a single band crossing 1.80 eV above the Fermi level. This band crossing is at the high-symmetry K point located on the Brillouin zone edge, and the degeneracy is due to hybridized boron p-states. Introducing surfaces, by cleaving the (001) planes, breaks the symmetry and lifts the degeneracy, opening a gap. For sheets thinner than 7 Å quantum confinement opens the gap. The band gap of a 7 Å thick MgB<sub>2</sub> nanosheet is calculated by many-body Green's function methods to be 0.51 eV. These results suggest not only that MgB<sub>2</sub> is potentially new class of 2D semiconductor, but also that it is fundamentally different from traditional 2D semiconductors, such as graphene and MoS<sub>2</sub> because quantum confinement can be used to tailor the electronic properties.

556.prez_name: New Intermetallic Phases in the Ternary Al/Ga-Ni-B and Al-Pd-B Systems
556.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
556.prez_authors: Andreas  Leithe-Jasper, Qiang   Zheng, Yurii  Prots, Walter  Schnelle, Roman  Gumeniuk, Yuri  Grin
556.prez_abstract: We investigated the ternary Al/Ga−Ni/Pd−B systems, and found two new isostructural compounds AlNi9B8 and GaNi9B8 with two-dimensional porphyrin-like boron rings. Parallel to this research, we also discovered Ga2Ni21B20, with a new modified Zn2Ni21B20-type structure containing separated [B20] clusters. In this structure, [Ni6B20] cages share ligand boron atoms with [Ga2B4Ni9] hexa-capped square prisms, forming two dimensional layers. Ga2Ni21B20 is a metallic Pauli paramagnet, in agreement with electronic structure calculations.In the Al-Pd-B system we discovered the ternary compound AlPd15B7 with new type of structure, which is closely related to the archetypal Remeika phase Yb3Rh4Sn13 prototype. In its structure, 3 Pd atoms, 4 B atoms and 1 Al + 12 Pd atoms occupy the sites for the M, T, X atoms in the M3T4X13 structure, respectively, and the remaining 3 B atoms fill the remaining empty octahedra. Physical property measurements reveal superconducting behavior of this new boride with Tc ≈ 2.9 K.

557.prez_name: Obtaining of Boride Coatings under SHS Conditions for Car Parts
557.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications

558.prez_name: Oxidative Unzipping and Transformation of High Aspect Ratio Boron Nitride Nanotubes into White Graphene Oxide Platelets
558.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
558.prez_authors: Pranjal  Nautiyal, Archana  Loganathan, Richa  Agrawal, Benjamin  Boesl , Chunlei   Wang, Arvind  Agarwal
558.prez_abstract: High temperature atmospheric oxidation behavior of ultra-long and fine Boron Nitride Nanotubes (BNNT) is investigated by simultaneous Thermogravimetric Analysis and Differential Scanning Calorimetry. Oxidation of BNNT to form B<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>3</SUB> is found to initiate at ~750<SUP>°</SUP>C. This is accompanied with O<SUB>2</SUB> induced cleavage and unzipping of BNNTs. The unwrapped BNNTs were found to coalescence to form stacks of 2D platelets. FTIR and EDS analysis suggests these 2D structures to be Boron Nitride Oxide platelets, with analogous structure to Graphene Oxide. Therefore we term them as White Graphene Oxide (WGO). Oxidation process accelerates after 900<SUP>°</SUP>C. Nevertheless, not all BNNTs are deteriorated even at temperatures as high as 1000<SUP>°</SUP>C. This leads to the formation of a hybrid nanomaterial system comprising of 1D BN nanotubes and 2D BN oxide platelets at high temperatures. This is the first report on high temperature transformation of BNNT bundle to a continuous array of WGO nanoplatelet stacks.

559.prez_name: Practical Insights Obtained from the Theoretical Analysis of Boron Nanotubes, Boron Sheets and Alpha-tetragonal Boron
559.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
559.prez_abstract: We found by means of first-principles molecular dynamics simulations that free-standing, single-wall BNTs are thermally stable at the experimentally reported synthesis temperature of 870°C and higher. The walls of the BNTs have mixed triangular-hexagonal morphologies. Our results indicate that such morphologies are a structural paradigm for atomically thin boron [1].Furthermore, we show how chemical functionalization of atomically thin boron sheets can tune the basic electronic properties from metallic to semiconducting. Finally we report about the structure, nonstoichiometry, and geometrical frustration of alpha-tetragonal boron. Our results have resolved the structural and thermodynamic characteristics of pure alpha-tetragonal boron and reestablish it as truly elemental phase of boron [2]. Ref: [1] J. Kunstmann, V. Bezugly, H. Rabbel, M. H. Rümmeli, G. Cuniberti, Adv. Funct. Mater. 24, 4127 (2014); [2] N. Uemura, K. Shirai, H. Eckert, J. Kunstmann, Phys. Rev. B 93, 104101 (2016).

560.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
560.prez_abstract: Boron analogues have been predicted, as boron atoms possess a short covalent radius and the flexibility to adopt sp2 hybridization, which favours the formation of 2D allotropes s, and one example of such a borophene material has been recently reported. Here we present a work that 2D boron sheets can be epitaxially grown on a Ag(111) substrate Two types of boron sheets - a β12-sheet and a χ3-sheet - exhibiting a triangular lattice with different arrangements of periodic holes, are observed by scanning tunneling microscopy. Density functional theory simulations accord with experiments very well and indicate both sheets are planar without obvious vertical undulations. The boron sheets are quite inert to oxidization and interact only weekly with their substrate. The realization of such long expected boron sheets paves the way toward possible 2D boron electronics in the future.

561.prez_name: Recent Progresses in Understanding Boron Phase Diagram and Peculiar Properties of Boron Allotropes
561.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
561.prez_abstract:
In spite of extensive experimental and theoretical efforts in determining the phase diagram of boron [Chem. Rev. 113, 3425 (2013)], the phase boundaries reported in literature has significant discrepancy. Recently, Gibbs free energy profile of alpha-rhombohedral and beta-rhombohedral boron was investigated based on specific heat measurements, which provided the first experimental information about alpha-beta phase boundary at low temperature [Angewandte Chemie 127, 3697 (2015)].It was only several years ago that the underlying mechanism of an unique property of boron, partially occupancy in beta-boron, has been elucidated [JACS 131, 1903 (2009); PRB 81, 020102 (2010)]. I'll discuss about the dynamical aspect of partial occupancy that were not understood at the time of publications. Interestingly, similar phenomena have been reported for alpha-boron and tetragonal boron in a recent years.
This work was performed under the auspices of the US DOE under contract no. W-7405-Eng-48.

562.prez_name: Relating Hardness, Bonding, and Composition in AlLiB14
562.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications

563.prez_name: Rising R-curve Behavior in Nanostructured Titanium Boride
563.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
563.prez_authors: Anthony P Sanders, Ahmed  Degnah, Ravi  Chandran
563.prez_abstract: The crack growth resistance (R-curve behavior) of novel nanostructured titanium boride (TiB) was studied for a range of compositions to determine how the microstructure and phase content affect the fracture resistance. The bulk TiB ceramic material was synthesized by reactive sintering of Ti, TiB2, and FeMo powders in a hot press. The powder compositions were varied (~44-48% Ti, 42-50% TiB2, 5% FeMo) to maximize TiB formation and study effects on mechanical properties. Standard four-point bend bars, 3 x 4 x 50 mm, were made from hot-pressed plates. Surface cracks were introduced by indentation with a Vickers indentor. The indented surface was lapped to remove the indent and arrive at an initial crack for the R-curve tests. The initial crack was loaded incrementally and crack extension was measured using an optical microscope. The R-curve results are reported and the aspects of TiB microstructure that lead to increased fracture resistance are identified.

564.prez_name: Sintering of B4C at Relatively Low Temperatures
564.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
564.prez_authors: Ramasis  Goswami, Syed  Qadri, James  Wollmerhauser, Noam  Bernstein
564.prez_abstract: B4C is the lightest among armor grade ceramic materials, with the highest compressive strength and Hugoniot (shock) elastic limit (HEL). In defense applications, there is significant interest in lightening vehicle and personnel loads by replacing current armor with lighter materials such as B4C. It is realized that a low-temperature sintering process that facilitates bonding between B4C powders, and retains the original lattice configuration and decreases the grain size would be desirable. We report here a significant improvement in sinterability at relatively low temperature of 1100°C by adding small amount of Ni to B4C powders. The improvement in the sintering ability of B4C is shown to be associated with the formation of Ni-boride, which enhances the bonding between B4C particles at a relatively low temperature of sintering.

565.prez_name: Structural and Mechanical Properties of Spark Plasma Sintered Boron Nitride Nanoplatelets
565.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
565.prez_authors: Archana  Loganathan, Chris  Rudolf, Cheng  Zhang, Benjamin  Boesl, Arvind  Agarwal
565.prez_abstract: Recently, two-dimensional boron nitride nanoplatelets (2D-BNNP) has been widely used in functional composites. In the present work, BNNP were sintered at 1650 °C for a pressure of 50 MPa by spark plasma sintering. Structural studies were carried out on the sintered compact using XRD. Preferred orientation of the BNNP perpendicular to the direction of sintering was observed. Tribological properties were studied at room and high temperature on the sintered compact.  In-situ indentation studies were carried out for the sintered compact in the orthogonal direction and on the top surface. Predominant deformation mechanism observed on the top surface indentation of the compact are compression, delamination, sliding and pile up. For the orthogonal direction, the key deformation mechanisms are cracking, kinking, delamination and fracturing. These results indicate the orientation of BNNP plays a significant role in their mechanical properties and will contribute further in designing the BNNP based composite materials.

566.prez_name: Synthesis and Thermal Stability of Boron Based High-temperature Thermoelectric Materials
566.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
566.prez_authors: Muhammad A Imam, Ramana G Reddy
566.prez_abstract: High-temperature thermoelectric materials are desirable to convert waste heat to electrical energy more efficiently. In this regard, borides are favorable because of their high thermal stability and semiconductor properties. In this study, high-temperature properties of MgB<SUB>2</SUB> such as heat capacity, and thermodynamics properties were investigated. The MgB<SUB>2</SUB> was synthesized using elemental powders of Mg and B. The mixed powders were pressed into pellets and pellets were sintered at 1173K for 3 hours in argon.Heat capacity and thermal stability of MgB<SUB>2</SUB> experiments were conducted using DTA in the temperature range 350 to 1200K in an argon atmosphere. The samples were characterized using XRD, SEM, and EDS. The heat capacity (C<SUB>P</SUB>) and the thermodynamic properties (ΔH, ΔS &ΔG) were calculated as a function of temperature. The sintered MgB<SUB>2</SUB> particle size was determined to be in the range of 20 to 60 nm.

567.prez_name: Synthesis of Atomically Thin Boron Films on Metal Substrates
567.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
567.prez_abstract: In the past decade, two dimensional (2D) boron materials have attracted extensively theoretical interests in recent years because of its exceptional structural complexity, and amazing physical and chemical properties. Recently, we have reported the large-area synthesis of atomically 2D boron thin films on Cu foils by chemical vapor deposition using the mixture of pure boron and boron oxide powders as the boron source, and reductive hydrogen gas as the carrier gas (ref: Guoan Tai, et al. Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2015, 54(51), 15473-15477). UV-Vis absorption spectroscopy and photoluminescence emission of the thin films were measured to determine the optical band gap. Furthermore, other substrates have also been adopted to grow the boron films. This study could pave the way for its attractive properties and applications in electronic and photonic devices.

568.prez_name: Synthesis of Borophenes: Anisotropic, Two-dimensional Boron Polymorphs
568.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
568.prez_authors: Andrew J Mannix, Xiang-Feng  Zhou, Brian  Kiraly, Joshua D Wood, Diego  Alducin, Benjamin D Myers, Xiaolong  Liu, Brandon L. Fisher, Ulises  Santiago, Jeffrey R. Guest, Miguel Jose Yacaman, Arturo  Ponce, Artem R. Oganov, Mark C. Hersam, Nathan P. Guisinger
568.prez_abstract: As the lightest metalloid element, bulk boron exhibits great physical and chemical complexity. In contrast, atomic clusters of boron form simple planar and cage-like structures that resemble those of carbon. Theoretical studies suggest that nanostructured boron allotropes (e.g., nanotubes and sheets) resemble atomic boron clusters. To date, however, boron nanostructures have been scarcely explored experimentally. Recently, we have reported the synthesis of two-dimensional boron sheets (i.e., borophenes) on a silver surface under ultra-high vacuum conditions. Atomic-scale scanning tunneling microscopy shows the growth of two distinct phases, both of which exhibit anisotropic structures. We confirm that these sheets are planar, chemically distinct, and atomically thin through extensive ex situ characterization supported by first principles calculations. Furthermore, in situ scanning tunneling spectroscopy suggests the borophene sheets exhibit metallic characteristics, consistent with theoretical predictions. These results provide fundamental insight to the nascent field of boron nanomaterials synthesis.

569.prez_name: The Nature of Thermoelectricity in AlYB14 Compounds
569.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications

570.prez_name: Thermal Transport through Individual Boron-based Nanostructures and their Contacts
570.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
570.prez_abstract: Boron-based materials, such as boron carbides, represent a class of ceramic materials of extremely complex structure and composition. Thermal properties of boron-based materials are not well understood because various factors, including the extremely complex unit cells containing many atoms, varying carbon concentrations, stacking faults, and grain boundaries all play significant roles in thermal transport through boron-based materials. The fact that bulk samples are often of polycrystalline nature with varying grain sizes only make it more complex. Recently, we conducted systematic measurements of thermal conductivities of different boron-based nanostructures including α-tetragonal boron nanoribbons, boron carbide and strontium boride nanowires. Here we report on our findings on the effects of various factors on thermal transport through these nanostructures. In addition, we also discuss the effects of van der Waals interfaces on thermal transport through single and double boron nanoribbons and how we can tune materials properties by modulating the interface morphology.

571.prez_name: Thermoelectric Properties and Carrier Control of Metal Borides
571.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
571.prez_abstract: Thermoelectric energy conversion is one of promising application fields of boron-rich solids, because some boron-rich solids possess high thermoelectric performance. Metal-doped beta-rhombohedral boron and boron carbide are studied intensively as p-type thermoelectric material. Although further enhancement of their electrical conductivity is necessary, it is difficult to control carrier concentration and carrier type. We found that the divalent hexabirede is another candidate for boron-rich thermoelectric material. The alkaline-earth hexaborides synthesized by borothermal reduction were n-type, while those synthesized by molten salt method were p-type. The result indicates that carrier type of the alkaline-earth hexaboride can be controlled. Control of carrier concentration and carrier type of the hexaboride and its mechanism will be presented at the conference.

572.prez_name: Understanding Size and Morphology Control of Boron Carbide Ceramic Powders Synthesized via Carbothermal Reduction Reaction
572.symp_name: Boron, Boron Coatings, Boron Compounds and Boron Nanomaterials: Structure, Properties, Processing, and Applications
572.prez_abstract: There have been numerous studies on the synthesis of boron carbide (B4C) powders including nanocrystalline B4C based on carbothermal reduction (CTR) reaction.  However, a significant knowledge gap exists concerning the fundamental interrelationships between compositions, processing condition, and the resulting product morphology for B4C formation via CTR. Here, the results of an in-depth study on the influences of precursors, CTR thermal profile and atmosphere on B4C product phase purity and morphology are reported. CTR temperature along with total reaction time are found to dominate the size and morphology of B4C products: at low to intermediate temperatures (e.g., ~1150-1450°C), large, micron-sized B4C particles with significant non-uniformity are usually produced due to concurrent nucleation and growth, while highly uniform submicron or nano B4C particles are produced at high CTR temperatures (e.g., ≥ ~1750°C) with very short reaction time within a few minutes or even seconds due to instant nucleation and limited growth.

573.prez_name: A Model for the Numerical Simulation of Liquid Silicon Infiltration into Porous Carbon/Carbon Preforms
573.prez_abstract: A model for the numerical simulation of liquid silicon infiltration into porous carbon/carbon preforms is presented. One major manufacturing process of the carbon fiber reinforced SiC composites is the liquid silicon infiltration (LSI). The LSI into porous carbon preforms is a fast and low-cost CMC manufacturing process. The time dependence of silicon concentration during infiltration is studied. Several studies on infiltration characteristics in the literature which is mostly experimental and little fundamental theoretical work has been done. The possible reasons for this gap might arise from the difficulties of studying the high-temperature and vacuum conditions.

574.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing of Ceramics Enabled by Flash Pyrolysis of Polymer Precursors with Nanoscale Layers
574.prez_authors: Rishi  Raj, Luca  Zoli, Setareh  Azarnoush
574.prez_abstract: We show that a polymer-based route to ceramics can be implemented into additive manufacturing by reducing the time for pyrolysis to about a second, which we call flash-pyrolysis. Repetitive deposition of nanometer scale coatings of the ceramic, in this way, is employed to create defect free infiltrations of carbon fiber composites. The mechanical strength of the fibers is retained in the composite. Excellent wetting properties of the polymer precursor permits three-dimensional, conformal coating through the three stages of infiltration: nanoscale coating of the single fibers, filling of interstitial spaces between the fibers, and a build up of the coating over the entire composite. The flash-pyrolysis method will enable a new genre of polymer-derived ceramics made into net-shape by this unusual method of additive manufacturing.

575.prez_name: Carbon Nanotube and In-situ Titanium Carbide Reinforced Titanium Diboride Matrix Composites Synthesized by Reactive Spark Plasma Sintering
575.prez_authors: Karthiselva S N, Srinivasa Rao Bakshi
575.prez_abstract: Mechanically milled powder mixtures of Titanium and Boron containing 1, 2, 4 and 6 vol.% multi-walled carbon nanotubes (CNT) were consolidated by reactive spark plasma sintering resulting in TiB2-TiC-CNT hybrid composites. Addition of CNT was found to affect the reaction rate for TiB2 formation which results in sudden volume shrinkage. Rod shaped TiC were formed due to reaction between Ti and CNT. TiB2-TiC-CNT hybrid composites having more than 96% relative density with nanosized TiB2 grains were obtained. XRD results revealed TiB2 and TiC as major and minor phases respectively. Unreacted CNT were observed in SEM and TEM. TiB2-TiC-CNT composites showed nanohardness of above 25 GPa and elastic modulus of 520 GPa. Indentation fracture toughness was improved by 55 % (3.3 ± 0.1 to 5.11 ± 0.6) by the addition of 4 vol. % of CNT. The effect of CNT addition on oxidation and co-efficient of thermal expansion is also presented.

576.prez_name: Compaction Plasticity of Ceramic Spray Dried Granules to Form Microstructural Uniformity and Green Strength
576.prez_abstract: Microstructural variability in ceramic green bodies has been a continuing issue during ceramic processing as it can lead to unwanted pores and fractures developing in the microstructure. Moisture and binders within the granules are needed to create temporary adhesion and strength before the firing process. The moisture governs the mechanical properties of the binder and thus affects the compaction behavior of the granules and the microstructures of the green body. In this study, alumina and clay based porcelain ceramics will be the two systems analyzed and will be processed by thermal spray drying. The plasticity of the spray dried granules on a compaction scale is used as a tool to determine the effects of moisture and thermal sensitivity from the different binders and clays within the ceramic pressed body and their relation to the green microstructural uniformity and green strength of the ceramic.

577.prez_name: Constituent Development for Higher-temperature Capable Ceramic Matrix Composites
577.prez_abstract: Two of the highest capability priorities for the Air Force, energy-efficient turbine engines and long-range precision strike require high-temperature CMCs to enable increased turbine engine efficiency and thermal protection of hypersonic vehicles. Ceramic-matrix composites (CMCs) currently lack the temperature capability and durability required for long-life at the highest temperatures envisioned.This presentation highlights research that is addressing the need for improved high-temperature-capable CMCs, with a focus on CMC constituents and an understanding of their processing, microstructure, and behavior in relevant service environments. The most pervasive lifetime and temperature limitations for SiC/SiC CMCs are related to creep and stress rupture of the fibers, oxidation-induced instability of the fiber-matrix interface, and instability of the matrix at temperatures >1400°C. Consequently, we are addressing these shortcomings by developing a phase-pure, stoichiometric SiC fiber, developing an oxide coating for SiC fibers, and developing refractory matrices for both turbine engine and hypersonic applications.

578.prez_name: Degradation Mechanisms and Models for SiC Fibers in Air, Steam, and Low pO2
578.prez_authors: Randall  Hay, Randall  Corns, Aric   Ross, Bridget  Larson, Paul  Kazmierski
578.prez_abstract: Oxidation of SiC fibers changes their strength.  After passive oxidation in air and steam, strengths are related to the effect that scale residual stress has on stress intensity factors of SiC critical flaws. The residual stress is thermal stress from CTE mismatch and/or growth stress from volume change during SiC oxidation. Compressive residual stress typical for glass scales strengthens fibers. Tensile residual stress typical for crystalline scales weakens fibers. Si(OH)4 saturated steam accelerates oxidation and crystallization rates, but OH- lowers scale viscosity and therefore growth stress. Some low viscosity scales formed in steam dewet SiC and spheroidize. Steam may also promote subcritical crack growth, even when a scale forms. When scales do not form during active oxidation in steam and low pO2, severe degradation is associated with SiC surface roughening. Models that capture and quantify the various strength change mechanisms and effects of fiber microstructure are discussed.

579.prez_name: Effect of SiC Content on Thermal and Ablation Properties of Pressureless Sintered ZrB2-based Ultrahigh Temperature Ceramic Composites
579.prez_authors: Rahul  Mitra, Manab  Mallik, Ansu J Kailath, Kalyan Kumar Ray
579.prez_abstract: The effects of SiC content (10–40 vol.%) on thermal and ablation properties of pressureless sintered ZrB2-SiC composites having interfacial W-segregation have been studied. Composites have been prepared by pressureless sintering of ball-milled ZrB2-SiC powders at 2000 °C, whereas, their thermal diffusivity and thermal expansion coefficient have been measured using laser-flash method and thermo-mechanical analyzer, respectively. The composite samples were subjected to thermal shock by holding at temperatures from 800 to 1200 oC and then water-quenched. Subsequently, the growth of indentation cracks was examined. Furthermore, ablation experiments have been carried out by 10 minute exposure to oxyacetylene flame, resulting in a maximum temperature of 2200 °C. The damage due to ablation has been determined in terms of change in mass, Young’s modulus, hardness and indentation fracture toughness. The most desirable combination of properties observed in the composite with 20% SiC is attributed to densification, thermal properties and interfacial W-segregation.

580.prez_name: Effects of Boron on Oxidation of Sylramic SiC Fibers
580.prez_abstract: Sylramic SiC fibers with and without a surface layer of in situ boron nitride were oxidized in dry flowing oxygen at temperatures between 800 and 1300C.  Oxidation kinetics were monitored by a thermogravimetric technique.  Oxide thickness was measured using scanning electron microscopy.  The thermally grown oxide scales were subsequently digested for analysis by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy to determine the boron to silicon ratio in the oxide.  Fiber diameters after oxidation were also obtained to measure SiC recession.  Results indicate that the presence of the surface BN layer increased the oxidation rate of the fibers at short times.  Results are interpreted in terms of the effect of boron on oxidant transport in thermally grown silica.

581.prez_name: Effects of Boundry Condition on Foreign Object Damage Behavior of a SiC/SiC Composite at Ambient Temperature
581.prez_authors: David Calvin Faucett, Nesredin  Kedir, Sung R Choi
581.prez_abstract: Foreign object damage (FOD) of melt-infiltrated (MI) SiC/SiC ceramic matrix composite (CMC) was assessed with 1.59 mm-diameter hardened steel ball projectiles using an impact-velocity range of 150 to 340 m/s at normal incident angle. Non-destructive inspection (NDI)using thermography and computed tomography was used to identify unique post impact damage pattern associated with cantilever support configuration. High resolution scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was also used to assess the severity of damage within regions identified by NDI methods.  Strength degradation was also characterized using 4-Point bending for each impact regime to quantify the degree of impact damage in conjunction with the NDI assessments.

582.prez_name: Engineered Matrix Composites: Design and Properties of the Engineered Matrix
582.prez_abstract: The planned use of conventional SiCf/SiC ceramic matrix composites (CMCs) in the next generation of aircraft engines requires that the durability and performance of these CMCs be improved and extended for applications up to 1482 ºC. The present paper proposes a methodology for improving the durability and reliability of the SiC matrix for high temperature applications. The paper discusses a general concept for designing these engineered matrices to minimize the global differences in the thermal expansion mismatches between them and the reinforcing fibers. The properties of some of these engineered matrices are discussed.

583.prez_name: Foreign Object Damage in SiC/SiC Fibrous Ceramics
583.prez_authors: Nesredin  Kedir, David   Faucett, Sung  R. Choi
583.prez_abstract: Foreign object damage (FOD) behavior of a SiC/SiC fibrous ceramic was determined at velocities ranging from 40 m/s to 150 m/s. Tests were conducted under ambient conditions using a partially supported configuration, and impact by 1.59 mm-diameter steel-projectiles at a normal incidence angle. Relative damage was visually assessed by determining the size of impact craters and spalls on the front and back surfaces respectively. The degree of damage was further evaluated via post-impact strength testing under flexural loading.  In addition, the fracture toughness of the ceramic was determined through Vickers indentation technique and single-edge-V-notched beam method (SEVNB). Prediction of impact force was also made using principles of energy conservation.

584.prez_name: High-temperature Calcium-magnesium-aluminosilicate (CMAS) Interactions with Ytterbium Disilicate Environmental Barrier Coating Material
584.prez_authors: Valerie L. Wiesner, Nathan  Johnson, David  Scales, Bryan  Harder, Narottam  Bansal
584.prez_abstract: Gas turbine engines regularly ingest particulate such as sand and volcanic ash during operation. At temperatures >1200°C, these particulates melt, resulting in glass deposits with compositions loosely corresponding to calcium-magnesium-aluminosilicate (CMAS). These deposits can significantly reduce the durability of present and prospective engine component materials, including silicon-based ceramic matrix composite (CMC) materials with environmental barrier coatings (EBCs).  In this study, a CMAS glass prepared by melting a synthetic sand mixture was used to evaluate the high-temperature interactions with an advanced environmental barrier coating (EBC) material of ytterbium disilicate. The CMAS glass was applied to the surface of hot-pressed EBC substrates, which were heated in air at temperatures from 1200°C to 1500°C. Samples were characterized using scanning electron microscopy, X-ray energy-dispersive spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction to evaluate the resulting microstructure and phase compositions at the CMAS/EBC interface.

585.prez_name: Influence of Impurity Inclusions on the Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of Titanium based Cermets (TiCN and TiN)
585.prez_authors: Munyadziwa Mercy Ramakokovhu, Mxolisi Brendon Shongwe
585.prez_abstract: The influence of impurities inclusions from the coal ash (Al, Si, Ca and Fe) on the properties of the titanium based cermet’s, was investigated using the spark plasma sintered samples. The coal ash represents the reduction fuel during the reduction stage of the cermets. Tabular mixed powder with various impurity compositions mixed with cermets were sintered at 1850ᵒC at 50MPa for 5 minutes under vacuum. The microstructure and phases present were characterised using SEM and XRD. The hardness was determined using a Vickers Hardness tester and the fracture toughness of the sample was determined using the fracture indentation method. The optimum mechanical properties and optimum densification was achieved at 30% Al and 25% Si content. Corrosion behaviour of the sintered samples were studied under synthetic acid mine water.  An increase in free Fe and Ca content to 5.5% and 9.6% respectively reduced the corrosion resistance of the cermets.

586.prez_name: Interplay of Temperature, Composition, and Geometry on the Crystallization of Polymer Derived Ceramics for CMC Manufacturing
586.prez_authors: David L Poerschke, Frederick S.  Lauten, Carlos G. Levi
586.prez_abstract: Matrix processing routes utilizing preceramic polymers are being developed as a cost-effective method to manufacture SiC-based ceramic matrix composites (CMC) without inclusions of free silicon or carbon. The notional approach involves repeated polymer/precursor infiltration and pyrolysis (PIP) cycles to form the matrix. A higher-temperature heat treatment then converts the amorphous polymer derived ceramic (PDC) to crystalline SiC, typically with additional off-gassing of CO and/or SiO. The matrix defects (pores and microcracks) and impurities (oxygen, excess C) introduced during the PIP process influence the crystallization kinetics and ultimately the ability to process the matrix without adversely impacting the properties of the fibers and fiber coatings. Employing complementary experiments on crushed powders, fiberless matrix monoliths, and fiber reinforced composites, this study aims to elucidate the influence of composition, geometry, and temperature on the crystallization kinetics of a commercial PDC (SMP10, Starfire Systems) processed under conditions relevant to CMC manufacture.

587.prez_name: Investigations on BTNN-PVDF Composites of 0-3 Connectivity

588.prez_name: Mechanical Behavior of an Oxide: Oxide Ceramic Matrix Composite at Elevated Temperature in Air and in Steam
588.prez_abstract: Mechanical behavior of an oxide-oxide ceramic composite was investigated at 1000-1200°C in air and in steam. Composite consists of a porous alumina matrix reinforced with mullite/alumina (Nextel™720) fibers, has no interface between fibers and matrix, and relies on porous matrix for flaw tolerance. Tensile and compressive stress-strain behaviors were examined and tensile and compressive properties measured. Tensile creep and compressive creep behaviors were investigated. Steam accelerated creep rates and dramatically reduced creep lifetimes. Tension-tension fatigue behavior was evaluated at 0.1, 1.0 and 10 Hz. The composite exhibited excellent fatigue resistance in air. Steam significantly degraded the tension-tension fatigue performance. Tension-compression fatigue behavior was studied at 1.0 Hz for the ratio of minimum to maximum stress of -1.0. Tension-compression fatigue was considerably more damaging than tension-tension cycling. Retained properties of all specimens that achieved creep or fatigue run-out were characterized. Composite microstructure, as well as damage and failure mechanisms were investigated.

589.prez_name: Mechanisms of Reactive Alloy Melt Infiltration for Ceramic Composite Matrices
589.prez_authors: Rebecca Beth Reitz, Frank W Zok, Carlos G. Levi
589.prez_abstract: Reactive melt infiltration can produce fully dense matrices for ceramic composites, but these matrices often containing low melting point residual phases, limiting the operating temperature of the CMC. The current study seeks to develop a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms involved in this process, thereby enabling the strategic optimization of this process. Infiltrations of Si and Si-Y alloy melts into model geometries have been used to study the kinetics of infiltration as well as the formation of solid phases during the reaction. The emerging knowledge of the mechanisms will be discussed and implications for modeling and/or optimizing the reactive alloy melt infiltration process will be explored.

590.prez_name: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of Metal-ceramic Composites Produced through In-situ Partial Reduction
590.prez_authors: Kevin P.  Anderson, Richard P. Vinci, Helen M. Chan
590.prez_abstract: Metal-ceramic composites ideally retain the hardness and stiffness of ceramic materials while improving fracture toughness.  However, microstructural engineering of metal-ceramic composites is often limited by processing methods.  The partial reduction of mixed oxides offers a simple and relatively inexpensive process for producing metal-ceramic composites.  By generating the reinforcing metal in-situ, the structure and scale of the resulting composite can be controlled, potentially yielding nanocomposites.  These principles were demonstrated in multiple material systems including Co-Ti-O and Cu-Al-O.  By varying time and temperature, the process was engineered to control the scale of the metallic phase.  Composite microstructures were characterized with SEM including EBSD, and TEM.  Mechanical properties including modulus and hardness were then assessed through micromechanical tests including nanoindentation and microcantilever beam bending.  The results will be discussed with respect to the morphology and scale of the composite and their effect on mechanical properties.

591.prez_name: Microstructure Evaluation of Extruded Titanium Dioxide
591.prez_abstract: Extrudable ceramic pastes consist of solid phases such as powder and reinforcement materials and liquid phase. The behavior of pastes is strongly dependent on the initial materials and they are subjected to a range of mixing and extrusion parameters. The microstructure is essentially influenced by the paste behavior; therefore, the properties and quality of extruded materials will be affected. The imperfection can associate with extrusion such as liquid phase migration, rough surface, and bulk defects. The rheological properties, porosity distribution, and paste flow can play a role in the final product properties which would be essential especially in the complicated systems. In this research, the optimal paste composition was determined. The mixing- extrusion parameters will be identified. The water content effect was investigated. The microstructure will be analyzed. Benbow-Bridgwater model will be applied to predict the porosity distribution and extrusion behavior.

592.prez_name: Microstructures and Properties of Al/Al2O3 Multilayers
592.prez_abstract: Multilayers made of hard and soft layers that can lead to higher strength and toughness have emerged. Koehler showed that if one of the constituent layer has a significantly lower shear modulus, dislocations would have to overcome a large repulsive image force in order to move from one layer of lower shear modulus into the other layer with higher modulus. Multilayers made of hard, Al-Oxide, and soft, Al layers were deposited by RF magnetron sputter deposition  in an Ar atmosphere at room temperature.  We show that the post annealing after growth of an Al/Al2O3 multilayered film increases the strength by an order of magnitude as compared to the as sputtered condition by modifying the microstructure of the metallic layers. The increase in strength is shown to be associated with the precipitation of extremely fine γ-Al2O3, 5 to 10 nm in diameter, in Al layers.

593.prez_name: Modeling Architecture-dependent Effects on Environmental Degradation of SiC-Fiber Reinforced CMCs
593.prez_authors: Triplicane  Parthasarathy, Qing Da Yang, Brian  Cox, David B Marshall, Craig  Przybyla, Micahel K Cinibulk
593.prez_abstract: A methodology to predict the spatio-temporal evolution of fiber degradation within a composite as a function of environmental variables, fiber architecture and mechanical loading is presented. We have explored the possibility of integrating an environmental degradation micromodel with an Augmented FEM model to accomplish this. The main focus of this presentation will be on the environmental micromodel. The various mechanisms that are involved in environmental degradation of SiC fiber reinforced ceramics are catalogued and modeled. The key mechanisms analytically modeled include oxygen depletion from matrix crack face oxidation, recession of BN interphase from oxidation and volatilization in the presence of moist air, the oxidation of the fibers, the loss of strength from fiber oxidation, and the closure in the matrix crack opening from scale formation. The details of the models are presented along with parametric studies. Preliminary results from integration of this model with an A-FEM model will be presented.

594.prez_name: Na2SO4 Salt-assisted Hot Corrosion of SiC Fibers
594.prez_abstract: The Na2SO4 salt-assisted hot corrosion resistance of Hi-Nicalon, Hi-Nicalon-S, Sylramic and Sylramic-iBN SiC fibers was characterized.  Fibers were loaded with salt and placed inside a tube furnace with 0.1% SO2/O2 gas flowing for exposure times between 45 mins - 24 hrs and temperatures between 900 C - 1100 C. Fibers were characterized by weight change, Scanning Electron Microscopy, and Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy after hot corrosion exposure and 24 hr water and HF soaks to remove the corrosion products. Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy was conducted on the water and HF solutions to quantify the chemical composition of the corrosion products.  It was observed across all fiber types that hot corrosion attack was initially rapid and severe, with fiber fusion, surface pitting and non-uniform scale build-up as common microstructural features. Hi Nicalon fibers exhibited the largest weight gain, while Sylramic, Sylramic-iBN and Hi Nicalon-S fibers had similar weight gains.

595.prez_name: Overview of Foreign Object Damage in Ceramic Matrix Composites
595.prez_authors: Sung  Choi, David C Faucett, Nesredin  Kedir, Joseph  Hunt, Luis  Sanchez
595.prez_abstract: Ceramic matrix composites (CMCs), because of their high-temperature capability and increased damage tolerance, are an enabling propulsion material system and are currently being used and targeted in hot-section components of advanced aeroengines. However, CMCs are still relatively brittle in nature, particularly compared with metallic counterparts such as superalloys, and consequently are susceptible to localized damage and/or cracking when subjected to impact by foreign objects ingested into hot sections. This would result in deleterious effects in both structural and functional durability/reliability of aeroengines. Therefore, foreign object damage (FOD) needs to be addressed when CMCs are designed and used in aeroengine components. A series of FOD work on various gas-turbine grade CMCs has been conducted in recent years both experimentally and analytically including efforts to develop FOD modeling. This paper will present and discuss an overview S&T on CMCs with respect to FOD and some aspects combined with environments.

596.prez_name: Processing and Elevated Temperature Mechanical Properties of ZrB2/ZrB2-C Laminates
596.prez_authors: Connor  Wittmaier, William G Fahrenholtz, Greg E Hilmas
596.prez_abstract: Elevated temperature flexure strength and fracture toughness of ZrB2 and ZrB2-C monolithic ceramics, and ZrB2/ZrB2-C laminates were investigated. Graphite and ZrB2 powders were batched and homogenously blended using thermoplastic based binder systems. The ceramic laden polymers were then compressed in a heated uniaxial press (130°C) to produce layers of consistent thickness, stacked in alternating layers, and pressed to final thickness. The pressed composites were pyrolyzed to remove the binder, and densified by hot pressing at 2150°C at 32MPa in an argon atmosphere. The flexure strength and fracture toughness were measured up to 2000°C. The monolithic and laminar composites will be compared, and the effect of layer thickness and volume fractions of ZrB2 and graphite will be discussed.

597.prez_name: Processing and Testing of Ultrahigh Temperature Fiber-reinforced Ceramic and Metal Matrix Composites
597.prez_authors: Jacob  Stiglich, Brian  Williams, Jerry   Brockmeyer, Victor  Arrieta, Therese  Grundl
597.prez_abstract: Ultramet has developed innovative processing for ultrahigh temperature fiber-reinforced ceramic and metal matrix composites. Using a rapid melt infiltration process, Ultramet fabricates high strength fiber-reinforced composite structures that can operate in hot-gas environments at temperatures of >2800°C. A low temperature process has also been developed to apply fiber interface coatings to protect fibers during processing and to maximize composite mechanical properties during use. The processing is applicable to ceramic matrices with extremely high melting points including zirconium carbide, hafnium carbide, tantalum carbide, and ceramic alloys as well as refractory metal matrices. Melt infiltrated composite structures have been hot-gas tested in oxidizing environments at various facilities, and the components survived with low or no erosion. These composites have also been combined with conventional carbon/carbon or lightweight, ultrahigh temperature, insulating foams to produce multiple-layered structures for an array of aerospace applications. Processing and testing of fiber-reinforced composite materials will be discussed.

598.prez_name: Processing of Cu-10 wt% Graphite Composite by High-energy Ball Milling

599.prez_name: Processing Optimization and Improved Tribological Performance of Si3N4/Ti(C,N) Nanocomposite under Low Hertzian Stress
599.prez_authors: Jow-Lay  Huang, Ching-Huan Alex Lee, Horng-Hwa  Lu
599.prez_abstract: Si3N4 is extensively used in energy-related devices, and thus improving mechanical performance of Si3N4 based devices is an attractive topic in the modern development of engineering ceramics. In this talk, a series of Si3N4 composites containing nanostructured grains were designed and developed through spark plasma sintering. The possible field-activated mechanisms, including joule heating, electro-wetting, interparticle tunneling mechanism, are addressed. The focus is to show the optimized composition and grain characteristics, less than 100 nm for the constituents, in Si3N4/TiC0.37N0.63 nanocomposites by controlling sintering schedules and the ratio insulating/conductive powder mixture. The wear resistance of Si3N4/TiC0.37N0.67 is increased by 30% when compared with the monolithic Si3N4 nanoceramic under a low Hertzian stress of 0.27 GPa. The distributed nano-TiC0.37N0.63 in Si3N4 matrix plays the most important role in enhancing the fragmentation, micro-fracturing behavior and tribochemical wear responses.

600.prez_name: Residual Strength of Hi Nicalon S Fibers and Tows after Slow Crack Growth at Intermediate Temperatures (600 – 800°C)

601.prez_name: Self-healing Function of Mullite-based Composites at High Temperatures
601.prez_abstract: Self-healing function of mullite-based composites dispersed with Ni particles is studied in the point of view on high-temperature structural applications.  Almost fully-densified 5 vol%Ni/mullite was prepared by using the pulsed electric current sintering with powder mixture of mullite and Ni.  Surface cracks with approximately 90 μm in depth were filled up with the oxidation products, NiAl<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>4</SUB> and Ni<SUB>2</SUB>SiO<SUB>4</SUB> at high temperatures in air.  Formation of their oxidation products are caused by outward diffusion of Ni.  Inward diffusion of O also occurs at high temperatures, and develops internally oxidized zone from the surface of the composite.  Ni/mullite has faster self-healing and slower oxidation rate than Ni/Al<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>3</SUB>.

602.prez_name: Structural, Dielectric, Piezoelectric and Ferroelectric Properties of PLZTFN Ceramics

603.prez_name: Study on the Characteristic and Effect of the Nickel Ferrite Spinel Cermet as Al Electrolysis Inert Anode
603.prez_abstract: A cermet composed of 85% nickel ferrite spinel and 15% metallic Ag used as inert anode for Al electrolysis was studied in this article. The works mainly focus on improving the boundary and microstructure between the metallic Ag and the nickel ferrite spinel ceramic interface. The test of this cermet material being used as Al electrolysis anode has been done in laboratory, and its effectiveness is quite better. We can draw the conclusion that the characteristic such as the conductivity, corrosion resistance and heat shock property of the cermet material can be greatly improved to meet the requirement of Al electrolysis by means of optimizing the spinel/metal interface, and once we settle the technique of fabricating this kind of anode to enough dimension, can we use this kind of material as inert anode in Al electrolysis industry to reduce the gas emission of carbon dioxide.

604.prez_name: Synthesis of Nanocrystalline Ultrahigh Temperature Tantalum Hafnium Carbide Solid Solution Powders and Related Nanocomposites
604.prez_abstract: Nanocrystalline powders of ultrahigh temperature tantalum hafnium solid solution (TaxHf1-xC) and related nanocomposites (TaC-HfC) are synthesized by solution processing of tantalum chloride (TaCl5), hafnium tetrachloride (HfCl4), and sucrose followed by pyrolysis and carbothermal reduction (CTR) reaction of the yielded molecular-scale mixed tantalum-hafnium oxide(s) and carbon.  The influences of solution processing conditions such as starting materials and solution homogeneity and also pyrolysis/CTR conditions such as temperature, dwell time, heating rate and gas flow rate/vacuum level on product phase composition and morphology are studied.  It was found that TaxHf1-xC uniform solid solution are produced with either very fast CTR heating rate (>~500 °C/min) or long-time holding at elevated temperature (e.g., 1600 °C for 10 h) while nanocomposites are produced under other conditions.  In addition, the phase separation of TaxHf1-xC uniform solid solution within its miscibility gap seems to be suppressed due to slow diffusion as well as size confinement within the nano-particles.

605.prez_authors: Woohong (Rick)  Kim, Brandon  Shaw, Shyam  Bayya, Charles  Askins, John  Peele, Daniel  Rhonehouse, Jason  Meyers, Rajesh  Thapa, Steven  Bowman, Daniel  Gibson, Jasbinder  Sanghera
605.prez_abstract: We report on the recent progress in the development of cladded single crystal fibers for high power single frequency lasers.  Crystal fibers offer several advantages over traditional glass fibers such as silica fiber due to higher thermal conductivity, higher SBS thresholds, and higher doping concentrations. Various rare earth doped single crystal fibers have been grown from either ceramic or single crystal feed stock. We have successfully drawn crystal fibers with diameters down to 17 µm with lengths >1m long by a state-of-the-art Laser Heated Pedestal Growth system.  Single and double cladded rare earth doped crystal fibers have been fabricated using glasses where optical and physical properties were precisely matched to the core single crystal fiber. We also show successful fabrications of all crystalline core/clad fibers where thermal and optical properties are superior over glass based fibers. Various fabrication methods, optical characterization and gain measurements on these clad fibers are reported.

606.prez_name: Er:Y2O3+MgO Nanocomposites for Mid-IR Solid-state Lasers
606.prez_authors: Victoria L. Blair, Zackery  Fleischman, Nicholas  Ku, Larry  Merkle
606.prez_abstract: Several challenges exist for mid-infrared laser materials: 1) need to dissipate heat generated in lasing, 2) luminescence quenching by multi-phonon relaxation, and 3) trade-off in high thermal conductivity and small maximum phonon energy. We are tackling these challenges by synthesizing a ceramic nanocomposite in which multiple phases will be incorporated into the same structure. The undoped majority species (MgO) will provide  high thermal conductivity while the rare-earth doped minority species (Y<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>3</SUB>) will have a low maximum phonon energy. We will present a detailed co-precipitation method where both components are synthesized together for intimate mixing on the smallest scale. This method produces Er:Y<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>3</SUB> which is spectroscopically similar to commercially available counterparts. However, the method must be modified to incorporate MgO without re-dissolution into the solution. This modification in the process leads to interesting spectroscopic behavior, which will be discussed.

607.prez_name: Fabrication of Polycrystalline BaCl2 Scintillators by the Hot-forging Technique
607.prez_authors: Taylor  Shoulders, Gregory  Bizarri, Edith  Bourret, Romain  Gaume
607.prez_abstract: BaCl2 is among a group of newly discovered halide scintillators with high light yield and high energy resolution for gamma spectroscopy applications.  It is conducive to ceramic processing methods due to its low hygroscopicity and difficult crystal growth. We demonstrate the fabrication of Eu2+:BaCl2 transparent ceramics by a combination of high pressure and low temperature conditions.  Powder compaction is carried out in a newly designed hot-press capable of much higher pressures below 600oC than conventional hot uniaxial presses. Ceramic microstructure is examined using scanning electron microscopy and related to sample transparency. Analysis of texture is done by using scattering models fit to transmission spectra along with x-ray diffraction. Thermoluminescence and optically excited luminescence are used to probe traps within the bandgap.  Scintillation performance is measured by pulse height spectroscopy.

608.prez_name: Fabrication of Re:YAG Transparent Ceramics with Different Sintering Aids
608.prez_authors: Xingtao  Chen , Tiecheng  Lu, Yiquan  Wu, Jianqi  Qi
608.prez_abstract: Transparent YAG ceramics have become an attractive alternative for high-power and high efficiency solid-state lasers due to a number of favorable characteristics, including: greater maximum dopant concentrations, more functional design freedom, greater ease of manufacture, lower cost, and especially, superior optical and thermal properties. Due to the sophisticated fabrication techniques and equipment currently employed to fabricate transparent ceramics, in addition to the fact that many of the basic scientific issues surrounding transparent ceramics are not yet well understood, there are still some problems to be solved in the fabrication, characterization, and application of this class of materials. We have systematically investigated the influence of sintering aids on Re:YAG transparent ceramics, including CaO, MgO, SiO2, as well as MgO and SiO2 as a co-dopant pair, etc. We have addressed some of the key scientific problems in the transparent ceramic field, and have generated a number of innovative research results.

609.prez_name: Fabrication of Transparent MgAl2O4 Spinel : A Strategy for Enhancing the Transparency
609.prez_authors: Ha-Neul  Kim, Jin-Myung  Kim, Young-Jo  Park, Jae-Woong  Ko, Hai-Doo  Kim
609.prez_abstract: Transparent magnesium aluminate (MgAl2O4) spinel prepared by homogeneous green compaction and sinter-HIP processes was investigated. The uniformity of the particle configuration in a green body could be improved by both a wet shaping via microfluidization of the slurry and following slip-casting process. Microfluidization was successful to disintegrate micro-sized agglomerates of nanoparticles entirely by applying a high shear stress of 100MPa on the aqueous slurry. The processing strategy for enhancing the in-line transmittance was suggested that the pre-sintered density is crucial for HIPed transparent MgAl2O4 spinel. Another crucial factor was the addition of a small amount of Ca additive, which could suppress the grain growth effectively by the segregation in the grain boundary. For the optimum-processed specimen, pre-sintered to ~96% TD with Ca additive, the light transmittance was significantly improved in near UV wavelength region, over 75% of ILT at 280 nm.

610.prez_name: Fracture Toughness of Rare Earth Doped Magnesium Aluminate Spinel
610.prez_authors: Fiona Yuwei  Cui, Animesh  Kundu, Richard  Vinci
610.prez_abstract: Rare earth doped magnesium aluminate spinel has demonstrated advantageous optical properties and mechanical properties for use as transparent armor. Adding rare earth dopants into the system has been observed to enhance the strength and fracture toughness by altering grain growth, interfacial chemistry, and ground boundary energy. Micro-scale mechanical testing has been employed here to measure the fracture toughness of individual grain boundaries in order to advance our fundamental understanding of the toughening mechanisms. Understanding the localized mechanical behavior of doped spinel is complicated by the material's elastic anisotropy and the presence of preferred cleavage planes.  Micro-cantilever deflection specimens and fixed-fixed micro-chevron notched specimens were developed to carry out the mechanical tests. This study will emphasize how the micro-scale mechanical property characterization techniques are carried out and what they can tell us about the dopants' effects on the mechanical properties of magnesium aluminate spinel.

611.prez_name: High Strength Transparent Spinel by Microwave Sintering
611.prez_authors: Shyam  Bayya, Guillermo  Villalobos, Michael  Hunt, Woohong (Rick)  Kim, Benjamin  Rock, Bryan  Sadowski, Jasbinder  Sanghera
611.prez_abstract: Transparent magnesium aluminate spinel (MgAl2O4) ceramic has excellent transmission from UV to midwave IR.  It is rugged with strength 5x that of glass.    Because of its superior mechanical and optical properties it is used as a sensor window for military platforms.  However, for several civilian applications the material cost has to be brought down to make it economically viable.  Traditionally spinel is made via hot pressing or conventional sintering.  In this paper, we report the fabrication of highly transparent spinel ceramics using a microwave sintering technique. Microwave sintering offers various advantages over conventional densification methods due to its capability of rapid and uniform heating, shorter sintering time, fine microstructure, higher strengths, scalability, and significantly lower cost.  Highly transparent and homogeneous ceramics have been obtained using commercial spinel powder by this method. The optical and mechanical properties from highly transparent ceramics are presented.

612.prez_name: Highly Translucent, High Strength Zirconia Ceramics with Nano-sized Tetragonal Domain
612.prez_authors: Isao  Yamashita, Yuya  Machida, Shouichi   Yamauchi
612.prez_abstract:
Highly translucent zirconia ceramics having high strength was developed using lanthanum as a novel stabilizer.  This is the first report of highly translucent zirconia having high strength.  Its total forward transmission at D65 is >60% (thickness 1mmt), and bending strength are estimated to be about 1000MPa.  
Detailed structural studies showed the novel zirconia ceramics was crystallized into fluorite structure; tetragonal and cubic phase were detected.  The lanthanum was detected in cubic phase, whereas no lanthanum was observed in tetragonal phase.  The XRD peak was extremely broadened; nano-sized tetragonal and cubic domain (<50nm) was also observed using HR-TEM.  Raman spectra of the fracture surface showed that the tetragonal phase underwent transformation into monoclinic phase under tensile stress.  Because a reduction of the size of ununiformity reduces effect of light scattering, it can be attributed to the high translucency.  Origin of the translucency and mechanical properties will be discussed.

613.prez_name: Hot pressing of ZnS-CaLa2S4 Composite Infrared Optical Ceramics
613.prez_abstract: Zinc sulfide (ZnS) and calcium lanthanum sulfide (CaLa2S4) are both desirable candidates for infrared optical ceramics. Compared with ZnS, which exhibits superior optical performance, the refractory ternary sulfide CaLa2S4 exhibits better thermal and mechanical properties, making ZnS-CaLa2S4 composite optical ceramics promising for applications in harsh environments. In the present study, ZnS-CaLa2S4 composite infrared optical ceramics with different compositions have been consolidated via hot pressing. Different raw powders were employed to study the influence of particle size and morphology on the phase transitions and densification behavior of the ZnS-CaLa2S4 ceramics. In addition, the densification mechanism of the composite ceramics was investigated through analysis of the materials’ microstructure, sintering shrinkage, and density. The compositions of the ZnS-CaLa2S4 composite ceramics were also optimized to achieve more favorable optical and mechanical properties.

614.prez_abstract: Magnesium aluminate spinel (MgAl<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>4</SUB>) is an attractive alternative material for the preparation of IR transparent windows with exceptional ballistic protection performance. Current powder synthesis methods (i.e., solid-state, coprecipitation, and sol-gel) rely on either high-temperature reactions, or on expensive precursors with large embodied energies. Overall, all developed techniques have ample energy requirements and therefore hinder economic success. This paper explores the viability of a hydrothermal reaction medium for the low-energy synthesis of MgAl<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>4</SUB> at subcritical water reaction conditions.

615.prez_name: Influence of Dopants on the Thermal Behavior of Y3Al5O12 Nanoparticles

616.prez_name: Influence of Residual Pore in the Powder on the Transmission of Y2O3 Ceramics
616.prez_authors: Wook Ki  Jung, Ho Jin  Ma, Yiyu   Li, Yiquan  Wu, Do Kyung  Kim
616.prez_abstract: Fully dense polycrystalline Y2O3 is considered as a promising transparent material because of its high melting point, high corrosion resistance and broad range of transparency. For this reason, the fabrication of transparent Y2O3 ceramics has been developed by many researchers for laser host materials as well as infrared-domes. Generally, it is well known that the use of ultrafine, mono-sized and low-agglomerated powders is helpful for sintering ability which is related to high transparent Y2O3 ceramics. Accordingly, a variety of wet-chemical powder synthesis has been reported for many years. However, it is still required to study on the relationship among the initial powder,sintering behavior and spectral properties. In this work, we investigated the effect of residual pore in the Y2O3 powder on the sintering behavior and optical properties for transparent ceramics by SEM, XRD, pycnometer, UV/Vis spectroscopy and FT-IR. In addition, we also fabricated transparent Nd:Y2O3 ceramics with well-controlled initial powder.

617.prez_name: Microstructure-property Relationships for Light Transmission, Absorption and Emission in Optical Ceramics
617.prez_authors: Elias   Penilla, Alex  Dupuy, Yasuhiro  Kodera, Javier  Garay
617.prez_abstract: It is well known that microstructure can significantly affect the optical properties of polycrystalline ceramics.  For example, holding the grain and pore sizes to length scales less than the wavelength of light can be significantly increase transparency. After an overview of our processing techniques, we will present results from ongoing work on tailoring the optical properties of oxide and nitride ceramics. We will discuss modeling and experimental results  linking light transmittance, absorption and luminescence with microstructure (grain size, phase distribution, etc.) In particular we will show result microstructural design on ceramics for gain media and electro-optical light manipulation.

618.prez_authors: Guillermo R Villalobos, Michael  Hunt, Bryan  Sadowski, Robert  Miklos, Shyam  Bayya, Woohong  Kim, Jasbinder  Sanghera
618.prez_abstract: NRL is developing revolutionary, alternating hard/soft, micro-layered transparent ceramic/polymer armors where instead of just using brute force to stop a ballistic threat, shockwave guiding and dissipation are used to increase the material resistance to penetration.  Initial ballistic testing on our preliminary samples has shown a 30% improvement in ballistic resistance. Modeling shows that shockwave guiding and dissipation in the hard/soft micro-layers leads to a tremendous decrease in the compressive and tensile stresses that result in, respectively, comminution and spalling of traditional armor designs. The result is a light weight composite that offers enhanced protection from ballistic threats without an increase in weight.  This material could be used in canopies, vehicle windows and warfighter face shields. We present our results on the development of transparent armor materials based on tape cast ceramics and polymer films. We will report on modelling, fabrication methods, optical and mechanical characterization on these novel materials.

619.prez_name: Novel Material Ceramics for Femtosecond Lasers
619.prez_authors: Akira  Shirakawa, Shotaro  Kitajima, Ken-ichi  Ueda
619.prez_abstract:
Applications of femtosecond lasers are growing and then research and development of laser-diode pumped mode-locked lasers are progressive. We have been investigating femtosecond lasers based on transparent ceramics for practical sources.Yb:LuAG is a promising gain medium for high power lasers due to its high thermal conductivity and high emission cross section but has not been considered to be suitable for femtosecond lasers due to its narrow gain bandwidth. We have shown Kerr-lens mode-locking can overcome the gain bandwidth limit and recently achieved 100-fs, 2-W class operation in Yb:LuAG ceramic.
Yb-doped CaF2 attracts growing attention for femtosecond lasers due to its characteristic broadband gain profile and favorite thermal property. Fabrication in the form of polycrystalline ceramics with high transparency is a challenging subject. We are studying transparent Yb:CaF2-LaF3 ceramics and recently obtained CW laser operation with a record-high output power of 3.97W with as high as 73.1% slope efficiency.

620.prez_name: Optical and Mechanical Properties of Y2O3-MgO Nanocomposite Synthesized by Sol-gel Combustion and Hot-press Sintering
620.prez_authors: Ho Jin  Ma, Wook Ki  Jung, Do Kyung  Kim
620.prez_abstract: The infrared transparent ceramics should meet superior mechanical, optical and thermal properties for infrared-guided missiles and domes considering severe external environment. Y2O3 is the representative transparent materials due to high transmittance in wide wavelength region. However, it is not suitable for application in harsh environment because of the weak mechanical strength.To improve the Y2O3 properties, Y2O3-MgO nanocomposite has been studied for enhanced infrared transparent ceramics. Fine Y2O3-MgO grains by Zener-pinning effect result in improved mechanical properties as well as high transmittance in mid-IR region.Instead, the transmission in visible is lost because of grain boundary scattering from the large difference of refractive index. In this work, Y2O3-MgO nanoparticles were synthesized by GNP under the various conditions and sintered by hot-pressing to minimize the unintended grain growth improving the optical and mechanical properties. By changing the synthesis and sintering condition, near-theoretical infrared transmittance and high mechanical property could be obtained.

621.prez_name: Optical Ceramics for High Energy Lasers
621.prez_authors: Woohong (Rick)  Kim, Colin  Baker, Guillermo  Villalobos, Jesse  Frantz, Brandon  Shaw, Michael  Hunt, Bryan  Sadowski, Lynda  Busse, Shyam  Bayya, Darryl  Boyd, Ishwar  Aggarwal, Jasbinder  Sanghera
621.prez_abstract: In this paper, we report our recent progress in the development of high quality transparent ceramic window materials and high power solid state laser gain materials for high energy laser (HEL) systems. We have developed low loss spinel as an exit window aperture for HEL systems.  Various powder purification methods to lower the absorption and scattering loss from hot pressed transparent spinel ceramic are reported. We also report high optical transparency from a spinel ceramic fabricated by microwave sintering process. High efficiency laser oscillations from various rare-earth sesquioxides are also presented. Antireflective surface structures (ARSS), fabricated directly into the surface of various substrates including transparent ceramics, single crystals, and fused silica windows and lenses, are also demonstrated. Very low reflection losses as well as high laser damage thresholds have been measured for optics with ARSS. Furthermore, these structures can be chemically modified to impart superhydrophobic character to the surface.

622.prez_name: Planar Waveguide YAG/RE:YAG/YAG Laser Ceramics Prepared by Non-aqueous Tape Casting and Vacuum Sintering
622.prez_authors: Jiang  Li, Lin  Ge, Yubai  Pan, Juntao   Wang, Qingsong  Gao, Tongyu  Dai, Baoquan  Yao, Weixue  Li, Heping  Zeng
622.prez_abstract: Planar waveguide structure (PWs) has peculiarities of low lasing thresholds, high gain, high heat transmission and optical confinement with respect to the traditional uniform bulk laser system [3], which makes waveguide lasers suitable for high power and compact devices. Taking the advantages of both the RE:YAG ceramics and the planar waveguide structure, it is very promising to construct a compact, efficient and high power solid-state laser. In this work, composite YAG/RE:YAG/YAG transparent ceramics for planar waveguide lasers were fabricated by tape casting and vacuum sintering. The densification behavior, doping concentration profile and planar waveguide laser of composite YAG/Nd:YAG/YAG ceramics were studied. The in-line transmittances of YAG/Nd:YAG/YAG ceramics reach 84.8% at the lasing wavelength of 1064nm and 82.5% at 400 nm. In addition, the planar waveguide laser of composite YAG/Yb:YAG/YAG, YAG/Tm:YAG/YAG and YAG/Ho:YAG/YAG ceramics were also demonstrated.

623.prez_name: Polymer-derived Rare-earth-activated Silicon Based Oxynitride Phosphors
623.prez_abstract: Rare-earth-activated silicon based oxynitride luminescence materials have attracted much attention in recent years due to their thermos-stability, non-toxicity and excellent optical properties. This novel class of inorganic phosphors exhibits a broad excitation and emission in ultraviolet to visible spectral region, and has potential applications in light emitting diodes. This talk will focus on our recent research progresses in preparations, crystal structures and photoluminescence properties of polymer-derived silicon based oxynitrides activated by rare-earth elements. Starting with organic raw materials, various rare-earth-containing precursors could be readily formed by reacting solid polycarbosilane with different acetylacetonates hydrates, followed by nitridation and calcination of the precursors at relatively mild conditions. By utilizing both distinctive polymer reaction and organic-inorganic transformation, the rare-earth elements were more efficiently and uniformly doped into silicon based oxynitrides. Accordingly, the blue to red emitted phosphors were obtained depending on the types of activators and doping elements.

624.prez_name: Processing of Electro-optic Ceramics Using Current Activated Pressure Assisted Densification (CAPAD)
624.prez_authors: Alex   Dupuy, Yasuhiro  Kodera, Javier  Garay
624.prez_abstract: Electro-optic (EO) materials allow for the precise control of light using electric fields, allowing the advancement of an incredible array of photonic technologies such as laser systems and optical telecommunications. Most EO materials are single crystals or thin films.  EO single crystals often have composition limitations since dopants can segregate and not all compositions can be grown using equilibrium restricted techniques. Thin films often suffer from substrate clamping effects which limits their efficiency. Polycrystalline ceramic materials can potentially overcome such limitations and allow for the exploration of new EO systems. However, it has proven difficult to process bulk EO ceramics. We present the results of EO ceramics processed using  Current Activated Pressure Assisted Densification (CAPAD). Perovskite EO ceramics were processed using CAPAD and their ferroelectric, optical, and EO properties were measured using standard methods. Emphasis will be placed on EO materials that are difficult to process using other techniques.

625.prez_name: Scale Up of Spinel Windows for High Energy Laser Systems
625.prez_authors: Shyam  Bayya, Colin  Baker, Guillermo  Villalobos, Woohong (Rick)  Kim, Michael  Hunt, Bryan  Sadowski, Ishwar  Aggarwal, Raouf   Loutfy, Juan   Sepulveda, Tim   Lowe, Jasbinder  Sanghera
625.prez_abstract: Ideal exit aperture windows for high-energy lasers (HEL) should possess low absorption and scattering losses and be environmentally rugged to protect the gain medium without compromising the light propagating through the window.  The conventional window material such as fused silica glass does not satisfy HEL systems requirement to operate in harsh environmental conditions. Transparent spinel (MgAl2O4) ceramic, due to its excellent mechanical properties and wide IR transmission, has been considered as an ideal window material for HEL systems. HEL windows fabricated using commercial spinel powders often show high absorption and scattering mainly due to the presence of chemical impurities and trapped pores, respectively. NRL had previously demonstrated technology to make spinel ceramic with an absorption loss of 6 ppm/cm at 1.06 µm in small size samples. In this presentation, we will provide an update of the results of the scale up process with a goal of 30 cm diameter windows.

626.prez_authors: Nerine  Cherepy, Zachary M. Seeley, Stephen A. Payne, Ivy Krystal Jones, Patrick R.  Beck, Erik L. Swanberg, Daniel J. Schneberk, Brian M. Wihl, Nicholas M. Harvey, Steven L. Hunter, Peter A. Thelin, Scott E. Fisher
626.prez_abstract: Transparent ceramics are polycrystalline, fully-dense optics that offer advantages over single crystals and glasses in low processing temperatures, ease of fabrication of complex shapes, high aspect ratio optics (such as plates and fibers) and fracture toughness.  In contrast to single crystals, transparent ceramics can be formed with high, uniform doping, or may be formed with spatially controlled doping and refractive index gradients.  We are developing two new mechanically rugged, high light yield transparent ceramic scintillators: (1) Ce-doped Gd-garnet for gamma spectroscopy, and (2) Eu-doped Gd-Lu-bixbyite for radiographic imaging.  A direction-finding Gd-garnet ceramic pixelated device offers R(662 keV) < 4% and rapidly locates point sources.  For radiography, we are fabricating the bixbyite transparent ceramic scintillator, (Gd,Lu,Eu)2O3, or “GLO,” in 10” diameter.  We have demonstrated that GLO outperforms scintillator glass for 9 MeV energy radiography, due to higher light yield and better X-ray stopping, while providing excellent spatial resolution.

627.prez_name: Transparent Oxide Ceramics: Advanced Optical Windows to Next Generation Fiber Laser Hosts
627.prez_abstract: There has been tremendous interest in recent years to explore transparent oxide ceramics including AlON, spinel, and rare earth oxides (Y2O3, Lu2O3, etc.) and aluminates (YAG, etc.). Particularly, optically transparent, doped polycrystalline ceramics of rare earth oxides and aluminates appear to be the next generation laser hosts for high power laser applications. This talk will focus on the fabrication of the emerging field of ceramic YAG fiber laser hosts. Several aspects that include powder synthesis, consolidation, and characterization will be explored for achieving laser quality fibers (YAG, etc.). Also, this talk will discuss the most challenging issues in developing the transparent oxide ceramics.

628.prez_name: Transparent Phosphor-in-glass (PiG) Luminescent Materials for Solid State Laser Lighting
628.prez_abstract: Solid state laser lighting is superior to white light-emitting diodes in brightness, efficiency and color gamut, which requires thermally robust color converters that can be endured by high power blue laser irradiations. Regarding this, the application of the bulk phosphor-in-glass (PiG) luminescent materials could be of great interest. Here, we report a green-emitting PiG material by co-firing β-Sialon:Eu phosphor powders with the ZnO-B2O3-BaO-Al2O3 glass frits at 630-660oC for 20-80 min in air. The microstructure analysis indicated that β-Sialon:Eu phosphor powders were uniformly dispersed in the glass matrix without any interfacial reactions.Under the blue laser excitation, the optimized PiG sample consisting of 5 w% β-Sialon:Eu showed a linear relationship between the luminous flux and the incident laser power when the blue laser flux density was below 0.7 W/mm2, indicating its potential applications in solid state laser lighting.

629.prez_name: Transparent, Fine-grained Polycrystalline Ceramics with Improved Properties
629.prez_authors: Marina R. Pascucci, Mark  Parish, John J. Gannon
629.prez_abstract: Transparent ceramics are finding increasing use in demanding applications where glasses are limited, and single crystals are not practical.  Commercial and military applications include: infrared transparent materials for sensor windows (flat panels, deeply concave shapes, conformal shapes), scintillators for medical diagnostics, laser host materials, transparent armor, and advanced lighting.Processing of ceramic powders into high quality optical components is critically dependent upon the properties of the starting materials, and subsequently controlling the balance between grain growth and densification.  CeraNova’s unique processing technology enables densification at lower temperatures and produces a fine-grained, homogeneous, defect-free microstructure.  High in-line transmission results through controlled processing to eliminate scattering and absorption.In addition to high transparency, the fine grain size and lack of second phase impart higher hardness and improved strength to CeraNova optical ceramics.  Also, the homogeneous microstructure enables high surface quality in optically polished parts.
