674.prez_name: 1D Optoelectronics of Organic Nanofibers Self-assembled from Pi-conjugated Molecules
674.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
674.prez_abstract: Shape-defined organic nanofibers can be fabricated from pi-conjugated, electronic active molecules via solution phase self-assembly.  These nanofibers possess one-dimensional (1D) confined optical and electronic properties along the long-axis, including the long-range exciton diffusion and expedient charge transport. The former enables amplified fluorescence quenching, while the latter is conducive to chemiresistive modulation upon surface adsorption of redox active species. When deposited on a substrate the intertwined nanofibers form a porous super net structure with large surface area that enhances capturing analyte molecules from the air through molecular diffusion and surface adsorption. Combination of these features makes organic nanofibers unique materials for development into optoelectronic sensors with high sensitivity and fast response. To be presented in this talk includes our recent progress in the fabrication and property characterization of high quality nanofibers from various building block molecules and the potential applications in trace chemical vapor detection.

675.prez_name: 3D Graphene Foam Reinforced Flexible Epoxy Composites
675.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
675.prez_authors: Leslie  Embrey, Pranjal  Nautiyal, Benjamin  Boesl, Arvind  Agarwal
675.prez_abstract: Three dimensional (3D) graphene foam (GF) is a porous structure of graphene sheets that potentially serves as an excellent reinforcement due to 3D interconnected structure that eliminates agglomeration of graphene and provides seamless pathways within the polymer matrix.  This interconnected pathway could provide interface area for stress-transfer for strengthening and electron/phonon transfer for electrical/thermal conductivity.  Excellent wettability of epoxy resin systems against 3D GF is concluded by measuring the contact angle. The 3D GF/epoxy composites are synthesized by dip coating and casting methods. The GF/epoxy ratio is controlled by varying dipping time and volume of epoxy resin cast onto GF.  Mechanical properties of 3D GF/epoxy composites are evaluated by tensile testing and DMA techniques.

676.prez_name: Commercial Processing of Aluminum Composites with Nano Alumina Reinforcement
676.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
676.prez_abstract: Gamma Technology has developed and patented a process to introduce nano size alumina particles into aluminum alloys.  This process has been scaled from a laboratory process to a prototype process and will be scaled to 200 pound samples during 2016.  This process does not require expensive procedures and will deliver nano particle reinforced aluminum at a reasonable cost.  This paper describes the tensile data for material made during the laboratory and prototype development.  Two matrix alloys were investigated, annealed 1100 aluminum and annealed 6063 Aluminum,.   The addition of nanometer size particles add strength and do not compete with precipitates for strengthening the matrix alloy.    All testing was conducted using fully annealed samples. The nanometer particles increase the strength of the matrix alloy at room temperature and at elevated temperatures.This talk will detail this work and additional work on other matrix alloys that are being investigated.

677.prez_name: Control of Nanostructures and Interfaces in Excitonic Solar Cells
677.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
677.prez_abstract: Nanostructured TiO2 or ZnO photoanodes offer large specific surface area for dye or quantum dot loading. The large surface area of such nanostructures also provide easy pathways for charge injection and recombination, and surface defects and connections between adjacent nanoparticles may retard effective charge injection and charge transport, leading to  a loss of power conversion efficiency. Surface facets and chemistry may also affect the conformal deposition and coherent contact of dye molecules, quantum dots, perovksite crystals, and active polymers. We will present and discuss our recent work on the design and control of (1) nanostructures and surface chemistry of photoanodes for excitnonic solar cells, (2) nonstoichiometric composition, doping, and allignment of quantum dots in quantum dot-sensitized solar cells, (3) introduction of semiconductor passivation layers to minimize the charge recombination, and (4) incorporation of plasmonic nanocrystals to improve the light absorption.

678.prez_name: Controlled Growth of Regular MoO3 Nanoribbons and MoO3-based Heterostructures
678.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
678.prez_abstract: Molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) is a versatile semiconductor material with a wide range of potential applications. It has an anisotropic layered structure with weak van der Waals interactions between the (010) layers. This highly anisotropic stucture makes it easy to form one dimensional (1D) layered MoO3 nanostructures, such as nanoplates, nanobelts, and nanoribbons. Here, we report the controlled growth of regular MoO3 nanoribbons with uniform rectangular shapes using chemical vapor deposition (CVD) at low growth temperature. It is found the residual deposition has an important effect on the growth of regular nanoribbons. Controlled growth of MoO3-based heterostructures will also be reported. Core-shell nanostructures of indium tin oxide (ITO)-MoO3 have been developed via two-step CVD growth. Transverse and longitudinal growth modes of MoO3 shells on ITO cores have been developed by controlling the growth conditions. Growth mechanisms for the controlled growth will be discussed for the development of devices using MoO3 nanostructures.

679.prez_name: Controlled Synthesis and Assembly of Hollow CeO2 Nanotubes
679.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
679.prez_abstract: Fabrication of nanomaterial with hollow interior has been developing and catching the eye of many in the nanoworld. There are a plethora of applications for hollow nanomaterial; drug delivery, photonic devices, and nanocatalyst, etc. This research we are looking to increase the efficiency of the catalytic converter via low temperature ranges and larger surface area through hollowing the nanomaterials.  While controlling the size and shape of the nanoparticle poses a large feat in and of itself. We also propose to hollow the interior while controlling the size and shape of CeO<sub>2</SUB> nanorods. This will convert CeO<sub>2</SUB> nanorods to CeO<sub>2</SUB> nanotubes via hydrothermal processes. The formation mechanism of the CeO<sub>2</SUB> nanotubes is put forward as Ostwald ripening.   With control parameters set on shape and size as well as a controlled synthesis for the interior of CeO<sub>2</SUB> nanotubes, this technique may soon be able to be applied to other metal oxide nanomaterials.

680.prez_name: Crumpled Graphene Balls for Energy and Lubrication Applications
680.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
680.prez_abstract: A major problem in bulk production and application of ultrafine particles is their tendency to aggregate due to strong van der Waals attraction. Particles with crumpled sheets shape represent a new type of ultrafine particles that does not aggregate in solid state or in solution. As is illustrated with crumpled graphene balls, such particles have very weak inter-particle attraction, and can be dispersed in nearly arbitrary solvents. This leads to their application in making scalable energy storage devices such as ultracapacitors and Li ion batteries, as well as their excellent performance as lubricant additive to reduce friction and wear of metal surface.

681.prez_name: Deposition of TiO2 and Antimony-doped Tin Oxide (ATO) Double Layer on α-Alumina Platelets for Conductive Pearlescent Pigment.
681.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
681.prez_authors: Beyene Anteneh Marelign, Hyun Min  Lee, Do Kyung   Kim
681.prez_abstract: Antistatic coatings are being applied for avoiding static charge build up and consequent static discharge problems. Conductive fillers like metal powders and carbon based materials have been used as a conductivity imparting agents in antistatic coatings. However, the low dispersibility and low chemical stability of metals and the dull appearance of carbon based materials have limited their application. Composite conductive pigments obtained by depositing very thin layer (few nanometer scale) conductive oxides, like antimony-doped tin oxide (ATO), on ceramic and mineral substrates are remedying the mentioned problems. In this study, we synthesized high aspect ratio α-alumina platelets to be used as a substrate for the conductive pearlescent pigment and very thin double layer of TiO2 and ATO, one on top of the other, has been deposited on its entire surface. The optical property (brightness and luster) and the electrical property (powder resistivity) of the resulting pigment have been analyzed.

682.prez_name: Fabrication of Transparent and Fluorescent Sialon Bulk Ceramics Composed of Nano-sized Grains
682.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
682.prez_authors: Junichi  Tatami, Takuma  Takahashi, Motoyuki  Iijima
682.prez_abstract: One of the problems to be solved in LED of high power application is the thermal degradation of the resin because the operation temperature increases as applied power. In this study, we prepared the transparent and luminescent SiAlON bulk ceramics composed of nano-sized grains by controlling powder processing. As a result, the developed Ce doped Y-α SiAlON ceramics showed over 60% transparency at 600 nm in wavelength and blue or blue-green emission excited by UV light. The maximum excitation and emission were obtained at 370 and 480 nm, respectively. Transparent Eu doped Ca-α SiAlON ceramics was also developed, of which emission was yellow color by blue light excitation. The wavelength of excitation and emission and quantum efficiency of the Ca-α SiAlON ceramics is almost the same as that of the powders reported in the previous study.

683.prez_name: High Density Grafting of Poly(allylamine) Chains onto Graphene Oxide for Improved Mechanical and Thermal Properties of Epoxy Composites
683.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
683.prez_authors: Megha  Sahu, Ashok M. Raichur, Om  Prakash
683.prez_abstract: Graphene and its derivatives, due to their excellent mechanical and thermal properties, are being explored extensively as possible toughening agents for polymer composites. However, the bottle neck is irregular distribution of sheets due to strong van der Waals forces in polymer. Functionalization of the graphene and graphene oxide (GO) surface with polymeric chains has been employed to solve this issue. However, limited density of functionalized polymer chains on GO sheet surface is still a problem. To address the above issues, poly(allylamine) (PAA) was grafted onto carboxylic acid functionalized GO and subsequently used as a toughening agent for epoxy. PAA with high density of amine groups on GO surface increases the dispersion as well as compatibility towards epoxy which leads to better interfacial stress transfer for improved mechanical and thermal properties. In this paper, the functionalization of GO along with its dispersion in epoxy and improvement in composite properties is discussed.

684.prez_name: Hydrothermal Synthesis of Copper Sulfides for Controlled Morphology and Composition
684.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
684.prez_authors: Jing  Liu, Zihe  Ren, Jingyang  Wang, Edouard  Asselin
684.prez_abstract: Copper sulfides have been identified as candidates for solar cell applications. There are multiple Cu-S compounds with different stoichiometric ratios. Several Cu-S compounds with different morphologies have been synthesized by a hydrothermal approach using CuCl2 and copper foil as the copper source and multiple sulfur sources. Different Cu-S products were obtained and were analyzed under XRD, SEM and EDX. It was found that with Cu and S at a 1:1 ratio, temperature has the most important influence on the composition and morphology. Nanotube shaped Cu1.75S and hexagonal shaped CuS can be formed by changing the reaction temperature. Round shaped Cu2S (chalcocite) particles and cubic shaped Cu1.997S (digenite) particles can also be formed under the same experimental condition but using different sulfur sources (L-cystein and formamidine sulfinic acid respectively). Computational chemistry work using a Gaussian engine was also performed on the sulfur-containing molecules in order to understand the formation mechanism.

685.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
685.prez_abstract: Suspension-based imprint lithography expands on imprint lithography by using a colloidal suspension of particles in place of the polymer precursor. In this study nonanoic acid is used to functionalize the ZnO nanoparticles prior to their suspension in anisole solvent. The effect of suspension methods on feature fidelity is compared by examining the line edge roughness and surface roughness of each feature. The ZnO:PMMA volume ratio is varied to determine the best conditions for producing high-fidelity features from suspension stamping. Varying levels of ZnO nanoparticles are also suspended in a PMMA matrix via in-situ polymerization. The resulting material is then stamped with feature arrays ranging from 250 nm to 1 µm feature sizes. The effect of polymerization temperature and ZnO:PMMA volume ratio on feature fidelity is studied as well the effect of the ZnO:PMMA ratio and feature size on the photoluminescence response.

686.prez_name: Large-scale Production of Three-dimensionally Tailored Nanofibrous Carbon Components Using Vapor-phase Deposition
686.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
686.prez_authors: Roger  Welsh, David  Edwards, Mark  Atwater
686.prez_abstract: Carbon nanofibers (CNFs) have a multitude of applications, enabling advancements in composites, filtration, electrical devices, and much more. Previously, fiber synthesis techniques using vapor-phase deposition were unsuitable for producing a scalable bulk product in a single step. A new direct synthesis method has been developed using two unique approaches: i) the catalyst is rapidly produced using mechanical alloying, which is capable of creating, nonequilibrium, nanocrystalline alloys at low cost, ii) CNFs are directly synthesized in a constrained environment to form mechanically stable, nonwoven structures centimeters in size. These bulk fibrous structures are able to endure repeated bending and compression without any significant degradation to the structural properties, and they can be grown to replicate three-dimensional molds using a one-step process. The as-grown carbon can then be used as-is or modified for specific needs. The benefits and challenges of integrating these methods into commercial applications will be highlighted.

687.prez_name: Laser Assisted Synthesis of Ligand Free Nanostructures for Sensing Applications
687.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
687.prez_authors: Komal  Bagga, Ronan  McCann, Robert Joseph Groarke, Brian  Freeland, Mercedes  Vazquez, Dermot  Brabazon
687.prez_abstract: Over the last decade, tremendous advancements have been made in the production of new nano- materials for a variety of bio-sensing applications. Pulsed Laser Ablation in Liquid (PLAL) is a green laser-based method developed for production of ultrapure nanomaterials with unique surface chemistry. Our group has reported generation of various forms of nanostructures (crystalline carbon nanoparticles, carbon nanotubes, gold nanoparticles) by high-frequency Nd:YAG laser ablation, and established a phase control mechanism dependent on the laser pulse energy. Here, we report the development of highly sensitive platform for sensing biological and chemical species, functionalized with carbon and gold nanostructures around 50-100 nm. The optical properties of the generated structures were investigated by UV-Visible absorption spectroscopy. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), micro-Raman spectroscopy, and High-Resolution Transmission (HRTEM) were used to evaluate the size distribution, morphology, chemical bonding, and crystallinity of nanostructures. Addressing the challenging issue of nanoparticle stability, systematic stability studies are presented.

688.prez_name: Low-temperature Synthesis of Transition-metal Diborides Using Reactive Laminates: An Analysis Using First-principles Modeling and Nanocalorimetry Experiments
688.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
688.prez_abstract: Transition metal diborides have garnered intense attention as structural materials and super-hard materials. Their high melting points require extreme synthesis conditions that have hindered their widespread use. Reactive nano-laminates that consist of alternating layers of a transition metal and boron provide a promising route for low-temperature synthesis of diborides. We investigate the thermodynamics and kinetics of synthesis of transition-metal diborides. On the modeling side, we illustrate the energetics, diffusion kinetics, and structural evolution of solid-state alloying of Zr-B using first-principles methods. Furthermore, we investigate the catalytic effect of C and N additives on the synthesis of ZrB2. On the experimental side, we examine the effects of heating rate and bilayer period on the reactions in the RNLs.  The microstructural  evolution  of  the multilayers is  revealed using  TEM. The combinatory first-principles theoretical studies of nanocalorimetry experiments provide a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental mechanisms underlying the synthesis of transition metal diborides.

689.prez_name: Metastable-stable Phase Diagrams in the Zirconia-scandia System for Controlled Synthesis on a Nanoscale
689.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
689.prez_authors: Hirotaka  Fujimori, Masatomo  Yashima, Masahiro  Yoshimura
689.prez_abstract: The ZrO<SUB>2</SUB>-ScO<SUB>1.5</SUB> system is very important because scandia stabilized zirconia exhibits the highest ionic conductivity in the zirconia solid solutions. Numerous studies have been done on the phase diagrams in this system. However, there exist many discrepancies and misunderstandings among them. One of the most important keys to solve these problems is the study of the metastable phase diagram, which describes phase changes in compositionally homogeneous samples without diffusion, phase separation. Two kinds of tetragonal phase exist in the ZrO<SUB>2</SUB> solid solutions. One, t-phase, is the tetragonal phase of an equilibrium phase that is formed at a high temperature with diffusion. The other, t'-phase, is a metastable tetragonal phase that is transformed from the high temperature cubic phase without diffusion by rapid quench etc. We have to distinguish clearly two states mentioned above. The experimental and literature data were critically reviewed and a reasonable metastable-stable phase diagram has been proposed.

690.prez_name: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of Electrodeposited Ni-W Alloys
690.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
690.prez_authors: Denise  Yin, Christopher  Marvel, Richard  Vinci, Martin  Harmer
690.prez_abstract: Ni-W thin films were produced by electrodeposition in an aqueous sodium citrate bath using reverse pulse plating. Films contained up to 21 at.% W. A wide range of annealing temperatures and times produced a variety of microstructures, which were characterized via TEM and STEM techniques. The mechanical properties were evaluated with hardness testing and fracture toughness measurements via micro-cantilever bend testing. Trace carbon contamination was detected and found to affect phase stability. It has been revealed that carbon contamination is not only difficult to eliminate but also more prevalent than realized. The current study sheds new light on the understanding of how the microstructural evolution of Ni-W is influenced by the presence of impurity contamination and how it correlates to the mechanical behavior.

691.prez_name: Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Glancing Angle Deposition of Polymer Nanoparticles
691.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
691.prez_abstract: Glancing angle deposition (GLAD) has been used to create thin films composed of arrays of nanostructures that possess useful photonic, photovoltaic, and surface wetting properties.  Traditionally, physical vapor deposition has been used to generate and accelerate clusters of only a few atoms. We propose combining GLAD with a gas-phase method, such as electrospray ionization, flame synthesis, or plasma synthesis. The new process would allow the deposition of  a wide range of larger building block materials (e.g., quantum dots, proteins, and polymers).  In this work, we explore the deposition behavior of polymer nanoparticles during the early stages of nanostructure formation on a silicon dioxide substrate using molecular dynamics simulations.   The deposition particles are 10 nm diameter spheres composed of short-chain polyethylene oxide polymers. We discuss how deposition angle and system temperature affect the shape of the initial impacted particle and the binding strength of compound structures formed by subsequent impacts.

692.prez_name: Nanoparticle Doping for High Energy Fiber Lasers
692.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
692.prez_authors: Colin  Baker, Joseph  Friebele, Woohong (Rick)  Kim, Charles  Askins, John  Peele, Barbara   Marcheschi, Jasbinder  Sanghera, Jun  Zhang, Radha  Pattnaik, Larry   Merkle, Mark   Dubinskii, Youming   Chen, Iyad   Dajani, Cody   Mart
692.prez_abstract: A nanoparticle (NP) doping technique was used for making erbium-doped fibers (EDFs) for high energy lasers. The nanoparticles were doped into the silica soot of preforms, which were drawn into fibers. The Er luminescence lifetimes of the NP-doped cores are longer than those of corresponding solution-doped silica, and substantially less Al is incorporated into the NP-doped cores. Optical-to-optical slope efficiencies were determined in a resonantly-core pumped master oscillator-power amplifier (MOPA) configuration. Efficiencies of greater than 71% have been measured. Initial investigations of stimulated Brillouin scattering (SBS) have indicated that SBS suppression is achieved by NP doping, where we observed a low intrinsic Brillouin gain coefficient, of ~1× 10 11 m/W and the Brillouin bandwidth was increased by 2.5x compared to fused silica.

693.prez_name: New Approach to Multifunctional Supramolecular Gels
693.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
693.prez_authors: Bhanu P. S. Chauhan, Daniela    Artiga, Aarti  Patel, Erika   Castelar
693.prez_abstract: In this work, we present a new catalytic approach to synthesize multifunctional metallogel containing polymeric systems. In these novel gels polymeric functionality is strategically placed to template self-assembled morphology and also to stabilize metallic nanoparticles.  A Pt-catalyzed catalytic reaction of poly(methylhydro)siloxanes with polybutadiene is used to create functional mesoporous silica network. In this reaction, PMHS plays the dual role of cross-linking as well as reducing agent to produce nanoimprinted polymers with Pt- nanoparticles. We will describe in detail the property profiling and morphological characterization of such Gels using, X-Ray, NMR, IR, UV-Vis, TEM and SEM techniques. We also have investigated the self-assembly properties of these gels to manipulate the ratio of metal contents and gel porosity.  In addition, we will present our preliminary studies of catalytic applications as templates for the formation of porous or nanoimprinted polymers.

694.prez_name: On the Possibility of Using Sintering to Synthesize Materials with Low Structural Defects for Opto-electronic Applications
694.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
694.prez_authors: Amit  Samanta, Andrew  Lange, Hasti  Majidi, Selim  Elhadj
694.prez_abstract: Thermal or laser based sintering of nanoparticles is important to emerging technologies, like additive manufacturing, or to established technologies involving material annealing. Since the final microstructure and the presence of atomic defects impacts the electrical, optical, and mechanical properties of a sintered material it is important to optimize the processing parameters. We studied the processing-structure-property relationship during the sintering of Au nanoparticles using in situ electron microscopy and atomic-level computational tools. Our results suggest that sintering of nanoparticles leads to the formation of a coherent particle without any residual dislocations or interfaces, both of which are detrimental for optoelectronic applications. In addition, using our simulated free energy landscapes and experimental results we are able to reconstruct a sintering mechanism map which illustrates that, in contrast to the classical notion of diffusion aided sintering, in nano-scale materials sintering is aided by extensive dislocation activity.

695.prez_name: Polar Surface Domains Strontium Titanate Surfaces
695.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
695.prez_authors: Yisi  Zhu, Paul  Salvador, Gregory S. Rohrer
695.prez_abstract: Polar semiconductors have recently received significant attention because their internal fields separate photogenerated electron-hole pairs and reduce recombination.  On surfaces with polar domains, electrons are attracted to positively terminated domains where they promote reduction reactions and holes are attracted to negatively charged domains where they promote oxidation.  We have found that polar domains can be created on the surfaces of non-polar materials, including SrTiO3.  In this case, polarity arises from polar terminations on different terraces. By annealing the surfaces in environments with an excess or deficit of strontium, it is possible to control the fraction of the surface terminated by positive or negative charges.  In this talk, we will describe photochemical reactions on the surfaces of materials with polar domains and discuss opportunities to exploit polar domains in materials where they are not expected on the basis of the known bulk properties.

696.prez_name: Polyethyleneimine-fatty Acid Complexes as Polymeric Dispersants for Tuning the Stability of Multicomponent Dense Non-aqueous Suspensions
696.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
696.prez_authors: Motoyuki  Iijima, Yasuhiro  Kawaharada, Naoki  Okamura, Junichi  Tatami
696.prez_abstract: Complex of polyethyleneimine (PEI) and fatty acids have designed as polymeric dispersants to control the stability of dense non-aqueous suspensions. A series of PEI-fatty acid complexes have successfully prepared through simple mixing of PEI having various molecular weights (average Mws of 600, 1800 and 10000) and various fatty acids (such as oleic acid, stearic acid, and isostearic acids) in non-aqueous solvents. By using PEI-oleic acid complex, it was conformed that the prepared complex can effectively adsorb on various species of nanoparticles, including oxides, nitrides, and metals, and reaches to saturated adsorption condition which was favorable to improve the stability of dense non-aqueous suspensions. The effect of molecular weights, solvents species and the structure of fatty acid side chains on the adsorption properties of PEI complex on nanoparticles and their dispersion stability has systematically investigated.

697.prez_name: Preparation and Characterization of Poly (meta-phenylene isophthalamide) Microporous Membranes by Coaxial Electrospinning
697.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
697.prez_abstract: Owing to their superior properties, especially high porosity and surface areas, porous fibers and membranes with ultrafine size have received widespread attentions in the fields of tissue engineering, filtration, catalysis, electronics, etc. In the present study, poly (meta-phenylene isophthalamide, PMIA) fibrous membranes with fatty acids encapsulated are first fabricated by coaxial electrospinning. After the removal of inner fatty acids by hot ethanol extraction, sandwich-structured PMIA membranes with spongy porous interlayer but compact surfaces are obtained. The microstructure of the resulting PMIA membranes are characterized by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) and confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM). Besides, their thermal behaviors are also investigated by using a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA). The prepared microporous membranes with excellent thermal resistance performance are expected to have wide prospects for high temperature applications.

698.prez_name: Pyrolysis of Agricultural Waste to Form Nano-structures of SiC and Si3N4
698.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
698.prez_authors: Edward  Gorzkowski, Syed  Qadri, Ramasis  Goswami, Jerry  Feng, Bhakta  Rath
698.prez_abstract: Globally, consumption of rice, wheat, sorghum, etc. is increasing and consequently large quantities of agricultural waste are generated.  The waste are usually disposed of by incineration, which creates air pollution in the form of ash and fine silica particles, which are toxic.  Additionally, Silicon Carbide (SiC) and Silicon Nitride (Si<SUB>3</SUB>N<SUB>4</SUB>) nanowires and nanorods have attracted much interest because of their potentially novel physical, thermal, and optical properties.  In this paper, we will demonstrate that large quantities of the nanostructures of SiC and Si<SUB>3</SUB>N<SUB>4</SUB> can be obtained from agricultural waste such as rice husks, wheat husks, and sorghum leaves by controlled conditions of temperature and surrounding atmosphere.   Using x-ray diffraction, SEM, TEM, and Raman Spectroscopy, we will show the simultaneous formation of carbon nanotubes and nanorod/nanowires.  The separation of these nanostructures from the extraneous by-products will be discussed and the use of graphite and nano-particles to improve the yield of nano-structures.

699.prez_name: SiCO Aerogels and their Performance in Environmental and Energy Applications
699.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
699.prez_abstract: We report synthesis of polymer derived silicon oxycarbide (SiCO) aerogels, their microstructural characterization and performance in environmental and energy applications. Our process consists of reacting siloxane precursors containing Si-H bonds with cross-linkers bearing vinyl groups using a platinum catalyst. The hydrosilylation reaction in diluted solutions (80-95 vol%) converts the polysiloxanes into aerogels after supercritical drying in CO<SUB>2</SUB>. Aerogels are transformed via thermal treatment in controlled atmospheres into SiCO ceramics aerogels. In addition, we augment the chemical synthesis by various treatments to tailor microstructural and chemical properties of aerogels. We characterize the aerogels’ specific surface area, nanoparticle size, pore size distribution, average pore size and total porosity. We emphasize the microstructural tailoring by heat treatment atmosphere and additional post-synthesis methods. We also study the potential applications of the aerogels, specifically the effects of different microstructures on their properties.

700.prez_name: Size Effects from Nanoindention to Microindentation in Microcrystalline and Nanocrystalline Ceramics
700.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
700.prez_authors: James A Wollmershauser, Boris N. Feigelson, Edward P Gorzkowski, Kathryn J Wahl
700.prez_abstract: The application of modified slip-distance theory to observations of size effects in metals suggests that hardness varies significantly with indent size when the indent size and grain size are within an order of magnitude of each other. However, simulations based on this theory also predict that small grained materials will appear to have a constant hardness and no indentation size effect (ISE) when indentations are large. Extrapolation implies that nanocrystalline materials will only demonstrate ISE during nanoindentation. The present work explores these concepts with new nanocrystalline ceramics which have average grain sizes as small as 28nm and demonstrate increasing hardness with decreasing grain size upon microindentation. Nanoindentation of microcrystalline ceramics and these new nanocrystalline ceramics reveal similar ISE trends when the indent size is similar-to or smaller than the crystallite size. However, the mechanical responses become distinct when the indent size is orders of magnitude larger than the grain size.

701.prez_name: Solution Based and Electrically Assisted Techniques for Formation of Graphene Oxide Coatings
701.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
701.prez_authors: Clovis  Weisbart, Srini  Raghavan, Krishna   Muralidharan, Barrett  Potter
701.prez_abstract: In this presentation, work carried out on the formation of graphene oxide (GO) films on electrically conductive substrates using a combination of electrophoretic deposition (EPD) and electrocoagulation (EC) techniques will be discussed. Specifically, films that were deposited from GO based aqueous dispersions using an electrochemical setup in which copper was usually used as the anode. The key experimental variables were dispersion pH (2-7), applied voltage (2-10V) and deposition time (10 seconds – 10 minutes).  The films were characterized by Raman Spectroscopy, X-ray Diffraction and Atomic Force Microscopy to gain information on composition, thickness, morphology, and surface coverage.

702.prez_name: Stress-induced Synthesis and Processing of Functionally Designed Nanomaterials
702.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
702.prez_abstract: Previous work on structural control and engineering of nanomaterials has been conducted largely at ambient pressure and relies on chemical methods through specific chemical or physical interactions. Here, I show a new Stress-Induced Fabrication method that uses mechanical compressive force applied to nanoparticles to induce structural phase transition and coalescence of nanoparticle assemblies to achieve precisely controlled structures and tunable properties. By manipulating nanoparticle coupling through external pressure, a reversible change in their assemblies and properties can be achieved. Additionally, the external pressure can also force these nanoparticles into contact and coalesce, forming1-3D nanostructures.  Through stress induced nanoparticle assembly, materials engineering and synthesis become remarkably flexible with morphology or architecture readily tuned to produce desirable properties.Sandia National Laboratories is a multi-program laboratory managed and operated by Sandia Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Lockheed Martin Corporation, for the U.S. Department of Energy’s National Nuclear Security Administration under contract DE-AC04-94AL85000.

703.prez_name: Synthesis of Magnéli Phases Nano-titanium Suboxides by Thermal Plasma
703.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
703.prez_authors: Baoqiang   Xu, Yousef  Mohassab, Yuanpei   Lan, Hong Yong   Sohn
703.prez_abstract: Anatase TiO<SUB>2</SUB> (< 44 µm) and titanic acid, H<SUB>2</SUB>TiO<SUB>3</SUB> (< 500 nm), were used as precursors to synthesize nano-titanium suboxides under different gaseous atmospheres in thermal plasma. The phases, particle size and morphology of product samples were analyzed by means of XRD, SEM and TEM. When the precursor was anatase TiO<SUB>2</SUB>, the crystal phase or particle size (5-50 μm spherical particles) did not change much after plasma processing under H<SUB>2</SUB>/Ar atmosphere. But when titanic acid was used as the precursor, bright blue to black spherical particles dominated by Magnéli phases (Ti<SUB>n</SUB>O<SUB>2n−1</SUB>, where n is an integer between three and ten) with particle size < 50 nm were obtained. TEM image showed disorder and defects in the crystal structure. The products of plasma processing were compared with the products prepared in a high temperature tube furnace under different H<SUB>2</SUB>/Ar atmospheres.

704.prez_name: Synthesis, Processing and Characterization of Oxide-Metal Exchange-Coupled Powder and Bulk 3D Nanocomposites for Permanent Magnetic Applications
704.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
704.prez_authors: Aleksey  Volodchenkov, Yasuhiro  Kodera, Javier  Garay
704.prez_abstract: Permanent magnets (PMs) are essential to a variety of current and future devices, causing interest in improving PM performance. A promising approach to improved PMs is exchange-coupling between hard and soft magnetic phases. This research presents a route to produce exchange-coupled nanocomposite SrFe12O19-Co PMs. In order to achieve a fine degree of mixing between the hard and soft phases required for effective exchange-coupling, soft phase precursor is precipitated onto SrFe12O19 flakes. The synthesized nanocomposite powder outperforms the energy product of SrFe12O19 powder by 162%. To avoid grain growth attributed from slow heating rates of traditional sintering techniques, core-shell SrFe12O19-Co nanocomposite powders are processed into bulk samples through Current Activated Pressure Assisted Densification (CAPAD). This processing route produces bulk SrFe12O19-Co nanocomposite material with a 70% improvement in energy product compared to the bulk SrFe12O19. First order reversal curve (FORC) and recoil loop analysis is used to provide evidence of exchange-coupling.

705.prez_name: Tailored Carbide Powder Morphologies:  Synthesis and Mechanisms of Formation
705.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
705.prez_abstract: Transition metal carbides such as tantalum carbide (TaC), hafnium carbide (HfC), zirconium carbide (ZrC), and niobium carbide (NbC) are classified as ultra-high temperature ceramics (UHTCs) due to their extreme melting temperatures. In this project, we are exploring the possibility of controlling the particle morphology of transition metal carbides through dopant incorporation. Powder samples have been synthesized using a solvothermal method. We have observed promising cubic-faceted sharply-edged particles in TaC:15Y (15 at% yttrium), TaC:10Zr (10 at% zirconium) and ZrC:10Ta (10 at% tantalum) under scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with sizes typically ranging from 50 to 100 nm. We believe that the dopants are effective in modifying the thermodynamic surface energies of the powders and the growth kinetics during synthesis. Characterization has been performed for assessing the changes in local geometry at the atomic scale under high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM).

706.prez_name: Two-stage Sintering of Nano-sized Yttria Stabilized Zirconia with Polymer Sphere Generated Porosity
706.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
706.prez_authors: Edward  Gorzkowski, Scooter D Johnson, James  Wollmershauser, Stephanie  Wimmer
706.prez_abstract: It is known that defects, such as grain boundaries and solute cations reduce the lattice thermal conductivity of materials by scattering phonons. However, these defects have little influence on the radiative component of thermal conductivity. To reduce this component, one must consider photonic mechanisms where differences in the refractive index (due to pores) are most successful in reflecting radiation.  However, the size and shape of the pores must be tailored in order to maintain mechanical integrity. One method to create this desirable microstructure ( i.e., small grain size with large pores) would be to control the pore size through a polymer sphere burnout followed by a two stage sintering process, i.e., short dwell at high temperature followed by quickly quenching to a lower temperature for a longer dwell. The processing steps needed to make the microstructure will be discussed, as well as, the resultant thermal conductivity.

707.prez_name: Van der Waals Epitaxial Strain in Soft Inorganic Thin Films
707.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
707.prez_abstract: Suggested by computational/theoretically work, strain could lead to interestingly either gradual or abrupt shifts of physical properties in a plenty of halides and chalcogenides van der Waals (vdW) solids and non-vdW solids. For elastic strain engineering of either quantum well lasing films, electrochemical electrolytes, electronic logic components or multiferroic perovskites in traditionally mechanically hard materials, a very common and effective approach is by conventional covalent/ionic epitaxial strain. If we want to reproduce the success of the elastic strain engineering achieved in conventional covalent/ionic epitaxy to  halides and chalcogenides vdW solids and non-vdW solids, two fundamental questions arise: (1) can we achieve significant strains via vdW epitaxy and how? (2) If there are significant strains built up in vdW epitaxy, what could the relaxation mechanisms be? In our report, by proposing growing thin films with low shear moduli and heavy elements, we explore the possibility to achieve significant vdW epitaxial strains.

708.symp_name: Controlled Synthesis, Processing, and Applications of Structural and Functional Nanomaterials
708.prez_authors: Ricardo H. R. Castro, Nazia  Nafzin
708.prez_abstract: Designed dopants prone to segregation to boundaries have been proposed to lower excess energies, increasing stability against coarsening and enabling the nanostructural features to survive high temperature processing and operational environments. It has been theoretically proposed that the grain boundary energy of a material can eventually zero as a function of dopant concentration, signifying negligible driving force for growth – an infinitely stable nanomaterial. In this work we use highly sensitive microcalorimetry to experimentally measure the absolute grain boundary energy of gadolinium doped nanocrystalline zirconia as a function of grain size and show that the energy can indeed reach a quasi-zero energy state (0.05 J.m-2) when a critical grain boundary dopant enrichment is achieved. This thermodynamic condition leads to unprecedented coarsening resistance, but is a temperature dependent function; since increasing temperatures deplete the grain boundary as the dopant dissolves back in the crystalline bulk.
