935.prez_name: A Multiscale Modeling Study of the Onset of Flow Localization in Irradiated Iron
935.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
935.prez_authors: Moon  Rhee, Nathan  Barton, Tom  Arsenlis, Jaime  Marian
935.prez_abstract: Low temperature irradiation of crystalline materials is known to result in hardening and loss of ductility. In bcc metals, this mechanical property degradation is caused by the interaction of in-grown dislocations with small irradiation defects. In this work, we present a multi scale model encompassing molecular dynamics, dislocation dynamics, crystal plasticity, and finite element simulations of bcc Fe containing various concentrations of dislocation loops produced by irradiation at room temperature. At high defect densities, the simulations reveal a transition from homogenous to highly localized deformation, while, above it, plastic flow proceeds heterogeneously, creating defect-depleted channels as a principal signature of softening. These simulations are then used to calibrate a tensorial crystal plasticity model capable of reaching strains in excess of 10% for linkage with the engineering scale. The calibrated crystal plasticity model is then used in FE simulations of polycrystalline irradiated Fe systems, and the results compared to experiments.

936.prez_name: An Approach to Develop Hansel-spittel Constitutive Equation during Ingot Breakdown Operation of Low Alloy Steels
936.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
936.prez_authors: Kanwal  Chadha, davood  shahriari, Mohammad  Jahazi
936.prez_abstract: The control of the final quality of a forged product requires an in-depth comprehension of the quality of initial cast ingot. Hot workability is an important property which can be evaluated by variation of strain, strain rate, and temperature. Modeling of the forging process always needs to define constitutive models for the material involved. In this study, 42CrMo steel with dendritic microstructure was used to generate the flow stress curves. In order to provide accurate predictions of the thermal and mechanical parameters in the actual ingot breakdown operation, hot compression tests were carried out at uniform temperatures ranging from 1050°C to 1200°C and strain rates of 0.25s-1 to 2s-1. Finally, Hansel-Spittel law was developed to represent the dependency of the material flow stress on strain, strain rate and temperature. FE Simulation results reveal that the model is able to predict the adiabatic heating during deformation.

937.prez_name: Collaborative Mechanisms of Plastic Deformation in Polycrystals : Experimental Studies, Quantification and Modeling
937.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation

938.prez_name: Collecting In-situ HR-EBSD and DIC Data Simultaneously Stamping a Pattern Semi-transparent to Electrons
938.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
938.prez_authors: Timothy J. Ruggles, Jacob D. Hochhalter, Andrew  Cannon, Geoffery F. Bomarito
938.prez_abstract: Micro digital image correlation (DIC) and high resolution electron backscatter diffraction (HR-EBSD) both provide important information concerning the deformation of  a material, DIC providing total deformation and HR-EBSD recovering elastic strain and dislocation content.  Coupled, these techniques would provide complete state variable information for plasticity models.  However, current methods of applying a pattern for DIC, such as lithography, focused ion beam damage, etchants and paint, render a surface unsuitable for EBSD.  To circumvent this incompatibility, a urethane rubber stamp is used to apply a pattern that is semi-transparent to electrons.  The resulting pattern provides sufficient contrast for image correlation without degrading the collected EBSD patterns.  Stamped micro-DIC patterns also have the advantage of being extremely low cost and allowing the application of the same optimized pattern every time, making the technique highly repeatable.  Preliminary results of this hybrid HR-EBSD/micro-DIC technique are presented here.

939.prez_name: Comparison of Strain Measurement Techniques for Tension Testing of Fine Nitinol Wires
939.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
939.prez_authors: Janet L. Gbur, Benjamin  Palmer, John J.  Lewandowski
939.prez_abstract: The challenge of measuring strain in fine wire is the ability to accurately record deformation with calculations from crosshead motion or standard clip-on extensometry. Crosshead motion calculations include compliance throughout the load train and in fine wires can significantly overstate the actual strain present in the sample. Clip-on extensometers, for most sample forms, can eliminate this problem by tracking strain between knife edges of the device which are attached to the sample. However, the weight of a clip-on extensometer is too large for fine wires contributing to erroneous results. Advances in imaging technology have provided an alternative in non-contact extensometers. In these systems, high resolution video cameras track fiduciaries placed on the sample, measuring strain between the marks. In this study, a novel system with the capability to track localized strain inhomogeneity using multiple fiduciaries on Nitinol superelastic wires is used and compared to crosshead motion calculations.

940.prez_name: Comparisons of 3D Orientation Mapping with Simulation Using a Spectral Method for Tensile Deformation of Zr
940.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
940.prez_authors: Anthony  Rollett, Jon  Lind, Reeju  Pokharel, Robert  Suter
940.prez_abstract: Spectral, image-based methods that use Fourier transforms for solving elastic, viscoplastic and elasto-viscoplastic problems are now available to complement finite element methods.  The resolution available permits many aspects of heterogeneity in deformation to be investigated.  Materials can also be orientation mapped non-destructively in 3D thanks to penetrating radiation at synchrotrons, which permits microstructural evolution to be characterized.  High Energy X-ray Diffraction Microscopy (HEDM) is a prime example of this approach.  Examples are given of 3D printed metals, 3D studies of twin creation during grain growth as it affects grain boundary engineering (GBE), orientation change and gradients in tensile tests of copper, fatigue crack initiation in superalloys, spatially varying strain and orientation gradients in steel, and tin whisker formation. Here we focus on experiment-simulation comparisons of tensile deformation in Zr.

941.prez_name: Correlating Dislocation Configuration to Deformation Behavior in Additive Manufactured IN718 and Ti-6Al-4V
941.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
941.prez_authors: Yung Suk Jeremy Yoo, Todd   Book, Michael D. Sangid, Josh  Kacher
941.prez_abstract: Additive manufactured materials show great promise in rapid machining of complex parts, but their long-term deformation behavior remains poorly understood. This study focuses on correlating deformation analysis across length scales using digital image correlation (DIC), electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD)-based dislocation density mapping, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) in IN718 and Ti-6Al-4V. EBSD-based dislocation mapping and DIC analysis were used to identify regions of interest, such as strain accumulation and high dislocation concentrations, in cyclically deformed samples. Focused ion-beam (FIB) machining was used for selective sample fabrication for in depth dislocation characterization. Special emphasis was given to dislocation configurations found near twin boundaries in IN718 samples, as these have been highlighted as possible crack initiation sites in fatigued samples. Discussion will focus on insights into the mechanics of crack formation as well as the effectiveness of using macroscales deformation mapping techniques to understand local dislocation configurations.

942.prez_name: Deformation at Grain Boundaries in Oligocrystalline Metals
942.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
942.prez_abstract: Deformation in polycrystalline metals is highly heterogeneous due to the presence of interconnected grain boundaries and triple junctions as well as three-dimensional grain constraint.  In this talk, we will present our recent work on plastic deformation in oligocrystalline metallic samples where grain constraint is significantly reduced.  In this case, the observed local deformation heterogeneity can be attributed to grain boundaries or triple junctions, and correlated with the crystallographic character of these interfaces.  The fundamental understanding gained will be critical for establishing quantitative structure-property relationships of bulk polycrystalline materials.

943.prez_name: Deformation History of Individual Grains in Polycrystalline Mg-Y by In-situ 3D-XRD
943.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
943.prez_authors: Leyun  Wang, Zhonghe  Huang, Jun-Sang  Park, Sangbong  Yi, Erica  Lilleodden
943.prez_abstract: Addition of small amount of Y significantly improves the ductility of Mg alloys. It has been proposed that solute Y can make non-basal slip modes and uncommon twin modes more active in Mg. However, this effect has not been quantified so far. In this work, we tackle this problem by using a three dimensional X-ray diffraction (3D-XRD) technique available at the Advanced Photon Source. Polycrystalline Mg-3wt%Y tensile specimens were incrementally deformed with 3D-XRD characterization for each load step. From the 3D-XRD data, individual grains in the bulk specimen are analyzed for their crystal orientation, center of mass, and stress tensor. Activation of slip systems and twin systems are inferred from grain rotation and nucleation of new grains, and their critical resolved shear stress (CRSS) can also be estimated. The result will be compared with pure Mg to understand the effect of Y on the mesoscale deformation of Mg.

944.prez_name: Deformation Mechanisms during High Speed Impaction of Ag Nanoparticles
944.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
944.prez_authors: Tushar  Chitrakar, Michael F. Becker, John W. Keto, Desiderio  Kovar
944.prez_abstract: Laser ablation of a microparticle aerosol (LAMA) is an efficient process for producing patterned, nanoparticulate thick films by high speed impaction of a nanoparticle (NP) aerosol. Molecular dynamics (MD) is an ideal method to study the deformation mechanisms that occur during NP impaction because the high strain rates that occur during impaction can be analyzed directly on relevant timescales (1 - 500 ps). In this paper, we report MD simulations of a silver NP(2 – 9 nm) impacting the Ag(001) surface at a range of velocities (10 - 1500 m•s-1). Three mechanisms are identified that play an important role in determining the final nanostructure following impaction.  These include energy driven boundary migration, plastic deformation by the motion of partial dislocations (twins), and amorphization.  The influence of particle size and impaction velocity on the relative importance of each of these mechanisms and their role in determining the final nanostructure is discussed.

945.prez_name: Design of  Heterogeneous Nano-microstructure for Improved Mechanical Properties
945.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
945.prez_authors: Mehdi  Hamid Vishkasougheh, Hao  Lyu, Hussein  Zbib
945.prez_abstract: The heterogeneous nature of microstructure, like grain size spatial distribution, can have pronounced effect on strength and ductility. Typically, a homogenized grain size is assumed to affect the strength like in the Hall-Petch model. Here, the influence of heterogeneous microstructure with both nano and micron size grains is investigated by applying a dislocation-based multi-scale framework, including discrete dislocation dynamic, continuum dislocation dynamic and a visco-plastic self-consistent model. In order to capture the grain size effect, a stress/strain gradient theory is implemented. Different distributions of nano-layers composed of nano-grains are imbedded into an otherwise homogenous microstructure composed of micro-grains, resulting into a gradient nano-microstructure. Several simulations with various grain size spatial distributions were performed for microstructures with different number of nano-layers, and the results are compared with homogenized structures. The results show that the heterogeneous nano-microstructure can have improved mechanical properties compared to the equivalent homogenous microstructure.

946.prez_name: Developing a Crystal Plasticity Model Based on the Discrete Element Method
946.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
946.prez_authors: Agnieszka  Truszkowska, Qin  Yu, P. Alex  Greaney, T. Matthew  Evans, Jamie J. Kruzic
946.prez_abstract: Material failures due to plastic and/or creep deformation occur by the emergence of necking, microvoids, and cracks at heterogeneities in the material microstructure. While many traditional deformation modeling approaches have difficulty capturing these emergent phenomena, the discrete element method (DEM) has proven very effective for the simulation of materials whose properties and response vary over multiple spatial scales, e.g., granular materials. The DEM framework has the central advantage that it naturally captures the heterogeneity and geometric frustration inherent to deformation processes. While DEM has recently been adapted successfully for modeling the fracture of brittle solids, to date it has not been used for simulating metal deformation. In this paper we present our progress in reformulating DEM to model the key elastic, plastic, and visco-plastic deformation characteristics of FCC polycrystals to create an entirely new crystal plasticity modeling methodology well-suited for the incorporation of heterogeneities and simulation of emergent phenomena.

947.prez_name: Development of Many-body Potentials for Al-TiN Nanolayered Composites
947.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
947.prez_authors: Paul  Simanjuntak, Ridwan  Sakidja, Caizhi  Zhou
947.prez_abstract: We are developing an interatomic potential that is suitable for the ternary system of Al-TiN. The ternary system has garnered a great interest especially due to the potential use of Al-TiN nanolayered composites.   Previous works have primarily concentrated solely on the binary systems of Al-Ti and Ti-N by using the Embedded Atom Model (EAM) or Modified Embedded Atom Model (MEAM) and so far, there has been no potential development work reported on the more complex ternary system.  We employed the force-fitting code Potfit and the large sampling of force, stress & energy  calculation results from the ab-initio molecular dynamics simulations  (as implemented in VASP) to optimize the analytical forms of the many-body potentials. The deformation behavior of the nanolayered composites will be further assessed through the classic molecular dynamics simulations and discrete dislocation dynamics method.

948.prez_name: Dislocation Density-based Modelling of Plastic Deformation of Lath Martensite
948.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
948.prez_authors: Taku  Niino, Shoichi  Nambu, Junya  Inoue, Toshihiko  Koseki
948.prez_abstract: A dislocation density-based model of plastic deformation of lath martensite is proposed in the present by following the approach by Kocks and Mecking. The model takes into account of the early formation of dislocation cell structure during plastic deformation and the effect of solute carbon, both of which are the typical characteristics of lath martensite. Because of its low ductility, the work hardening behavior of lath martensite and effects of solute carbon have not been clarified. In this study, multilayered steel composite being consisted of martenste layer and ductile stainless steel layers was employed to achieve sufficient plastic strain in martensite layer. Thereby, the work hardening behaviors and changes in dislocation density in several martensitic steels with different carbon contents up to 0.30 mass% were investigated, and the model was evaluated.

949.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
949.prez_authors: Ricky D Wyman, David  Fullwood, Robert  Wagoner, Eric  Homer
949.prez_abstract: Grain boundaries are known to nucleate dislocations as one of several stress accommodation mechanisms. Numerous publications detail atomistic tensile tests used to characterize dislocations emitted from the grain boundaries, though these are typically limited to a uniaxial tensile stress applied perpendicular to the grain boundary plane. We generalize these tests by performing a limited subset of triaxial stress tests on a single grain boundary. A map of the different slip systems activated show a systematic response as a function of the applied stress state. These conditions indicate the influence of non-Schmid effects for dislocation nucleation at grain boundaries. The criterion for nucleation appears to be a function of both slip system and grain boundary geometry.

950.prez_name: Effects of Martensite and Ferrite Properties on Hole Expansion Ratio of Dual Phase 980 Steel
950.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
950.prez_authors: K.S.  Raghavan, Xiaohua  Hu, Xin  Sun
950.prez_abstract: The role of microstructure heterogeneity on damage occurrence during hole punching and subsequent hole expansion/extrusion is evaluated using a traditionally-processed dual phase 980 grade and a variant that involves tempering the martensite to minimize the strength difference between the two phases.  Extensive characterizations of the individual phase mechanical properties are carried out using in-situ high energy X-ray diffraction (HEXRD) and with nano-indentation techniques.   True stress versus strain curve is developed at large strains by accumulative rolling to facilitate accurate trimming simulations.  3D X-ray tomography is carried out to characterize the punching induced damages at the sheared edge, and interrupted trimming and interrupted hole extrusion/expansion tests are also carried out for model validations.  The validated microstructure-based integrated punching and hole expansion simulation framework is then used to examine the influences of various aspects of the microstructural features on the edge damage and subsequent HER of the dual phase material.

951.prez_name: Experimental, Analytical & Numerical Studies on the Relation between R-value & Earing Profile in Deep Drawing
951.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
951.prez_authors: Soheil  Bakhshivash, Bagher  MohammadSadeghi, Farhad  Rahimi, Meysam  Haghshenas
951.prez_abstract: Numerous investigations have been made to determine the correlation between R-value and the earing profile as a consequence of anisotropic behavior in deep drawing. Although the analytical formulas are used to predict this phenomenon, they are not accurate due to the assumptions made. In the present study, the relation is numerically investigated and a comparison with analytical and experimental results are made. Deep drawing is performed for 304 and 304-L stainless steels to predict the R-value using the analytical formulas. Finite element analysis is employed to simulate the process with random R-values. A curve is fitted to the earing profiles obtained from the analysis to develop a numerical formula. The accuracy of the analytical and numerical approaches is validated by comparing their predicted R-value to the exact R-value calculated from the tensile test. It is observed that the numerical formula is much more accurate than the analytical one.

952.prez_name: Exploring the Effects of Grain Size on Dislocation Interactions and Hardening Using Phase Field Dislocation Dynamics
952.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
952.prez_authors: William J. Joost, Abigail  Hunter, Irene J. Beyerlein
952.prez_abstract:
Dislocation motion and interaction with obstacles largely controls the mechanical behavior of materials; however, the complexity of these processes presents challenges for both experimental and computational techniques. In this study, we apply phase field dislocation dynamics (PFDD) simulations and report the interaction of dislocations with grain boundaries and other dislocations, providing insight into the hardening behavior of FCC metals. Combined with insight from the experimental literature, we describe the relationships between grain size, features of the stacking fault energy surface, partial dislocation activity, and ultimately mechanical behavior in several FCC metals. We further demonstrate how dislocation characteristics strongly affect the behavior of nano-crystalline metals and the interactions between dislocations, with significant implications for materials design. 
This work was supported in part by Los Alamos National Laboratory’s Institute of Materials Science.

953.prez_name: Exploring the Energy Landscape for Dislocation Motion in Tantalum
953.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
953.prez_abstract: Motion of screw dislocations control many important features of plastic deformation in BCC materials. Consequently, numerous studies have focused on understanding the stability of the various core structures, namely the easy-core (E), the hard-core (H) and the soft-core (S). Using results from ab initio DFT calculations for tantalum I show that the small periodic supercell sizes used in DFT calculations necessitate careful accounting for non-linear elasticity and that, once the latter is indeed accounted for, dislocation core energies can be extracted with very high precision. We predict that the ground state of the screw dislocation in tantalum is the non-polarized E-core at pressures from 0 to 7 Mbar. Together with an in depth analysis of the relative stability of the H, E and S-core structures, we are able construct a potential energy landscape from ab initio calculations that can describe the motion of screw dislocations in tantalum.

954.prez_name: Formability of Magnesium Alloy AZ31B from Room Temperature to 150° C
954.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
954.prez_authors: Isaac  Chelladurai, Andrew  Orme, Michael  Miles, David  Fullwood, John E Carsley, Raja  K Mishra
954.prez_abstract: Magnesium AZ31B sheets, 2mm thick, were stretch formed using a 100 mm diameter punch at room temperature and subsequent increments from 25°C - 150°C. Surface strains were measured using a digital image correlation method, for a quantification of biaxial strain. Finite element modeling was also used to validate the strains. The punch height vs load curve was found to be the same for temperatures of 25°C and for 50°C. From 75°C the load for a given punch height began to decrease. This seems to indicate a change in deformation mechanism between 50°C and 75°C. Examination of the microstructures of strained specimens revealed that twin density was similar for 25°C and 50°C, but less for 75°C and higher. Electron Backscatter Diffraction (EBSD) was used to quantify features of the microstructure in the as-received and the strained specimens. Evidence of a relatively low temperature transition from twinning to slip will be presented.

955.prez_name: Generalised Relations between Microstructure and Yield Stress
955.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
955.prez_authors: Marius  Gintalas, Pedro Eduardo Jose  Rivera-Díaz-del-Castillo
955.prez_abstract: The paper presents generalised equations describing relations between microstructure and yield stress in pearlite, marteniste and nano-structured bainite. The presented approach is based on a single master equation which takes into account strengthening contributions from various sources of microstructure. Each strengthening term of the proposed master equation is specified for the considered microstructures. Grain boundary strengthening is seen as a key factor as a result of the hierarchy of the microstructures. Hall-Petch-type equations are employed to reveal grain boundary strengthening mechanisms. An attempt to demonstrate the influence of prior-austenite grains, packets and laths sizes on the total grain boundary strengthening component is presented. Finite element simulation of idealised morphologies and structures is performed as an attempt to capture the relation between grain boundaries and yield strength, and to compare it with available expressions.

956.prez_name: Grain-scale Validations of BCC Crystal Plasticity Model with Single and Polycrystalline Experiments
956.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
956.prez_authors: Hojun  Lim, Corbett  Battaile, Jay  Carroll
956.prez_abstract: Understanding the fundamental plastic behavior of polycrystalline metals using computational models requires quantitative validations with experiments. In this work, a physically-based BCC crystal plasticity finite element (CP-FE) model is used to simulate plastic deformation of single and oligocrystal tantalum specimens and the model predictions are quantitatively compared with different grain scale experiments. An experimental technique combining in-situ electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD), high-resolution digital image correlation (HR-DIC), and profilometry, was used to map intergranular crystal rotation, surface strain fields, and out-of-plane topographic distortion, respectively. The model is then used to investigate microstructural variability in stress-strain responses and local stress fields at the notch tip of polycrystalline tantalum specimens. It is shown that the CP-FE predictions of grain scale variability agree reasonably well with experimental measurements.

957.prez_name: High Throughput Experimental Exploration of Structure-processing-property Relationships in Structural Metal Alloys
957.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
957.prez_abstract: This paper describes some of the recent advances in our group in the area of high throughput observations of multiscale process-structure-property linkages in advanced structural metal alloys. These new protocols are aimed at supporting rapid screening of the extremely large material and process spaces needed in accelerated design, development, and deployment of materials in high performance products. Although much of the core materials activity is focused on the hierarchical process-structure-property relationships in advanced metals, the protocols employed in current literature usually incur very high cost and effort. The protocols presented here  purposefully impose controlled gradients of thermomechanical deformation histories, document microstructure evolution at salient locations in the sample, and document the corresponding local mechanical responses using spherical indentation techniques. In particular, the indentation techniques are capable of extracting indentation stress-strain curves which expressly relate the local microstructure to its mechanical response.

958.prez_name: Influence of Adjoining Twin Pairs on Subsequent Twinning and Detwinning in HCP Metals
958.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
958.prez_authors: M.  Arul Kumar, Irene  J Beyerelein, Rodney J McCabe, Carlos N Tome
958.prez_abstract: Twins in HCP polycrystals nucleate from grain-boundaries and propagate to span the entire grain. Twins usually terminate at grain-boundaries and these twins are referred to as isolated-twins. Post-mortem characterization also shows adjoining-twin-pairs (ATPs) where twins from neighboring-grains appear to be connected at a common grain-boundary. Simulations show that simultaneous twin nucleation from the grain boundary into each of the neighboring grains or transmission of a twin from one grain into the neighboring-grain may lead to the formation of ATPs. Here we employ automated electron-backscatter-diffraction(EBSD) and full-field Fast-Fourier-Transform(FFT) modeling to study the influence of ATPs on subsequent twinning. EBSD establishes the following observations: (i) twin thicknesses at grain-boundaries are larger for APTs compared to isolated-twins; (ii) the tendency for detwinning during cyclic loading is less for ATPs compared to isolated-twins. The FFT model explains and provides a deeper understanding of these observations in connection with the predicted twin local stresses.

959.prez_name: Influence of Grain Size and Crystallographic Orientation on Localized Plastic Strain Distribution in Polycrystalline Beta Titanium Alloys
959.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
959.prez_authors: Vahid  Khademi, Thomas R Bieler, Masahiko  IKEDA, Carl J Boehlert
959.prez_abstract: It is well-known that the elastic and plastic responses of polycrystalline materials to applied load is generally heterogeneous, especially at the micro scale. Understating the plastic deformation behavior is essential for studying the failure mode of material. The plastic deformation behavior of beta titanium alloys is investigated at the micro scale using in-situ SEM tensile loading in conjunction with EBSD mapping to study the localized plastic deformation.  Two beta titanium alloys are compared: Ti-13Cr-1Fe-3Al and TIMETAL®21S. The relationship between plastic strain levels and misorientation was quantified at the grain scale. The influence of parent grain crystallographic orientation and grain size on localized plastic strain distribution are examined. The results revealed that larger grains have locally more contribution in accommodating the plastic deformation than small grains at higher strain levels. Furthermore, it was observed that the effect of parent orientation becomes more significant on heterogeneous deformation with increasing the plastic strains.

960.prez_name: Insights on Shear Band Behavior in BMGMCs from FFT-based Continuum Modeling
960.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
960.prez_authors: Stephen  Niezgoda, Nichael  Gibbons, Emmanuelle  Marquis, Katharine  Flores, Wolfgang  Windl
960.prez_abstract: In bulk metallic glass-matrix composites (BMGMCs), the nature of shear bands and their interaction with the crystalline phase reinforcement play an important role in the overall mechanical behavior of the composite. However, the rapid timescales involved with their formation has posed a hindrance for experimentalists in studying the precise way in which they initiate and propagate in the amorphous matrix, and furthermore terminate at an adjacent interface. These phenomena will be examined here with fast Fourier transform (FFT) based continuum modeling, which makes it possible to simulate deformation in two-phase heterogeneous systems at higher spatial and temporal resolutions than that offered by traditional finite element methods given the same computational resources. We conduct a thorough analysis of the stress and strain evolution during shear banding in both phases of Zr-Ti-based composites and compare our results with characterization work on deformed microstructures obtained from experimental BMGMC tensile test specimens.

961.prez_name: Investigating the Heterogeneous Deformation of Polycrystalline Materials at the Mesoscale
961.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
961.prez_abstract: An experimental and analytical approach to investigate the mesoscale heterogeneous deformation of polycrystalline alloys is introduced. The deformation of the material surface at the microstructural length scale was continuously tracked during in-situ mechanical testing by a combination of scanning electron microscopy and digital image correlation (SEM-DIC). High-resolution displacement and strain fields were obtained by distortion-corrected two-dimensional DIC. Individual slip and twinning traces in the resulting full-field strain maps were successfully identified and correlated with the active deformation modes through the consideration of a combination of parameters, which will be discussed. Electron-backscattered diffraction (EBSD) with post-deformation serial sectioning provided crystallographic information in three-dimensions, enabling the investigation of subsurface microstructural effects on the observed surface displacements. The combined approaches of SEM-DIC, EBSD, and post-deformation microstructural reconstruction provided statistically significant information for analyzing the effect of microstructural features on the deformation modes as well as strain localization through statistical learning approaches.

962.prez_name: Investigation of Local Slip Heterogeneity in Al-Li Alloy 2195
962.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
962.prez_authors: Wesley A. Tayon, Roy  Crooks, Jacob  Hochhalter, John  Newman, Ashley  Spear
962.prez_abstract: Aluminum-lithium alloys are of interest to NASA launch vehicle programs due to their low density and high specific strength and stiffness compared to conventional Al alloys. However, these alloys are highly anisotropic and prone to intergranular failure. One plausible explanation is that planar slip leads to intense, highly localized stress concentrations at grain boundaries and failure occurs at grain pairs with the greatest slip incompatibility. The purpose of this study was to interrogate the inhomogeneous slip behavior of Al-Li alloy 2195 in the solution heat-treated only and peak-aged conditions at the mesoscale. High-resolution digital image correlation was performed in situ during tensile experiments to measure local strain heterogeneity. Grain-to-grain variations in strains were assessed in connection to strain localization at grain boundaries. Experimental results will be compared to crystal plasticity simulation results to provide a thorough analysis of slip heterogeneity in Al-Li alloys.

963.prez_name: Linking Nanoscale Deformation Mechanisms and Interfaces with Diffraction Profiles in Nanocrystalline Materials
963.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
963.prez_authors: Daniel   Foley, Shawn  Coleman, Mark  Tschopp, Garritt J Tucker
963.prez_abstract: Nanocrystalline materials exhibit many superior properties compared to their polycrystalline counterparts, making them desirable candidates for a variety of industrial and technological applications. Previous efforts, both experimental and computational, have shown that the properties of nanocrystalline metals are largely driven by crystalline interfaces, such as twins and grain boundaries. Utilizing atomistic simulations and virtual diffraction techniques we are able to isolate mechanistic differences as a function of microstructure and interfacial-driven phenomena. Furthermore, by leveraging non-local estimations of strain and rotation fields from the simulated microstructures, we demonstrate the role that grain morphology plays in determining driving mechanisms behind deformation and link that deformation activity to diffraction profiles. Our results provide insight into how diffraction and atomistics can be leveraged to provide a more complete understanding into the deformation mechanisms in nanocrystalline metals and provide a potential avenue to do so from experimentally available techniques.

964.prez_name: Measurement of Strain Localization during Creep of a Polycrystalline Superalloy Using SEM-based Digital Image Correlation
964.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
964.prez_authors: Connor E Slone, Michael J Mills
964.prez_abstract: High-temperature deformation of polycrystalline superalloys is a complicated process involving many possible mechanisms that depend on temperature, applied load, and microstructure. Coupling multi-scale material characterization to local mechanical behavior is essential to building and validating physics-based models for deformation in these materials with complex, heterogeneous microstructures. In this work, scanning electron microscopy digital image correlation (SEM-DIC) is employed with nanoscale hafnia speckles to measure local deformation at elevated temperatures. An ex situ technique is used to facilitate testing with low strain rates. Full-field strain maps are produced and compared to the underlying microstructure using EBSD (grain size, boundary misorientation), EDS (chemical composition and segregation), and ECCI (defect content). These measurements were performed on polycrystalline Inconel 740H and have shown strain localization around high angle grain boundaries, in contrast to low strain accumulation around twin boundaries and intragranular regions. The results directly link surface microstructure to local, heterogeneous creep deformation.

965.prez_name: Meso-scale Interactions between Bulk Dislocations and Grain Boundaries in FCC and BCC Metals
965.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
965.prez_authors: David  Fullwood, Landon  Hansen, HyukJong  Bong, Ricky  Wyman, Austin  Foster, Eric  Homer, Robert  Wagoner
965.prez_abstract: Understanding the interactions between grain boundaries (GB) and dislocations is critical to understanding how GBs affect strength and ductility of materials. Much is currently known about unitary dislocation interactions but in order to optimize microstructures for enhanced strength and ductility greater information is required about how bulk dislocation densities influence a material at the mesoscale. This work involves a collaborative effort to examine bulk dislocation densities and their interactions with GBs through a combination of a mesoscale super dislocation (SD) finite element model, cross-correlation EBSD characterization, and molecular dynamics simulations of GB-dislocation interactions. The MD simulations provide new insight into the possible interactions of different slip systems with the GB of interest. This paper will summarize the results of a series of experiments involving dislocation-GB interactions in bi- and oligocrystal Ta and Ni in order to develop the framework across both FCC and BCC materials.

966.prez_name: Microstructure and Mechanical Behavior of HCP/BCC Bulk Nanolaminate Composites Produced by Accumulative Roll Bonding
966.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
966.prez_authors: Nathan  Mara, Daniel  Savage, John  Carpenter, Rodney  McCabe, Thomas  Nizolek, Nan  Li, Sven  Vogel, Marko  Knezevic, Irene  Beyerlein
966.prez_abstract: Two-phase nanolaminate thin film composites have demonstrated an unusually broad number of desirable properties, such as high strength, high strain to failure, thermal stability, and resistance to light-ion radiation.  Recently we have shown that bi-phase HCP/BCC nanolaminates with individual layer thicknesses approaching 10 nm can be made via severe plastic deformation (SPD) in bulk sizes suitable for structural applications. Mechanical testing of these HCP/BCC nanolaminates shows exceptionally high strength and characterization via a suite of techniques including neutron diffraction, EBSD, and TEM indicates that the crystals are highly oriented.  While the cause of these unusual properties can easily be associated with a high density of bimetal interfaces, how the interfaces physically control microstructural evolution and macroscopic properties remains an area of intense research. This presentation highlights our modeling and experimental efforts to understand and link the evolution of the nanostructure, the interface properties, and preferred texture during the SPD process.

967.prez_name: Performance of Viscoplastic Self-Consistent Models in Reflecting Twin Activity in Mg Alloys
967.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
967.prez_authors: Devin  Adams, David  Fullwood, Marko  Knezevic, Stephen  Niezgoda, Irene  Beyerlein, Isaac  Chelladurai, Andrew  Orme
967.prez_abstract: This paper reports on a study to determine the underlying microstructure characteristics that most influence twin formation in Mg. A Viscoplastic Self-Consistent (VPSC) model provides a convenient predictive tool that can be compared with statistical experimental data. In order to obtain suitable data, multiple EBSD scans were taken of an AZ31 sheet strained to different levels. The resulting regions were studied to determine microstructure features associated with twin activity, and then compared with the results from predictions made by a VPSC model. Starting from the VPSC model developed by a team at Los Alamos National Laboratory, we assess the ability of various implementations to more correctly capture the underlying physics of twin formation.

968.prez_name: Plasticity-induced Restructuring of Nanocrystalline Grain Boundary Networks
968.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
968.prez_abstract: Nanocrystalline microstructures can evolve through plasticity mechanisms such as grain boundary migration and grain rotation.  We present coupled atomistic modeling and experimental tasks that aim to understand how the character and connectivity of grain boundaries changes with cyclic plastic strain.  First, we develop tools to fully characterize grain boundary networks in atomistic models and subsequently track their evolution during molecular dynamics simulations.  We tracked the grain boundary character distribution of nanocrystalline Al (grain sizes of 5 and 10 nm) during monotonic tension, cycling loading, and annealing, finding that higher temperature and smaller grain size resulted in increased evolution of the grain boundary network.  This work is complemented by sliding wear experiments which track wear damage and the evolution of surface microstructure in nanocrystalline Ni-W thin films (3 nm grain size).  These experiments connect contact load, sliding speed (related to surface temperature), and cycle number to sub-surface gradients in grain structure.

969.prez_name: Practical Methodology for Inverse Design Exploration of Fatigue Resistant Ti Alloys
969.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
969.prez_authors: David L McDowell, Matthew  Priddy, Jordan  Weaver, Noah  Paulson, Soumya  Mohan, Donald  Shih, Surya  Kalidindi
969.prez_abstract: We introduce a methodology for employing the crystal plasticity finite element method (CPFEM) to inform and calibrate a materials knowledge system (MKS) approach to efficiently explore local grain-level responses for polycrystalline alpha-beta Ti-64.  Responses of interest focus on cyclic plasticity and fatigue indicator parameters that serve as surrogate measures for driving force to form and grow microstructurally small cracks under cyclic loading, averaged over a finite process zone at the sub-grain/phase scale.  CPFEM analyses are also employed in collaboration with experimental characterization (e.g. EBSD) and spherical nanoindentation to quantify individual phase properties as well as effects of alpha-alpha grain boundaries and alpha-beta phase boundaries.  Anisotropic mechanical behaviors of individual phases are considered.  The established protocols for integrating CPFEM with MKS, spherical nanoindentation, and EBSD will be presented, along with a framework for inductive design exploration.

970.prez_name: Predicting the Bauschinger Effect in Aged Aluminum Alloys
970.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
970.prez_authors: Wei  Gan, Hyuk Jong  Bong, Hojun  Lim, Richard K. Boger, Frederic  Barlat, Robert H. Wagoner
970.prez_abstract: Three special wrought Al-Ge-Si alloys were designed and produced to ensure dislocation bypass strengthening without significant precipitate cutting/shearing. They were processed from the melt and solution heat treated and aged. Aging curves at various temperatures were established and corresponding precipitate conditions were measured using TEM. The role of non-shearable precipitates on the Bauschinger effect was revealed using novel, large-strain tension/compression tests. Precipitates were found to be at least twice as effective as grain boundaries as obstacles. The Bauschinger effect increases dramatically from the underaged to the peak aged condition and is constant thereafter. This behavior contrasts with the behavior of Al-Cu and commercial Al alloys. The Al-Ge-Si alloy response is simulated with three microstructural models, including a novel Super-Dislocation model, to reveal the origins of the Bauschinger effect in dilute precipitation-hardened / bypass alloys. The dominant mechanism is related to elastic inter-dislocation interactions.

971.prez_name: Prediction of the Mechanical Response of DP980 Steel Incorporating a Realistic RVE
971.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
971.prez_authors: Hyuk Jong  Bong, Hojun  Lim, Myoung-Gyu  Lee, David  Fullwood, Eric  Homer, Robert. H.  Wagoner
971.prez_abstract: A realistic representative volume element (RVE) for a dual phase steel was constructed based on known microstructural properties, contrary to the common practice of inferring hypothetical microstructural properties by back-fitting to macroscopic data using an assumed constitutive model and RVE. The new approach allows the assessment of the constitutive model itself by comparing RVE-predicted mechanical behavior with macro measurements, thus revealing the nature of the controlling micromechanisms. The finite element (FE) predictions of three constitutive models were compared with the measured stress-strain in the elastic-plastic transition region: 1) a standard continuum model for the RVE fit to macroscopic data, 2) a standard crystal plasticity (CP) model based on slip system geometry without discrete dislocation interactions, and 3) a Super Dislocation (SD) model similar to CP but including discrete dislocation interactions. The results reveal that dislocation interactions play a dominant role for the nonlinearity behavior in the elastic-plastic transition regime.

972.prez_name: Recent Progress in the Concurrent Atomistic-continuum Method and Its Applications to Nano- and Microscale Metal Plasticity
972.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
972.prez_authors: David L McDowell, Shuozhi  Xu, Liming  Xiong, Youping  Chen
972.prez_abstract: Metal plasticity involves irreversible microstructure rearrangement associated with nucleation, multiplication, interaction, and migration of dislocations. Long range elastic interactions between dislocations and other crystal defects are important to describe, along with the nonlocal nonlinear dislocation core field. These requirements necessitate multiscale modeling techniques where dislocation core effects are treated with atomistic resolution within systems at the submicron scale, beyond the scale at which molecular dynamics can be reasonably applied. One such approach is the concurrent atomistic-continuum (CAC) method, which admits motion of dislocations and intrinsic stacking faults through a lattice while employing an underlying interatomic potential as the only constitutive relation. Here, we review recent progress in the CAC method and its applications to a number of dislocation-mediated phenomena in metal plasticity, including dislocation/grain boundary interaction, transonic dislocation dynamics, dislocation/void interaction, dislocation multiplication from Frank-Read sources, screw dislocation cross-slip, as well as brittle-to-ductile transition in dynamic fracture.

973.prez_name: Recrystallized Grain Size Distribution and Mechanical Response of Formed Components in Incoloy 800H
973.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
973.prez_authors: Catherine  Bishop, Shaun  Mucalo, Milo V. Kral
973.prez_abstract: 800H, an austenitic steel alloy, is used typically in industrial applications at high temperature, where creep is the predominant damage mechanism.  In component manufacture, forming operations introduce plastic strain gradients.  A solution anneal heat treatment is then required to remove the introduced cold work.  The variation in prior cold work due to bending results in a grain size distribution (GSD) that is spatially varied through the formed section due to a combination of recrystallization and grain growth.To study the effect of spatially inhomogeneous GSD, samples with variable plastic strain were designed using FEM simulations, manufactured and heat treated. The GSD and the spatial-GSD of the as-formed and annealed test samples were characterized using OIM-EBSD.  Mechanical response of the spatially inhomogeneous microstructures will be calculated using FFT-based elastoplastic methods. The mechanical response will be related to the spatial-GSD and the plastic strain profile.

974.prez_name: Reference Selection for EBSD Based Grain Reference Orientation Deviation Maps
974.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
974.prez_authors: Stuart  Wright, Seiichi   Suzuki, Matthew M. Nowell
974.prez_abstract: Grain Reference Orientation Deviation (GROD) maps can be constructed from EBSD data. GROD maps show the angular deviation at each point within a grain with respect to a reference orientation. A key factor governing this calculation is the choice of reference. One approach is to set the reference orientation to the average of the orientations of all points within the grain. Other approaches are tied to the orientation of a specific point within the grain. These include the point with the lowest kernel average misorientation, the point at the grain’s geometric center and the points producing the largest and the smallest average orientation deviation. The choice of reference orientation has a significant effect on the map and its interpretation in terms of the local accommodation of deformation within the microstructure. EBSD measurements from an austenitic steel sample deformed in-situ are used to evaluate the different reference orientation selection approaches.

975.prez_name:
Simulating Heterogeneous Deformation in Experimentally Characterized Microstructures in 
Commercial Purity Ti and a Ti alloy
975.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
975.prez_authors: Thomas R. Bieler, Harsha  Phukan, Chen  Zhang, Martin A Crimp, Philip  Eisenlohr, Carl J. Boehlert, Leyun  Wang, Jonathan   Lind, Robert  Suter, Peter  Kenesei, Jun-Sang  Park, Ruxing  Xu, Wenjun  Liu, Wenjun  Liu
975.prez_abstract: Deformation within a given grain is highly influenced by deformation in neighboring grains, and all grains impose boundary conditions on other grains that vary spatially.  To investigate this effect, detailed experimental measurements of heterogeneous deformation that include local stress and strain measurements are desirable to assist model development and validation, and models assist in interpreting measured quantities.  Two examples of this kind of interactive analysis will be described: (1) in-situ tensile deformation of polycrystalline pure titanium using High Energy X-ray Diffraction, with both near-field and far-field measurements that provide grain shape and average strain tensors, and (2) assessment of bent polycrystalline samples using Differential Aperture X-ray Microscopy, which provides 1 micron voxels of orientation with most of the strain tensor.  Origins of localized heterogeneous deformation and nucleation of mechanical twins are examined locally.  Supported by NSF, DOE/BES, and the Advanced Photon Source beamlines 1 and 34.

976.prez_name: Strain Evolution in TBF 1180 Microstructures during In-situ Tension Testing
976.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
976.prez_authors: Jeffrey  Cramer, Tyson  Mathis, Michael  Miles, David  Fullwood, Eric  Homer, Tyson  Brown, Raja K. Mishra
976.prez_abstract: Strain evolution in 1.2 mm TBF 1180 steel was measured by digital image correlation during in situ testing of mini tensile specimens. Micrographs were taken at different strain levels, at magnifications of up to 12,000x, by scanning electron microscopy. Strain maps were correlated to individual phases in the microstructure, in order to understand the role of local hardness and morphology on material formability. Electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) was also applied to in situ tension specimens. The EBSD scan data were used to calculate tetragonality of each phase, in an effort to identify phase fractions. This was done to track conversion of austenite to martensite as a function of strain.

977.prez_name: Strain Localisation and the Ductility of HCP Alloys
977.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
977.prez_authors: Joao  Fonseca, Alberto  Orozco-Caballero, Feng  Li, Daniel  Esque-de los Ojos
977.prez_abstract: Metals with an hexagonal crystal structure are often dismissed as brittle, due a limited availability of slip systems, which can be somewhat improved by increasing the temperature. However, hexagonal alloys like CP-Ti and Mg alloys show large elongations to failure at room temperature, and their ductility during biaxial stretching often decreases with temperature. In an effort to better understand the origins of this behaviour, a combination of uniaxial and biaxial testing and high resolution digital image correlation (HRDIC) strain mapping experiments were carried out on CP-Ti and AZ61, at different temperatures. The experiments showed that the alloys show differences in strain localisation patterning, which depends on texture and loading mode. Crystal plasticity finite element modelling simulations can reproduce these trends and suggest that the ductility of these alloys is a primarily limited by texture and the limited work hardening available via slip.

978.prez_name: Stress Concentration and Redistribution at/near Grain Boundaries during Dynamic Recrystallization: An Integrated Modeling Study
978.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
978.prez_authors: Pengyang  Zhao, Thaddeus Song En  Low, Yunzhi  Wang, Stephen  Niezgoda
978.prez_abstract: When subject to mechanical loading, polycrystalline metals build up an internal stress field with significant localization at or near grain boundaries. Dislocation-mediated plastic deformation relaxes this internal stress field and consequently heterogeneous dislocation field starts to establish. As dislocation density reaches to certain values, “boundary bulging” may operate to trigger the nucleation of new grains, further relaxing the internal stress via dynamic recrystallization (DRX) at a much higher length scale. An integrated model of phase-field and FFT-based crystal plasticity is developed and applied to investigation of stress relaxation during high-temperature uniaxial compression of polycrystalline copper. The well-observed macroscopic softening is quantified and correlated with the underlying new grain nucleation processes, with the microstructural evolution being captured and quantified as well. The three-dimensional full-field simulations reveal that upon DRX internal stress is redistributed significantly within the new grains, together with considerable influence on the stress state of neighboring grains as well.

979.prez_name: Study of Residual Stress in a Ti-7Al Alloy
979.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
979.prez_abstract: Finite element simulations are carried out to follow the evolution of residual stresses in Ti-7Al alloy, as developed through a process of combined bending and tension about a stress concentration.  A virtual polycrystal geometry is generated using the position and orientation information of the grains. This information is obtained from High Energy X-Ray Diffraction (HEXD) experiments performed at the Advanced Photon Source of Argonne National Laboratory. A finite-element model using mesoscopic field dislocation mechanics (Roy et al., 2007) is employed to simulate the deformation history of bending, tension and unloading.   Model predictions show good agreement with the experimental results generated from HEXD experiments. Conclusions from this work are that room temperature creep plays a role in the development of grain-level residual stresses, and grains deform mainly via prism slip.

980.prez_name: Study of β-tin Plasticity by Instrumented-indentation Testing
980.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
980.prez_authors: Zhuowen  Zhao, Aritra   Chakraborty, Martin A. Crimp, Thomas R. Bieler, Philip  Eisenlohr
980.prez_abstract: Investigation of the temperature-dependence of plasticity in single crystalline β-tin is useful for it shows highly anisotropic deformation behavior under thermal cycling. Instrumented-indentation testing (IIT) is used to study the mechanical behavior of a small volume of material at the single crystal scale. The load–displacement curves and surface topographies generated by the indentations into individual crystallites of β-tin show marked orientation dependence and could differ for different indentation temperatures as well. Based on such experimental data, we are aiming at establishing a constitutive parameter dataset for β-tin through an inverse method. The constitutive parameters used in crystal plasticity finite element (CPFE) simulations of the indentation process are varied until an optimum match for the load–displacement curves and surface topographies for a number of crystallite orientations is achieved. Using such methodology can reveal the relative and absolute ease of activation for the multiple slip families reported in β-tin.

981.prez_name: Studying the Micromechanics of Martensitic Phase Transformations Using High Energy Diffraction Microscopy
981.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
981.prez_abstract: Modern theories of the micromechanics of martensitic phase transformations are nearly 80 years mature. Experiments to verify these theories at the micro-scale, however, are a relatively new success, as definitive ex-situ observations of these mechanisms are difficult. New non-destructive in-situ High-Energy Diffraction Microscopy (HEDM) techniques are being developed to address this gap. Nickel-Titanium and Iron-Palladium shape memory alloys, and also 301L Stainless Steel, have been used as model materials in the first experiments. In this presentation, we will review the development of new analysis methodologies that strongly couple simulations with HEDM data, as well as the new micromechanical insights arising from applying these analyses.

982.prez_name: The Influence of Elastic Anisotropy and the γ Surface in Cross Slip of Copper
982.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
982.prez_authors: Ben A. Szajewski, Abigail  Hunter, Irene  Beyerlein
982.prez_abstract: Research into the physical processes governing the mechanical behavior of crystals has identified dislocation cross slip as an important mechanism which influences the hardening behavior observed in FCC metals. While both experimental and numerical investigations of this phenomenon have continued to provide insight a quantitative relationship between the intrinsic properties of FCC metals and cross slip remains a challenge. To this end, we present several results of the constriction of a copper screw dislocation using a phase field model which incorporates both the inelastic inter-planar potential (i.e., the γ surface) as well as full elastic anisotropy. The inclusion of anisotropy dramatically reduces the energy barrier required for constriction when compared to similar isotropic numerical and theoretical estimates. These results provide possible insight into the prevalence of cross slip in copper despite its relatively low intrinsic stacking fault energy.

983.prez_name: Tracking Plastic Deformation and Damage Evolution in Polycrystals Using High-energy X-ray Diffraction Microscopy
983.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation

984.prez_name: Using a Machine Learning Approach to Predict Stress Hotspots
984.symp_name: Heterogeneity during Plastic Deformation – Synergy between Experimental Investigation and Simulation
984.prez_abstract: Stress hotspots are regions of high stresses in a microstructure, and they also tend to have large stress gradients. They are correlated with the nucleation of damage such as voids in ductile fracture. Stress hotspots tend to form near microstructural features, such as grain boundaries, triple and quadruple junctions and usually form in textures corresponding to maxima in the Taylor factor for a given loading condition. We simulate deformation in a uniaxial tensile test in cubic polycrystals with equiaxed grain structures, using the elasto-viscoplastic Fast Fourier Transform (EVPFFT) code. After identifying stress hotspots by thresholding, we characterize their neighborhoods using various metrics that reflect local crystallography, geometry, and connectivity. This data is used to create input feature vectors to train a supervised machine-learning algorithm, which predicts the location of stress hotspots. The results show the power and the limitations of the machine learning approach applied to the polycrystalline grain network.

1028.prez_name: Advanced Polymer-derived Ceramics with a Controlled Nanocarbon-phase
1028.symp_name: Innovative Processing and Synthesis of Ceramics, Glasses and Composites

1029.prez_name: Application of Porous MgTi2O5 Ceramics with Pseudobrookite-type Structure for Diesel Particle Filter Application
1029.symp_name: Innovative Processing and Synthesis of Ceramics, Glasses and Composites

1030.prez_name: Ceramics with Unique Pore Structures via Freeze Casting of Preceramic Polymers
1030.symp_name: Innovative Processing and Synthesis of Ceramics, Glasses and Composites
1030.prez_authors: Maninpat  Naviroj, Paolo  Colombo, Katherine  Faber
1030.prez_abstract: To optimize the functionality of porous ceramic components, the ability to create ceramics with controlled and unique pore structures is desired. Freeze casting is a sacrificial templating technique where pores are generated from a crystal growth process, enabling a wide variety of pore structures. While freeze casting of ceramic suspensions has widely been studied, the use of preceramic polymers as an alternative precursor in freeze casting has been lightly explored. In this work, silicon-based polymer derived ceramics with various pore structures are obtained from freeze casting with solvents such as dimethyl carbonate, cyclohexane, cyclooctane, and t-butanol. We show how differences in the solidification process between each solvent result in different pore structures. Additionally, the differences in pore structures also lead to differences in permeability and compressive strength. In particular, lamellar structures are shown to have significantly lower strength but higher permeability when compared to dendritic pore structures.

1055.prez_name: Porous Bioceramics from Preceramic Polymers and Engineered Fillers
1055.symp_name: Innovative Processing and Synthesis of Ceramics, Glasses and Composites
1055.prez_authors: Enrico  Bernardo, Laura  Fiocco, Hamada  Elsayed, Mirko  Sinico, Paolo  Colombo
1055.prez_abstract: Highly porous foams, based on akermanite (Ca2MgSi2O7) and wollastonite (CaSiO3)–diopside (CaMgSi2O6) ceramics, may be produced with commercial silicones mixed with CaCO3 and Mg(OH)2 micro-sized particles. An extensive foaming is achieved simply by water release, at 300-350 °C, from decomposition of sodium borate or phosphate hydrated salts, used as secondary fillers and forming liquid phase (favouring ionic interdiffusion) upon firing at 1100°C. Operating with anhydrous salts, silicone-based pastes can be applied also for direct ink writing, leading to 3D reticulated structures, later ceramized as above. Optimized formulations lead to materials with remarkable compressive strength (well exceeding 5 MPa, with a total porosity in the order of 70%) and bioactivity, confirmed by in vivo cell tests.The overall approach may be extended even to Ca-Zn bioactive silicates. In this case, foaming and phase evolution are associated with the use of calcium borate, leading to novel B-doped hardystonite ceramics (Ca2Zn1-xB2xSi2-xO7).
