1069.prez_name: A 3D Polyhedral Description of Grain Boundary Structural Features Based on the Structure of Defects in Bulk FCC Metals
1069.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1069.prez_abstract: The atomic structure of defects and interfaces influence a wide range of material characteristics. While traditional structural unit models (SUMs) have been developed to facilitate the study of grain boundary (GB) structures, no SUMs have been proposed to describe the atomic structure of defects in bulk crystals, such as vacancies or line defects. In this talk, we present a general voronoi vertex clustering technique for describing the atomic structure of close-packed materials. We use the proposed method to describe the structure of point and line defects in bulk FCC metals and will identify polyhedral units (PUs) that construct the structure of defects. We demonstrate how the proposed method can provide a space-filling description for several tilt GBs and will illustrate how the GB features can be described by the PUs that have been identified along the line defects in bulk crystals.

1070.prez_name: A Phase Field Crystal Study of Defects in Multilayer Graphene
1070.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1070.prez_abstract: The electronic properties of graphene strongly depend on the structure of defects. We present a phase field crystal approach for obtaining grain boundary structures and the distribution of defects in strained bilayer graphene which is consistent with molecular dynamics simulations and experiments. We identify general trends in low energy structures, in particular the arrangement of 5-7 ring units and microfacets. Large spatial scale simulations show patterns at length scales not accessible with other atomistic simulation methods.

1071.prez_name: Agglomeration of Kinetically Constrained Thin Metal Films
1071.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1071.prez_abstract: For kinetically constrained thin metal films changes in temperature typically alter film morphologies and, ultimately, lead to film break-up and agglomeration. This behavior is often referred to as dewetting.  Characterizing the kinetic behavior of film agglomeration for film thicknesses below 100nm requires high speed imaging with nanosecond time and nanometer spatial resolution. In this presentation we will report dynamic transmission electron microscopy characterization of solid-state and liquid-state “dewetting” of nickel films on Si/SiO2 and SrTiO3 substrates to distinguish transport mechanisms that govern film agglomeration. A pulsed electron beam was used to enable temporal resolution, while pulsed laser irradiation on the TEM sample was employed for local heating. High-speed imaging further enabled the direct imaging of laser ablation processes for liquefied metal films. This research is supported by a Faculty Early Career award from the US National Science Foundation (DMR-0955638).

1072.prez_name: An Atomistic and Continuum Approach to Dopant Segregation and Embrittlement at Molybdenum Grain Boundaries
1072.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1072.prez_authors: Zihan  Xu, Richard  Tran, Naixie  Zhou, Balachandran  Radhakrishnan, Jian  Luo, Shyue Ping  Ong
1072.prez_abstract: Mo is known for its excellent high temperature properties, but has a critical limitation on account of its low ductility. Doping the grain boundaries (GBs) of Mo with certain metallic elements can resolve this limitation, while other elements may exacerbate them. In this work, we investigated the segregation and mechanical strengthening/embrittling effects of 30 dopants at the Σ5 (310) tilt and Σ5 (100) twist Mo GBs using density functional theory (DFT) and empirical continuum models. We found that differences in metallic radii and cohesive energies are good predictors of dopant segregation tendency and strengthening effect respectively. Assuming a fast cleavage model of fracture, only Ta and W are predicted to have a weak strengthening effect on Mo for the Σ5(310) tilt GB, and Mn, Fe, Co, Re and Nb are predicted to have reasonable strengthening effects for the Σ5(100) twist GB.

1073.prez_name: An Efficient Algorithm for Determining the Minimum Energy Structures of Grain Boundaries
1073.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1073.prez_authors: Arash  Dehghan Banadaki, Mark A. Tschopp, Srikanth   Patala
1073.prez_abstract: Sampling minimum energy grain boundary structures in the five-dimensional crystallographic phase space can provide much-needed insight into how grain boundary (GB) crystallography affects various interfacial properties (e.g., functional and mechanical properties). However, the complexity and number of parameters involved often limits the extent of this exploration to a small set of symmetric tilt and twist configurations. The objective of this research is to develop a fast algorithm for generating zero kelvin, minimum energy GB structures in the five-dimensional crystallographic phase space. We present several methods based on removing or inserting atoms in the GB to lower the grain boundary energy, rapidly converging on the minimum energy structure. We have verified the robustness of this approach by simulating over 900 tilt, twist, and mixed character GBs in both fcc (Aluminum and Copper) and bcc (Iron and Molybdenum) metallic systems.

1074.prez_name: An Explanation for the Maintenance of the Polyhedral Shape of Abnormal Grains during their Growth
1074.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1074.prez_abstract: In many single phase systems, such as BaTiO3 and Ni, the shape of abnormal grains is well faceted and is maintained during their growth. It was puzzling that the velocity of the migrating boundary of the abnormal grains is constant, irrespective of the orientations of the adjacent shrinking grains. To understand the shape maintenance of abnormal grains, we carefully observed the migrating and impinged boundaries of abnormal grains in a model Ni system. We found that the grain boundaries terminated by {100} planes were singular with atomic steps and have a lower energy than the boundaries terminated by other planes. These findings indicate that grain growth in Ni is governed by the movement of {100} singular planes, i.e., the step formation and spreading at the singular planes, similar to the migration of a faceted solid/liquid interface. The results are also discussed in relation to previous experimental observations in other systems.

1075.prez_name: Anorthite (CaAl2Si2O8)-Aluminium Interface:  Kinetics of High-Temperature Interactions
1075.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1075.prez_authors: Esmaeil  Adabifiroozjaei, Hongyang   Ma, Pramod   Koshy, Charles Christopher Sorrell
1075.prez_abstract:
The present work focuses on the kinetics of interaction between anorthite and aluminium.  High-density anorthite was produced and exposed with molten aluminium for varying times (0.5 to 250 h) at different temperatures (850°, 950°, 1050°, and 1150°C).  The ceramic-metal interface was analysed by optical microscopy (OM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) and electron probe microanalyser (EPMA) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM).  The thickness of the interfacial region showed a parabolic growth rate with increasing temperatures and this suggests the anorthite-aluminum interaction occurs through diffusion controlled processes.  In-depth analyses revealed that the process involves Al3+-Si4+ and Al3+-Ca2+ interdiffusion and this results in the conversion of anorthite to alumina through the following path: 

Anorthite (CaO.Al2O3.2SiO2) → Gehlenite (2CaO.Al2O3.SiO2) → CA (CaO.Al2O3) → CA2 (CaO.2Al2O3) → CA6 (CaO.6Al2O3) → alumina (Al2O3)

1076.prez_name: Application of ASTAR/PED Orientation Microscopy Technique in Grain Boundary Character Distribution of Nano-size Pure Zirconium
1076.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1076.prez_authors: Iman  Ghamarian, Peyman  Samimi, Gregory  S.  Rohrer, Peter C. Collins
1076.prez_abstract: Recently, research efforts have directly incorporated the characteristics of the grain boundary, including the five orientation parameters (three for the misorientation made by the grain boundary in Euler space and two for the normal of the grain boundary plane in spherical coordinate). In order to properly characterize these parameters, it is necessary to conduct orientation microscopy. Further, when the counting statistics of distributions of grain boundary character are sufficient (i.e., >100,000 grain boundaries), it allows for additional aspects of the material to be understood. While some work has been conducted on coarse grained materials, little work has been conducted on ultrafine grained materials. In this research, grain boundary character distributions of nano-size pure zirconium deposited on a fused silica was studied via a new emerging TEM-based orientation imaging microscopy technique, ASTAR/precession electron diffraction, which enables orientation studies with few nanometer spatial resolution.

1077.prez_name: Atomic Simulations: Development of an Adhesion-interface Relationship in Crystalline Structures
1077.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1077.prez_abstract: A hybrid approach for the atomistic modeling of a multi-layer crystalline structure using a two-scale classical/quantum mechanic approach is presented. This approach utilizes the adhesive characteristics between two materials to create a simulated interfacial region that is used to transfer forces between two dissimilar interatomic potentials. The adhesive strength is calculated using small-scale density functional theory calculations and applied at the surface interface through hypothetical bonds. By simplifying the complex diffusive behaviors of an interface to one-dimension, we can reduce computational time and the need to develop full interatomic force fields between new material interactions. Thus allowing us to study phenomena such as fatigue caused by layer delamination for various configurations of thin film coating applications. The application and effectiveness of the hybrid approach are demonstrated by comparing the mechanical properties of a copper/cuprous-oxide interface to a traditional single force field model.

1078.prez_name: Atomistic Simulation of Grain Boundary Structures and Complexion Transitions
1078.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1078.prez_authors: Shengfeng  Yang, Naixie  Zhou, Tao  Hu, Jian  Luo
1078.prez_abstract: Impurities adsorbed to grain boundaries (GBs) can induce interfacial structural (complexion) transitions. In this study, we first modify a genetic algorithm to predict GB atomic structures in binary systems by searching for the lowest-energy interfacial configuration at 0K. Subsequently, a hybrid molecular-dynamics/Monte-Carlo method is used to predict GB structures and complexion transitions at finite temperatures. The simulation results are used to construct GB complexion diagrams revealing the GB excess, interfacial width, structural disorder, and GB diffusivity as functions of the bulk composition and temperature; this study uncovers the atomic-level structural, chemistry, and kinetic details at binary GBs systematically. Examples of Ni-doped Mo and S-doped Ni are discussed. Our results reveal the existence of first-order "clean-bilayer" complexion transitions at special GBs and coupled premelting and prewetting transitions at general GBs in Ni-doped Mo, consistent with the predictions of GB thermodynamic models. The atomic simulation results are critically compared with experimental observations.

1079.prez_name: Capillarity in Pressure Infiltration Part II: Modeling
1079.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1079.prez_authors: George  Varvanides, Gionata  Schneider, Andreas  Mortensen, William Craig  Carter
1079.prez_abstract: The infiltration of molten metal into ceramic preforms is influenced, among other parameters, by the wetting angle of the metal on the ceramic in question. The link between local wetting and pressures required for metal flow can, in some cases, deviate strongly from what one would expect on the basis of elementary thermodynamic considerations. We explain some of the trends observed in experimental studies of the pressure required to infiltrate ceramic preforms with molten metals by means of percolation models that give a simple yet realistic treatment of the infiltration process, including the influence of stochasticity and pinning points in the preform pore geometry. Results show the appearance of percolation phenomena and significant irreversible energy losses, which become particularly apparent the metal wetting angle of the ceramic falls to approach, or enter, the wetting regime, in keeping with experimental data.

1080.prez_name: Capillarity in Pressure Infiltration Part I: Experimental
1080.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1080.prez_authors: Gionata  Schneider, Alain  Léger, Ludger  Weber, William Craig  Carter, Andreas  Mortensen
1080.prez_abstract: Molten metals generally do not wet ceramics; to produce metal matrix composite materials, therefore, mechanical pressure is frequently applied to overcome capillary forces. In metal pressure infiltration processing, thermodynamic, statistical, chemical, and kinetic phenomena combine to determine the range of pressures required to drive the metal into the preform, the infiltration path it adopts, and the microstructural evolution of the resulting composite material. This presentation and the next will present an overview of capillarity in molten metal pressure infiltration, and will give results of a combined theoretical and experimental investigation of the process. This first part will present the experimental approach that was designed and is currently implemented at EPFL to quantify the infiltration of ceramic preforms with molten metals based on copper or aluminium, at temperatures and under applied pressures typical of actual composite fabrication processes.

1081.prez_name: Carbon Adsorption, Segregation and Diffusion on Grain Boundaries Emerging on the Surface of BCC Iron
1081.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1081.prez_authors: El Tayeb  Bentria, Normand   Mousseau, Charlotte  S. Becquart, Othmane   Bouhali, Fadwa   El Mellouhi
1081.prez_abstract: Segregation and diffusion in solids are known to occur along grain boundaries and over free surfaces more rapidly than through the bulk crystals. A grain boundary that emerges at a free surface presents a high potential for impurities to adsorb at the steps and edges then segregate within the GBs and possibly diffuse into the bulk. By means of density functional theory (DFT), we investigate the effect of Carbon adsorbents on BCC Iron Σ3GB emerging at the surface. Models of around 158 iron atoms cleaved perpendicular to GB <110> surface are used. Subsequently, we calculate bulk segregation energies at differents interstitial and substitutional sites, showing that Carbon prefers to segregate at few GB substitutional sites. While this suggests that C bulk diffusion through this type of  GB in iron might be inhibited,  a detailed  analysis of the diffusion pathways, density of states and electronic density is carried out to explain this finding.

1082.prez_name: Chemical Demixing and Thermal Stability of Supersaturated Nanocrystalline CuCr Alloys: Insights from Advanced TEM
1082.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1082.prez_authors: Gerhard  Dehm, T.  Harzer, T.  Dennenwaldt, C.  Freysoldt, C.H.  Liebscher
1082.prez_abstract: Nanocrystalline metals are prone to grain growth preventing their use in structural and functional applications. In this study we have analysed the thermal stability and phase formation in nanocrystalline Cu-Cr alloy films. Although Cu and Cr are immiscible, single phase bcc films with up to 67at.%Cu were realized, while a single phase fcc alloy with 4at.%Cr was established. The nanostructure evolution of the alloys is reported exemplarily for a bcc Cu67Cr33 (at.%) alloy film. Strong compositional fluctuations exist inside the 50 nm small grains. Cu- and Cr-rich domains with composition of Cu85Cr15 and Cu42Cr58 and domain size of 1 – 5 nm are observed. The alignment of the interface between the bcc Cu- and bcc Cr-rich domains shows a preference for {110}-type habit planes. The nanocrystalline single phase microstructure is maintained even at 573K. The mechanisms of nanostructure evolution and their impact on the mechanical performance are discussed.

1083.prez_name: Coherency Strain Reduction in Particles on a Substrate as a Driving Force for Solute Segregation
1083.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1083.prez_authors: Dor  Amram, David  Barlam, Eugen  Rabkin, Roni  Shneck
1083.prez_abstract: It is well-established that solute segregation to interfaces is driven by the reduction of their energy. Here we demonstrate the importance of a different driving force for segregation which had not been considered previously: a reduction in coherency strain energy due to lattice misfit modification, at the interface between alloy particles and a substrate. Previously we performed quantitative experimental and computational analyses of Au segregation to multiple surfaces and interfaces in Fe-Au thin films, micro- and nanoparticles. Here we focus on Au segregation to the Fe/sapphire interface and consider the contribution of lattice misfit at that interface to the driving force for segregation owing to a reduction in the particles’ total elastic energy. Our experimental results together with finite element method calculations demonstrate that the elastic energy contribution to the total driving force for Au segregation exceeds that of the interfacial energy for particles larger than ~10 nm in size.

1084.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1084.prez_authors: Jeffrey  Rickman, Helen   Chan, Martin  Harmer, Jian  Luo
1084.prez_abstract: We investigate, both numerically and using atomistic computer simulation, grain-boundary layering transitions associated with boundary segregation.  Two complementary approaches are taken.  First, we study these transitions by using a semi-grand Monte Carlo simulation of an alloy to generate composition histograms.  An analysis of these histograms enables the construction of complexion diagrams. Second, we consider such transitions in a lattice-gas model of a bicrystal that incorporates elastic fields.  Complexion diagrams are then constructed to illustrate the richness of the phase-like behavior.  Finally, we examine the implications of these transitions for phonon properties, focusing on the thermal conductivity and the Kapitza resistance.

1085.prez_name: Determining Appropriate Representative Volume Element Sizes for Grain Boundary Networks
1085.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1085.prez_abstract: Quantitative models of grain boundary networks that predict a microstructure’s effective properties are necessary to investigate correlations between the structure and properties of a material. These models are difficult to create, and those that currently exist ignore certain complexities in real grain boundary networks, such as crystallographic and topological constraints. To effectively develop these models and perform accurate simulations, a representative volume element (RVE) must be used.  RVE sizes have been previously determined for texture sensitive properties, but these findings have not addressed the influence of the grain boundary network. We present findings on appropriate RVEs for grain boundary networks across various microstructures. Our findings also include analysis of spatial correlations in the grain boundary network and their effect on RVE size. These results will allow researchers to accurately simulate and model grain boundary networks in a computationally efficient manner.

1086.prez_name: Dewetting Transitions of Au/Ni Bilayer Films
1086.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1086.prez_authors: Xi  Cen, Andrew  Thron, Klaus  van Benthem
1086.prez_abstract: Thin films deposited at low temperatures are often kinetically constrained and will agglomerate on the underlying substrate when heat-treated. This behavior is often referred to as dewetting and can be a serious concern in microelectronics reliability, while it can also be utilized for engineering of nanostructures. In this study, the solid state dewetting of Au/Ni bilayer films from SiO2/Si substrates has been investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) techniques. The studies revealed different morphology and chemical distribution change from the center to the edge of the substrate wafer, along with strong texture formation and void nucleation at preferential sites. In-situ TEM and SEM studies are currently underway to further investigate agglomeration kinetics of metal bilayer films.

1087.prez_name: Direct Correlation between Complexion Types and Grain Boundary Mechanical Behavior of Rare Earth Doped Magnesium Aluminate Spinel
1087.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1087.prez_authors: Fiona Yuwei  Cui, Onthida  Kosasang, Animesh  Kundu, Richard  Vinci
1087.prez_abstract: Adding rare earth dopants into magnesium aluminate spinel has been observed to cause different grain growth behavior. By altering the dopant type and the doping conditions, e.g. dopant concentration and annealing temperature, we achieve different complexion types within the system. In order to verify this result, high-resolution electron microscopy characterization is used to observe the grain boundary structure. A micro-scale mechanical testing technique is utilized to measure fracture toughness of a single grain boundary. AFM is also employed to measure the grain boundary groove depth, in order to analyze the relative grain boundary energies. Together, the grain growth behavior, the boundary structure and chemistry, the grain boundary energies, and the fracture toughness results provide a unified picture of the behavior of the system. Hence, by combining these results, we can build a direct correlation between complexion types and grain boundary mechanical behavior systematically.

1088.prez_name: Eigendecomposition and the Network Structure of Grain Boundaries in Polycrystals
1088.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1088.prez_abstract: Grain boundaries (GBs) form a complex network whose collective structure strongly influences the mechanical, physical, and transport properties of materials. Attempts to quantify the structure of GB networks have employed metrics such as cluster sizes, Betti numbers, and triple junction fractions. However, all of these methods rely on the binary classification of GBs as either “special” or “general” and represent assumptions about what constitute important structural features. We present a new approach for characterizing the structure of GB networks based on eigendecomposition of graph representations of polycrystals. This method is capable of handling a continuous spectrum of GB types and naturally indicates the important features of the microstructure that govern the effective response of the polycrystal. We demonstrate that this strategy clearly distinguishes between different microstructures and show the correlation between the natural measures of structure that emerge and the effective properties of model polycrystals.

1089.prez_name: Exploring the Thermal Stability of Nanocrystalline Fe-Mg Alloys
1089.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1089.prez_abstract: The thermal stabilization of Fe-based nanocrystalline (NC) alloys by means of grain boundary segregation could enable improved mechanical properties surpassing those of the hardest steels, possibly even at elevated temperatures. In recent work Mg has been identified as a promising candidate for NC-stabilization, and improved thermal stability in Fe-Mg thin films was demonstrated in both experiments and simulations. Here we study the alloy configuration and attendant thermal stability in NC Fe-Mg alloys. At the mesoscale, grain structure evolution is studied by ex- and in-situ annealing during x-ray diffraction, and by electron microscopy.  The grain structures are also compared with Monte Carlo simulations, and with unalloyed iron. At the nanoscale, the local grain boundary structure and chemistry are also probed. The unique role of the allotropic α↔γ transformation in NC Fe is discussed.  These results, along with preliminary work on other solutes, help elaborate the design space for NC alloys.

1090.prez_name: Faceting Model for Σ3 Grain Boundaries: Testing the Hypothesis
1090.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1090.prez_authors: Dustin  Doty, Oliver  Johnson, Eric  Homer
1090.prez_abstract: A faceting model was recently proposed, which predicts the energies of Σ3 grain boundaries in Al with different boundary planes based on the energies of the those boundaries at the corners of the boundary plane fundamental zone (BPl-FZ). With only three parameters, this model showed excellent agreement with simulation results. We investigate the hypothesis of this model that an arbitrary Σ3 grain boundary is composed entirely of facets corresponding to the grain boundaries at the corners of the BPl-FZ. Using graph theoretic tools we identify atomic motifs or patterns appearing in arbitrary Σ3 grain boundaries generated by molecular dynamics simulation and compare these to those appearing in the boundaries at the corners of the BPl-FZ.

1091.prez_name: Grain-boundary Character Distribution and Correlations with Electrical and Optoelectronic Properties of CuInSe2 Thin Films
1091.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1091.prez_authors: Anthony  Rollett, Daniel  Abou-Ras, Norbert  Schäfer, Gregory  Rohrer
1091.prez_abstract: Thin-film solar cells based on Cu(In,Ga)Se2 absorbers exhibit record conversion efficiencies of close to 22 %. There is still a lack of a quantitative connection between grain-boundary character and the corresponding electrical and optoelectronic properties. The present work deals with the assessment of grain-boundary character distributions  by the evaluation of microstructural data from a CuInSe2 thin film acquired by electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD). CuInSe2 thin films were chosen instead of Cu(In,Ga)Se2 layers for the study since they do not exhibit any compositional gradients of the matrix elements, which may influence the EBSD measurements. Moreover, combining EBSD with electron-beam-induced current and cathodoluminescence (measurements on the same identical area on a CuInSe2/Mo/glass stack provide the means to relate the grain-boundary occupation with the corresponding electrical and optoelectronic signals across the grain boundary. In part, determining this relationship is accomplished by means of correlation analysis using measurement data from more than 100 grain boundaries.

1092.prez_name: Grain and Domain Interfaces for Thermoelectric Oxide Materials
1092.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1092.prez_abstract: Multilayer thermoelectric generators using oxide materials were suggested as power sources for wireless sensor network nodes. These applications will be expanded to more fields if the conversion efficiency of the device is improved. The key point is how to reduce only the thermal conductivity in these materials. Scattering phonons on the interfaces is useful, and reported in some papers. However the grain boundaries might be an incoherent interface and also scatter electrons. On the other hand, the domain boundary was suggested as a coherent one to scatter only phonons. To control domain size, not only the cooling process but also the grain size was changed in CaTiO<SUB>3</SUB>. With rapidly quenched and/or smaller grain size samples we can realize finer domain structures and thereby reduced thermal conductivity. These results will be reported and the effects of grain and domain interfaces in these thermoelectric oxide materials will be discussed.

1093.prez_name: Grain Boundary Energy and Curvature Determined from Three-dimensional Microstructure Data
1093.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1093.prez_abstract: The five-parameter grain boundary population and energy distributions have been measured for a variety of polycrystalline microstructures.  Here, we present a technique to measure the grain boundary mean curvature as a function all five crystallographic grain boundary parameters.  The method is validated on ideal shapes such as spheres to determine how measurement resolution affects the results.  We find that the curvature varies systematically with both grain boundary misorientation and the grain boundary plane orientation.  For most types of boundaries, the mean curvature has an inverse linear correlation to the grain boundary energy.  The inverse linear correlation of these quantities is consistent with a constant chemical potential throughout the grain boundary network.  However, singular grain boundaries such as coherent twins are characterized by both low energy and low curvature.

1094.prez_name: Grain Boundary Engineering of Shape Memory Alloys for Enhanced Transformation Ductility
1094.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1094.prez_abstract: Many polycrystalline shape memory alloys undergo intergranular fracture due to stress concentration and strain incompatibility at grain boundaries during martensitic transformation shear in adjacent grains.  To improve their transformation ductility, we perform grain boundary engineering and stimulate the precipitation of a ductile second phase, which is a face-centered-cubic solid solution, along grain boundaries, by tailoring composition and thermal processing.  These precipitates can accommodate transformation strain, relieve constraint in adjacent austenite grains, and arrest cracks by extensive plastic deformation, thereby improving transformation ductility and shape memory effects.

1095.prez_name: Grain Boundary Line Defects in Polycrystalline Al2O3 and their Dominant Role in High Temperature Phenomena
1095.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1095.prez_abstract: Three distinct types of grain boundary line defects can be present in polycrystalline Al2O3—dislocations, the familiar translational defect, disclinations, a less familiar rotational defect, and disconnections, an interfacial ledge defect characterized by a step height h and a Burgers vector b. Grain boundary dislocations and grain boundary disconnections can be studied using TEM, while grain boundary disclinations can be resolved using high resolution electron back scattered diffraction (EBSD) in an SEM. Grain boundary disconnections mediate exaggerated grain boundary diffusion, and thus play a crucial role in all high temperature processes in Al2O3 (sintering, grain growth, oxidation of Al2O3 -scale-forming alloys, etc.), while dislocations and disclinations mediate high temperature plastic deformation.These line defects have been studied in fine-grained un-doped and Y-doped polycrystalline Al2O3that had been sintered to full density at 1300◦C, and after 2% plastic deformation at 1300◦C under a 50 MPa stress.

1096.prez_name: Grain Boundary Segregation in Nanocrystalline Alloys: Case Study of Platinum-gold
1096.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1096.prez_authors: Stephen M. Foiles, Ping   Lu, Christopher J. O'Brien, Nicolas  Argibay, Michael E. Chandross, Fadi F. Abdeljawad, Blythe G. CLARK, Brad L. Boyce
1096.prez_abstract: Nanocrystalline metals have many improved materials properties, but suffer from potential instability of the nanocrystalline grain structure.  Grain boundary segregation has been proposed as a method to stabilize these grain structures either by reduction of thermodynamic driving forces or kinetic inhibition of boundary motion through precipitate pinning and/or solute drag.  In this talk, segregation phenomena in Pt-Au alloys will be examined as a specific example of such a system.  Atomistic off-lattice Monte Carlo simulations determine the segregation in a nanoscale polycrystal and show that the segregation of Au to the grain boundary network is heterogeneous.  These simulations are compared to electron microscopy based observations and quantification of the segregation.  Further, simulations of the segregation to model grain boundaries will be coupled with molecular dynamics investigations of its influence on boundary mobility.  These results will provide input for mesoscale phase field simulations of the nanocrystalline stability to evaluate stability mechanisms.

1097.prez_name: Grain Boundary Structural Length Scales and their Effects upon Mobility
1097.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1097.prez_abstract: Recent molecular dynamics simulations have suggested that the mobility of certain incoherent sigma-3 grain boundaries may increase as temperature decreases, referred to as anti-thermal motion. Because this boundary type can be quite prevalent in FCC metals, these fast, cold boundaries may significantly affect microstructural evolution, especially at low temperatures. Synthetic driving force molecular dynamics simulations were performed to examine anti-thermal mobility in a selection of such boundaries. These boundaries are faceted, and motion occurs via the glide of sets of three Shockley partial dislocations. One implication of this motion mechanism is that there are three important boundary structure length scales: the CSL unit cell, primary (01-1) facets, and secondary (-211) facets. In addition, both sets of facets can undergo thermal roughening at different temperatures. Finally, the dislocation glide mechanism results in significant driving force dependence. We discuss how these factors must be taken into consideration when simulating such boundaries.

1098.prez_name: Grain Boundary Structure-property Relationships: Single Disorientation Axis Trends
1098.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1098.prez_abstract: Grain boundaries (GBs) are known to play an important role in several material properties, including strength, ductility, corrosion resistance, cracking resistance, conductivity, etc. GB engineering is a potential solution to making materials with superior GB performance. However, knowledge about the properties exhibited by different types of GBs is required for optimal performance. In the present work, we detail structure-property relationships of GB energy, mobility and other properties over specific regions of the 5D GB space. Specifically, we examine the role of boundary plane orientation as a function of different disorientation axes. In addition, we examine the energy and mobility of a high angle GB. These trends are compared with predictions made by a five-parameter GB energy function created by Bulatov, Reed, and Kumar.

1099.prez_name: Grain Growth Transitions in Perovskite Ceramics
1099.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1099.prez_abstract: Several perovskite ceramics are known to show non-Arrhenius type grain growth. E.g. for strontium titanate a grain growth transition was documented with decreasing growth rates between 1350°C and 1425°C. Other materials as barium titanate, lithium lanthanum titanate and barium strontium titanate indicate grain growth transitions as well. The growth transitions are coupled to bimodal microstructures and seem to be caused by grain boundary transitions.This talk gives a review on the details of the grain growth transitions in perovskite ceramics. A simple mean field approach allows quantifying these effects in a macroscopic scale. However, this approach is far too simple to understand bimodal anisotropic grain growth completely as apparent in perovskites. Important parameters such as anisotropy, atomistic boundary structure, segregation, wetting, faceting, boundary stoichiometry, space charge and interfacial drag effects need to be considered. A summary of open questions and future directions is given.

1100.prez_name: Heteroepitaxial Recrystallization in γ- γ ' Nickel Base Superalloys
1100.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1100.prez_abstract: An original recrystallization mechanism arising from a phase transformation occurring in primary γ’ particles has recently been reported in a γ- γ ' Nickel Base superalloy. This mechanism leads to the formation of large heteroepitaxial structures, each made of a primary particle surrounded by a recrystallized grain having the same crystallographic orientation.  It was therefore referred to as "heteroepitaxial recrystallization".  It has been demonstrated to occur in several  γ- γ ' alloys with a low γ- γ ' lattice mismatch, when submitted to a suitable thermomechanical path.

1101.prez_name: Interface Stabilization and Epitaxy of Rutile and α-PbO2 Polymorphs of MO2 Dioxides on Columbite-structured Substrates
1101.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1101.prez_authors: Julia  Wittkamper, Gregory S Rohrer, Paul A. Salvador
1101.prez_abstract: We have been developing a robust high-throughput method to explore how surfaces of polycrystalline ceramics, over the entire range of orientation space, impact phase formation and epitaxial orientation relationships during thin film growth. We call this method combinatorial substrate epitaxy (CSE), which involves the deposition of thin films on polished surfaces of polycrystals and determining the local epitaxy using electron back-scatter diffraction. Our prior work has focused on understanding the growth of SnO<sub>2</sub> on CoNb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub>. We will build off of these observations to discuss the phase competition for TiO<sub>2</sub>/RuO<sub>2</sub> films on several columbite substrates (including CoNb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub> and CaNb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub>). The focus of this talk will be on the differences observed in these systems relative to the energetic differences of phases and the volumetric strain from interfacial lattice matching between the different phases.

1102.prez_name: Investigating the Interplay between Grain Boundary Facet Junctions and Interfacial Dislocations
1102.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1102.prez_authors: Douglas L. Medlin, K.  Hattar, J. A. Zimmerman, F.  Abdeljawad, S. M. Foiles
1102.prez_abstract: Grain boundaries often develop faceted morphologies in systems for which the interfacial free energy depends on the boundary inclination.  Although the mesoscale thermodynamic basis for such morphological evolution is well established, less clear are the atomic-scale influences on the behavior.  In this presentation, through a combination of atomistic simulations and electron microscopic observations, we examine in detail the structure of an asymmetric Σ=5 [001] grain boundary in body centered cubic (BCC) Fe.  The observed boundary forms a hill-and-valley morphology composed of nanoscale {310} and {210} facets.  Our analysis clarifies the atomic structure of the facet junctions and shows their relationship to an array of secondary grain boundary dislocations that accommodate deviation from the exact Σ=5 orientation relationship.  These observations motivate the development a new phase-field formulation incorporating a description of both the anisotropic interfacial energy and the non-local interactions between facet junctions.

1103.prez_name: Materials Databases: Grain Boundary Datasets for Quantifying Structure-property Relationships
1103.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1103.prez_authors: Mark  Tschopp, Shawn  Coleman, Srikanth  Patala, Arash  Banadaki, Zachary  Trautt
1103.prez_abstract: Grain boundary (GB) engineering and GB segregation engineering are emerging as techniques for tailoring the GB character distribution and solutes, respectively, to improve properties of polycrystals.  The research objective herein is to develop generalized approaches for generating GBs, characterizing their structure, and linking this to properties.  The present talk will discuss these techniques as applied to large datasets of GBs in metals and ceramics in an effort to understand grain boundary structure-property relationships, such as the interaction between point defects/solutes/impurities and the GB structure (microscale) and character (macroscale).  Additional efforts are focused in quantifying the GB structure-property datasets using simple informatics approaches/analytical models for reducing the dimensionality of atomistic information and identifying important physical/structure parameters.  Such studies provide insight into how microscale and macroscale GB structure influences interfacial properties, ultimately leading to a better understanding of how to tailor polycrystalline microstructures for increased performance.

1104.prez_name: Modeling the Effect of Adsorption on the Kinetics of Grain Growth
1104.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1104.prez_abstract: The interplay between grain growth and adsorption in a closed system is investigated.  The process of grain growth leads to a decrease in grain boundary area and a corresponding increase in the matrix concentration of adsorbate.  To maintain equilibrium between the matrix and boundary the boundary is further enriched in adsorbate.  The associated drop in surface energy will continuously change the grain growth kinetics throughout the evolution of the structure.  This process and implications for the structural evolution of real materials are discussed with the aid of Surface Evolver.

1105.prez_name: Origins of Residual Stress in Thin Films: Effects of the Microstructure and Growth Kinetics
1105.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1105.prez_abstract: We describe a model for stress evolution that focuses on the developing boundary between adjacent grains while the film is deposited. Formation of new grain boundary generates tensile stress while insertion of atoms into it makes the stress more compressive.  The balance between these processes (and hence the stress) is affected by the growth conditions and the microstructure.  To test this model, we have measured stress evolution using wafer curvature during growth under different conditions.  Analysis of the experiments in terms of the model illustrates how the temperature and growth rate change the stress evolution.  Cross-sectional measurements after growth are also used to determine the grain size at different stages of the growth.  From these measurements we create a 2-d map of stress vs growth rate and grain size that shows how these parameters interact.  Extension of the model to consider energetic particles in sputter deposition is also considered.

1106.prez_name: Partially Agglomerated Metallic Thin Films Formed by Annealing of Solid Solution Nanoparticles at Low Homological Temperatures
1106.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1106.prez_authors: Nimrod  Gazit, Leonid   Klinger, Eugen   Rabkin
1106.prez_abstract: Partially agglomerated metallic thin films deposited on ceramic substrates represent an important component of the electrode-electrolyte system in various solid-state electrochemistry applications. In particular, the electrochemical reaction usually occurs at the triple lines. Therefore, the total length of these triple lines should be maximized for improving the electrochemical performance of the system. In this study, we propose a novel method of manipulating the total length of the triple lines in partially agglomerated metal thin films deposited on ceramic substrates. First, the solid solution nanoparticles have been fabricated employing the dewetting phenomenon. Then, a metal layer was deposited on the particles followed by annealing at low homological temperature. During this annealing, the material of the film diffuses into the particles, which accelerates the grain boundary grooving and dewetting processes and results in high area density of holes in the film.

1107.prez_name: Probing Grain Boundaries to Determine the Thermal Stability Mechanisms of Nanocrystalline Ni-W
1107.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1107.prez_authors: Christopher J. Marvel, Kristopher A Darling, B.  Chad Hornbuckle, Martin P. Harmer
1107.prez_abstract: Nanocrystalline grain growth is stagnated by thermodynamic and kinetic mechanisms that revolve around grain boundaries. However, it remains unclear which mechanisms are the most promising to limit grain growth. This study represents a comprehensive experimental approach using aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy and atom probe tomography to study the atomic structure of mechanically alloyed Ni-W, a material system heavily debated, in order to determine the most promising thermal stability mechanisms. Four Ni-W alloy compositions were fabricated, annealed, and characterized to track the microstructural evolution. Two potential stability mechanisms were observed: solute segregation and Ni4W chemical ordering.  Interestingly, at the lowest annealing temperature, the solute enrichment occurred in amorphous intergranular regions and not grain boundaries in the classical sense. Furthermore, 10 nm Ni4W domains were observed that may reduce long-range diffusion.  Thus it was determined that the stability of Ni-W is governed by several mechanisms that limit grain growth.

1108.prez_name: Simulated Migration of Incoherent Facets in Twin Grain Boundaries
1108.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1108.prez_authors: Jonathan  Priedeman, David  Olmsted, Eric  Homer
1108.prez_abstract: Twin grain boundaries are important interfaces that play an important role in the behavior of many materials. Coherent twin formation is dependent on the migration of incoherent twin facets. This study utilizes molecular dynamics to examine the mobility of various Σ3 nickel grain boundaries. Mobility is simulated down to cryogenic temperatures to complement the results of a previous study by Olmsted, Holm and Foiles, and confirms that the majority of the simulated incoherent Σ3 nickel boundaries exhibit non-thermally activated mobility, while the remaining simulated incoherent boundaries demonstrate thermally activated behavior. The thermally activated facets move by random motion of the atoms across the grain boundary plane while the non-thermally activated facets manifest ordered dislocation motion. The mobility trends for the different boundary planes becomes remarkably clear when examined in the grain boundary plane fundamental zone.

1109.prez_name: Spin-polarized Two-dimensional Electron Gas at Ferroelectric Oxide Interfaces
1109.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1109.prez_abstract: Oxide interfaces are home to emergent novel phenomena in physics as inversion symmetry is inherently broken at the interface, while the high electronegativity of oxygen creates strong electrical fields on the atomic scale. Combining such behavior with a ferroelectric material containing switchable domains will result in even more exotic effects, stemming from polarization induced arrangements of charge, spin and orbital degrees of freedom. Here, we report the discovery of a ferromagnetic two-dimensional electron gas at the interface between nonpolar SrTiO3 and ferroelectric PbZr0.2Ti0.8O3. Our results provide definite experimental proof that ferromagnetism can be created at a well-controlled interface formed between non-magnetic elements. Theoretical calculations indicate that the interface electron states are heavily localized at Ti atoms with on-site Coulomb interaction, and hence the spin-polarized states are energetically stable under band bending.

1110.prez_name: Stress Relaxation in Tin Thin Films: From Whiskers to Grain Growth
1110.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1110.prez_authors: Carol  Handwerker, John  Blendell, Ying  Wang, Wei-Hsun  Chen, B.G.  Yoo, Oliver  Kraft, Stefano  Curiotto, Dominique  Chatain, Maureen  Williams
1110.prez_abstract: Whiskers and hillocks have been observed to grow spontaneously from Sn thin films in response to in-plane stresses. Stress relaxation occurs by diffusion to specific grain boundaries in the plane of the film, leading to an out-of-plane relaxation, with hillocks being formed when grain boundary migration accompanies growth out of the plane of the film. In this presentation we present experimental evidence of the changes in local dynamics of stress relaxation as the stress state changes. In particular, hysteretic phenomena observed in-situ during thermal cycling and ex-situ for different temperature extremes reveal the changing state of the film and its ability to relax stresses at the gain level.

1111.prez_name: Structural Characterization of Triangle-shaped Lattice Defects in 4H-SiC Epitaxial Layer
1111.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1111.prez_authors: Eita  Tochigi, Hirofumi  Matsuhata, Hirotaka  Yamaguchi, Takashi  Sekiguchi, Yuichi  Ikuhara
1111.prez_abstract: Two types of triangle-shaped lattice defects in a 4H-SiC epitaxial layer were characterized by X-ray topography and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). X-ray topography analysis suggested that both the triangle-shaped defects are stacking faults on the (0001) plane; one is formed by the removal of a single SiC-molecule layer, whereas the other is formed by the insertion of a single SiC-molecule layer. Atomic-resolution scanning TEM analysis revealed that the latter stacking fault is formed by not only the insertion of a single SiC-molecule layer but also three translation components on the (0001) plane (Shockley component). In addition, the three translation components were found to be cancelled out each other, so that it is considered that these components were not detected by the X-ray topography. In the presentation, we will discuss the atomic structures of the stacking faults in detail.

1112.prez_name: Surface and Grain Boundary Segregation of Hydrogen and Its Effect on the Ideal Work of Fracture of Iron and Nickel
1112.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1112.prez_abstract: During fracture new surfaces are formed by a propagating crack. Depending on the chemical potential of the constituents of a material and their mobility the composition of the newly formed surfaces changes. Thus the surface energy as part of the work to fracture will be affected. This will be treated by combining the work to fracture representing the mechanical aspect and the Gibbs Adsorption Isotherm covering the chemical aspect. Compared to previous studies the present one provides a more generalized but also a simpler insight into chemomechanical effects. In extreme cases separation of lattice planes or separation of two crystals with a common interface occurs without applied external forces. Closed solutions for the work of fracture are derived for brittle fracture and surface segregation of solutes in the limit of a mean field approach. Chemomechanical effects including plastic deformation by dislocation or vacancy generation are discussed qualitatively.

1113.prez_name: Synthesis of Hollow Metal Nanostructures by Surface Diffusion Induced Bulk Intermixing
1113.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1113.prez_authors: Eugen  Rabkin, Nimrod  Gazit, Leonid  Klinger, Gunther  Richter
1113.prez_abstract: We demonstrate that metal nanotubes and hollow nanoparticles can be produced at low homological temperatures employing a combination of surface, interface, and grain boundary diffusion. Silver nanowhiskers and nanoparticles were manufactured employing molecular beam epitaxy and solid state dewetting techniques. A thin nanocrystalline gold overlayer was then deposited on these silver nanostructures, and the systems were annealed at low temperatures at which no bulk interdiffusion occurs. After annealing, gold nanotubes and nanoshells were formed. Silver atoms rejected by the hollowing structures were absorbed by a layer of silver-gold alloy forming on the gold film surface, resulting in significant thickening of the film. The hollowing process was discussed in terms of surface diffusion induced bulk intermixing (SDIBI) model. This process leads to bulk intermixing by the short-circuit diffusion alone, and represents a new mechanism of solid state intermixing in the systems with high specific surface area.

1114.prez_name: The Curious Role of Nickel in Ceramics for Energy Applications
1114.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1114.prez_abstract: Transition metal oxide dopants such as nickel oxide are known to influence the sintering, microstructure development, and properties of ceramics.  Nickel oxide is particularly interesting and technologically very useful especially for catalysts and fuel cells.  Reduction/oxidation behavior is of great interest not only with regard to potential degradation during service, but also in relation to processing.  This presentation will describe the roles of nickel in these situations, focusing on nickel-zirconia and nickel-barium yttrium zirconate systems. It is revealed that internal reduction may be used to produce unique metal-ceramic nanostructures.  Evolution of these nanostructures proceeds in distinct stages, each with its own kinetics description dependent on the starting porosity and grain size. The transitions between stages depend on electrostatic potentials at the grain boundaries that act upon the relevant transporting species, namely oxygen vacancies, electrons, nickel ions and zirconium vacancies.  An understanding of these mechanisms enables the design of specific nanostructures.

1115.prez_name: The Development of Physically Based Atomistic Microstructure: The Effect on the Mechanical Response of Polycrystals
1115.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1115.prez_authors: Jacob  Gruber, Fadi  Abdeljawad, Hojun  Lim, Stephen  Foiles, Garritt  Tucker
1115.prez_abstract: Molecular dynamics methods are commonly used to study the behavior and properties of nanocrystalline systems, usually constructed using Voronoi tessellation methods. In this work, a method for the generation of atomistic realizations of polycrystalline aggregates from a phase field is presented. The topological properties of microstructures generated through this method are computed and directly compared to structures constructed using Poisson Voronoi tessellation. While there is little difference in the macroscale mechanical response, substantial differences in the deformation mechanisms under uniaxial tension are observed. Structures generated from phase field exhibit a propensity toward dislocation plasticity while Poisson Voronoi structures tend to deform through grain-boundary mediated mechanisms. These differences suggest that grain topology and grain boundary character significantly affect local responses of polycrystals and that careful consideration of these effects is required in order to quantitatively predict the behavior of nanocrystalline systems.

1116.prez_name: The Effect of Oxygen Partial Pressure on Oxygen Transport Kinetics in Alumina Grain Boundaries
1116.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1116.prez_authors: Yan  Wang, Helen M. Chan, Jeffrey M. Rickman, Martin P. Harmer
1116.prez_abstract: It is generally believed that because alumina exhibits negligible deviation from stoichiometry, the concentration of intrinsic oxygen vacancies is practically speaking independent of oxygen partial pressure (PO2). However, recent high temperature oxygen permeation experiments at 1650oC have suggested a dependence of oxygen grain boundary (GB) diffusivities on PO2, which was interpreted using defect chemistry arguments. In order to elucidate this phenomenon at temperatures more relevant to alumina scale formation, oxygen GB transport kinetics were measured in alumina at 1400oC, and PO2 from 10-10atm to 10-20atm. The studies utilized dense polycrystalline alumina samples containing NiAl2O4 spinel particles at triple points. The reduction of NiAl2O4 to Ni delineates the position of the reduction front, and enables the determination of the oxygen transport kinetics. The results will be discussed in terms of the functional dependence of the oxygen transport kinetics on PO2, and the implications for the role of alumina non-stoichiometry (if any).

1117.prez_name: The Effect of the Grain Size on the Growth Kinetics in the IMC Layer in Fe-Al Binary System
1117.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1117.prez_authors: Lei  Xu, Joseph  Robson, Zhigang Zak Fang, Philip  Prangnell
1117.prez_abstract: The growth behavior of the intermetallic compound (IMC) reaction layer, formed in dissimilar welds between common automotive steel and aluminum alloys (DC04-AA6111), has been studied under the static condition. The microstructure of the joint interface was observed by high resolution SEM, EBSD and TEM, to collect detailed information on the microstructure of the IMC layer. Only the η phase (Fe2Al5) was identified in the IMC layer. The growth kinetics for the η phase was calculated and found to fit the parabolic law. However, the activation energy was found to change with different annealing temperatures, and two activation energies were calculated: 116 kJ/mol between 400 and 500oC, 248 kJ/mol between 500 and 570 oC. Simple modelling has been used to show that this transition occurs because grain boundary diffusion dominates at lower temperatures and, as a result, the grain size and coarsening behavior of the η phase affects their growth kinetics.

1118.prez_name: The Generating Algorithm for Coincidence Site Lattices in General Bravais Lattice Systems
1118.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1118.prez_abstract: Coincidence Site Lattices and their corresponding Σ-misorientations play a fundamental role in the analysis of interfaces both in experiments and simulations. Grimmer, in a series of articles, has proposed the generating functions for determining the coincidence site lattices for cubic, hexagonal, trigonal and tetragonal Bravais lattices. These generating routines become increasingly complexity as the underlying symmetry of the lattice is reduced. In this talk, I will present a simple algorithm that computes all the unique CSL generating rotations for any Σ and in general Bravais lattice systems. The algorithm involves two simple steps: (i) determination of all the unique sub-lattices of volume Σ, and (ii) the computation all the unique pairs of sub-lattices that are not related by the symmetry operations of the underlying crystals. I will also present strategies for extending this algorithm for computing near-CSL rotations between any two Bravais lattice systems (i.e. both homo-phase and hetero-phase interfaces).

1119.prez_name: The Influence of Crystallographic Constraints on Percolation
1119.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1119.prez_authors: Jarrod M Lund, Oliver K Johnson
1119.prez_abstract: Percolation, or the existence of connected pathways within a material, strongly influences certain properties, such as diffusivity and crack propagation. Such phenomena exists in a polycrystal along the network of grain boundaries and the resulting properties can vary by orders of magnitude depending on whether that network percolates or not. Although percolation models have been applied to grain boundary networks, they do not fully incorporate crystallographic constraints to predict a percolation threshold.  We use simulated annealing to explore the configuration space for grain boundary networks that respect crystallographic constraints. We demonstrate how the addition of these constraints change the percolation threshold and describe how this variation highlights topological features that are characteristic of real grain boundary networks.  As a case study, we show how including these constraints improves the fidelity of percolation models for the effective diffusivity of grain boundary networks.

1120.prez_name: The Mechanics and Thermodynamics of Interfacial Complexions in Transition Metal Alloys
1120.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1120.prez_abstract: Recent studies have shown that doped interfaces can have intriguing structures and that, in some cases, thermodynamically-stable interfacial complexions can form.  In this talk, we will explore the usage of complexions as structural features that can alter mechanical behavior.  Molecular dynamics will first be used to show that crack initiation and grain boundary damage are related to interfacial state, while hybrid Monte Carlo-molecular dynamics simulations will be used to identify the processing conditions which promote the formation of beneficial complexions.  Our results are used to identify the effects of chemistry, temperature, and boundary character on grain boundary structural transitions.  Experimental validation will be provided by high resolution transmission electron microscopy on specially-designed thin film samples that systematically explore these variables.  As a whole, this work lays the foundation for engineering internal interfaces to create tougher engineering materials.

1121.prez_name: The Role of the Water/Glass Interface on Material Properties
1121.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1121.prez_abstract: Oxide glasses are important in touchscreens, solar panels, active windows, etc., where surfaces often dominate properties. The interface between water and the glass surface has significant effects on the properties of both the glass as well as the interfacial water. Even in polycrystalline ceramics, the amorphous intergranular films can come in contact with moisture at exposed surfaces, with behavior different than the surrounding crystals. Properties that can be affected include enhanced proton transport at the water-silica interface, dissolution, and strength. While water is known to cause stress corrosion cracking of amorphous silica, recent experiments have shown that insertion of water into the glass surface creates a compressive layer that enhances strength. We will discuss detailed molecular dynamics simulations of water interactions on glass surfaces, evaluating enhanced proton transport, localized dissolution, and the role of H2O molecules versus silanols on the expansion of the glass surface and strength enhancement.

1122.prez_name: Thermal Stability and Phase Transformation of Nanostructured Nb3O7(OH) Photocatalyst
1122.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1122.prez_abstract: The rising demand on renewable energy sources have intensified the research activities in finding materials capable to produce solar-driven hydrogen via photocatalysis. Promising materials are nanostructured niobium oxides and niobium hydroxides due to their high chemical stability, large surface area and suitable optical properties. In our work we have fabricated hierarchical 3D Nb3O7(OH) arrays which possess a high surface area using a hydrothermal synthesis approach. The array consists of nanowires which are several tens of nanometers thick and highly crystalline. In the interior of the nanowires stacking faults form to compensate a non-stoichiometric composition. These stacking faults play a major role during the phase transformation to Nb2O5 which starts above 500°C as determined by ex-situ and in-situ transmission electron microscopy. Surprisingly, the 3D morphology is stable up to an annealing temperature of 850°C. Above this temperature the nanowires grow together and finally individual µm sized particles are formed.

1123.prez_name: Understanding the Role of Interfaces and Hierarchical Microstructure on the Behavior and Stability of Metallic Nanolaminates Using Atomistic Modeling
1123.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1123.prez_abstract: Nanocrystalline metals have exhibited improvements in material strength when their grain size is decreased, attributed to the high interfacial density associated with small grain sizes confining traditional dislocation mechanisms and leading to interfacial-mediated mechanisms. Complimentary studies have shown the remarkable tunability of metallic nanolaminates and multi-layers through hiererachical design and engineering. Utilizing atomistic simulations and multiscale calculations of non-local nanoscale deformation fields, we demonstrate how interfacial engineering can be leveraged to tune the mechanical properties of alternating crystalline-amorphous layers in metallic nanolaminates. Furthermore, altered mechanical behavior is observed by modulating both the layer thicknesses and the hierarchical microstructure within the crystalline layers (i.e., grain boundaries). These results suggest avenues for improving mechanical properties, such as strength and ductility, by fundamentally controlling the operation and evolution of the underlying deformation and strain accommodation processes.

1124.prez_name: Wetting Dynamics of Liquid Lead on Silica-patterned Iron
1124.symp_name: Interfaces, Grain Boundaries and Surfaces from Atomistic and Macroscopic Approaches -- Fundamental and Engineering Issues
1124.prez_authors: Marie-Laurence  Giorgi, Moustapha  Diallo, Hervé  Duval, Jean-Michel  Mataigne, Alexey  Koltsov
1124.prez_abstract: Wetting experiments with liquid lead on heterogeneous surfaces were performed at 450°C using the dispensed drop technique. The surfaces were composed of regular silica-patterned high-purity iron with different square pillars and spacing (both from 5 to 500 µm). Iron is wetted by liquid lead whereas silica is not. The dynamic wetting was filmed at very short contact time (less than 1 s), in order to measure the evolution of the spreading diameter and the contact angle as a function of time. The contact angle hysteresis was deduced from these measurements. At the end of the spreading, the triple line of the solidified droplet was observed to be pinned on iron and to avoid the silica pillars. The experimental results obtained, namely the final contact angle, the contact angle hysteresis, the maximal spreading diameter and the dynamic contact angle, will be compared to theoretical estimations from models proposed in the literature.

1145.symp_name: International Symposium on Defects, Transport and Related Phenomena

1154.prez_name: Ab initio Modelling of the Cation Diffusion in La1-xSrxMnO3±δ and Yttria-stabilized Zirconia for SOFC Applications
