1155.prez_name: 3D Visualization of Elemental Tracer Foils after Friction Stir Welding
1155.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1155.prez_authors: Richard  Fonda, Amanda J Levinson, Keith E Knipling
1155.prez_abstract: This study examines the different behavior of elemental additions in commercial purity titanium friction stir welds.  Nickel additions have been shown to significantly enhance the weldability of CP titanium friction stir welds (FSWs), and other elements may also provide benefits.  However, those benefits will depend strongly on the strength and reactivity of the elemental foil additions. This talk will present the different 3D distributions, revealed by x-ray microtomography, of elemental foil fragments that can result and their reaction with the surrounding matrix for a variety of common elements.  These results will be correlated to the weldability and surface finish of each weld.

1156.prez_name: A Preliminary Research of Microstructure and Properties of Li-Ti Ferrite Joints Fabricated by Brazing Technique with Bismuthate Glass Solder
1156.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1156.prez_abstract: The Bi2O3-B2O3-SiO2-ZnO-BaO glass solder was used to join the Li-Ti ferrite. The Bi5(Ti3Fe)O15 whiskers were observed in the joints when the bonding temperature was equal to or higher than 700℃. The quantity and morphology of the Bi5(Ti3Fe)O15 whiskers could be controlled by adjusting the bonding temperature and applied pressure, which could decide the Ti content in the seam. Nearly defect-free joints were obtained and a maximum in the shear strength of 92MPa was achieved at 750℃ for 30min under 100Pa applied pressure. The dielectric properties of Li-Ti ferrite were barely affected by the bonding temperature of 700℃. The dielectric constant and dielectric loss of Li-Ti ferrite joints increased from 18 to 26 and from 0.07 to 1.85, respectively, when the brazing temperature rose from 675℃ to 750℃. The glass solder used in this investigation was quite compatible to Li-Ti ferrite and have a little influence on the joints.

1157.prez_name: Applicability of Filler Metal 16-8-2 for Structural Welds in 304H and 347H Steels for High Temperature Service
1157.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1157.prez_authors: Carolin  Fink, Huimin  Wang, Taylor  Wyan, Matthew  Bowen, Boian  Alexandrov, Jorge  Penso
1157.prez_abstract: Type 16-8-2 filler metal has been evaluated for use to weld Type 304H stainless steel to avoid hot ductility and creep-fatigue problems. Filler metal manufacturer information state this weld metal is characterized by an excellent high temperature microstructural stability, high hot cracking resistance at very low ferrite levels and good low-temperature toughness.This study presents results on the application of 16-8-2 filler metal for pressure vessels and piping, and structural welds on 304H and 347H for high temperature service in downstream oil and gas applications. An evaluation is made for susceptibility to sigma formation, stress relaxation cracking (SRC) during stabilization PWHT and service, toughness and corrosion behavior. Metallurgical characterization was performed by ferrite number measurement, LOM and SEM (EDX). Microstructural stability was investigated by simulating typical production PWHT and service conditions in a convection furnace and GleebleTM simulator. Further testing included Charpy impact testing at room temperature, SRC and IG corrosion testing.

1158.prez_name: Application of Modeling Tools for Understanding the Microstructures and Performance of Engineering Alloys
1158.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1158.prez_abstract: CALPHAD based tools have been developed over the last 30 years and used to accelerate materials design and process improvement. These tools are ideally suited for improving and controlling microstructural evolution for welding and joining applications, and several examples are provided such as: understanding microsegregation in welds and its influence on precipitation and creep properties, selection of filler metals, design of post weld heat treatments, and development of improved dissimilar metal welds.

1159.prez_name: Atomistic Simulations on the Sintering of Cu-Ag Core-shell Structures: Part 1 Theory and Approach
1159.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1159.prez_abstract: Sintering of nanoparticles (NPs) or nanowires (NWs) can be utilized for bonding between paste and the host electronic devices in electronic packaging. For property enhancement and more popular use, core-shell structures are employed for the NPs or NWs, which enables the cost reduction as well as the property tuning (via the control of structural parameters). Theoretical, numerical study of the sintering process and properties is expected to improve our understanding of nanostructure sintering and to facilitate the effective control of nanostructures and sintering conditions. As systems of interest fall into nanoscale, atomistic simulations are available for assessing sintering processes and sintered structure properties. This talk introduces various atomistic simulation methods, and discusses how simulation results are used for the analysis of sintering phenomena and for the calculation of mechanical, electrical, optical, and thermal properties. As an example, our recent research on the sintering of Cu-Ag core-shell nanostructures is demonstrated.

1160.prez_name: Bonding of Al Alloy Utilizing Instantaneous Melting by Multiple-reactions Combining Combustion Synthesis with Thermite Reaction
1160.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1160.prez_authors: Tomoki  Matsuda, Tomokazu  Sano, Akio  Hirose
1160.prez_abstract: Energy saving in bonding process is required particularly for the highly thermal diffusive materials such as Al. While combustion synthesis could be applied to the bonding, it has difficulties in activation energy of the reaction or formation of porosity. In contrast, bonding process utilizing two-step reactions combining thermite reaction with combustion synthesis would be effective in those problems. Purpose of this study is to investigate the influence of the bonding process on the bondability of Al joint. A three-layered compacted disc, consisting of materials for thermite reaction (Al-CuO) and combustion synthesis (Ti-B), was prepared as reaction material for bonding of Al alloy. The bondability was evaluated by strength test and microstructural observation. It was found that composite structures comprising both synthesized TiB2 and Al base metal, which was flown into the porosity during melting, contributed to the bonding. Details of the experimental results will be addressed in the presentation.

1161.prez_name: Ceramic-metal Joining on the Nanoscale: Engineered Interfaces for Robust Thermal Performance
1161.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1161.prez_authors: David R Driscoll, Stephen W Sofie
1161.prez_abstract: A unique perspective regarding the necessity of robust ceramic-metal interfaces is observed in high-temperature metallic catalysts.  Catalyst attrition in automotive catalytic converters is so severe that harvesting platinum metals group from roadside soils has been considered.  In high-temperature electrochemical cells, atomic migration of nano-scale nickel supported on oxide ceramics yields severe performance loss through loss of surface area and electronic percolation within device electrodes.Aluminum titanate, Al2TiO5 (ALT), has been used stabilize nickel microstructures supported on yttria-stabilized zirconia substrates against thermal coarsening via chemical doping and subsequent thermal processing.  ALT modified interfaces have been investigated by atom probe tomography where secondary phases form diffuse interfaces with nickel.  The phenomenon of triple line ridging as a potential diffusion barrier is also being investigated.  Finally, the influence of ALT doping on the mechanical strength of cermets will be discussed with respect to the joining of metal with the ceramic support.

1162.prez_name: Characterization of Fatigue Damage in Dissimilar Friction Stir Welded Aluminum-to-Magnesium alloys
1162.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1162.prez_authors: H. M. Rao, JB  Jordon, W  Yuan
1162.prez_abstract: Friction stir welding has been demonstrated as an effective welding process for joining dissimilar metals like aluminum and magnesium alloys.  However, limited research exists on the fatigue performance and failure mechanisms.  As such, in this presentation, we present the results of a recent study on the fatigue behavior of friction stir linear welded dissimilar 6022 aluminum to AM60 magnesium alloys. Several lap joint configurations were explored including lap-shear and coach-peel coupons. In general, the test results exhibited significant scatter in the fatigue life and the corresponding failure modes. Post-mortem analysis revealed two distinct modes of failure. The first mode of failure was dominated by kinked crack formation in the thermo-mechanically affected zone, where fretting debris was observed at the initiation sites. The second mode of failure occurred by interfacial weld separation, where fatigue cracks initiated at weld defects and then propagated through the brittle intermetallic phase.

1163.prez_name: Characterization of Joints Formed Using an Air Braze Joining Process for Silicon Carbide and Silicon Nitride Substrates
1163.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1163.prez_abstract: Fabrication of technical ceramics into larger and often more complex components for industrial use - such as in heat exchangers and energy production systems, wear components, metrology tooling, semiconducting processing equipment, etc. - requires joining solutions that are robust, with sufficient joint strength and corrosion resistance.  Ceramatec has developed a diffusion-enhancing air braze process for both silicon carbide and silicon nitride.  Joints exhibit strength similar to those of the substrates joined.  Current joint characterization, strength, and corrosion resistance of joints formed using both silicon carbide and silicon nitride substrates will be discussed.

1164.prez_name: Deposition of Reactive Multilayer Films for Nanojoining
1164.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1164.prez_authors: Ying  Ma, Hong  Li, Anming  Hu
1164.prez_abstract: Reactive multilayer thin film is a relatively new form of energetic material that consists of a well-defined, heterogeneous structure and stored chemical energy. It has obtained intense scientific interest due to its potential application in diverse fields such as joining components, igniters, and power sources. Compared to conventional joining methods, reactive multilayer films can provide higher reaction velocity and faster heating/cooling rate within 50ms due to self-propagating high-temperature synthesis (SHS). Here we present a Ni/Ti multilayer film prepared by magnetron sputtering, compared with Ni/Al and Ti/Al multilayer films, ignited by laser. The influence of different sputtering parameters and ignition parameters on multilayer structure and laser-induced self-propagating behaviors will be discussed. The interface formation and revolution will be demonstrated. The shearing strength of the joint also will be discussed. Reactive multilayer film provides a promising bonding technique for packaging of functional devices and mechanical systems.

1165.prez_name: Development of Graded Transition Joints for Avoiding Dissimilar Metal Weld Failures
1165.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1165.prez_abstract: Dissimilar Metal Welds (DMWs) are critical for design, development, and manufacturing of Very High Temperature Reactors (VHTR).  Premature failures of DMWs in service  are associated with the sharp change in composition, microstructure, and properties that exist across the fusion line. A proposed solution is a joint whose composition changes gradually from ferrous to austenitic steel to mitigate carbon diffusion and property mismatch. This research proposes that a graded transition joint (GTJ) will exhibit minimal changes in hardness when compared to the DMW, suggesting carbon diffusion will be limited. The DMWs exhibited large changes in hardness over short distances due to carbon diffusion, while the GTJ did not exhibit drastic changes in hardness values after aging. The GTJs exhibited no local softening near the fusion line. Future work includes hardness tests after longer aging times with finer spaced traces to continue investigation of carbon diffusion.

1166.prez_name: Diffusion and Phase Transformations during Dissimilar Metal Welding of Grade 91 Steel
1166.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1166.prez_authors: Michael W Kuper, Boian T Alexandrov, D Joshua Burgess, Michael J Mills
1166.prez_abstract: Recently, a handful of premature and unpredictable failures have occurred near the dissimilar interface between Grade 91 and nickel based filler metals used in fossil fired power plants.  This type of failure can result in the loss of millions of dollars in revenue due to down time and repairs.  To better understand these failures and their root cause, it is important to understand how chemistry and temperature are influencing the microstructural evolution and properties near the fusion line.  Therefore, thermal histories from the heat affected zone were measured by implanting thermocouples into the base material and plunging an additional one into the weld pool during welding.  This data was then used to model diffusion and phase transformations during welding to predict the final microstructure and composition near the fusion boundary.  These results were then compared with real welds for experimental validation.

1167.prez_name: Dissimilar Friction Welding of Stainless Steel to 1018 Steel
1167.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1167.prez_authors: Zhenzhen  Yu, Nathan  Switzner, Michael  Eff, Thomas J. Lienert, Stephen  Liu
1167.prez_abstract: The feasibility of applying inertia friction welding technique for solid-state cladding was investigated. Dissimilar joining of 304L stainless steel to 1018 steel was performed using both inertia friction welding and fusion welding, and comparison of the parameters-microstructure-property relationships was made between the two techniques.  IFW resulted in a narrower HAZ (~2.5 mm) in the 1018 base metal than the fusion cladding (~5 mm). Martensite exists at the interface of both the IFW and the fusion weld, but the martensite layer is discrete and narrower in IFW. Moreover, the austenite near the IFW interface was found to be fine grains of 5-10 µm in size in contrast with the coarse austenite solidification structure in the fusion weld with anisotropic grains larger than 80 µm in the growth direction. IFW exhibited slightly higher ultimate tensile strength and lower elongation than fusion weld, which is attributed to the narrower HAZ in IFW.

1168.prez_name: Dissimilar Friction Welding of Titanium Alloy to Nickel Alloy Using Insert Metal
1168.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1168.prez_authors: Tomo  Ogura, Takahiro  Matsumura, Tomoya  Imai, Kazuyoshi  Saida
1168.prez_abstract: The effects of insert metal on friction weldability of Ti-6Al-4V alloy to Inconel 718 alloy was investigated. Microstructural analysis was revealed that formation of intermetallic compounds between titanium and nickel at the interface were suppressed using inset metal. Diffusion of solutes in base metal and melting of insert metal was also recognized at the interface, showing the combined effects of friction and brazing. Tensile strength of the joint was significantly improved to over 700MPa as compared with the direct friction-welded joint of 400MPa.

1169.prez_name: Ductile Boron Bearing Welding Materials for TIG-braze and Weld Repair of Turbine Engine Components
1169.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1169.prez_authors: Mathieu  Brochu, Yuan  Tian, Alexandre  Gontcharov, Paul  Lowden, Joe  Liburdi
1169.prez_abstract: Microstructure and mechanical properties of multi-pass Tungsten Inert Gas (TIG) welds produced using Inconel 625 and Haynes 230 wires modified with B / B and C were studied. It was observed that B / B and C modification have increased the eutectic amount to a level sufficient to heal cracks from backfilling effect. In B-modified IN625 build, the Laves phase formed during welding transformed into isolated borides after annealing and aging processes. In B and C-modified IN625 build, a higher fraction of NbC were detected. In B-modified H230 welds, agglomerated W borides and Cr carbides were observed after PWHT process. Finally, in B and C-modified H230 welds, a higher content of Cr carbides was detected. The tensile tests at both ambient and elevated temperatures indicated that multi-pass TIG welds using B / B and C-modified IN625 and H230 possessed superior strength and ductility.

1170.prez_name: Effect of Hydrogen Dissolution on Advanced Welding Flux Design for High Strength Steels
1170.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1170.prez_abstract: Recently developments in the commercialization of advanced high strength steels containing high contents of Mn have resulted in significant focus on hydrogen embrittlement and induced cracking at the weld zone. However, the amount of hydrogen effect on the mechanical properties on dissimilar metal welds have been widely studied, the initial control of the hydrogen infiltration into the weld zone by utilizing an optimized welding flux has only limited studies. In the present work, the effect of hydrogen solubility in NaF-CaO-Al2O3-FeOt flux system for AHSS. According to result, higher contents of Fe3+ affected hydrogen solubility depending on the dominant mechanism. At acidic flux composition of CaO/Al2O3 is on 0.8, incorporate hydroxyl was dominant mechanism, which higher contents of Fe2O3 increased the hydrogen dissolution in flux system. At basic flux compositions of CaO/Al2O3 above 1.0, free hydroxyl was dominant mechanism, which higher contents of Fe2O3 decreased the hydrogen dissolution in flux system.

1171.prez_name: Effect of Multiple Reweld Passes on the Solidification and Cracking Response of 304L Stainless Steel
1171.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1171.prez_authors: Jeffrey M Rodelas, Charles  V Robino, Michael  C Maguire
1171.prez_abstract: Recent experience has shown increased solidification crack susceptibility in autogenous laser welds on 304L stainless steel during routine rework/repair welding.  Microstructural examination shows a shift from the desired solidification crack-resistant primary ferrite solidification mode to crack-susceptible primary austenite as the number of rewelds increases.  Solidification cracks have been observed after a single reweld of otherwise crack-resistant 304L compositions.  This shift in primary solidification mode is attributed to selective loss of high vapor pressure alloying elements, predominantly Cr and Mn, through evaporation.  In this work, electron microprobe measurements of weld composition are used to quantify alloying loss and its effect on solidification behavior.  The effects of welding mode (i.e., pulsed seam vs. continuous wave seam), alloy composition, and atmosphere will also be presented.  *Sandia is a multiprogram laboratory operated by Sandia Corporation, a Lockheed-Martin Company, for the United States Department of Energy’s National Nuclear Security Administration under contract DE-AC04-94AL85000.

1172.prez_name: Effect of Secondary Phases on the Corrosion Behaivour of Duplex Alloys Subjected to Natural Seawater
1172.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1172.prez_abstract: A duplex, superduplex and a hyperduplex stainless steel were aged at 900°C for 1, 10 and 60 minutes in order to promote the formation and susceptibility of secondary phases. Thereafter, the samples were inmersed to natural seawater for thirty days in order to study their corrosion behaviour in function of the volume of secondary phases. Microstructural analysis in the aging-condition showed Cr-depletion zones due to the formation of sigma phase, indicating a high predisposition to localized corrosion. On the other hand, all samples after inmersion were attacked by pitting corrosion, showing that the superduplex and hyperduplex stainless steel are more affected than the duplex stainless steel due to the high volume of sigma phase formed, making evident that the more content of Cr, the more formation of sigma phase.

1173.prez_name: Enabling Curvilinear, Dissimilar Alloy Tailor-welded Blanks
1173.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1173.prez_authors: Yuri  Hovanski, Piyush  Upadhyay, Dustin  Marshall, Thomas  Luzanski
1173.prez_abstract: While tremendous success has been shown in using high speed friction stir welding to produce aluminum tailor-welded blanks between similar alloys with dissimilar thicknesses, unique challenges arise when trying to combine different combinations of alloys.  An evaluation of high speed FSW temperatures in 5XXX, 6XXX and 7XXX aluminum alloys was made to demonstrate the relevant thermal regimes for each alloy.  Overlaying the thermal telemetry with the elevated temperature flow stress data revealed unique operating windows for each set of alloy combinations such that successful joints could be produced between 5XXX, 6XXX, and 7XXX series alloys.  The individual response of alloys to welding speed is explored in relation to the overall development and location of the heat-affected zone, and weld properties and post-weld formability of the dissimilar alloy blanks are evaluated.

1174.prez_name: Evaluation of Solidification Crack Susceptibility in Laser Beam Welds of Reduced Activation Ferritic/Martensitic Steel F82H
1174.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1174.prez_authors: Hiroaki  Mori, Takaya  Hitomi, Hideki  Mitsunari, Masakazu  Shibahara, Hideo  Sakasegawa, Takanori  Hirose, Hiroyasu  Tanigawa
1174.prez_abstract: Reduced activation ferritic/martensitic steel F82H has been decided to be used as a structural material for the blanket modules set on inner walls of fusion reactors. Laser beam welding (LBW) will be adopted as a welding method to construct them. However the design guide for LBW is unspecified yet. Because, the weldability of the steel using LBW has not been investigated adequately. Therefore, in this study, to evaluate the susceptibility and critical strain for the center-line cracking, which is one of typical solidification cracking, the side-bead test was adopted as a testing method. Based on experiments and calculation by a thermal elastic plastic analysis, cracks were found to be stopped at a certain value of 1/ρ. Thus, in the case of LBW for the steel, it was assumed that the critical strain for preventing the center-line cracking can be determined due to evaluate the critical 1/ρ value using the test.

1175.prez_name: Evolution of Grain Boundary Coarsened Zones in INCONEL Alloy 740H
1175.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1175.prez_abstract: An investigation into the microstructural evolution of INCONEL® alloy 740H® fusion welds during creep has been conducted, with particular emphasis on γ’-coarsened zones that form via grain boundary deformation-induced discontinuous coarsening. Interrupted creep and creep-rupture tests have been used to assess the evolution of the coarsened zones as a function of time at temperature, creep strain, and plastic prestrain. Post-weld processing has been investigated as a means to inhibit coarsened zone formation and restore weld metal creep performance. The development of γ’-coarsened zones has been shown to depend most strongly on the total strain experienced during creep. The differences in coarsened zone formation between creep specimens have been related to the differences in strain and the relative ease of grain boundary motion. The results presented in this study offer detailed observations on the evolution of deleterious grain boundary features.

1176.prez_name: Examination of Explosively Bonded Interfaces via Three-dimensional Reconstruction
1176.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1176.prez_authors: Olivia  Underwood, Jonathan  Madison, Lisa  Deibler, Jeffrey  Rodelas
1176.prez_abstract: Three-dimensional reconstructions produced from micro-computed tomography are used to evaluate the bonding characteristics of explosively bonded interfaces in stainless steel.  Joining length, bonding cross-sectional area and characteristic feature lengths will be presented as functions of processing parameters.  This interrogation serves as a portion of a larger effort to steer, guide and provide a more rigorous scientific basis for regimes of favorable and unfavorable joining parameters.  A discussion of the metallurgical joining processes at play will also be provided. Sandia National Laboratories is a multi-program laboratory managed and operated by Sandia Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Lockheed Martin Corporation, for the U.S. Department of Energy’s National Nuclear Security Administration under contract DE-AC04-94AL85000

1177.prez_name: Explanation of the Presence of Ferrite in the Simulated ICHAZ Microstructure of Grade 91 Steel
1177.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1177.prez_abstract: Through dilatomerty measurements, a ferrite phase transformation has been observed on cooling from the intercritical heat affected zone temperature range (Ac1 to Ac3 temperature) in Grade 91 samples heated in a GleebleTM Thermo-Mechanical Simulator.  LOM, SEM and EPMA characterization methods have been used to try and identify the ferrite constituent in the microstructure.  Though additional GleebleTM experiments, the factors that influenced the amount of ferrite within the microstructure were investigated.  From these experiments, explanations to explain why ferrite is present in just the interracial HAZ and nowhere else in the HAZ have been developed.

1178.prez_name: Factors Affecting Grain Size in High Frequency Welding
1178.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1178.prez_abstract: High Frequency (HF) welded tube and pipe is used for oil and gas and automotive to mechanical tubing and hollow structural sections.  The principles are straight forward: heat two edges using electric currents then forge together into a solid state weld.  However, new alloys and increased demands on properties of final product have necessitated improved process control.  The research presented here focuses on the factors that influence grain size in the heat affected zone (HAZ), which can be used to better characterize the weld and improve weld quality.  This research includes controlled mill experiments as well as laboratory based heat treatments.  Line speed, welder AC frequency, welder power, forge pressure, alloy composition, weld area setup, and post weld cooling are considered in this study.  The results revealed the strongest relationship between welder power level and HAZ grain size, but line speed and weld area setup also play a significant role.

1179.prez_name: Fatigue Behaviour of AL-6XN Super Austenitic Stainless Steel Welds
1179.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1179.prez_authors: Iván Salvador Cortés-Cervantes, Víctor Hugo López-Morelos, Yukio  Miyashita, Carlos Alberto León, Alberto  Ruiz
1179.prez_abstract: In this study, plates of AL-6XN<SUP>®</SUP> alloy with a single-V-groove preparation were gas metal arc welded (GMAW) using an ER-NiCrMo3 filler wire and Ar+3%N<SUB>2</SUB> as shielding gas, parameters were adjusted to heat input 1.38 kJ/mm. The aim of this work was to evaluate the fatigue behavior of the welded joint under constant stress amplitude (Δσ/2) between 135 to 170 MPa (R=0.1) and uniaxial load. Wöhler diagram (S-N) was obtained and fractured surfaces of the fatigued specimens were observed in the scanning electron microscope. The results indicate that for a stress amplitude of 170 MPa, 4.19x10<SUP>5</SUP> cycles are required for failure, whereas for 135, 140 and 145 MPa, 1x10<SUP>7</SUP> cycles were reached without failure. The failures were characterized by brittle fracture due to cleavage associated with intrusions and extrusions at the surface of the specimens by fatigue crack nucleation at the HAZ and then propagating toward the weld metal.

1180.prez_name: Ferrite Control in Type 410 Stainless Steel
1180.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1180.prez_authors: David  Stone, Boian T Alexandrov, Jorge  A Penso
1180.prez_abstract: In the Oil and Gas industry, high amounts of sulfur found in the working condition leads to highly corrosive environments. Because of its hardenability and adequate resistance against oxidation, sulfur attack, and halide stress corrosion cracking (SCC), martensitic stainless steels are generally selected for such applications. Due to the unexpected loss of toughness found in 410 steel welds, a study was carried out on delta ferrite volume control. Through a model based design of experiment (DOE) over the 410 steel composition window, the possible rage of ferrite content was predicted using thermodynamic simulations. The results from the DOE were used to develop a model predicting ferrite content in type 410 alloys. Validation of the model was then carried out over custom alloys using imaging analysis to find total ferrite content. By using the created model for alloy selection, reducing total ferrite to below 20% (FN) is possible.

1181.prez_name: Finite Element Analysis of Groove Shrinkage in Muti-pass Circumferential Welding with Narrow Gap
1181.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1181.prez_authors: Hisashi  Serizawa, Ryosuke  Doi, Hidekazu  Murakawa
1181.prez_abstract: In order to predict the gap width shrinkage in multi-pass circumferential butt welding of thick-walled pipes, three-dimensional (3D) thermal elastic-plastic finite element analyses were conducted, where the out & inner diameters and the width of target model are 700, 400 and 650 mm, respectively according to the experimental result.  The materials of pipes and filler wire are set to be IN617.  From the serial computations by varying the total angle and the model with of 3D pipes, it is found that 90 degree model is considered to be enough and the width of pipes should be wider than 500 mm for demonstrating the experimental result.  In addition, the numerical result of groove shrinkage up to 74th pass suggests that a point at the change of groove shrinkage is affected by the penetration shape while the slopes of groove shrinkage seem to be independent of the penetration shape.

1182.prez_name: Fracture Toughness Comparison between Friction Stir Welds in Two API-5L-X80 Steels with Different Microstructure and Composition
1182.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1182.prez_authors: Julian Arnaldo Avila, Eduardo  Fonseca , Johnnatan  Rodriguez, Antonio Jose Ramirez
1182.prez_abstract: Friction stir welding (FSW) offers attractive mechanical properties for pipeline steel applications; however, differences in weld properties related to parent materials have not been reported in the open literature. In order to establish whether the initial microstructure and mechanical properties of t API-5L-X80 steel base plate affects the microstructure and fracture toughness of a two- pass FSW joint, two steels fabricated with differences in microstructure and chemical composition were assessed by fracture toughness testing in different microstructural regions of the weld. Crack tip opening displacement (CTOD) tests were performed at 0, -20 and -40°C. The fracture toughness values were similar in the assessed conditions, where high values on average (CTOD >0.1 mm) at 0 ºC and -20°C were found. Finally, at -40°C all the assessed conditions suffered a further generalized drop in toughness; however, through-thickness notches located at the hardest zone presented CTOD values below 0.1 mm.

1183.prez_name: Friction Stir Welding: Benefits and Unique Issues
1183.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1183.prez_abstract: In the last ~20 years friction stir welding (FSW) has matured and a number of benefits attributable to this solid state joining process have been demonstrated.  Indeed, FSW is now used in production applications around the globe.  Benefits have been demonstrated in different material systems including aluminum, iron, magnesium, and copper based alloys.  This includes both wrought and cast materials.  These benefits will be highlighted.  However, FSW does have unique issues and challenges.  To optimize potential opportunities, users of FSW also need to understand associated limitations.  Limitations can include limited access, lack of portability and other logistical issues but also unique flaws or defects that require NDE approaches, or if necessary selective destructive tests, that are tailored to locate flaws specific to FSW.  Thus, this presentation will balance a review of the benefits of FSW coupled with unique issues that the FSW practitioner needs to consider.

1184.prez_name: Fundamental Issues of Wetting and Interfacial Reactions during Joining of Ceramics by Brazing Alloys
1184.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1184.prez_abstract: Interfacial reactions between liquid metals and ceramics are of technological importance in many fields of materials engineering such as joining of ceramics by brazing alloys, manufacturing of metal/ceramic composites, casting of metals, etc. In non-reactive metal-ceramic systems non-wetting is usually observed. In these systems, wetting can be significantly improved by certain alloying elements which form continuous layers of compounds at the interface, by reaction with the ceramic substrate. Such reactions are used in practice to promote wetting, especially for joining of ceramics by brazing alloys. The purpose of this presentation is to focus on the fundamental issues of reactive wetting and interfacial reactions that intervene during brazing of ceramics by reactive alloys. Some particular cases of brazing of metals and oxide or non-oxide ceramics in non-reactive and reactive systems are presented and discussed in order to show how wetting and reactivity can affect brazeability and the properties of brazed joints.

1185.prez_name: High Performance Micro-supercapacitors on Flexible Polyimide Sheets Using Femtosecond Laser Writing and Au Coating
1185.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1185.prez_authors: Anming  Hu, Shutong  Wang, Yongchao  Yu, Denzel  Bridges, Delong  Ma, Guoying  Feng
1185.prez_abstract: We successfully demonstrated flexible high performance micro-supercapacitors (MSCs) on polyimide sheets through 3D femtosecond laser direct writing (3D-FLDW) and Au coating. SEM images displays that focused pulsed laser irradiation rapidly converts the polyimide surface into an electrically conductive porous carbon structure, and 3D-FLDW is an effective tool to construct multi-layer device with micro/nano porous structure on a flexible substrate. Compared to the in-plane MSc, the specific capacitance of the mutil-layer MSCs increase from 15 mF/cm2 to 25 mF/cm2 at a voltage scan rate of 10 mV/s. After Au coating and thermal sintering of nanoparticles, these flexible MSCs reached superior rate capability even at a field sweeping rate of 200 V/s due to 3D conductive network. These high performance MSCs can be potentially integrated with applications for portable and wearable electronic devices, solar cells, gas sensors, field-effect transistors, and chip-level display devices.

1186.prez_name: Improvement of Fatigue Properties of Laser-welded 2024-T3 Aluminum Alloy Using Femtosecond Laser Peening
1186.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1186.prez_authors: Takayuki  Eimura, Tomokazu  Sano, Akio  Hirose, Seiichirou  Tsutsumi, Masami  Mizutani, Yousuke  Kawahito, Seiji  Katayama, Kazuto  Arakawa, Ayumi  Shiro, Takahisa  Shobu, Kiyotaka  Masaki, Yuji  Sano
1186.prez_abstract: Femtosecond laser peening can improve fatigue properties of 2024-T3 aluminum alloy without plasma confinement medium and coating on the surface in the air. The purpose of this study is to investigate effects of femtosecond laser conditions such as pulse energy and the pulse number per unit square on the fatigue properties of laser-welded 2024-T3 aluminum alloy.Plane bending fatigue tests were conducted at a stress ratio of −1.The fatigue life of laser-welded 2024-T3 aluminum alloy which is peened by femtosecond laser was over 50 times greater than unpeened specimens at the stress amplitude of 120 MPa. The fatigue strength at 2106 cycles of laser-welded 2024-T3 aluminum alloy which is peened by femtosecond laser alloy was 20 MPa larger compared to unpeened specimens.Effects of femtosecond laser peening on reinforcement factors such as height, width and flank angle on will also be addressed in the presentation.

1187.prez_name: In-situ Microstructure Distribution during Friction Stir Welding of Austenite Stainless Steel
1187.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1187.prez_abstract: The pin route during welding termination were tracked and used to determine the pin position just prior to weld termination. This approach enable analyzing the in situ microstructure distribution and the nature of material flow during FSW. During FSW, a compression zone (CPZ) and a material flow zone (MFZ) formed in sequence ahead of the pin. The CPZ mainly consisted of coarse deformed grains. The MFZ was characterized by fine recrystallized grains. As the material approached the pin, the cubic texture of the base material was transformed into C fiber texture in the CPZ. The shear direction aligned at about 40 to 60 deg from the pin tangent. As material from the CPZ entered the MFZ, the C fiber transformed into A fiber texture in the material flow zone. The shear direction is approximately parallel to the pin tangent.

1188.prez_name: Interface Characterization in Alumina Joints Brazed Using Ag-Cu-Ti Alloys
1188.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1188.prez_authors: Kun-Lin   Lin , Mrityunjay   Singh , Rajiv  Asthana
1188.prez_abstract: Two Ag–Cu–Ti brazes, Cusil-ABA (63Ag–35.3Cu–1.75Ti) and Ticusil (68.8Ag–26.7Cu–4.5Ti) were used to join polycrystalline Al2O3 previously sintered to achieve different porosity contents. Joint characterization using optical microscopy (OM), x-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) revealed a duplex interfacial reaction layer comprised of Ti2O and Cu3Ti3O. The reaction layer thickness was independent of the porosity content in the Al2O3. Thicker reaction layers formed with Ticusil (4.5%Ti) than with Cusil-ABA (1.75%Ti). Possible mechanisms for Ti2O and Cu3Ti3O formation in the reaction layer at braze/Al2O3 interface will be discussed together with their effect on joint properties.

1189.prez_name: Interpretation of Friction Stir Welding Flow Paths
1189.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1189.prez_abstract: Nanolamellar Cu-Nb bimetallic composites display high strength and ductility, in addition to radiation damage resistance.  Methods to join this type of material by friction stir welding may also provide insight into the material flow paths that occur.  The nanolamellar microstructure is composed of alternating layers of Cu and Nb approximately 200 nm in thickness.  Because of this unique nanolamellar structure, it is possible to interpret the final microstructure in terms of streamline flow to provide more details on the deformation experienced by the material during the friction stir welding process.  The stability and evolution of the interfacial microstructure and mechanical properties have been characterized using TEM, SEM, and nano indentation.

1190.prez_name: Investigation of the Effect of Composition on the Cracking Susceptibility of P91 Steels HAZ
1190.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1190.prez_authors: Guilherme Abreu Faria, John  Sieffert, Boian  Alexandrov, Antonio J. Ramirez
1190.prez_abstract: P91 steels are widely used as pressure vessels in the power generation industry due to their high creep resistance at high temperatures if compared to other ferritic steels combined with their low cost if compared to other potential alloys suitable for the same working conditions. However, the HAZ of such steels typically presents poor creep properties and susceptibility to cracking. Several different mechanisms have been proposed to explain the source of such susceptibility, but a consensus has not yet been achieved. In this work, we present a post mortem analysis of three P91 components which presented HAZ failure during service. The simulated HAZ of the analyzed components presents widely different creep properties and therefore they present a unique opportunity to identify what are the most sensible parameters regarding cracking susceptibility. Creep void nucleation within these materials was extensively investigated concerning their relationship with precipitates, inclusions, and tramp elements.

1191.prez_name: Joining Dissimilar Materials with Friction Stir Scribe Technology
1191.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1191.prez_authors: Piyush  Upadhyay, Yuri   Hovanski , Saumyadeep  Jana, Leo  Fifield
1191.prez_abstract: Automotive components once built almost entirely from mild steel are now a mix of multiple grades of steels, several alloys of magnesium, numerous forms of aluminum and an ever increasing mix of composite and polymer structures.  This multi-material solution provides a much needed flexibility in design optimization, but introduces significant challenges in joining materials with very different properties in a cost effective way.  Friction stir scribe technology was engineered to meet the demands of joining materials with drastically different properties and melting regimes. The process enables lap joining of metals like magnesium and aluminum to much higher melting temperature metals like titanium and steels. Furthermore, it creates linear joining opportunities between polymeric materials and metals. Current state of the art, progress made and challenges associated with this innovative derivative to traditional friction stir welding will be presented in reference to joining dissimilar metals and polymer/metal combinations.

1192.prez_name: Joining of Polymer Composite to Advanced High Strength Steel by Friction Bit Joining Process
1192.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1192.prez_authors: Hoonmo  Park, Yong Chae   Lim, Jong Khak   Keum, Junho   Jang, Zhili  Feng
1192.prez_abstract: Lightweight multi-material autobody structure becomes a new paradigm for automotive industries in order to comply with government regulations: to improve fuel efficiency and reduce green gas emission. These lightweight materials are aluminum alloys, magnesium alloys, advanced highs strength steels, and polymer composites. This mixed autobody structure must be fabricated while maintaining safety and performance of vehicle. However, technical difficulty in joining of dissimilar materials due to differences in its physical and chemical properties is a critical concern to achieve multi-material design approach. To overcome this technical obstacle, we employed novel solid-state joining process, which is called friction bit joining, to join advanced high strength steel (σTS>980MPa) to polymer composites. In this presentation, joining of advanced high strength steel and polymer composites by friction bit joining (FBJ) techniques is presented. Mechanical joint strength and microstructure of specimens made by FBJ is presented and discussed.

1193.prez_name: Laser Beam Weld for Thin-walled FeCrAl Cladding for Accident Tolerant Fuel
1193.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1193.prez_authors: Jian  Gan, Nathan D Jerred, Emmanuel  Perez, DC  Haggard, Corrie I Nichol, Haiming  Wen
1193.prez_abstract: FeCrAl alloy has been considered as cladding material for the light water reactor (LWR) accident-tolerant fuel due to its improved properties on oxidation resistance under loss-of-coolant condition over the present LWR zircaloy cladding. Because of higher thermal neutron absorption for FeCrAl alloy, weld techniques must be developed for FeCrAl cladding with wall thickness approximately 50% of the current zircaloy cladding.  This presentation will focus on the recent development on the laser beam weld for the thin-walled cladding with wall thickness of 350 micrometer.  The microstructure of the weld-affected zone will be characterized and mechanical property of the weld zone will be evaluated. This work has been focused on joining the emulated FeCrAl thin-walled cladding to the end plug.

1194.prez_name:
Life Extension of Pressurized Components
by Structural Weld Overlays
1194.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1194.prez_abstract: There are numerous damage mechanisms that occur in pressurized components such as corrosion, erosion, and fatigue.  Common code accepted repair techniques for pressurized components include weld metal buildup, sleaving, flush patch or window replacement, or component replacement.  Structural weld overlays are increasing being accepted as a viable alternative repair approach to increase component life, and have many advantages over conventional techniques such as increased corrosion or erosion resistance, increased structural strength, stress reversal and/or redistribution, and in some cases the ability to be applied in-situ while the component is in service.  The U.S. nuclear power generation industry has extensively utilized structural weld overlay to address widespread stress-corrosion cracking issues in austenitic stainless steel piping and alloy 600 dissimilar metal welds in nozzles and piping.  Case studies of the application of structural weld overlays will be provided including applications in nuclear and non-nuclear power generation, and the oil & gas industries.

1195.prez_name: Low Alloy Steel Welds in X65 Pipes Internally Clad with Nickel-based Alloy: Process Development and Mechanical Testing
1195.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1195.prez_abstract: Extraction of oil reserves from pre-salt subsea oil fields requires pipelines and risers to be joined with welds that overmatch the X65 pipe by 100 MPa, have high toughness, and do not utilize a PWHT. To meet these requirements, research is being conducted on low alloy steel (LAS) consumables as fill passes to join X65 pipes that are internally clad with nickel-based alloy with the root passes welded using nickel-based filler metal. Welding experiments commenced with bead-on-plate testing and proceeded into groove welding once compatibility was established with the end goal to create groove joints free of defects/cracking (solidification and liquation cracking, shrinkage porosity, and lack of fusion). Multiple welding processes and nickel-based substrates were used in a succession of Design of Experiments to identify a compatible combination. Mechanical testing, including hardness and tensile testing, was performed on groove welds to verify adequate properties.

1196.prez_name: Mechanical Properties of Ni-base Superalloy Brazed Joints for High Temperature Gas Turbine Applications
1196.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1196.prez_authors: Bryan E Riggs, Boian  Alexandrov, Avraham  Benatar, Ray  Xu
1196.prez_abstract: Brazing has been commonly used in the aerospace industry for manufacturing and repair of high temperature gas turbine engine components made from Ni-base superalloys. When designing and modeling brazed joints it is important to account for the size and distribution of phases and micro-constituents, their properties and property gradients across the joints. However, determining brazed joint properties is not very straight forward due to high tri-axial stress, the presence of flaws and stress concentrations in the joints. In this research, several new techniques were investigated to reveal the joint mechanical properties of CMSX-4 and Inconel 718 suberalloys brazed with AWS BNi-2 and BNi-9 filler metals. These techniques included small-scale tensile testing, fracture mechanics testing and digital image correlation (DIC). The experimental results using these test methods and their applications for Integrated Computational Materials Engineering (ICME) multi-scale modeling of braze joints will be discussed.

1197.prez_name: Metallurgical Characterization of Dissimilar Metal Welds in Grade F65 Steel to Grade F22 Steel Overlaid with Low Alloy Steel Filler Metal
1197.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1197.prez_abstract: Dissimilar metal welds (DMWs) are used regularly in the oil and gas industry to join high strength steels in order to eliminate the need for post weld heat treatment (PWHT) following field welding. Previous research has found nickel based overlays to be susceptible to hydrogen assisted cracking during sub-sea service while under cathodic protection. Low alloy steel (LAS) overlays have been used in place of nickel based overlays in order to mitigate the detrimental effects of carbon diffusion during PWHT. The goal of this research was to perform metallurgical characterization of low alloy steel (LAS) overlays welded to F65 steel pipes using nickel based Alloy 625 filler wire. Three different multi pass welding procedures were compared, none of which included a final PWHT. Optical microscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) and hardness testing were used to characterize the dissimilar joints.

1198.prez_name: Metallurgical Characterization of Super Duplex Stainless Steel & Nickel Alloy Dissimilar Metal Welds
1198.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1198.prez_abstract: Bead on plate experiments were performed using various super duplex stainless steel consumables over a nickel alloy substrate. Discontinuities encountered include solidification cracking and inter-dendritic voids in the partially mixed zone, called shrinkage porosity. Both were eliminated through using SDSS/nickel combinations that had a narrow, consistent solidification temperature range as a function of dilution between the two. Shrinkage porosity is theorized to be caused by a liquid layer suspended between two solidification fronts at the end of bulk solidification. Embrittling intermetallic phases are also an issue, and are evaluated using fractography of multi-layer bend tests.

1199.prez_name: Microestructural Evolution of Dissimilar Metal Weld at 475°C
1199.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1199.prez_abstract: The dissimilar metal weld between API X-52 and SAF 2507 were produced by GTA welding process employing ER-2594 as a filler metal. The microestructural characterization was carried on by optical and scanning electron microscopy in order to determine the nature of the fusion boundary region. Thereafter, the samples were submitted to thermal cycles at 475 ˚C for times of 1, 10 and 100 hours. Results showed the epitaxial growth from the grains in the partial melting zone to the weld metal through the martensite band, which confirms the formation of the grain boundary type I. The effect of the thermal cycles is represented by the thickness reduction of the martensite band due to the diffusion of alloy elements such as carbon, which promotes carbide formation in the weld metal and represents a reduction of the hardness and tensile test properties of the dissimilar metal weld.

1200.prez_name: Microstructural Evolution of Friction Stir Welded Steel Joints
1200.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1200.prez_authors: Yusei  Maeda, Tomoki  Matsuda, Tomokazu  Sano, Akio  Hirose, Atsushi  Takada, Muneo  Matsushita, Naoya  Hayakawa, Kenji  Oi
1200.prez_abstract: The purpose of the present study is to classify zones formed in friction stir butt welds of mild steels based on microstructural aspects of steel through observations using optical microscope, SEM and EBSD. Stir zone existed in the central part of the newly formed zones, which consisted of both the transformation microstructure from gamma to alpha phase due to heating above the A<SUB>c3</SUB> temperature and the dynamically recrystallized microstructure. Thermo-mechanically affected zone existed outside of the stir zone, where pearlite band was deformed and globular pearlite was observed, which was caused by the heating above the A<SUB>c1</SUB> temperature. In the zone between the thermo-mechanically affected zone and the base metal, the form of pearlite was not granulated and the pearlite band was slightly deformed, which indicates the heat affect was negligible and the mechanical affect was dominant in this zone. Therefore this zone can be named mechanical affected zone.

1201.prez_name: Microstructural Evolution of Simulated Heat Affected Zones in Cast Precipitation Hardened Stainless Steels 17-4 and 13-8+Mo
1201.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1201.prez_abstract: The objective of this project is to establish welding procedures for restoring the strength of welds on high strength steels. Welds were made on cast precipitation hardened (PH) stainless steels 17-4 and 13-8+Mo in the solution and aged condition (S-A-W condition) and in the solution treated condition with a post weld age (S-W-A condition). The microstructures were characterized using light optical microscopy, hardness traces were measured, cross-weld tensile testing was performed and MatCalc thermodynamic and kinetic modeling software was employed to predict the precipitate evolution through the heat affected zone (HAZ). Hardness values were higher through the HAZ for GMAW samples prepared in the S-W-A condition relative to the S-A-W condition, attributed to formation, growth and dissolution of strengthening precipitates. The results demonstrate that welding in the solution treated condition and giving a post weld with the established heat treatments can restore about 95% of the base metal properties.

1202.prez_name: Microstructure-property Relations in Arc Welded High Strength Low Alloy Steel Plates for Haul Truck Applications
1202.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1202.prez_authors: Emanuel  Santos, Adrian  Gerlich, Sashank  Nayak
1202.prez_abstract: Progressively increasing demands for higher base metal strengths in rigid dump trucks has led to their weldability testing. Gas metal arc welding with ER70S-6 welding wire and a shielding gas containing 90% Argon and 10% CO2 was used to weld ASTM A656 Grade 50 and Grade 80 steel plates. Microstructures at different weld zones were characterized using optical microscopy and scanning electron microscopy. Properties of the welded plates were measured in terms of hardness profiles, tensile test, and Charpy V-notch (CVN) impact toughness testing at -29ºC. Joint efficiency ranged from 89% to 100%, with tensile fractures always in the weld metal. CVN toughness of weld metal (18-21 Joules) was found to be lower compared to those of the heat affected zone (28-43 Joules). The paper will correlate the microstructure formed across the weldment with the properties and the specimen fracture mode.

1203.prez_name: Minimization of Carbon Diffusion and Thermal Stresses in Dissimilar Metal Welds in Nuclear Applications by the Development of Novel Functionally Graded Transition Joints
1203.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1203.prez_abstract: Dissimilar Metal Welds (DMWs) are critical for design, development, and manufacturing of Very High Temperature Reactors (VHTR). Experience has demonstrated that failures of such DMWs can be caused by carbon diffusion and thermal stresses due to CTE and property mismatch, each of which are driven by the large concentration gradient.  Graded transition joints (GTJ) were designed using alloys Grade 22, 347H, In82, and P87 and aged up to 6 months. Microstructural characterization was preformed to determine the concentration and hardness gradient, as well as the carbon diffusion through the grade. The results demonstrate that increasing the length of the grade in the GTJ significantly reduces the amount of carbon diffusion.  Furthermore, the steep hardness gradients seen in DMWs are significantly reduced in GTJs, thus eliminating the weak regions experienced in DMWs.  This research will benefit both the nuclear and fossil power generation industry by avoiding premature DMW failures that have plagued each industry for more than 40 years.

1204.prez_name: Optimization of Electron Beam Welding Parameters for Ti-6Al-4V Alloy by Using Taguchi Method
1204.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1204.prez_authors: Sandeep Vinayakrao Thakare, N  Prabhu, Rajkumar P Singh
1204.prez_abstract: In the present work electron beam welding was successfully applied to join Ti-6Al-4V alloy. Electron beam welding parameters such as accelerating voltage, beam current and welding speed was selected with the objective of full weld depth penetration with minimum weld bead width. For the optimization of welding parameters Taguchi approach was used as statistical design of experimental technique. From the experimental results it is found that the effect of welding parameters on the welding quality decreased in order of welding speed, beam current and accelerating voltage. The optimal combination of welding parameters is the accelerating voltage 60kV, beam current 70mA and welding speed 800mm/min. One more set of experiment at same parameters was conducted to validate the optimized parameters.

1205.prez_name: Optimization of Formate Coating Conditions on Cu Powder and Its Application for Solid-state Bonding of Cu/Cu Interface and Persistence of Reformed Layer
1205.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1205.prez_abstract: To examine the effect of bond strength at the Cu/Cu bonded joint interface of formate coated Cu powder, the interfacial microstructures and fractured surfaces of joint were observed using SEM. Cu powder surface was modified by exposure to formic acid vapor for predetermined time, and solid-state bonding was performed at a bonding temperature of 473-673 K under a load of 20 MPa (for a bonding time of 30 min). As a result of the formate coating, high strength joint can be achieved with lower bonding temperature. From the experimental results, it is found out that formate coating process is effective at removing oxide film and substitution to a metal salt on the Cu powder surface. In addition, the duration of the modification effects was investigated by exposing the modified surface to an air atmosphere furnace kept at 323 K.

1206.prez_name: Optimization of Induction Bending Parameters for DMW Overlays
1206.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1206.prez_abstract: Cracking of corrosion-resistant nickel-base alloy overlays on low-alloy carbon steel has been experienced in the Oil and Gas industry during the induction bending process while trying to reduce cost by using Alloy 825 as a cladding material in place of Alloy 625. The weld overlay microstructure has been classified as potentially susceptible to Ductility Dip Cracking (DDC). The aim of this research is to determine an optimal parameter window for induction bending of dissimilar metal weld overlays, particularly between Alloy 825 and X65 steel. Strain-to-fracture samples are removed from an overlaid pipe supplied by industry sponsors. The Gleeble™ thermo-mechanical simulator is used to recreate processing conditions seen during manufacturing. In-situ Digital Image Correlation (DIC) is used with the Gleeble™ to measure strain distribution during bending. Strain-to-fracture plots at varying strain rates are produced, and crack susceptibility is evaluated as a function of temperature, total strain, strain rate, and cooling rate.

1207.prez_name: Phase Transformations and Mechanical Properties of the Heat-affected Zone in 10 wt% Nickel Steel
1207.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1207.prez_abstract: 10 wt% Ni steel is a new high-strength steel that possesses high toughness from a deformation induced transformation of austenite to martensite, thereby classifying it as a TRIP steel. The objective of this study is to understand phase transformations and resultant mechanical properties of the heat affected zone (HAZ) in fusion welds of 10 wt% Ni steel. HAZ thermal cycles were simulated for gas metal arc welding conditions using a Gleeble 3500 thermo-mechanical simulator using a wide range of peak temperatures. The regions were chosen to match observed microstructures in a gas tungsten arc weld performed previously. Mechanical property measurements were made using tensile, Charpy impact, and hardness testing. The retained austenite content of the regions was quantified using X-ray diffraction. Microstructural characterization was accomplished through light optical and scanning electron microscopy, including electron backscattered diffraction. ThermoCalc, DICTRA, and MatCalc modelling was performed to help understand property and structure trends.

1208.prez_name: Precipitation Behavior during Welding of Ni-base Precipitation Strengthened Alloys 282 and 718.
1208.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1208.prez_authors: Graciela Carolina Penso, Boian T Alexandrov
1208.prez_abstract: Welding of internally clad X65 pipes for offshore tube reeling, must acquire filler metal overmatching strength by 100 MPa. Gas metal arc welding (GMAW) without post heat treatment (PWHT) is considered to achieve high productivity in this field welding.  The problem with using low alloy steel is that it causes solidification cracking, due to dilution with the alloy 625 internal pipe cladding. Precipitation behavior during multipass welding in alloys 282 (γ’) and 718 (γ’’) is evaluated as a potential strengthening mechanism to meet the weld metal overmatching strength requirement. In this investigation continuous cooling transformation diagrams for weld metal of alloys 282 and 718 will be developed. Several experimental techniques will be utilized to gain the desired results, such as single sensor differential thermal analysis (SS DTA), to determine the solidus and liquidus temperature, as well the formation of eutectic constituents and precipitation reactions.

1209.prez_name: Quantitative Microstructure Study of High Speed FSW Aluminum Alloy
1209.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1209.prez_authors: Jingyi  Zhang, Piyush  Upadhyay, Yuri  Hovanski, David   Field
1209.prez_abstract: Friction-Stir-Weld (FSW) is a time and cost efficient joining method for a wide variety of materials. And high speed FSW of aluminum alloys is of special interest to automobile industry due to the potential ability to further reduce body weight and enable more flexible alloy choices. In this study we employ electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) method and optic microscopy to generate systematic microstructural description of aluminum butt joint made of welding speed on the order of meters/minute. We focus on quantifying microstructural parameters and their correlation to mechanical properties of the weld. Butt joints of AA7075 and AA6022 welds are investigated in this work, their mechanical behavior along with texture evolution under different welding speed are presented.

1210.prez_name: Recent Developments on FSW of High Temperature Alloys
1210.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1210.prez_abstract: The increasing complexity of structural and functional materials is driving the development of new joining technologies. As an example, Friction Stir Welding (FSW) and other related processes have become a source of innovation and at the same time a challenge for the materials community. FSW has evolved to a mature and widely used technology to join Al, Mg and Cu alloys. However, expanding this technology to higher melting temperature materials as steels, stainless steels, Ti-alloys and Ni-based alloys has not been a trivial task. Steels, Stainless Steels and Ni-based alloys joining and processing using FSW and friction stir processing (FSP) is today possible and there are plenty of opportunities for this emerging technology application. Our most relevant R&D work on this field will be presented with examples on the joining and processing of steels, stainless steels, Ni-based alloys and some dissimilar combinations involving these materials.

1211.prez_name: Reduction Behavior of CuO Paste during Cu-to-Cu Bonding
1211.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1211.prez_authors: Takafumi  Yao, Tomokazu  Sano, Tomoki  Matsuda, Akio  Hirose, Katsunori  Ishii, Chiaki  Morikawa, Atsushi  Ohbuchi, Hisashi  Yashiro
1211.prez_abstract: We have been developing a bonding processes using CuO paste containing CuO particles and Polyethylene glycol 1000 (PEG1000) as a reduction solvent aiming to apply to joining electronic devices. Although Cu-to-Cu bonding using CuO paste was achieved in the air through reduction of CuO by the reduction solvent, the mechanisms of the reduction and bonding process have not been clarified. The purpose of the present study is to investigate the reduction behavior of CuO and the formation process of the bonding layer using simultaneous measurements of XRD and DSC and FT-IR analysis. XRD results showed CuO was once reduced to Cu2O around 235 degrees Celsius and subsequently reduced to Cu around 265 degrees Celsius. Results of FT-IR analysis clarified the reduction process of CuO and Cu2O by PEG1000, which is consistent with the results of XRD analysis.

1212.prez_name: Role of Inter-critical Heat-affected Zone in Type IV Cracking of Grade 91 Pipe Steel Weldments
1212.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1212.prez_abstract:
Grade 91 steel, also known as modified 9Cr-1Mo-VNb steel, is a creep strength-enhanced ferritic (CSEF) steel. It has been widely used in fossil fired power plants due to its high creep performance. However, creep strength degradation of its weldments commonly failed with the infamous Type IV cracking in inter-critical heated affected zone (ICHAZ). Study on ICHAZ can provide more understanding of Type IV cracking mechanism.
In this work, as-welded ICHAZ structure was investigated by field emission SEM and electron backscatter diffraction. The so-called soft zone is identified in ICHAZ by hardness mapping method. Characteristic structure in soft zone is a mixture of newly transformed prior austenite grains and fine retained tempered martensites (TMs). Those retained TMs are identified as recrystallized grains with a lower plastic strain magnitude, which is believed to undertake preferentially faster grain growth and larger creep strength decrease in the subsequent post-weld heat treatment and creep exposure.

1213.prez_name: Room Temperature Molecular Dynamics Simulations on the Sintering of Cu-Ag Core-shell Structures: Nanoparticles and Nanowires
1213.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1213.prez_abstract: Atomistic understanding of sintering mechanism is conducive to control sintering process and obtain sintered nanomaterials with tailored properties, so as to improve industrial applications in printable nanoinks, electrodes, and catalysts. Nanojoining by sintering of nanoparticles (NPs) and nanowires (NWs) with different geometries are carried out at room temperature with molecular dynamics simulations. The evolution of potential energy and local crystalline structure during sintering process are analyzed to identify sintering mechanisms (SMs). Depending on different shell thickness, various SMs including crystallization-amorphization, reorientation, Shockley partial dislocation are determined. In all NP and NW sintering cases, a three-stage sintering scenario can be observed and the Cu core does not participate in sintering process, however, it plays the role of enhancing the mobility of Ag shell atoms, contributing to the shrinkage growth and bonding strength at low temperatures. The Young’s modulus and yield strength of sintered NWs are finally obtained from tensile test.

1214.prez_name: Soldering and Brazing Microelectronic Components without Thermal Damage
1214.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1214.prez_abstract: Over the last two decades we have developed reactive nanostructured foils that can act as local heat sources to solder microelectronic components without thermal damage. The foils contain hundreds of nanoscale layers that alternate between materials with large, negative heats of mixing, and heat is generated when the layers react exothermically to form compounds in a rapid, self-propagating manner. The presentation will begin by exploring the physical parameters that control the ignition and the propagation of the reactions. Then examples of joining applications will be described, and the thermal and mechanical properties of the bonds will reviewed. Examples include CPU and LED bonding. The presentation will conclude by introducing a new thermite foil that enables brazing at room temperature.

1215.prez_name: Stereolithographic Additive Manufacturing of Metal Photonic Crystals for Terahertz Wave Modulation
1215.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1215.prez_abstract: By using stereolithographic additive manufacturing, micro photonic crystals with metal lattices could be fabricated to control electromagnetic waves in terahertz frequency. Aspect ratio of lattice length to diameter and spatial coordinates of binding sites were modulated and defined using 1/f fluctuation theory. A laser scanner with automatic collimator was newly equipped to realize precise micro pattering and high speed drawing by finer or larger beam spots, respectively. Photo sensitive acrylic resins with pure copper of 3 μm in diameter at 60 vol.% were spread on a substrate with 10 μm in thickness. An ultraviolet laser beam of 355 nm in wavelength was adjusted from 10 to 100 μm in diameter and scanned on the pasted resin surface. Irradiation power was changed from 10 to 200 mW to obtain enough solidification depth for layer joining. Cross sectional patterns were laminated, and composite precursors were dewaxed and sintered in vacuum atmosphere.

1216.prez_name: Stress Relief Cracking in Precipitation Strengthened Alloys
1216.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1216.prez_abstract: Many alloys that are used at high temperature exhibit stress relief cracking (SRC) during welding and/or service. This form of cracking typically occurs along the grain boundaries and results in a low ductility fracture. The problem is often associated with precipitation strengthened alloys in which a locally soft precipitate free zone forms along the grain boundaries.  In this research, SRC tests were conducted with Gleeble methods on Alloys 617, 740H, 230, and 347H, and the results were supported by various microstructural characterization techniques. The results are described with the aid of known precipitation processes in these alloys.

1217.prez_name: Three-dimensional Numerical Simulations of Keyhole  Behavior and Molten Pool Dynamics in Laser Welds Based on Thermal-hydraulic
1217.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1217.prez_authors: Qiaofeng  Zhou, Katsuma  HORIO, Fumikazu  MIYASAKA, Hiroaki  MORI, Masami  MIZUTANI, Yosuke  KAWAHITO, Seiji  KATAYAMA
1217.prez_abstract: Porosity is one of the problems in laser beam welding. Numerical analyses based on fluid dynamics and in-situ observation using the X-ray transmission real-time imaging system were conducted in this study, to make clear the mechanism of porosity formation in weld metal during LBW. Moreover, prediction of porosity formation due to the numerical analysis is investigated, to establish the system to produce sound joints of LBW for aluminum. At the recent study, the formation of keyhole, dynamic flow of molten aluminum and bubbles’ formation and their movement during LBW were calculated and observed by the simulation and imaging system, respectively. The calculated dynamic flow of molten aluminum around the keyhole and motion of bubbles formed in weld metal were quantitatively good accordance with those of observation results. Therefore, it was concluded that the developed numerical simulation method in this research might be useful to predict the porosity formation in LBW.

1218.prez_name: To Design of Welding Procedure to Avoid Delayed Cracking Phenomenon in ASTM A335 P22 Material
1218.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1218.prez_authors: Fahad  Riaz, Muhammad  Kamran, Adil  Ashraf, Nauman  Aslam, Tahir  Ahmad
1218.prez_abstract: Single side 12mm thick V butt joint was prepared applying GTAW and SMAW process on 2.25Cr-1Mo (P22) low hydrogen filler material 90SB3.  A post weld heat treatment (PWHT) was  carried out on these welded samples to reduce the induced stresses in weld joints. Weld joints were characterized in terms of change in mechanical properties and development in microstructure. It was observed that weld joint prepared using GTAW is more ductile than weld joint prepared using SMAW. After PWHT, the ductility of the welded materials is increased regardless of the joining process. It was also observed that SMAW weld joint of P22 material exhibited high hardness compared to GTAW weld joint. Hardness and tensile values obtained were in compliance to the standard requirements to suppress delayed cracking phenomenon. Delayed cracking phenomenon was successfully eliminated by using low hydrogen electrode and by increase in heat input rate during different passes of welding.

1219.prez_name: Weldability of Titanium Alloy Using Transient Liquid Phase Diffusion Bonding Method
1219.symp_name: Joining of Advanced and Specialty Materials (JASM XVIII)
1219.prez_abstract: The viability of joining of titanium alloy using transient liquid phase (TLP) diffusion bonding was investigated. Commercially pure Ti (Ti-2), and Ti-6Al-4V (Ti-5) have been TLP bonded using silver or copper interlayers. The effect of joining parameters such as bonding temperature, bonding time, interlayer thickness, and surface roughness of the faying surface was evaluated. The intermetallics always formed in the joining area with a silver (Ag) interlayer. However, Cu interlayer was found to be a viable candidate for joining titanium alloy. At 1000ºC or higher joining temperatures, no intermetallics was found in the microstructure of Ti-2 bonded area. The microstructure of bonded area was consisted of eutectic mixtures and Ti-Cu solid solutions. The microstructure of Ti-5 joint centerline was also consisted of eutectic of Cu-Ti and solid solution of Ti-Cu. The mechanical properties of the TLP bonded titanium alloy are being determined.

1286.prez_name: Annular Accident Tolerant Fuel with Disc Inserts
1286.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1286.prez_authors: Robert  Mariani, Pavel  Medvedev, Douglas  Porter
1286.prez_abstract: An innovative oxide fuel design will lower peak operating temperatures and allow power up-rates. An annular fuel pellet is used to house inserts to improve thermal conductivity, and discs are used between the pellets to gain the maximum improvements. Simulations were performed with the BISON fuel performance code. Peak operating temperatures were lowered from 1375 C to 733 C with Nb annular inserts and discs, at 426 W/cm. The enrichment needed to compensate for the loss of UO2 volume was determined. An enrichment as low as 7.5% could be used to maintain the average reactivity of conventional solid pellets with 5% enrichment. Enrichments as high as 8-10% could be employed for power plant up-rates to offset the added fabrication costs while still giving an enhanced safety margin under both normal operation and accident scenarios. Benefits and drawbacks for the design are listed. Different sizes and materials are evaluated.

1290.prez_name: Characterization of Radiation Induced Microstructural and Thermoelectric Property Changes in Bismuth Telluride and Half Heusler Materials
1290.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1290.prez_authors: Medha  Veligatla, Joseph R Croteau, Nicholas  Kempf, Luke  Schoensee, Brian J Jaques, Chao  Han, Jonathan  Gigax, Ran  He, Lin  Shao, Zhifeng  Ren, Yanliang  Zhang, Darryl P Butt
1290.prez_abstract: There is growing interest in harvesting the thermal energy generated by nuclear power or spent nuclear fuel using thermoelectric devices. In order to integrate this technology in nuclear applications, the materials and components must have excellent radiation and thermal tolerance as well as good thermal electric properties. In the present work, due to their potential for applications in at least two temperature regimens, the performance of bismuth telluride and half Heusler thermoelectric materials were evaluated as a function of temperature (ΔT)  and irradiation conditions using ion and gamma sources. TEM and XRD were used to characterize the microstructures of these materials before and after irradiation. The change in thermoelectric properties, including the Seebeck coefficients and thermal diffusivities, were measured and correlated with observed microstructural changes.
