1299.prez_name: Creep-fatigue Crack Growth Mechanisms for Alloy 617 at 800°C
1299.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1299.prez_authors: Dylan A Addison, Jamie J Kruzic
1299.prez_abstract: Understanding the elevated temperature crack growth mechanisms for Alloy 617 under creep-fatigue conditions is of interest so it can be safely used in heat exchangers and steam generators in next generation nuclear power plants. At 800°C, there is a potential competition between transgranular cracking, the effect of stress assisted grain boundary oxidation (SAGBO), and creep cavitation depending on the test conditions. To examine the range of potential behavior, experiments using compact tension specimens were performed under cyclic fatigue conditions, creep-fatigue conditions using cyclic loading with hold times, and statically loaded creep crack growth conditions. Fracture surfaces and crack profiles were compared to elucidate the crack growth mechanisms.  It was found that both intergranular creep damage and transgranular fatigue damage mechanisms compete to create a complex response at the crack tip.  It is expected that these results will aid in multi-scale model development for creep-fatigue crack growth in alloy 617.

1302.prez_name: Development of Advanced Ferritic Steels for Fast Reactor Applications
1302.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1302.prez_authors: Stuart Andrew Maloy, Osman  Anderoglu, Tarik  Saleh, Mychailo  Toloczko, Thak-Sang  Byun, Curt  Lavender, G. Robert  Odette, Dave  Hoelzer
1302.prez_abstract:
The Fuel Cycle R&D program is investigating options to transmute minor actinides.  To achieve this goal, new fuels and cladding materials must be developed and tested to high burnup levels (e.g. >20%) requiring cladding to withstand very high doses (greater than 200 dpa) while in contact with the coolant and the fuel.  
To develop and qualify materials to a total fluence greater than 200 dpa requires development and testing of advanced alloys and irradiations in fast reactors. Specimens of previously irradiated HT9 specimens are being irradiated in a fast reactor to high doses (>200 dpa).  In addition, improvements in the radiation tolerance of HT-9 are being made through minor changes in the composition.  Advanced radiation tolerant materials with fine oxide dispersion strengthening are also being developed to enable the desired extreme fuel burnup levels.  Recent progress in high dose irradiated materials testing and materials development will be presented.

1304.prez_name: D. T. Rankin Award Lecture: Thermochemical Modeling of Nuclear Fuel and Its Use in Fuel Performance Codes
1304.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1304.prez_authors: Theodore  Besmann, Benjamin G Gaston, Jacob W McMurray, Srdjan  Simunovic, Markus H Piro
1304.prez_abstract:
The new complex compositions and higher burn-ups envisioned for future nuclear fuels emphasize the importance of understanding and representing their properties and performance.  High temperatures, large numbers of elements generated, and their significant concentrations when fuels are taken to high burn-up, introduce new materials and modeling challenges. A thermodynamic data set for oxide fuel and fission products has been developed and continues to be expanded.  It has been used to model fuel behavior, and is now linked with an equilibrium solver, THERMOCHIMICA, in the MOOSE-BISON fuel performance simulation codes. The presentation will review the behavior of high burn-up fuels, efforts to model and simulate that behavior, and what will be needed to understand their performance.
	
This research was sponsored by the U.S. Department of Energy through the Office of Nuclear Energy–Fuel Cycle R&D and Nuclear Energy Advanced Modeling and Simulation Programs.

1307.prez_name: Effect of Laves Phase Precipitating Behavior on the Impact Properties of P92 Heat-resistant Steel
1307.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1307.prez_authors: Wei  Yan, Xu   Yang, Wei   Wang, Yiyin  Shan, Ke   Yang, Wei   Sha
1307.prez_abstract: For the structural steels used in the ultra super-critical (USC) power plant, the impact toughness is the most important issues for safety. Laves phase has been widely accepted to cause the impact brittleness of 9Cr martensitic heat-resistant steels after long time aging. The P92 steel aged at 600 oC for 2035 h, Laves phase precipitated in the matrix, accordingly the impact energy decreased from 154 J to 63 J. It seemed that once the Laves phase precipitated in the P92 steel, the impact brittleness increased. While the long-term aged P92 steel was tempered at 700 oC, 730 oC and 760 oC for only 1 h, the Laves phase barely changed, but the impact energy of P92 steel turned up to 120-150 J. So this interesting result strongly indicated that the presence of Laves phase might not be the real reason for the impact brittleness.

1314.prez_name: Fabrication Development Efforts in Support of the Accident Tolerant Fuel Program
1314.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1314.prez_authors: Connor  Woolum, Brian  Durtschi, Clint  Baker, Josh  Daw, Glenn  Moore
1314.prez_abstract:
The Accident Tolerant Fuel (ATF) program aims to develop and demonstrate novel fuel systems as candidates for replacement of the current UO2-Zr fuel-clad system for light water reactors (LWRs). The new fuel systems must exhibit increased safety, reliability, and performance. A three phase approach leading to commercial reactor demonstration in 2022 has been adopted; this includes feasibility studies, irradiation loop testing under prototypical PWR conditions, and transient testing of the candidate systems.
The program is currently in the planning and preparation stages for the irradiation loop test, to be conducted in the Advanced Test Reactor (ATR) at Idaho National Laboratory (INL). The design of the test train is novel, and thus requires development efforts in order to optimize fabrication, which includes welding and brazing of candidate cladding materials. Development efforts must then be qualified to ensure integrity of the experimental assembly. A review of related efforts is presented here.

1315.prez_name: Fretting Studies of Accident Tolerant FeCrAl Cladding
1315.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1315.prez_authors: Sobhan  Patnaik, Christian  Williams, Raul B. Rebak, Raghunath  Kanakala
1315.prez_abstract: Fuel rods in a nuclear reactor are kept aligned by grids made of X-750 Alloy. The vibration of the rods against the X-750 grids or against debris caught in the grids causes fretting/wear damage on the cladding material in the fuel rods. Current work studies the fretting behavior of the proposed new accident tolerant cladding material Iron-chromium-aluminum (FeCrAl). Samples with four different cladding materials are tested against the standard sample (for this testing) X-750 alloy which is the material for making grids, like FeCrAl, Zircaloy, 304SS and Inconel 600.

1318.prez_name: Helium Retention in Various Grades of Tungsten
1318.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1318.prez_authors: Chase N. Taylor, Osman  El-Atwani, James  Frishkoff, Wayne  Harlow, Mitra L Taheri
1318.prez_abstract: Retention of tritium in fusion plasma facing components (PFCs) poses a technological and safety concern that must be understood and controlled.  Deuterium-tritium fusion produces neutrons and helium, which damage material bulk and surface, respectively.  Generally, neutron damage increases retention, but helium damage can reduce retention depending on the incident parameters. In the present study, helium retention is examined at room temperature and 500 C for three grades of tungsten: nanocrystalline, ultrafine grain, and ‘ITER grade’.  Grain boundaries act as defect sinks for radiation damage, and ultrafine and nanocrystalline tungsten are considered to be more radiation tolerant materials due to the larger grain boundary area.  We show that helium retention is highest in ITER W at both room temperature and 500 C He<SUP>+</SUP> irradiations, and lowest in nanocrystalline tungsten.  In addition, helium desorption profiles are presented and possible retention mechanisms are proposed via correlating with the tungsten surface morphology.

1321.prez_name: Influence of Compositional Changes on Defect Evolution in Advanced Alloys
1321.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1321.prez_authors: Hongbin  Bei, Ke  Jin, Chenyang  Lu, Mohammad W.  Ullah, Laurent K  Beland, Dilpuneet  Aidhy, Lumin  Wang, William J. Weber, Roger E. Stoller, G. Malcolm  Stocks, Yanwen  Zhang
1321.prez_abstract:
Recently developed single–phase concentrated solid solution alloys consists of two to five principle elemental species, but their atomic arrangements occupy randomly on the crystalline lattice. Such structural configuration results in disordered chemical environments and unique site–to–site lattice distortions. Studies of a unique set of Ni–containing concentrated solid solution alloys with a face centered cubic structure have revealed that compositional complexity has an enormous impact on intrinsic properties and also on defect evolution during ion irradiation. Considerable improvement in radiation resistance under ion irradiation can be achieved through changing alloy composition. The insights into defect dynamics at the level of atoms and electrons may allow major advancements in alloy development for radiation resistance materials.

This work was supported as part of the Energy Dissipation to Defect Evolution (EDDE) center, an Energy Frontier Research Center funded by the US Department of Energy, Office of Science, Basic Energy Sciences.

1330.prez_name: Molecular Dynamics Simulation of Defect Production in FeCr Alloys
1330.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1330.prez_abstract: FeCrAl-based alloys are currently being investigated worldwide for use as accident-tolerant cladding materials to replace the current zircaloy cladding in light water reactors. These alloys offer excellent aqueous corrosion resistance, oxidation resistance at elevated temperature, and good mechanical properties. However, some Fe-Cr alloys are known to be susceptible to the precipitation of a finely-dispersed Cr-rich phase. To understand the effects of radiation and elevated temperature on FeCr alloys, we have performed classical molecular dynamics simulations of defect production by energetic displacement cascades in Fe-Cr alloys for seven different compositions. The simulations used a two-band model based on the embedded atom method. The results reveal remarkable dynamic annealing and preferential displacement of Cr atoms. We will discuss the implications for Cr segregation and changes in thermomechanical properties of Fe-Cr alloys.

1331.prez_name: Nanostructured Glass Ceramic for High Temperature Well Logging Applications
1331.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1331.prez_authors: Maxim  Vasilyev, Valery  Khabashesku, Toyli  Anniyev, Devesh  Agrawal, Mikhail  Korjik, Andrei  Fedorov, Eugene  Tretyiak, Ekaterina  Trusova
1331.prez_abstract:
Here we report results for a family of materials on a base of nanostructured glass ceramics. 
Li-Si based, neutron-sensitive, glass-ceramic   scintillation material absorb thermal neutrons in the 3 mm layer (>95%). Scintillation peaked at 410 nm and has a light yield of ~8000 ph/n, with decay time ~70ns. Light output decrease is <30% at 160C.
Gamma-sensitive, stoichiometric Ba-Si based glass ceramics, is a radiation-hard scintillator with a 3.5 g/cm3 density. Its radiation hardness to gammas and  protons with fluence up to 3x1013 p/cm2 was confirmed.  
Gamma-sensitive, stoichiometric Ba-Si-Gd oxide and oxy-fluoride glass ceramics  possess density 5.4 g/cm3 and LY of 50% from BGO. Scintillation peaked in the 430-450nm range with 70 ns decay constant.  
The materials developed can find application not only in the oil field industry, but also in any applications under harsh environment conditions, such as high temperature and/or high dose radiation environment.

1334.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1334.prez_abstract: The Light Water Reactor Sustainability (LWRS) Program, funded by the U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Nuclear Energy, aims to provide scientific, engineering and technological foundations to extend the life of operating light water reactors (LWRs). Within the LWRS program, the Advanced Instrumentation, Information, and Control (II&C) Systems Technologies Pathway conducts targeted research and development (R&D) to address aging and reliability concerns with the legacy analog instrumentation and control and related information systems of the U.S. operating light water reactor (LWR) fleet. This work involves two major goals: (1) to ensure that legacy analog II&C systems are not life-limiting issues for the LWR fleet, and (2) to implement digital II&C technology in a manner that enables broad innovation and business improvement in the nuclear power plant operating model.

1338.prez_name: Precipitation Modeling in Nuclear Steels with Cluster Dynamics
1338.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1338.prez_authors: Dane  Morgan, Huibin  Ke, Mahmood  Mamivand, Jia-Hong  Ke, Nicholas  Cunningham, Peter  Wells, G.R.  Odette
1338.prez_abstract: Cluster dynamics is a powerful and flexible tool for modeling precipitate nucleation and growth in complex alloys.  In this talk we discuss how relatively simple cluster dynamics models can be used to yield insights and semi-quantitative simulations for precipitation under irradiation in a range of steels, including Fe-Cr model alloys, reactor pressure vessel (RPV) steels, oxide dispersion strengthened (ODS) steels, steels, T91 ferritic-martensitic alloys, and austenitic stainless steels. We discuss some approaches and open challenges to treating complex phenomena within cluster dynamics including multiple components and radiation enhanced nucleation, diffusion, segregation, and dissolution.

1346.prez_name: Surface Modification of Zircaloy-4 for Isotope Producing Target Designs
1346.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1346.prez_authors: Walter Gordon Luscher, David J Senor, Kenneth J Geelhood, Stan G Pitman, Kevin K Clayton
1346.prez_abstract: Zircaloy-4 (Zr-4) exhibits a wide array of desirable properties and is commonly used in reactor environments making this alloy an obvious candidate material for isotope producing target designs.  Tritium producing burnable absorber rods (TPBARs) are target rods containing Zr-4 components and are irradiated in a light water reactor environment.  During irradiation, tritium produced in annular lithium aluminate (LiAlO<sub>2</sub>) pellets may be released as either diatomic tritium or as tritiated water vapor. While diatomic tritium is readily absorbed by getter components within the TPBAR, tritiated water vapor must first be reduced by a cracking (i.e., oxidizing) surface prior to reacting with getter components.  Since Zr-4 is highly resistant to oxidation, a surface modification technique has been developed to tailor the oxidation performance of Zr-4 components to accommodate tritiated water vapor generated during service.  Details regarding the surface modification process and results from complimentary in- and ex-reactor test campaigns will be discussed.

1350.prez_name:
The Effect of Stoichiometry on the 
Mechanical Properties of CeO2-x
1350.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1350.prez_authors: Ursula  Carvajal, Nathan  Mara, Andrew   Nelson
1350.prez_abstract: Due to its identical fluorite-type structure, microstructural and thermal properties, cerium oxide has been proposed as a surrogate material to better understanding of the behavior of nuclear fuels during in pile. Structural defects, like vacancies, affect the material properties of both fresh samples and those during irradiation in reactors, with potential influences on fuel performance and eventually on the safety of the reactor operation. For instance, vacancies lead notably to distortion of lattice structure and macroscopic swelling. Compared with other properties, mechanical properties of non-stoichiometry ceria has not been reported in the open bibliography. The structure of nuclear fuels at high burnup can prove especially difficult given the significant changes in both chemistry and microstructure caused by fission products. In this study, we report nobel results for the measurements of fracture toughness and hardness of ceria at small scales by the use of nanoindentation method.

1353.prez_name: Understanding Hydride Formation in Alpha-Zr at the Atomic Scale
1353.symp_name: Materials Development for Nuclear Applications and Extreme Environments
1353.prez_authors: Yongfeng  Zhang, Chao   Jiang , Xianming   Bai, Jianguo  Yu, Simon  Phillpot , Michele  Fullarton, Mark  Noordhoek
1353.prez_abstract: The formation of hydrides degrades the toughness of Zr-based claddings. However their formation mechanisms are yet to be fully understood. In this work, atomic scale studies including density functional theory (DFT), molecular dynamics (MD) and kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) have been used to investigate H diffusion and hydride nucleation. Here, DFT calculations serve to assess the thermodynamic stabilities of H solid solution and hydrides, and the diffusion mechanisms of H, with the effects of stress included. The results are also used to parameterize a KMC model to obtain the effective H diffusivity and to optimize a recently developed charge-optimized-many-body (COMB) potential, which is adopted in MD simulations to investigate hydride nucleation. It is shown by MD that the formation of face-centered hydrides starts with coherent zeta-phase, shearing of which in the basal plane changes the hcp stacking into fcc and leads to the formation of gamma-hydride nuclei.

1467.prez_name: Advanced Electrochemical, Spectroscopic and Microscopic Techniques for the Study of Corrosion Processes
1467.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1467.prez_abstract: Corrosion damage on the macroscale is commonly controlled by processes occurring on the micron to atomic scale, whose elucidation requires a convoluted knowledge of bulk and surface properties. The distribution and rate of accumulation of damage is inevitably non-uniform and susceptible to local variations in microstructure and the distribution of impurities. Investigation of such processes requires the employment of a suite of electrochemical, spectroscopic and microscopic techniques.  In this presentation, a number of studies, employing advanced methodologies, will be briefly described, including; (i) the use of scanning electrochemical microscopy to characterize the identification of reactive localized sites on Mg and Al alloys; (ii) the application of atom probe tomography to detect the influence of minor impurities on the intergranular corrosion of Ti under creviced conditions: (iii) the quantitative determination of damage at galvanically corroded sites on Cu-coated steel substrates analyzed by X-ray tomography.

1468.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1468.prez_authors: Nicholas J. Jones, Rebecca  Stevens, William  Golumbfskie
1468.prez_abstract: 5xxx series Aluminum alloys are strengthened through the addition of magnesium, although this addition sometimes exceeds the solubility limit. Over time at low temperatures (< 100 °C), the Mg comes out of solution, and forms Mg<sub>2</sub>Al<sub>3</sub>, the β-phase, which preferentially nucleates at the grain boundary. This leaves the aluminum in a sensitized condition, and, in the presence of salt water, this can lead to stress corrosion cracking (SCC) and other mechanical issues. While the traditional evaluation technique measures mass loss due to nitric acid exposure, calorimetry and specific heat has been used here to track the kinetics of this phase evolution, and to characterize the performance of the alloy. 5083 alloys and pure aluminum alloys are discussed along with performance over time at temperature using Modulated Differential Scanning Calorimetry (MDSC) and Heatflow Calorimetry (HFC).

1469.prez_name: Characterization of Surface Films on Magnesium Alloy AZ31D in NaCl Solutions with electrochemcial techniques
1469.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1469.prez_abstract: MgO-Mg(OH)<sub>2</sub> bi-layer films formed on the surface of cast Mg alloy AZ31D are believed to play an important role in the alloy’s corrosion resistance. In this research, the film characteristics induced by 0.01 M, 0.05 M and 0.1 M NaCl solutions have been investigated with electrochemical techniques. In the initial stage of immersion, the films experience a quick increase in both thickness and polarization resistance, which is Cl<sup>-</sup> ions concentration dependent. After this period, the bi-layer structures reach a continuous breakdown-and-repair near steady state, which is the result of the combined effects of galvanic corrosion and Cl<sup>-</sup> ion-accelerated local breakdown of the films. Although the outer porous hydroxide layers are not be able to offer much protection in most cases, higher E<sub>corr</sub> and film breakdown potentials in potentiodynamic polarization curves scanning from more cathodic potentials indicate that an alkaline environment helps to obtain denser Mg(OH)<sub>2</sub> layers.

1470.prez_name: Comparative Studies of the Corrosion Potentials of Three Proprietary Micro Alloyed Steels in Aerated Brine Solutions
1470.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1470.prez_authors: Lawrence Ibe Onyeji, Girish M. Kale, Bijan M. Kermani
1470.prez_abstract: The corrosion potentials of three proprietary micro alloyed steels designated as A, B, and C were compared with API 5L X65. Electrochemical corrosion tests were conducted in aerated 3.5 wt% NaCl solution. Pre corrosion analyses revealed that samples A, B and X65 consist of ferrite-pearlite microstructures while steel C has bainitic microstructure with dispersed acicular ferrites. The results of the corrosion tests showed that the corrosion rate (CR) of the samples can be ranked as CR(C)< CR(A)< CR(B)< CR(X65). The corrosion kinetics of all the samples obey the bi-logarithmic equation: C = At^B and the NPFlex pit analyses revealed the presence of micro pitting. These results can be attributed to the presence of micro alloying elements such as Cr, P and Cu and the differences in microstructures of the samples as revealed by ASTM grain size number and ferrite-pearlite volume fractions.

1471.prez_name: Correlation of Grain Boundary Plane, Sensitization and Corrosion Resistance
1471.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1471.prez_abstract: The excellent corrosion resistance of austenitic stainless has led to their widespread utilization in a number of industries including petrochemical, nuclear power and renewable energy.  However, their service lives are limited when exposed to elevated temperatures due to the precipitation of chromium carbides, reducing the level of chromium in solution at grain boundaries.  Grain boundary engineered microstructures have been shown to reduce the sensitization of stainless steels, however not all low ∑3n grain boundaries are as resistant to sensitization as expected.  Experiments will be presented utilizing EBSD, TEM, APT and corrosion samples to correlate the corrosive attack of ∑3 and ∑9 grain boundaries to the grain boundary plane and chromium depletion.

1472.prez_name: Corrosion Analysis of Wire Cleaning Processes for Biological Use Wire
1472.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1472.prez_authors: Daniel John David Sullivan, Brad  Burrows, Eric  Ross
1472.prez_abstract: The process of examining wires and other materials used in medical process is very important.  One concern is for the effects of cleaning on wire integrity and contamination in the process.  In this paper one wire, 316LVM surgical implant wire 0.045” diameter, is analyzed as received for  the control.  Additional samples of the wire are subjected to a variety of cleaning processes and then examined.   The examinations include: Optical and SEM imaging to check for pitting and corrosion.  The wires will be tested for break strength by pull testing and cross sectioned to examine any reduction in diameter and changes in shape compared to the control.  EDS will be used to determine any gross changes in the wire surface composition while Auger Spectroscopy will analyze very near the surface, ~ 100 Angstroms, and profile to check the oxide /surface layer thickness.

1473.prez_name: Corrosion Behavior of Nanocrystalline Al-M (M: Cr, Mn, Ti, Ta, Si, Ce and Mo) Alloys Produced via High-energy Ball Milling
1473.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1473.prez_abstract: Alloying elements such as Mo, W, Ta, Cr, Nb, V and Zr in aluminum alloys have been reported to enhance resistance to localized corrosion when produced by non-equilibrium alloying techniques that can retain these elements in solid solution. In this work, the corrosion behavior of  Al, Al-5at.%Cr, Al-5at.%Mn, Al-5at.%Si, Al-5at.%Ta, Al-5at.%Ti, Al-5at%Ce and Al-5at.%Mo produced by high energy ball milling and subsequently consolidated by cold pressing followed by sintering was studied. Corrosion studies were conducted by potentiodynamic polarization and immersion tests. Alloy characterization was performed using X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscope. Hardness, a representative of the strength, was also measured for all the alloys. The study was focused on understanding the interactions between the formed phases and the influence of intermetallic size and distribution in each of these systems that could lead to the development of a new generation of aluminum based alloys with superior mechanical and corrosion properties.

1474.prez_name: Corrosion Behavior of Nuclear Waste Glasses in Geological Repository Systems
1474.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1474.prez_abstract: Plans for the safe disposal of this waste in a geologic repository generally involve direct disposal of the reactor spent nuclear fuel (SNF) or treatment of the SNF through methods such as vitrification, where the unusable SNF fraction is immobilized in a glass waste form. In order to design and manage a secure disposal site, the waste glass must limit the release of radioactive materials to the surrounding environment for very long time periods. To build technically defensible performance assessment models that are capable of predicting the release of radionuclides from the glass in the repository environment, a mechanistic understanding of the glass-water interaction at different time periods is necessary. In this paper, we present the current understanding of the glass-water interaction and an overview of experimental and modeling approaches designed to elucidate various processes that may control glass corrosion at various time periods.

1475.prez_name: Corrosion Behaviour of AZ31 in Highly Alkaline Environment
1475.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1475.prez_authors: Somi  Doja, Lukas  Bichler, Simon  Fan
1475.prez_abstract: Magnesium-aluminum alloy AZ31 sheets are often used in diverse engineering applications where component strength and durability are important.  This alloy, however, may be susceptible to corrosion in alkaline environments due to its composition.  In this work, corrosion  of commercially available AZ31 alloy plate was examined in highly alkaline electrolyte (KOH) using immersion and potentiostatic testing.  The results suggest that the concentration of Al and Mn in the alloy may govern the kinetics of micro-galvanic corrosion.  Further, trace impurities of Ni, Fe and Cr had a deleterious effect on the corrosion resistance, since X-ray diffraction analysis suggested formation of nickel hydroxide layer on the surface of the  alloy,  leading  to accelerated  pitting  and  surface degradation.  Electrochemical  Impedance Spectroscopy was carried out to further understand the mechanism for formation of this layer.  The effect of pH of the electrolyte on the corrosion behavior of AZ31 was studied with reference to Pourbaix diagrams.

1476.prez_name: Corrosion Resistance of Transmission Pipeline Steel Coated with Five Types of Enamels
1476.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1476.prez_authors: Liang  Fan, Fujian  Tang, Signo T.  Reis, Genda   Chen, Michael L.   Koenigstein
1476.prez_abstract: Corrosion is one of the main causes of incidents occurred in hazardous liquid and gas transmission pipelines in the U.S., resulting in a loss of over $12 billion per year. In this study, the corrosion resistances of pipeline steel coated with five types of enamel were investigated in 3.5 wt.% NaCl solution with open-circuit potential, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and potentiodynamic polarization tests. Steel coupons were cut from API 5L X65 pipeline steel, and coated with five types of enamels in the wet process. The microstructures of all enamels were investigated with an optical microscope. Experimental results showed that three enamels provided the best corrosion protection for pipeline steel, including pure enamel 16R-001, the mix designs of enamel 15R-972 (25 wt.%) + 16R-001 (75 wt.%) and 15R-972 (50 wt.%) + 16R-001 (50 wt.%).

1477.prez_name: Corrosion Response of ASTM A-299 Steel Weldment in As-weld and Post Weld Heat Treatment Condition
1477.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1477.prez_abstract: Pressure vessel fabrication and its service life assessement is critical to avoid any catastrophe incident. Welding of candidate material and interaction of weldment to working environment are key parameters to assess any risk. ASTM A-299 grade steel is one of the popular material used for pressure vessel fabrication. During fabrication the weldment undergoes different microstructural and residual stress variations with respect to base metal. This variation can affect the corrosion mechanics. In this study corrosion response of butt welded A-299 plate both for as weld and Post Weld Heat Treatment condition was evaluated. The weld was produced applying both Gas Tungsten Arc Welding and Shielded Metal Arc Welding techniques using ER90S-B9 filler wire and E-9015-B9 filler rod respectively. Corrosion behavior was estimated using potentiodynamic scan technique in simulated environment and results were compared both for as-weld and post weld heat treatment conditions.

1478.prez_name: Diffusion Bonding of Ni-based Superalloys for Microchannel Heat Exchanger for Application in  Supercritical CO2 Cycles
1478.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1478.prez_authors: Monica  Kapoor, Omer  Dogan, Kyle  Rozman, Jeffrey  Hawk, Rajesh V Saranam, Patrick  McNeff, Brian K Paul
1478.prez_abstract: Interest in power generation using supercritical CO2 (sCO2) cycle has increased in recent years. The sCO2 cycles rely heavily on heat recuperation to increase efficiency. Microchannel heat exchangers (µHX) are proposed to reduce equipment size and enhance heat transfer between heat source and sCO2. Microchannel architectures are typically formed by a lamination process wherein microscale channels are formed in shims, which are then stacked and diffusion bonded (DB) together. DB and transient-liquid-phase-bonding (TLP) are considered robust joining techniques for µHX.   Therefore, DB and TLP of H230 and H282 Ni-based superalloys were investigated for use in a heat exchanger operating at 700°C-800°C and 20-30 MPa pressure. Tensile testing results of DB stacks at room temperature and at 750°C and microstructure evolution of the DB stacks using optical, scanning and transmission electron microscopy will be discussed.

1479.prez_name: Early Stage Oxidation of NiCrAl Alloys
1479.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1479.prez_abstract: The superior ability of NiCrAl alloys to resist oxidation is reliant upon their ability to develop and maintain a continuous, dense, and slow-growing oxide scale on their surface, best accomplished by α-Al<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>3</SUB>. The formation of a complete, passivating oxide scale is preceded by an initial period of transient oxidation, where several oxide species can develop simultaneously, including NiO, Cr<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>3</SUB>, NiCr<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>4</SUB>, NiAl<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>4</SUB>, and/or other polymorphs of Al<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>3</SUB>. Generally, the formation of non-passivating oxides is detrimental to the oxidation resistance of the alloy. Studying and understanding the transient oxidation stage and the nucleation behavior of oxide phases in these alloys potentially allows control over the oxidation behavior of the system for better corrosion resistance. Counting statistics and size measurement will be applied to SEM images of oxide nuclei particles in order to estimate the value of key thermodynamic parameters.

1480.prez_name: Effect of Carbon Content on Corrosion Properties of Plain Carbon Steels
1480.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1480.prez_authors: Amer Nadeem Malik, Aqil  Inam, Rafiq  Ahmad, Muhammad  Ishtiaq, Riaz  Sarwar, Khubaib Ahmed Zohaib, Muhammad  Shaheen
1480.prez_abstract: Plain carbon steels, AISI 1020,1030,1040,1045 and 1050 are widely used in manufacturing industries. Corrosion properties of these steels from various microstructures are important from practical applications point of view. To study the effect of carbon concentration on corrosion properties of these plain carbon steels from starting microstructures, coarse ferrite-pearlite, fine ferrite-pearlite, martensite, and bainite, the annealing, normalizing, quenching and austempering heat treatments were performed, respectively. LOM of the heat treated samples was carried out on Leica brand metallurgical microscope. Tafel polarization technique was used to determine the corrosion rate of heat treated steel samples in 3.5% NaCl solution on Gamry potentiostat. It was revealed that with increase in carbon content the corrosion rate was increased from coarse ferrite-pearlite, fine ferrite-pearlite and martensite microstructures. While a drop in corrosion rate was observed from bainitic microstructure.

1481.prez_name: Evaluation of Corrosion of Shielded Metal Arc Weldment in Boiler Tube Steel in 3.5% NaCl solution
1481.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1481.prez_abstract: Shielded metal arc weldment was performed in boiler tube steels namely SA210- GrA1, SA213- T11 (T11) and SA213-T22 (T22).  Corrosion behaviour of SMAW weldment in these  boiler tube steel was evaluated in 3.5% NaCl solution using static method & accelerated method.  Welded GrA1 steel showed the higher corrosion rate than unwelded steel. The unweld T22 steel is good resistant to corrosion due to adherent oxide layer of yellowish colour form on the surface. Welded T11 showed the better resistance to corrosion. It was also found that welded GrA1 steel showed the more corrosion rate than base steel in accelerated condition. The surface morphologies of the various steels after exposure were studied using a scanning-electron microscope, and XRD measurements were carried out to characterize the nature of the corrosion product. XRD reveals that the yellow (orange) colour corrosion product was iron oxide hydrate (FeOOH) form on all the steel surface.

1482.prez_name: Hardware Materials in Molten Carbonate Fuel Cell
1482.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1482.prez_authors: Ling  Chen, Adam  Franco, Chao-yi  Yuh
1482.prez_abstract: The high-temperature molten carbonate fuel cell is an ultra-clean and high-efficiency power generator. It is operated at ~550-650ºC, considered optimum to facilitate fast fuel-cell reaction kinetics, utilize waste heat efficiently, and allow use of commercial commodity construction materials. Commercial MW-size power plants of FuelCell Energy (FCE) are already deployed worldwide and have generated over four billion kWh of ultra-clean power using renewable biogas as well as clean natural gas.  Metallic hardware materials are extensively utilized. They experience high-temperature reducing-oxidizing atmosphere in the presence of liquid alkali carbonate electrolyte. Materials selections are founded on many years of focused R&D and field experience. Results to date show that the baseline construction materials meet the endurance goals.  Material durability is well understood and solutions are available to further extend the durability.  The paper will review hardware materials experience and development approaches that would further reduce cost and extend life.

1483.prez_name: Influence of Deformation Temperature on Mechanical and Corrosion Property of 6082-Al Alloy
1483.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1483.prez_authors: Nikhil  Kumar, Devasri  Fuloria, Sunkulp  Goel, R.  Jayaganthan
1483.prez_abstract: The 6082 Al alloy was subjected to cryorolling and cold rolling up to 75% thickness reduction. The cryorolled sample showed higher grain refinement as compared to cold rolled sample due to suppression of dynamic recovery during cryorolling as confirmed by EBSD and TEM study. The significant improvement in hardness and tensile strength of cryorolled (CR) sample was obtained as compared to cold rolled sample. Further annealing at 200˚C, the ductility, hardness and tensile strength have increased for cryorolled sample as compared to cold rolled sample. Electrochemical investigation has shown that the passive potential range of CR sample was large as compared to cold rolled sample due to more grain refinement. The corrosion resistance of CR sample has significantly improved as compared to cold rolled sample after annealing at 300˚C for 1 hr.

1484.prez_name: Long-term Field Corrosion Monitoring in Supporting Structures of China Xiamen Xiangan Submarine Tunnel
1484.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1484.prez_authors: Xuan  Cheng, Chaoyang  Gong, Xiaoyong  He, Yongwei  Li, Sizhe  He, Liuying  Huang, Ying  Zhang, Jiubin  Chen, Jianbin  Zhang, Chao  Zeng
1484.prez_abstract: Xiamen Xiangan Submarine Tunnel is located in the southeastern coastal city of China and has put into service since April 2010. The total length is 6.05 kilometers with the undersea length of 4.2 kilometers. In an effort to online monitor the dynamic states of embedded steels in reinforced concrete structures inside the tunnel, a series of commercial CorroWatch sensors were embedded in advance for the selected critical cross-sections of concrete structures during the constructions. Possible correlations among the measured parameters and corrosion situations are discussed preliminarily based on the real-time measured data collected for five years. Problems associated with the long-term filed corrosion monitoring are also pointed out. These findings, along with the progressive ongoing research, will provide valuable and informative information on concrete durability and service life prediction in reinforced concrete structures exposed to harsh environments.

1485.prez_name: Materials Selection for Use in Concentrated Acids
1485.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1485.prez_abstract: Nickel-alloys containing optimum amounts of chromium (Cr), molybdenum (Mo) and tungsten (W) are widely used in the chemical process industries due to their tolerance to both oxidizing and reducing conditions. Unlike stainless steel (SS), Ni-Cr-Mo (W) alloys exhibit remarkably high uniform corrosion resistance in major concentrated acids, like HCl and H2SO4. A higher uniform corrosion resistance of Ni-Cr-Mo (W) alloys in concentrated acids can be attributed to the formation of protective oxide film of Mo in reducing acids, and Cr-oxide film in oxidizing solutions. The present study investigates the role of alloying elements to uniform corrosion resistance in concentrated acids (HCl, HCl + oxidants and H2SO4) and localized corrosion resistance in chloride-rich environments. The uniform and localized corrosion tests were conducted on various HASTELLOY (like C-276, C-22, C-2000, B-3, HYBRID-BC1 and G-35 alloys). Further, results were analyzed using weight loss technique and electrochemical techniques, in conjunction with surface characterization tools.

1486.prez_name: Mechanism of Magnesium Corrosion Poisoning through Alloying
1486.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1486.prez_authors: Krista  Limmer, Joseph  Labukas, Michael  Garvey, Santanu  Chaudhuri, Jan  Andzelm
1486.prez_abstract: The rapid corrosion of magnesium is one of the primary limitations for using magnesium in lightweight structural applications. Recent experimental work has suggested that arsenic poisons the cathodic reaction on magnesium, preventing hydrogen recombination and evolution. In this study the mechanism of cathodic poisoning from metalloid alloying was investigated from first principles using density functional theory. The effect of metalloids was investigated by examining the cathodic reaction on multiple surface configurations within the alloy system including: 1) dilute metalloid concentrations in magnesium solid solution, 2) second phase precipitates, and 3) metalloid adatoms. The effect on corrosion was determined by considering the kinetic barriers associated with hydrogen diffusion, recombination, and evolution. This mechanistic understanding of how metalloids contribute to the poisoning of magnesium corrosion may be used to develop magnesium alloy systems with reduced corrosion kinetics.

1487.prez_name: Mitigation of Stress Corrosion Cracking of Austenitic Alloys by Laser Shock Peening
1487.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1487.prez_authors: Bai  Cui, Fei  Wang, Qiaofeng  Lu, Chenfei  Zhang, Qing  Su, Yongfeng  Lu, Michael  Nastasi
1487.prez_abstract: Fe- and Ni-based austenitic alloys are susceptible to stress corrosion cracking in hot and corrosive water environments, which becomes a significant lifetime limit of these materials in petroleum, chemical, and nuclear industries. The existing methods for controlling SCC have many limitations and problems. A laser shock peening (LSP) process has been identified as a new approach to effectively prevent SCC of austenitic alloys, but the mechanisms remains poorly understood. In the LSP process, laser-driven shock waves are generated which penetrate the bulk material and induce significant compressive residual stresses. This research will use a combination of experimental approaches to understand the microstructural evolution generated by LSP, determine the effects of LSP parameters on SCC of austenitic alloys, and elucidate the mechanistic mechanisms that enable LSP to prevent SCC. Preliminary results show that LSP leads to SCC prevention by way of compressive residual stress and deformation microstructures caused by LSP.

1488.prez_name: Modification of AC/DC/AC Technique for Organic Coatings
1488.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1488.prez_authors: Qi  Gui, Dajiang  Zheng, Guang-Ling  Song
1488.prez_abstract: High corrosion-resistant organic coatings are highly demanded in industries. An ideal organic coating should be able to sustain its anti-corrosion performance and significantly extend the service life of coated metals. To rapidly evaluate the corrosion resistance of an organic coating, electrochemical methods are often used. The recently developed AC/DC/AC is an accelerated cyclic test, which combines electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements with cathodic polarization. To further improve this technique, some parameters of the AC/DC/AC technique were modified, and the corrosion acceleration effect of the modified AC/DC/AC method was investigated in this study. Apart from SEM observation, differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were also employed to characterize the coatings and verify the modified AC/DC/AC technique..

1489.prez_name: Painting Aluminum: Easier Said Than Done
1489.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1489.prez_abstract: Aluminum is a popular architectural substrate because of its corrosion resistance, ease of manufacture and modest cost.  Despite these attributes, it is one of the most difficult substrates to paint successfully.  A naturally formed, inert or passive aluminum oxide layer covers the surface of untreated aluminum and renders aluminum relatively corrosion resistant when exposed to mild environmental conditions, such as atmospheric corrosion.  The attributes of this layer that make it resistant to atmospheric corrosion also tend to block coating adhesion.  The key to achieving good coating adhesion is to remove the naturally formed oxide, immediately apply a different passivating layer (collectively called the pretreatment), and then apply an organic coating.  The complex nature of this pretreatment process often leads to premature coating failures and resulting corrosion issues.  Common means and considerations regarding successful aluminum coating preparation and common coating failures resulting from inadequate preparation will be described in this paper.

1490.prez_name: Remarkable Oxidation Resistance due to Nanocrystalline Structure of Fe-Cr Alloys
1490.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control

1491.prez_name: Role of Admixtures in Concrete during Corrosion of Rebar: Effect of Glycerol and Silica Formulations
1491.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1491.prez_authors: Robert  Blair, Batric   Pesic, Krishnan S Raja, Ian  Ehrsam, Jacob  Kline
1491.prez_abstract: Addition of glycerol as viscosity modifier is proposed to decrease the permeability of concrete to corrosion inducing ions such as chloride and sulfate. Similar effect could be realized by addition of silica formulations as these additives decrease the volume of pores in concrete that act as conducting pathways. In addition to controlling the permeability of concrete, these admixtures could perform as inhibitors of corrosion of rebar steel. In this presentation, the corrosion inhibiting role of admixtures will be elucidated. Cyclic polarization studies were carried out on the metallographically polished rebar steel specimens in actual concrete solutions at three different pH conditions (pH: 12.5, 11.0, and 9.0) and different chloride concentrations. Threshold chloride concentrations required for passivity-breakdown were determined with and without addition of admixtures at different pH levels. Addition of 2% fumed silica increased the threshold concentration of chloride by 50% as compared to the solution without any admixture.

1492.prez_name: Study on Corrosion Resistance of the Effect of the Temperature on Thread Steel
1492.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1492.prez_authors: Zhitong  Wang, jiongming  Zhang, bo  Wang, yanbin  Yin, qipeng  Dong, Shunxi  Wang, Wei  Song, lilei  Han
1492.prez_abstract:
Abstract   Wear water process is usually adopted during thread steel production process. Wear water thread steel generates red rust inevitably during storage and transportation. Owing to the existence of red rust, the prices and performance of thread steel production are affected. Steel plants prevent rust erosion of thread steel by means of anti-rust agents. Nevertheless, this method is unefficient and expensive. Since the continuity and compactness of oxide layer on the steel surface are important factors for rust corrosion and local electrochemical pitting, continuous and compact oxide layer on the thread steel surface can prevent rust erosion efficiently. This paper aims to rust erosion phenomenon of wear water thread steel. By mean of increasing the temperature on cooling bed, this paper studies the control of oxide layer of steel surface, which can be provided theoretical foundation for studies of the rust erosion of the thread steel.
Keywords  Thread steel, oxide scale, corrosion resistance

1493.prez_name: The Galvanic Corrosion between Steel and Carbon Fiber Reinforced Polymer
1493.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1493.prez_authors: Chi  Zhang, Dajiang  Zheng, Guang-Ling  Song, Yang  Guo, Ming  Liu, Hamid  Kia
1493.prez_abstract: The galvanic corrosion between steel and carbon fiber reinforced polymer (CFRP) in 3.5 wt.% sodium chloride solution was investigated. The effect of the conductivity and surface state of CFRP on the galvanic corrosion behavior, as well as the contribution of crevice corrosion to the galvanic effect, was analyzed. Based on the obtained experimental results, a simple galvanic corrosion model is proposed for the CFRP-steel couple.

1494.prez_name: Threshold Chloride Concentration for Passivity Breakdown of Mg-Zn-Gd-Nd-Zr Alloy (UNS M12310) in Basic Solution
1494.symp_name: Materials Selection and Characterization for Corrosion Control
1494.prez_abstract: Mg-Zn-Gd-Nd-Zr Alloy (UNS M12310) is a heat treatable magnesium cast alloy that can be used up to 200 ºC for automobile and aerospace applications. This alloy has excellent mechanical properties (UTS: 280 MPa at room temperature, and ~230 MPa at 200 ºC) and improved corrosion resistance. Electrochemical corrosion studies were conducted on this alloy under different heat treatment conditions in 0.1 M NaOH solution with different concentrations of chloride. The alloy showed excellent passivity in the 0.1 M NaOH solution. The passive potential range typically extended to more than 1 VAg/AgCl. The transpassive potential was observed to be a function of heat treatment condition of the alloy. The solution treated alloy showed the highest transpassive potential and the overaged (aged at 300 ºC for 4 h) alloy. Electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and spectro-electrochemical techniques (in situ Raman, and UV-Vis) have been used to understand the passivation behavior of this alloy.
