1704.prez_name: A New Method to Produce Macroporous Bone Cement
1704.prez_abstract: The ability to produce macroporous bone graft substitute (BGS) is an important research topic in orthopedic applications. This paper reports a new real-time in situ technique to create macroporous Mg-phosphate orthopedic cements. The cement is made from amorphous Mg-phosphate (AMP) as the precursor.  The method uses biodegradable Mg-particles as the porogen. As opposed to the conventional wisdom of providing corrosion protection layers to biodegradable Mg-alloys, the present method uses the fast corrosion kinetics of Mg to create macropores in real time during the setting of the cement. Using this technique, a highly macroporous cement is obtained, as determined by pycnometry. Due to formation of H2 gas bubbles from corrosion of Mg, the macroporous cement shows bimodal pore size distribution in nano/micro and macro range. The results of SBF soaking indicated change in crystallinity as confirmed via scanning electron microcopy (SEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD).

1705.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing of Functionally Graded Titanium Alloys for Biomedical Devices
1705.prez_authors: Srinivas Aditya  Mantri, Trina  Majumdar, Calvin  Mikler, Tushar   Borkar, Chris  Yannetta, Rubens  Caram, Nick  Birbilis, Rajarshi  Banerjee
1705.prez_abstract: Additive manufacturing processes such as laser engineered net shaping (LENS™), a near-net shape processing technology, has the potential for fabricating functionally graded biomedical implants. With regard to titanium alloys, the use of LENS™ technology to process low modulus alloys, such as Ti-35Nb-7Zr-5Ta (wt%) has been well established. Bone fixation plates used for holding together fractured bone fragments, typically require low elastic modulus (or stiffness) at the ends, comparable to the bone modulus, and higher elastic modulus at the center, close to the site of the fracture. This study focuses on the development of a novel LENSTM deposited, compositionally and functionally graded Ti-based metallic plate for potential bone fixation. The gradation has been achieved between a low modulus Ti-35Nb-10Zr (wt%) alloy and the higher modulus commercially pure Ti near the center of the plate. Site-specific mechanical, corrosion, and in vitro properties along the compositional gradient will be discussed in this paper.

1706.prez_name: Additive Manufacturing of Microscale and Nanoscale Structures for Medical Devices
1706.prez_abstract: Two photon polymerization is an additive manufacturing technology that has been developed for creating three-dimensional medical devices with microscale and nanoscale features directly from computer designs. Two photon polymerization uses nearly simultaneous absorption of two photons within a small volume to initiate chemical reactions between photoinitiators and monomers. Many types of organically-modified ceramic materials, acrylate-based polymers, titanium-containing hybrid materials, zirconium sol-gels, and other photosensitive materials are used for two photon polymerization-based additive manufacturing. Some materials that are commonly used in two photon polymerization-based additive manufacturing were originally utilized as negative photoresists in ultraviolet photolithography. In this talk, use of two photon polymerization-based additive manufacturing for medical applications will be considered. Use of soft lithography approaches for replication of two photon polymerization-produced structures will be considered.  Structural, mechanical, biological, and functional testing of the two photon polymerization-produced structures will be described.

1707.prez_name: Advanced Freeze Casting for Mimetic Bone and Biomaterials
1707.prez_authors: Steven Eric Naleway, Marc A. Meyers, Joanna  McKittrick
1707.prez_abstract: The recent interest in biocompatible and bioabsorbable bone implants over permanent devices has driven a multitude of research into bioinspired designs and biomaterials. Key to these designs is mimicking the complex hierarchical structure of natural bone, which displays tailored porosity and interplay between biopolymer and bioceramic. It is this hierarchical design that promotes healthy growth and provides impressive mechanical properties. We present novel methods for the fabrication of bioinspired materials that mimic this complex and hierarchical porosity through the freeze casting technique, where a ceramic scaffold is templated by the growth of ice crystals. This technique allows for the fabrication of porous materials in a variety of biocompatible and potentially bioabsorbable ceramic materials and composites. Chemical and physical techniques can be employed to alter and control this process. Applications as biomedical implants and structural materials will be discussed.

1708.prez_name: Bio-mediated Materials Fabrication: Exopolysaccharides as Structural Templates

1709.prez_name: Bioactive Materials Releasing Biologially Active Ions: Li and Nb Doped 45S5 Bioactive Glasses
1709.prez_authors: Aldo R Boccaccini, Valentina  Miguez-Pacheco, Rainer  Detsch
1709.prez_abstract: In this study two novel bioactive glasses (BGs) based on the 45S5 composition were developed and characterized. Li and Nb were considered as biologically active ions. These two ions have been previously shown to stimulate cellular response, in particular in osteoblast cells. It was found that lithium substitution did not impair the bioactivity of the different Li-BG compositions, as evidenced by deposition of an apatite-like crystalline phase on the surface of scaffolds after one day immersion in SBF. No significant difference in cellular metabolic activity between 45S5 BG and Li-BGs was found and cells were fully spread and attached to the surface of scaffolds 14 days after seeding. In the case of Nb-BGs, their biocompatibility was assessed by indirect culture of fibroblast-like mouse derived ST-2 cells and the angiogenic potential of Nb-BGs was confirmed by measuring the secretion of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by fibroblasts over a 48h period.

1710.prez_name: Biomimetic Coatings Using Simulated Body Fluids: A Status Review
1710.prez_abstract: For over the last twenty-five years, Kokubo and his colleagues have pioneered the use of Simulated Body Fluid (SBF) compositions to coat surfaces of implants with bioactive coatings for potential use in orthopedics. Other than Kokubo’s original compositions, there are many different compositions available in the literature. This paper will examine the pros and cons of the various compositions of the SBFs. The types of implant surfaces including metals, ceramics, polymers and the properties of the resulting coatings will be reviewed. In most of the coating compositions and processes, the kinetics of coating formation is sluggish. Strategies to accelerate the kinetics of coating formation will be described with emphasis on our contributions. Two important strategies are to deviate from the biomimetic condition by enhancing the ionic strengths of the coating solutions and application of microwaves. Finally, the possibility to combine other techniques will also be discussed.

1711.prez_name: Comparison of Annealing and Hot Isotactic Pressing for Post Processing Heat Treatment of Direct Metal Laser Sintered Ti6Al4V
1711.prez_authors: Yangzi  Xu, Yuan  Lu, Jianyu   Liang, Richard Dean Sisson
1711.prez_abstract: Ti6Al4V is a popular alloy for orthopedic applications in hip replacement, total knee replacement and dental implants. Due to the advantage of additive manufacturing techniques in producing highly customized parts, it has the potential to be applied in the orthopedic industry. However, the as-fabricated part possesses an acicular martensite structure with poor ductility and anisotropic properties. Corrosion and wear of Ti6Al4V in the hip replacement is currently the main concern on revision surgery. Therefore, proper post- treatments are required for the as-fabricated parts. In this paper, comparisons of annealing and hot isotactic pressing (HIP), as the post-treatments for directed metal laser sintered Ti6Al4V, are presented. The microstructures were examined using Scanning Electron Microscopy and X-ray diffraction. The residual stress was also measured by X-ray diffraction. The comparisons of corrosion resistance with different post-treatments are presented and discussed.

1712.prez_name: CVD Grown Anti-inflammatory Cerium Oxide Coatings for Orthopedic Implants
1712.prez_authors: Ankur  Gupta, Soumen  Das, Sudipta   Seal
1712.prez_abstract: Inflammation is a critical issue for the periprosthetic osteolysis. Despite superior mechanical properties of CoCrMo and Ti alloys, 10-15% of total joint replacement will expected to fail due to osteolysis. Osteolysis is mainly due to chronic inflammation from particles or debris generated through wear, electrochemical dissolution or released matrix metalloproteinase during the inflammatory process. In recent years, cerium oxide nanoparticles have been explored for its regenerative antioxidant activity. Current study focus on utilizing anti-inflammatory property of cerium oxide to delay the osteolysis. Thin film of cerium oxide have grown on Ti or CoCrMo alloy using CVD technique. Scratch test on coatings was performed to understand tribological performance and generated wear debris were utilized for cell culture. We hypothesize that generated wear debris will be partially coated with cerium oxide and presence of cerium coating will reduce inflammatory reaction by balancing the redox environment around the implant.

1713.prez_name: Developing Functionally Graded Ti Orthopedic Implants: Compositional Gradient via LENS Process

1714.prez_name: Development of Novel Implants with Embedded Therapeutics Using Additive Manufacture
1714.prez_authors: Parastoo  Jamshidi, Sophie C Cox, Moataz M Attallah, Hany  Hassanin, Liam  Grover, Duncan T Shepherd, Owen T Addison
1714.prez_abstract: In this study the potential to additively manufacture a metallic antibiotic eluting implant containing a reservoir connected to the surface extremities via a series of channels was investigated. A parametric study was performed to assess the influence of process parameters of selective laser melting (SLM) technique on the morphology, size, and surface topography of printed implant models. The influence of pore orientation on the release profile of therapeutic reagent loaded cement phase from the implant was assessed. The results of this study demonstrate that the metallic antibiotic eluting implant were successfully manufactured via SLM and filled with antibiotic loaded cement phase. It was shown the printed implant model was effective to inhibit the growth of the bacterial culture highlighting the potential of this strategy to address infection issues associated with implants, which currently devastatingly impact patient quality of life.

1715.prez_name: Development of Osseointegrated Implants and Antimicrobial Technologies
1715.prez_abstract: Osseointegrated implant (OI) technology provides a promising approach to address the current clinical problems of prosthetic sockets including skin breakdown and limited use. Over the past decade, animal models have been used to develop OI implants. This development has culminated in the implantation of four OI implants in human patients within the Veterans Affairs System in Salt Lake City under FDA feasibility study guidelines. Despite these advances, the overarching clinical concern of infection at the skin/implant interface remains. This interface is an optimal environment for biofilm growth and formation. Active release antimicrobial technologies are being developed to address this risk. A novel class of antimicrobial agents, referred to as CZ compounds, have been synthesized with 2-in-1 ability to disperse and kill bacterial biofilms. These technologies are under development in an effort to reduce rates of biofilm implant-related infection of OI and other implanted devices.

1716.prez_name: Direct Ink Writing of Bioactive Silica-bonded Calcite Scaffolds from a Preceramic Polymer and Fillers
1716.prez_authors: Enrico  Bernardo, Laura  Fiocco, Hamada  Elsayed, Devis  Bellucci, Valeria  Cannillo, Rainer  Detsch, Aldo R. Boccaccini
1716.prez_abstract: Novel silica-bonded calcite 3D scaffolds were achieved by direct ink writing of a paste comprising a silicone polymer and calcite powders. The scaffolds were first cross-linked at 350 °C, and then fired at 600 °C in air, with conversion of the polymer into amorphous silica but no decomposition of calcite. The products (with SiO2/CaCO3=35/65 by wt.) featured an open porosity of 56-64 % and a compressive strength of 2.9-5.5 MPa, depending on the geometry. Dissolution studies in SBF and cell culture tests, with bone marrow stromal cells, confirmed the in vitro bioactivity and biocompatibility of the scaffolds. The seeded cells were found to be alive, well anchored and spread on the samples surface. The new silica-calcite composites are expected to be suitable candidates for regeneration of cancellous bone defects. Preliminary tests on SiOC-bonded calcite scaffolds, from the firing of silicone-calcite scaffolds at 600 °C in nitrogen, are also presented.

1717.prez_name: Effect of Pretreatment on Microarc Oxidation of Magnesium: Characteristics, Corrosion Resistance and Bioactivity
1717.prez_authors: Sankara Narayanan  TSN, Min Ho  Lee
1717.prez_abstract: Surface modification by microarc oxidation (MAO) is a viable approach to control the corrosion rate of Mg and its alloys. The present study aims to explore the effect of pretreatment of Mg using oxide and fluoride coatings obtained by chemical and electrochemical methods on the characteristics of MAO coatings. The resultant coatings were characterized for their morphological features, phase content, corrosion resistance in Hank’s balanced salt solution and bioactivity in simulate body fluid. The presence of an oxide and fluoride coating significantly influences the discharge characteristics, which results in change in pore size and density, chemical composition and corrosion resistance. The findings of the study indicate that the characteristics of MAO coatings could be effectively manipulated by employing a suitable pretreatment. (This work was supported by the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) grant funded by the Korea government (MSIP) (2011-0028709, 2013R1A1A2012322 & 2014R1A4A1005309) and Regional Strategic Industry project (2013-R0002274).

1718.prez_name: Effects of Forming Voltage on Surface Characteristics and Shear Strength of Anodized Titanium
1718.prez_authors: Sakshi  Jain, Scott  Williamson, Michael  Roach
1718.prez_abstract: Electrolytes used for titanium anodization control the resulting porosity, crystallinity, surface roughness, and chemistry of the oxide layers.  The main objective of the present research was to evaluate the shear strengths of anodized layers produced with increasing forming voltages in four different electrolytes. Additionally, these shear strengths were related to the crystallinity, morphology, thickness, and chemistry present in the anodized layers.  Samples fabricated from 2.00-mm Cp-Ti grade 4 sheet were anodized using potentiostatic 12V, 10 second steps up to a final forming voltage in four mixed-acid electrolytes.  Shear strength was measured using the ASTM F1044-05 standard.  Crystalline phases were determined using XRD.  The surface morphology, layer thickness and chemistry were evaluated using SEM and EDS.  Shear strength was shown to decrease with increasing porosity and layer thickness at higher forming voltages.  Shear strength was also shown to be related to the chemistry and crystalline phases present in the anodized layers.

1719.prez_name: Electric Field-mediated Growth of Osteoblast on 3D Printed Ti-6Al-4V Alloy Porous Scaffolds under Dynamic Condition
1719.prez_authors: Alok  Kumar, Krishna Chaitanya  Nune, Devesh   Misra
1719.prez_abstract: The endogenous electric field plays an important role in biological functions and can accelerate the bone regeneration. The objective of the study is to elucidate the effect of electric field in providing a guiding cue to osteoblasts in terms of cell-cell interactions and synthesis of adhesion and cytoskeleton proteins. Furthermore, dynamic flow of media was maintained during the electric field stimulation to further enhance the expression of these proteins and constitutes the novel aspect of the study. We provide an understanding of the impact of pulsed DC electric field on cellular activity on 3D printed Ti-6Al-4V scaffolds. A higher cell proliferation and expression of vinculin and actin with minimum necrosis at 0.5 V/cm electric field strength was observed. It is underscored that the biological functionality can be altered on 3D printed scaffolds using electric field under dynamic conditions with consequent effect on cell proliferation and expression level of prominent proteins.

1720.prez_name: Electrochemical Laboratory Biofilm Reactor and Its Validity
1720.prez_authors: Hideyuki  Kanematsu, Chisei  Kato, Nobumitsu  Hirai, Akiko  Ogawa, Takeshi  Kogo
1720.prez_abstract: The formation of biofilm seems to relate closely to corrosion in various ways.  Since biofilm forms due to bacterial activities, biofilm associated corrosion (BAC) should be considered a sort of MiC, whatever the mechanism might be.  We have investigated and confirmed that the dissolution of ion from the substrate  promoted the corrosion.  We found that biofilm formation could be controlled, when the dissolution of iron would be decreased.   If the correlation between the iron dissolution and biofilm formation could be measured in-situ and directly, it would help us to fix the mechanism of BAC and also to establish the in-situ monitoring.  We have developed some kind of laboratory biofilm reactors for biofilm research including MIC studies on laboratory scale so far.  In this experiment, we coupled electrochemical measurement to the LBR and carried out the investigation about the validity using the new apparatus.

1721.prez_name: Electrophoretic Deposition of Functionalized Graphene on Ti6Al4V Alloy for Biomedical Applications
1721.prez_authors: Hassnain  Asgar, Zia Ur  Rahman, Umair Hussain Shah, Mohsin Ali Raza, Kashif Mairaj Deen, Waseem  Haider
1721.prez_abstract: Graphene is a 2-dimensional one atom thick layer of sp2 bonded carbon atoms. It has gained attention of researchers worldwide due its excellent properties such as high strength, transparency, electrical conductivity, chemical inertness and high surface area. Chemical inertness and biocompatibility of graphene makes it suitable for biomedical applications.  The present research focuses on depositing functionalized graphene (FG) coatings on titanium alloy (Ti6Al4V) by electrophoretic deposition technique to improve its corrosion resistance and biocompatibility. Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared by ultra-sonication of graphite oxide which was produced from natural graphite following modified Hummers’ method. Metallic cations were attached on GO to get functionalized graphene. GO and FG were characterized with Raman spectroscopy, XRD, FTIR and AFM. The as-deposited coatings were studied for their corrosion resistance using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and cyclic polarization. Cytocompatibility of FG coatings was studied by proliferation of Pre-Osteoblast cells.

1722.prez_abstract: The work presented here focuses on a novel nanomaterials processing method developed by my research group, that is high-throughput electrospinning. The advantages of this nanomanufacturing process is that it can use materials processing recipes developed for single jet systems, while providing a high product output. In this way, it offers a scalable and affordable process for the manufacturing of scaffolds for tissue engineering, nanofibrous mats for drug delivery and biosensing, and nanowire sensors for breath and skin-based non-invasive diagnosis based on gaseous biomarker detection. Examples of the next generation biomaterials processed by electrospinning and used for each of these applications will be provided in this talk, spanning bone engineering to asthma monitoring.

1723.prez_name: Evaluating Mechanisms of Metastasis of Cancer Using a 3D Bone-mimetic Model
1723.prez_authors: Kalpana S. Katti, MD Shahjahan   Molla, Dinesh R Katti
1723.prez_abstract: Cancer often spreads from location of origin to a distant location through a process called metastasis. Prostate and breast cancers are specifically inclined to metastasize to bone. We have developed nanoclay based 3D scaffold systems that create a bone-mimetic environment when seeded with human mesenchymal stem cells. These scaffolds mimic the mineralization of new bone formation. Here we report tumor formation in these bone-mimetic scaffolds on seeding with prostate and breast cancer cells. Tight and dense spheroids similar to the behavior in biological processes are observed. We also report spectroscopic analysis of the nature of metastatic cancer in the bone-mimetic system. RNA are extracted from cells cultured on 3D scaffolds followed by reverse transcription of cDNA to describe target gene expressions and differences for metastasized cancer cells. The bone-mimetic scaffold system represents a good model for the study of tumor formation metastasis of breast cancer and prostate cancer to bone.

1724.prez_name: Fabrication of Porous Bioabsorbable Magnesium Alloys
1724.prez_abstract: Certain magnesium-based alloys have the ability to be absorbed into the body as they corrode. The yield strength of Mg alloys allows them to be adaptable to load-bearing applications. Porosity in the alloy permits for a tunable modulus to match closely to bone and for integration with bone and tissue where the implant can be absorbed by the body during the healing process. Eliminating the need for implant removal and minimizing the risk of rejection of the implant by the body. A 3-D printer was used to establish a base structure which was packed with salt to form the initial preform. The 3-D printing material was removed and the magnesium-based alloy was casted into the salt preform under vacuum. After casting, the salt preform is dissolved away leaving a porous magnesium-based alloy structure. This porous structure allows for adequate strength and osteointigration. The porous magnesium-based alloy structure can be adjusted by varying the level of porosity in the 3-D printed preform.

1725.prez_name: Fabrication of Zinc Doped Magnesium Silicate Ceramics for Orthopaedic Applications
1725.prez_abstract: In recent years, silicate based bioceramics has drawn much attention because of its high biocompatibity and good mechanical properties. In the present study, 0.25 and 0.5 wt% zinc oxide doped magnesium silicate ceramics were prepared by sintering at 1200º C for 2 h. The in vitro biodegradation was investigated by immersing them in simulated body fluid (SBF) for 2, 4, 6, 8 weeks. Structural changes of the compacts were analyzed by micro-computed tomography and scanning electron microscopy. Micro CT results have indicated an interconnected porosity of nearly 300 µm with total porosity of 24 volume%. The in vitro degradation study revealed slow and sustained release of Mg2+ and Zn2+ ions from magnesium silicate ceramics. Bioactivity of doped and undoped samples was tested using osteoblast cells. The presentation will discuss about the microstructure of the samples, in vitro ion release, and cell-material interactions of doped and undoped magnesium silicates.

1726.prez_name: Guided Biotemplating: Phototactic Structuring of Polysaccharides by Microalgea

1727.prez_name: Hierarchical Carbon Scaffolds for Tissue Regeneration: Case Study with Muscle Cell Development
1727.prez_authors: Akhil   Patel, Anil  Karumuri, Wenhu  Wang, Shilpaa  Mukundan, Vinayak  Sant, Shilpa  Sant, Sharmila M. Mukhopadhyay
1727.prez_abstract: This investigation focuses on development of multiscale hierarchical scaffolds of biocompatible carbon such that their alignment, surface morphology and chemistry can be tuned for devlopment of specific biological cells and tissues.  In this presentation, we will show that controlled tailoring of multiscale hierarchy can enable coordinated regeneration and differentiation of myoblasts. Carbon nanotube (CNT) carpets were grown on two types of scaffolds, interconnected microporous carbon foams and aligned carbon fiber mats. Nanostructured CNT carpets offered fine control over nano-roughness and wettability facilitating myoblast adhesion, growth and differentiation into myocytes. However, microporous foam structure failed to promote their fusion into multinucleated myotubes. On the other hand, aligned fibrous architecture stimulated formation of multinucleated myotubes.  More importantly, nanostructured CNT carpets interfaced with microscale aligned fibrous structure significantly enhanced myocyte fusion into multinucleated mature myotubes.  This study underscores the synergy between nanoscale surface features and macroscale substrate architecture for enhancing coordinated tissue regeneration.

1728.prez_name: High Temperature Anodization of Magnesium Based Alloys for Controlling Degradation in Physiological Environment
1728.prez_authors: Zia Ur  Rahman, Waseem  Haider, Umair  Shah, Hassnain  Asgar
1728.prez_abstract: Permanent implants in the body lead to complications, including sensitizations and allergies. In this regard, magnesium alloys have raised an immense amount of interest to researchers because of their biodegradability in a physiological environment. However, a major concern with magnesium alloys is fast and non-uniform degradation. Controlling the degradation rate in physiological environment determine the success of biodegradable implants. In this study, new technique of anodization is carried out at high temperature on magnesium alloys. The surface crystallinity was compared through XRD before and after immersion tests in PBS. SEM confirmed new surfaces, and EDS was carried out for compositional analysis. FTIR for each sample, to confirm the oxides present on the surface. The corrosion resistance of the film was evaluated by EIS (ASTM: G 3-89) and potentiodynamic polarization scans (ASTM: G 102-89). Additionally, the cytotoxicity of the leached metal ions was evaluated by using a tetrazolium-based bioassay, MTS.

1729.prez_name: II Biological Window All-optical Imaging Players: A General Prospective and a Multifunctional Newcomer
1729.prez_authors: Antonio  Benayas, Elisa  Carrasco, Blanca  del Rosal, Fuqiang  Ren, Eva  Hemmer, Dongling  Ma, Fiorenzo  Vetrone
1729.prez_abstract: Near infrared (NIR)-based optical bioimaging has become a quickly emerging field and manifold new NIR-emitting nanoprobes have been reported, with the goal of developing more accurate, efficient, non-invasive and fast diagnostic tools. In this context, various approaches have been followed in research laboratories around the globe in the search for appropriate candidates to tackle that endeavor. In this communication few ongoing trends and highlights are summarized and put into context, regarding NIR-to-NIR bioimaging nanoprobes´ results, lately published, within the region above 1000 nm (2nd and 3rd biological windows, BWs, of "tissue transparency"). As a specific insight, the case of the PbS/CdS/ZnS quantum dots (QDs) is thoroughly presented. This system has recently attracted certain deal of attention as a "low-dose" II-BW in vivo bioimaging nanoprobe, also showing an attractive multifunctionality. Specifically, fluorescent nanothermometry performance of these QDs, together with photo-thermal therapy (PTT) preliminary results, is discussed.

1730.prez_name: Improving the Flexural Mechanical Properties of Bioactive Glass (13-93) Scaffolds for Structural Bone Repair
1730.prez_authors: Mohamed N Rahaman, Wei  Xiao, Mohsen  Asle Zaeem, Sonny  Bal
1730.prez_abstract: There is interest in the use of bioactive glass scaffolds for healing large defects in structural bone. However, most studies have targeted bioactive glass scaffolds with low strength, such as compressive strength comparable to trabecular bone. In this presentation, we will describe our recent studies on the development of bioactive glass scaffolds with an optimal combination of high compressive and flexural strength, coupled with a microstructure conducive to supporting bone infiltration in vivo. The use of finite element modeling (FEM) to simulate the mechanical properties of a variety of structures, the creation bioactive glass (13-93) scaffolds with the requisite microstructures by robotic deposition, mechanical testing of fabricated scaffolds to validate the predictions of the FEM simulations, and evaluation of the scaffolds in a rat calvarial defect model in vivo will be described. The potential of these bioactive glass scaffolds for repairing large defects in structural bone will be discussed.

1731.prez_name: In Vitro Depth-dependent Hyperthermia of Human Mammary Gland Adenocarcinoma
1731.prez_authors: Donglu  Shi, Yu  Zhang, Andrew  Dunn
1731.prez_abstract: Nanoparticle mediated photothermal ablation of cancerous tissue shows promising results as an efficacious treatment method. However it is important to understand the effects of greater laser attenuation on photothermal efficacy mediated by changes in the scattering and absorption profiles of soft tissue. Photothermal efficacy using a near infrared (NIR) 785 nm laser irradiating polystyrene (PS) stabilized magnetite (Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) nanoparticles (PS-Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>) is examined on MDA-MB-231 human mammary gland adenocarcinoma in-vitro. Agarose gel columns of various heights were created to simulate soft tissue and subsequently used for NIR laser attenuation. PS was found to significantly improve magnetite nanoparticle stability in modified Hank’s Balanced Salt Solution, serum containing media, reduces innate toxicity over 48 hours compared to uncoated magnetite, and allows for effective hyperthermic ablation. Agar gel layers provide similar optical attenuation in the NIR region to soft tissue and provide a convenient base gel material for advanced soft tissue modeling.

1732.prez_name: In Vivo Evaluation of Novel Amorphous Silicon Oxynitrophosphide Implant Coatings for Rapid Bone Healing
1732.prez_authors: Venu G Varanasi, Azhar   Ilyas, Pranesh  Aswath, Harry  Kim, Phillip  Kramer
1732.prez_abstract: Structurally unstable fracture sites require permanent or semi-permanent bone implants that are typically made of titanium (Ti) or other inert metals. The material properties of these fixative devices play significant role in bone healing. A material that that reacts favorably and adheres well to the in-vivo bone environment is critical for rapid bone healing. Here, we propose the use of nanofabricated amorphous silicon oxynitrophosphide (Si-O-N-P) as an overlay onto metal implants in load-bearing bone defect applications. We will exhibit the mechanical and chemical characterization of nanofabricated device to assess its adhesion to the underlying metal/metal oxide. We will also reveal its osteoinductive behavior when placed in biological environment in-vitro and craniofacial defects in-vivo. The interaction of the elemental components at bone-SiONP/TiO2/Ti interface will be presented and discussed. A novel antioxidant role will be revealed that will illustrate the connection between immunological and pathways that enhance bone healing.

1733.prez_name: Laser Desorption/Ionization (LDI) Mass Spectrometry Based on Nanomaterials for Biomedical Applications

1734.prez_name: Load-to-failure of Composite Bone Following Removal of Proximal Femoral Fixation Hardware

1735.prez_name: Model Biomimetic Dental Composites: Processing and Mechanical Properties of Glass Fiber Model Systems

1736.prez_name: Nanoscale Structure and Modification of Biomaterials
1736.prez_abstract: Modifying the nanostructure/chemistry of materials allows to optimize their properties. Our strategy rests on creating nanopatterns that act as surface cues affecting cell behavior. Chemical oxidation creates unique topographies becoming a general strategy to improve biocompatibility. Our treatment selectively inhibits fibroblast growth while promoting osteogenic cell activity in vitro. Enhancement of mechano-biocompatibility may occur by coating with spider silk. Improvement of antibacterial properties using laser and plasma strategies will also be discussed.

1737.prez_name: Nanoscale Surface Modification of Metallic Biomaterials for Orthopedic Applications
1737.prez_abstract: We have been exploring different nanoscale strategies for the surface modification of metallic biomaterials for use in orthopedic applications. Surface mechanical attrition treatment was used to engineer nanocrystalline surfaces on 316L stainless steel. Surface nanocrystallization modified the nature of oxide layer present on the surface. It increased the corrosion-fatigue strength in saline by 50%. Nanocrystallization also enhanced osteoblast attachment and proliferation. The improved performance of the biomaterials is attributed to the change in the surface oxide layer. In another study, we have developed a novel reactive ion etching route that yields randomly oriented anisotropic nanostructures inspired by the nanotopography on insect wings.  The nanostructures were found to kill bacteria on contact by mechanical rupturing the cells without compromising cytocompatibility of the titanium. The titanium also  induced osteogenic differentiation even in the absence of soluble factors. Thus, the bioinspired anisotropic nanostructures on titanium impart multi-biofunctional properties for use in orthopedics.

1738.prez_name: Nanostructured Amorphous Magnesium Phosphate/Poly (Lactic Acid) Composite Coating for Enhanced Corrosion Resistance and Bioactivity of Biodegradable AZ31 Magnesium Alloy
1738.prez_authors: Yufu  Ren, Elham  Babaie, Sarit B.  Bhaduri
1738.prez_abstract: The severe galvanic corrosion of magnesium alloys in electrolytic physiological environment limited their wide applications in biomedical fields. Recent studies have shown polymeric coating such as PLA, PLGA and PCL films can provide effective corrosion protection to magnesium-based substrates. Magnesium phosphates, including amorphous magnesium phosphate (AMP) are promising alternatives to calcium phosphates and present outstanding biocompatibility and bioactivity.  In addition, the rapid mineralization of amorphous magnesium phosphate (AMP) could further stimulate the cellular response. The motivation of this work is to take advantages of PLA and AMP to improve the degradation and biological performance of AZ31 magnesium alloy.  In this study, AMP/PLA composite films were spin coated on AZ31 substrates using a PLA suspension containing AMP nanoparticles. The as-prepared AMP/PLA coating was characterized using TEM, SEM, XRD and FTIR.  Afterwards, the in-vitro degradation behavior and biomineralization of AMP/PLA coated AZ31 were investigated by electrochemical and immersion tests.

1739.prez_name: Novel Bioactive Glass Containing Dental Composites for Slowing Secondary Caries
1739.prez_authors: Jamie J. Kruzic, Dmytro  Khvostenko, Jack L Ferracane, Thomas J Hilton, John C Mitchell
1739.prez_abstract: The most common reason for the replacement of resin based composite tooth restorations is secondary caries occurring at the margins of the restoration. In this study, a novel bioreactor system has been developed to allow cyclic mechanical loading of simulated tooth restorations while a controlled oral biofilm environment is allowed to grow on the sample. A synergistic effect was found whereby cyclic loading promotes deep penetration of bacteria along gaps at the dentin-composite interface for 100% of the samples compared to only ~50% occurrence for the unloaded samples. Next, composites with 15wt% bioactive glass additions were produced to provide an antimicrobial environment along the interfacial gaps. In this case, bacterial penetration along the interface was significantly slowed, with the mean penetration depth only ~61% of the interface for bioactive glass containing composites compared to ~100% for the control composites. Thus, bioactive glass fillers show promise for slowing secondary caries formation.

1740.prez_name: On Additive Manufacturing and Restoration of  Tooth Cavities Using Chemically Bonded Ceramics - an Overview
1740.prez_abstract: This paper relates to dental implants and restoration materials, wherein Additive Manufacturing including CAD/CAM or similar technologies are used for machining dense blanks into a close correspondence with the cavity geometry. The blank materials can be produced from chemically bonded ceramics of the CASPH-system (CaO-Al2O3-SiO2-P2O5-H2O). The same basic system, the CASPH-system can be used as a cement for fixation of the blanks to the surrounding tooth tissue. In this way minimal mechanical and thermal tension between the biomaterial and the biological tissue is possible to achieve.The use of the chemically bonded ceramic cement facilitates also the filling of a dental cavity with a waist, where the cement also works as a base. The dense blanks facilitate improved mechanical properties including wear resistance, as well as improved optical properties including transparency of the dental cavitiy.

1741.prez_name: Osteoblast Functions in Functionally Graded Ti-6Al-4V 3D Printed Mesh Structures
1741.prez_authors: Krishna Chaitanya  Nune, Devesh   Misra, Li  SJ, Hao  YL, Yang  R
1741.prez_abstract: We describe here the combined efforts of engineering and biological sciences as a systemic approach to fundamentally elucidate osteoblast functions in functionally graded Ti-6Al-4V mesh structures in relation to uniform/monolithic mesh arrays. First, the interconnecting porous architecture of functionally graded mesh arrays was conducive to cellular functions including attachment, proliferation, and mineralization. Second, a comparative and parametric study indicated that gradient mesh structure had a pronounced effect on cell adhesion and mineralization, and strongly influenced the proliferation phase. Cells adhered to the mesh struts by forming a sheet, bridging the pores through numerous cytoplasmic extensions, in the case of porous mesh structures. Intercellular interaction in porous structures provided a pathway for cells to communicate and mature to a differentiated phenotype. Furthermore, the capability of cells to migrate through the interconnecting porous architecture on mesh structures led to colonization of the entire structure. Cells were embedded layer-by-layer in the ECM.

1742.prez_name: Physically Crosslinked Injectable Composites for Bone Tissue Engineering
1742.prez_authors: Mohamad Nageeb Hassan, Shaimaa  Mohamad, Ahmed   El-Tawila, Ahmed   Abd El-Fattah, Sherif   Kandil
1742.prez_abstract: Injectable biomaterials were developed for tissue engineering applications to flow through a small-bore needle or a catheter. This could overcome the trauma resulting from surgical implantation of 3D biomaterial templates and to fit into irregular defects. In addition, it achieves a minimally invasive surgical approaches to deliver drug molecules or accelerate healing.Crosslinking of biopolymers could be achieved by chemical methods. However, physical methods are recently used to avoid the cytotoxic effects associated with the residual chemical cross-linkers. In this work, we will discuss two types of physically crosslinked injectable biopolymer composites for bone tissue engineering developed by our group. We have developed a novel dehydrothermal approach to achieve physical crosslinking of fibrillar collagen hydrogel composite with hydroxyapatite. On the other hand, we have used repeated freeze-thaw cycles to crosslink poly(vinyl alcohol) hydrogel with bioactive glass particles which showed good bone regeneration in the mandible of a canine model.

1743.prez_name: Preparation and Characterizations of  Nano Composites Based on Biphasic Mixture of Bioactive Ceramics for Biomedical Applications
1743.prez_authors: Nida  Iqbal, Mohammed Rafiq  Abdul Kadir
1743.prez_abstract: Bioactive bioceramics have been developed to promote a regeneration of bones. Among all these hydroxyapatite is the most commonly used for clinical applications due to its similarity to inorganic mineral component of bone. However, clinical application of HA is limited due to its slow rate of biodegradation which results a very slow osseointegration rate and requires the long-term stability of implants in bony tissue. Therefore, in this study, two-phaseHA/TCP ceramics was developed.  Firstly, separate syntheses of HA and TCP via microwave irradiation and physical mixing of component powders in speciﬁed ratios followed by sintering was developed. The crystalline phase, chemical composition, and morphology of the prepared samples were characterized using (XRD) (FTIR), (EDX), and (SEM). The chemical analysis indicated the presence of a calcium phasphates phases. Scanning electron microscopy analysis showed a spheroid-like morphology. These ﬁndings suggested that two-phase HA/TCP ceramics could potentially be used for bone regeneration applications

1744.prez_name: Processing and Characterization of Silicon Nitride Bioceramics
1744.prez_authors: Bryan J. McEntire, Alan  Lakshminarayanan, Prabhakar  Thirugnanasambandam, Jacob  Seitz-Sampson, Ryan  Bock, David  O'Brien
1744.prez_abstract: Silicon nitride (Si3N4) is used as an arthrodesis device in the cervical and thoracolumbar spine, and has been proposed as a bearing material for total joint arthroplasty.  Its favorable combination of properties, such as high strength and fracture toughness, inherent phase stability, biocompatibility, hydrophilicity, and bacterial resistance, make it an ideal biomaterial for these applications.  In this paper, the initial development and validation of the processes used in manufacturing spinal implants from Si3N4 are presented and discussed.  These manufacturing methods were industrialized using fractional factorial experiment designs in accordance with Taguchi methods, followed by implementation of statistical process controls.  The roles of various processing parameters including raw materials, pressing, and firing conditions (i.e., time, temperature, and pressure) are elucidated.  It is demonstrated that acceptable physical, mechanical, and dimensional quality attributes are consistently obtained from these statistically designed and controlled processes.

1745.prez_name: Silicon Nitride Implants with Complex Structures Created by Robocasting
1745.prez_authors: Mohamed N Rahaman, Santuan  Zhao, Wei  Xiao, Sonny  Bal, Bryan J McEntire, Darin  Ray
1745.prez_abstract: Silicon nitride implants are currently used clinically in spinal repair and are under consideration for use as bearings in total joint arthroplasty. In the present study, silicon nitride biomaterials with complex three-dimensional structures were fabricated by a robotic deposition (robocasting) technique followed by sintering and hot isostatic pressing (sinter/HIP). We developed a paste with optimal rheology for printing by dispersing silicon nitride particles (plus sintering additives) in an aqueous solution containing a dispersant and binder. Green articles with complex structures were printed through nozzles of diameter 400 or 600 microns. After drying and binder burnout, the sinter/HIP step resulted in linear shrinkage of 25% and the production of a silicon nitride material with a density of 95% of the theoretical and a microstructure composed of fibrous grains. The robocasting route developed in this study is promising for the production of silicon nitride implants with anatomically relevant shapes.

1746.prez_name: Surface Texture and Wettability of Amorphous Metallic Biomaterials
1746.prez_authors: Sanghita  Mridha, Ayyagari  Aditya, Sundeep  Mukherjee
1746.prez_abstract: Metallic glasses are multi-component metallic alloys that have exceptional stability against crystallization and remarkable properties including excellent wear resistance, superior corrosion resistance under physiological conditions, high strength, and unique thermo-plastic processing ability. These properties make them attractive for next generation bio-implant applications. In addition, the surface of metallic glasses may be textured to achieve favorable topography for enhancing cell-implant interaction. Surface wettability mediates protein adsorption and biological response to biomaterial surfaces. Recent results on wettability of amorphous metallic surfaces in biological media will be presented which may promote faster wound healing and tissue regeneration.

1747.prez_name: Tantalum Diffusion Coating for Increasing the Biocompatibility of Conventional Metal Implant Alloys
1747.prez_authors: Jacob   Stiglich, Brian  Williams, Roger  Narayan, Therese  Grundl
1747.prez_abstract: Tantalum has long been used as an implant material in bone and soft tissue, and Ultramet developed and licensed a process for fabricating open-cell tantalum metal foam bone implants that is approved by the FDA. Under NASA funding, Ultramet diffused highly corrosion-resistant tantalum metal into the surface of conventional stainless steels and superalloys to improve acid corrosion resistance of precision valve components. A thin, metallurgically bonded surface layer was established that graded from pure tantalum to a mixture of tantalum and the substrate elements. The tantalum surface layer precisely replicates intricate substrate features and does not require machining. This diffusion coating can increase the biocompatibility of conventional metal implant alloys, and the ability to harden the surface via partial or full conversion to tantalum nitride has been demonstrated. Additional surface treatments to alter texture may be used to improve biological functionality (e.g. enhance bone formation) of dental and orthopedic implants.

1748.prez_name: The Synergy of Conventional Ceramic Forming and Electronic Device Manufacturing Process to Develop Hermetic High Density Feedthroughs for Miniature Implantable Medical Devices
1748.prez_abstract: Electronic biomedical implants are being increasingly used to diagnose, prevent and treat diseases and other conditions. Such implanted devices are typically housed in hermetic packages that incorporate electrical feedthroughs for signal transfer between the housed electronic device and the environment. The emerging implantable devices, especially those that interface with the human nervous system, the cochlea, or the retina, require a multiplex of leads in a very small feedthrough. Conventionally available feedthrough technologies are incapable of providing lead-to-lead spacing approaching 250µm and thus, fail to comply with integrated circuit I/O interface. This presentation will report the development of a hermetic high-density feedthrough (HDF) technology. The fabrication process utilizes the synergy of conventional ceramic forming and miniature device manufacturing process to yield a robust and cost-effective solution to fabricate hermetic HDF for miniature implantable devices. The inherent benefits of the developed technology and the impact on device fidelity will also be discussed.

1749.prez_name: Advice for Professional Engineering (PE) Licensure for Emerging Professionals

1750.prez_name: Capitalizing on Success: How to Reclaim the Direction of Your Education and Career at the Undergraduate Level

1751.prez_name: Engineering Survivor: Perspectives on Mid-career Job Moves, Layoffs, and Corporate Structure Changes

1752.prez_name: How to Aim at a Career as a Leader in Industry and End up as a Happy Professor

1872.prez_authors: Kourosh  Kalantar-zadeh, Arnan  Michell, Khashayar  Khoshmanes, Shi-Yang  Tang
1872.prez_abstract: Liquid metal marbles that are droplets of liquid metal encapsulated by micro- or nanoparticles are introduced. Droplets of gallium alloys liquid metal are coated with insulators (including Teflon and silica) and semiconductors (e.g. WO3, TiO2, and carbon nanotubes) by rolling over a powder bed and also by submerging in colloidal suspensions. It is shown that these marbles can be split and merged, can be suspended on water, and are even stable when moving under the force of gravity and impacting a flat solid surface. Furthermore, the marble coating can operate as an active electronic junction and the nanomaterial coated liquid metal marble can act as a highly sensitive electrochemical based heavy metal ion sensor. Liquid metal marbles can be propelled using chemical, electrochemical, optical and mechanical means which will be presented in this talk. This new element thus represents a significant platform for the advancement of research into soft electronics.

1873.prez_name: Amino Acids Adsorption on Graphene Oxide, Titanium Dioxide and their Nanocomposite
1873.prez_authors: Liangliang  Huang, Mykola  Seredych, Teresa J. Bandosz
1873.prez_abstract: As the fundamental biomolecular building blocks, amino acids are excellent simple models for understanding the interactions of biomaterials with surfaces and interfaces. In this work, we combine multi-scale modeling techniques to study the behavior of amino acids on graphene oxide (GO), titanium dioxide (TiO2) and their nanocomposite (GO/TiO2). By ab initio density functional theory (DFT) method and reactive molecular dynamics (RxMD) simulations, we calculate amino acid interaction with these model systems. Specific focuses have been placed on: (a) the surface functionalization of GO, that is, a comparison between pristine graphene and realistic atomistic GO models will be discussed; (b) the facet reactivity of TiO2 and the solution effect, following our previous results where water demonstrates significantly different properties on various TiO2 facets. The GO/TiO2 nanocomposite and the enhancement towards amino acid adsorption and diffusion will be also discussed. Parallel experimental studies will be discussed and compared with the theoretical results.

1874.prez_name: Assembling Freestanding Conductive Polymer Tube Arrays at Liquid/Liquid Interface
1874.prez_abstract: Patterned tube array structures are mainly synthesized by template-assisted and substrate-initiated methods so far, which meet significant challenges in scale-up manufacturing and non-destructive transfer to desired support. In this talk, a new method will be discussed on synthesizing freestanding tubular array of conductive polymers without using template or substrate. A “water/oil/water” triphasic reaction system was employed to control diffusion and reaction at separate “water/oil” and “oil/water” interfaces. The former controls reactant feeding rate and the latter determines reaction rate. By synergistic integration of diffusion and reaction in one reactor, freestanding tubular-arrayed conductive polymer thin films were successfully fabricated. Molecular dynamic simulation was performed to understand the reactant diffusion across the two interfaces. This “water/oil/water” triphasic method opens up a new approach to synthesize other patterned three dimensional materials by careful designing the reaction system.

1875.prez_name: Boosting Energy Efficiency of Hierarchical Electrodes via Nano-interfacial Engineering
1875.prez_authors: Long  Chen, Liwen  Mu, Tuo  Ji,
1875.prez_abstract: Hybrid electrodes with electroactive components on conductive substrates have been demonstrated effective strategy to achieve high energy and power density in supercapacitor. However, the mismatch of interface property could be a huge hurdle to further improve energy storage performance and long term stability. In this work, an interfacial metal seeding approach has been developed targeting to strengthen the interfacial interaction between electroactive NiCo2O4 nanostructure and carbon substrate as well as to promote electron transfer across interface. A synergistic contribution of promoted interfacial interaction, reduced internal resistance and enlarged surface area leads to a boosted energy efficiency of NiCo2O4 in this study. A comparative study on different metal nanoparticles (nickel, cobalt and iron) reveal that not only metal species but also particle concentration play significant roles in determining the energy storage property of the hierarchical NiCo2O4/carbon electrodes.

1876.prez_name: Break and Reform Chemical Bonds in Energy Materials by Electrons
1876.prez_abstract: The interplay among the microscopic degrees of freedom can generate macroscopic phenomena, such as the insulator-metal transition that has attracted long-standing interest for their potential applications in data storage, information processing and photonic technology. Here I will report our recent computational simulations on two different systems. One is vanadium dioxide (VO2), which shows a phase transition from a low-temperature semiconducting phase to a high-temperature metallic phase at 68°C with a rapid change in the electronic and optical properties. Our calculations reveal the underlying physics of the phase transition and its response to external (thermal, photo, electronic and chemical) stimuli. In the second example, I will discuss results on chemical functionalization of metal-supported graphene using iron phthalocyanine, and focus on reversible control of the interfacial bonding between non-covalent and covalent interaction via electronic and thermal stimuli. Application of these responsive behaviors will also be discussed.

1877.prez_name: Development of Lead Free Organometallic Solid State Perovskite Solar Cell
1877.prez_abstract: Methyl-ammonium lead iodide (MAPbI3) based perovskite solar-cell (PSC) has attracted lot of attentions recently because of their high efficiency (PCE >20%) and low cost. However these PSCs are toxic, environmentally hazardous and unstable in humid condition. Hence, their temperature and moisture stability need to be improved to counter degradation of solar-cell. In the current investigation methyl-ammonium bismuth iodide (MABiI3) based perovskite solar absorber were synthesized using solution processing technique to develop lead free nontoxic environmental friendly PSCs. Thin-films of MABiI3 were fabricated by spin coating the solution on FTO-coated glass. Structural analysis of MABiI3 perovskites was carried out by XRD. FESEM studies determined the presence of dense large grain-size perovskite thin-films. UV-Vis and FTIR spectra showed high absorbance and less moisture affinity respectively. Photoluminescence, Raman Spectroscopy and electrical characterizations like I-V, J-V, Hall effect were also carried out to evaluate the potential of MABiI3 perovskites for solar cell applications.

1878.prez_name: Development of Metal Nanoparticle as Direct Visible Light Photocatalyst for Numerous Organic Syntheses
1878.prez_abstract: Metal nanoparticles have proven successful in harvesting visible light across a wide range of wavelengths, efficiently converting the photon energy into the chemical energy for catalyzing important organic reactions at ambient temperatures - and thus the Direct Photocatalysts of Metal Nanoparticles becoming a class of new photocatalysts independent from semiconductors. Recent advances with direct photocatalysts of MNP under visible light are the photo-induced or photo-enhanced catalytic chemical transformations using metal nanoparticles supported on photocatalytically-inert materials (ZrO2, Al2O3 etc.). This is in stark contrast to the earlier perception of the metal nanoparticles’s traditional role as an enhancer of the catalytic performance of semiconductor. Representative examples include, azo compound synthesis with Au NP catalysts supported on ZrO2 and the oxidation of ethylene to epoxides using Ag NP on Al2O3. Followed by our another benchmark discovery - numbers of non-plasmonic metal nanoparticles can be effective photocatalysts without semiconductors.

1879.prez_authors: Huaiyuan  Wang,  Zhanjian  Liu, Yanji   Zhu, Liwen  Mu, Jiahua   Zhu
1879.prez_abstract: Biomimetic superhydrophobic surfaces have attracted significant attention in recent years. However, satisfying the structure and surface energy requirements of superhydrophobic coatings usually sacrifices its durability. Self-healing capability is a good prospective approach to extend the lifespan of superhydrophobic coatings. Although different strategies have been developed to construct self-healing superhydrophobic coatings, most of them are still at an early stage of application. The self-healing coatings are currently restricted by their poor mechanical strength and low stability of the healing agent. In this study, an analogous “Chloroplast” structure has been successfully replicated in a graphene/SiO2 composite coating, porous graphene construction assisted by dopamine self-polymerization and in-situ growth of nano-SiO2 on graphene surface. The healing agent of POTS was stored in the analogous “Chloroplast” structure by both chemical bonding and physical absorption. This unique structure enables the superhydrophobic coating with excellent self-healing capability, durability performance.

1880.prez_name: Engineering Iron Oxide Nanoparticles for Magnetic Imaging Applications
1880.prez_abstract: Iron oxide nanoparticles (IONPs) are widely investigated due to their chemical tunability and great potential as diagnostic and therapeutic agents. In magnetic particle imaging (MPI), which is an emerging imaging modality that enables the direct mapping of IONP tracers, the signal generation relies heavily on the magnetization reversal of the IONP tracers. As such, it is essential to tune the IONP’s magnetic properties in order to achieve good MPI image resolution. To date, most studies have focused in optimizing spherical IONPs in MPI applications. In this presentation, a systematic investigation of the effects of chemical doping and shape anisotropy on the MPI performance of IONP tracers will be discussed. Moreover, the demonstration of targeted hyperthermia through an MPI-guided approach will be presented.  In addition, this presentation will cover the development of a novel synthesis approach to fabricate high-index faceted IONPs that have high T2 relaxivities for MRI applications.

1881.prez_name: Enhancing Photovoltaic Response of Solar Cell Devices Using Nanomaterials
1881.prez_authors: John  Bell, Hongxia  Wang, Aijun  Du
1881.prez_abstract: The holy grail of photovoltaics is to capture more light and to convert into electricity at the lowest possible cost.  While silicon and other solid state solar cell performance have been increased through nanostructuring of devices (eg. creating nanostructured surfaces to enhance light capture and multi-junction devices to harvest more of the solar spectrum), the use of nanomaterials in this field really started seriously with the dye-sensitised solar cell utilising nanoparticle titania to create increased surfaces for dye absorption, and hence increase light capture.  This paper will describe several quite different approaches to using nanomaterials to increase solar cell efficiency, mainly in dye-sensitised solar cells and perovskite solar cells.  The approaches range of enhancing scattering to capture more light, adding quantum dot sensitisers to increase the absorption and spectral range of absorption, and the use of carbon nanotubes and graphene to enhance both light absorption and charge separation.

1882.prez_name: Influence of Solute (Impurity) Atoms on Microstructure and Deformation Mechanisms of Nanostructured Pure Titanium
1882.prez_authors: Guanyu  Deng, Yan  Chong, Nahoko  Saji, Ruixiao  Zheng, Tilak  Bhattacharjee, Yu  Bai, Akinobu  Shibata, Nobuhiro  Tsuji
1882.prez_abstract: Titanium and Ti-alloys are widely used in the marine, aerospace, automobile, and biomedical industries due to their good strength-to-weight ratio, high melting temperature, excellent corrosion resistance, and biocompatibility. Fabrication of nanostructured titanium managing both high strength and good ductility has attracted a lot of interest in the last two decades. However, the investigations considering the influence of solute (impurity) atoms on microstructure and deformation mechanisms of nanostructured pure titanium have been very limited. The present study is specifically designed to systematically understand the influence of oxygen (O) and iron (Fe) content during fabrication of nanostructured pure titanium using high pressure torsion (HPT) technique, which leads to significant grain refinement by introducing large plastic strains. Detailed microstructures are characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and mechanical behaviors are examined using tensile test method with a help of digital image correlation (DIC) technique.

1883.prez_name: Investigation of Vacancy-type Defects in Nanostructured Aluminum Alloys Processed by Severe Plastic Deformation
1883.prez_authors: Lihong  Su, Cheng  Lu, Huijun  Li, Guanyu  Deng, Kiet  Tieu
1883.prez_abstract: Nanostructured materials, processed by severe plastic deformation, have attracted a great deal of attention in the last decade due to their superior mechanical properties, such as significantly enhanced strength and hardness. Vacancy-type defects play an important role in the nanostructured materials, and the formation and migration of vacancy-type defects are strongly temperature-dependent. The present study use positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy (PALS) to test the vacancy-type defects in aluminum alloys processed by equal channel angular pressing (ECAP) and accumulative roll bonding (ARB) at both room temperature and cryogenic temperature. TEM observation and hardness tests were conducted to examine the microstructure and mechanical property evolutions in the nanostructure aluminum alloys. A detailed analysis was performed and a quantitative relationship between the material hardness and the defect concentration and defect diffusion coefficient has been established.

1884.prez_name: Modulation of Electronic Structure by Strain in 2D BiOX(X=Cl,Br)
1884.prez_abstract: The ability to continuously control the electronic structures in 2D semiconductors is highly desirable for a wide range of development of advanced electronic devices, sensors and of energy and environmental applications. As is known to us all, strain is an effective method to tune the band structure for coventional semicoductor materials. In this work, we illustrate experimentally and theoretically that the electronic structure of BiOCl and BiOBr  nanosheets can be tuned by the inner strain effect. Our work suggests that strain engineering could be an effective strategy to controlling the electronic structure of 2D semiconductors for further enhancement of their efficiency in converting light into other forms of energy.

1885.prez_name: Nanomagnetism Tunned by Crystal Facet Engineering
1885.prez_authors: Wenxian  Li, Ziqi  Sun, Rongkun  Zheng, Xiangyuan  Cui
1885.prez_abstract: The presentation aims at clarify the contribution of the exposed crystal planes on the magnetic behaviors of transition metal oxides nanocrystals based on the crystal facet engineering. The First Principle Calculation was employed to simulate the magnetic moments and their coupling modes in the exposed surface layer of nanocrystals. The exposed crystal plane was controlled accuratedly using different surfactants and structure-directing agents during the thermohydral synthesize of transition metal oxides. Correspondingly, different nanomagnetic performances were generated because the magnetic moment and their coupling mode were modified in the surface layer on the exposed crystal plane. The nanomagnetism was discussed based on the analysis of the crystallinity, lattice distortion, morphology, size, valence state, defect type and contents, and configuration environment. The contribution of different exposed crystal planes on the nanomagnetism was explored to explain the origination of nanomagnetism on the level of atom layout and electronic structure.

1886.prez_name: Preparation of Thermosensitive Magnetic Surface Protein Imprinted Microsphere and Its Application for Protein Recognition
1886.prez_abstract: At present, the major challenge of protein imprinting is that huge molecular size of protein rendered it difﬁcult to transfer. Surface imprinting can solve the problem of mass transfer in a certain extent, but it cannot control the capture and release of template proteins. In our work, a novel thermosensitive magnetic surface protein imprinted microsphere was prepared in the presence of N-isopropylacrylamide. When the adsorption temperature was higher than the lower critical solution temperature (LCST) of poly(N-isopropylacrylamide), shape memory effect of imprinted cavities would be more effective, which was more conducive to capture template molecules. On the other hand, when the desorption temperature was lower than the LCST, the decrease of shape memory effect between imprinted cavities and template molecules would facilitate the release of template molecules from the imprinted cavities. Based on this property, the adsorption and desorption of template molecules could be regulated by system temperature indirectly.

1887.prez_name: Several Fundamental Issues in the Assembly and Integration of Nanowires for Electronics and Sensor Applications
1887.prez_abstract: Nanowires have been explored for many potential applications in the past two decades, including nanoelectronics, nanophotonics, sensors/biosensors, solar cells, fuel cells, energy storage, and nanomedicine. While processing them, assembly and integration of individual nanowire components into functional electronics or devices remain critical steps. A variety of methods have been studied for the assembly of nanowires, such as molecular interactions (e.g., surface tension, hydrophobic force, electrostatic force), molecular linkers (e.g., antibody-antigen), or external forces (e.g., electrical, magnetic, or dielectrophoretic force). In this presentation, I will discuss several fundamental issues in the assembling and integrating nanowires into functional electronics or systems. First, I will review several techniques on how to effectively assemble and integrate nanowires. Then, I will discuss the oxidation effect and how to mitigate or solve this problem. Finally, I will show nano-joint formation and large-scale nanowire assembly and soldering, including atomic diffusion, intermetallic formation, and void formation.

1888.prez_name: SiOx Nanoflowers and Nanobangles Grown under Atmospheric Pressure
1888.prez_abstract: Using vapor liquid solid method with Au as catalyst and Si substrate as Si source by high temperature annealing under atmospheric pressure, we got a series of SiOx nanoflowers and nanobangles. The growth process and mechanism were investigated by comparing the morphologies of nanoflowers grown with different annealing conditions. Over ten micrometers triangular etch pits are found scattered on substrates, around which different SiOx nanoflowers are developed dozens of micrometers away. And photoluminescence measurements of nanoflowers demonstrate that the luminous intensities increase with the increasing of length and amount of nanoflowers petals.

1889.prez_name: Some Keys to Design/Propose New Functional Materials
1889.prez_abstract: Progress in computational environment is now promising chances to design new functional materials on the desk. Recent remarkable approach is on the basis of the connection between materials science and informatics. On the basis of the huge database of the material properties, empirical rules will be discovered by the informatics techniques, such as machine learning, and candidates of the functional materials with the desired properties will be listed as a result of the computation. Another approach, which is traditional, has a rather bottom-up style. Starting from the basic knowledge on the properties, a new way to change the properties will be devised. The high capability of the computation seems to change the environment of this approach also.  However, to maximize this approach, some keys or tricks will be required. I would like to discuss this with some our recent studies.

1890.prez_name: Study on the Microstructure and Properties of Bonding Interface in the Explosive Welded AZ31/1060 Composite Plate
1890.prez_abstract: In the present work, a composite plate of AZ31 magnesium alloy and 1060 pure aluminum was fabricated by explosive welding. The microstructure, distribution of elements and properties of bonding interface after explosive welding were investigated. The results show that, through explosive welding, the bonding rate of AZ31 magnesium alloy and 1060 pure aluminum can reach 99.4% and the bonding interface has a wavy appearance. In the process of explosive welding, elements diffusion is observed at the bonding interface and the thickness of the diffusion layer is about 8.39μm. With the increase of distance to the interface. microstructure of magnesium alloy changes from deformation bands to fine grains and then into elongated grains. Away from bonding interface, most of microstructure in magnesium alloy is equiaxed grains. During the tensile test, AZ31 magnesium alloy cracks firstly and then 1060 pure aluminum cracks. There is not delamination at the bonding interface in the process of fracture. In the shear test, adhesion of magnesium alloy and pure aluminum implies two kinds of metals bind firmly. Because of work hardening, the hardness of magnesium alloy near bonding interface is very high and the thickness of the high hardness zone is about 200μm.

1891.prez_name: Theoretically Understanding on Carbon-based Nanomaterials for Energy Application
1891.prez_authors: Ting  Liao, Debra   Bernhardt, Shixue  Dou
1891.prez_abstract: Inexpensive, metal-free materials of high performance in energy application as diverse as solutions, fuel-cell operation, supercapacitors, and catalyst, is highly desirable to replace currently widely used metal or metal oxides. Modification of carbon-based nanomaterials by the introduction of appropriate elements or functional groups or nanosized particles may enable the manipulation of electronic, structural and chemical properties that allows targeting of superior performance. In this presentation, a strong facilitating effect of heteroatom doping on graphene nanoribbons has been illustrated by DFT calculations, which includes stimulating dissociative adsorption of hydrogen, charge carrier adsorption and transfer in an aqueous environment, and change to the hydrogen evolution reaction with the presence of semiconducting nanoparticles. The calculated results not only confirm the possibility of manipulating the performance of carbon-based electrochemical devices in energy application through chemical functionalization but, more importantly, provides the physical rationale for further design strategies.

1892.prez_name: Wet Chemical Synthesis of High-performance Graphene-like Ultrathin 2D Metal Oxide Nanosheets
1892.prez_abstract: Two-dimensional (2D) transition metal oxide systems present exotic electronic properties and high specific surface areas, and also demonstrate promising applications ranging from electronics to energy storage. Yet, in contrast to other types of nanostructures, the question as to whether we could assemble 2D nanomaterials with an atomic thickness from molecules in a general way, which would give them some amazing properties such as those of graphene, still remains unresolved. In this presentation, we will report a generalized and fundamental approach to molecular self-assembly synthesis of ultrathin 2D nanosheets of transition metal oxides by rationally employing lamellar reverse micelles and the functional applications of those unique 2D nanomaterials. It is worth emphasizing that the synthesized crystallized ultrathin transition metal oxide nanosheets possess confined thickness, high specific surface area, and chemically reactive facets, so that they shew promising applications in nanostructured electronics, photonics, catalysis, and energy conversion and storage devices.
