1982.symp_name: Shaping and Forming of Composite Materials

1983.prez_name: Manufacturing Defects in Composite Sporting & Recreational Products
1983.symp_name: Shaping and Forming of Composite Materials

1984.prez_name: Mechanical Properties of Braided Reinforcement with Snap-cure Polyurethane Resins in RTM Processes
1984.symp_name: Shaping and Forming of Composite Materials

1985.prez_name: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of Ti/AZ31 Multi-layered Materials Processed by Accumulative Roll Bonding
1985.symp_name: Shaping and Forming of Composite Materials

1986.prez_name: Production and Characterisation of a Thermoformed Complexly Curved Component from Thermoplastic FRP/Metal Laminate
1986.symp_name: Shaping and Forming of Composite Materials
1986.prez_authors: Maik  Trautmann, Daisy  Nestler, Erik  Schmitteck, Guntram  Wagner, Tomasz  Osiecki, Lothar  Kroll
1986.prez_abstract: Hybrid laminates comprised of metal sheets and fibre-reinforced plastics (FRP) offer the potential to substitute steel components for light weight constructions. Compared to thermoset-based FRP the utilisation of thermoplastic matrices enables the thermal shaping of the laminates. Part of this contribution is the examination of a multi-directional combination of the unidirectional FRP layers between aluminium sheets. The mechanical properties of planar laminates with a multi-directional construction are determined by means of tensile and bending tests. The results of these tests are compared by utilising the classical laminate theory. A hybrid laminate construction designed for bending and torsion is thermally shaped to create a complexly curved component. Microstructural examinations showcase the effect the deformation has on the structure of the laminate and on the quality of the consolidation. The hybrid component structure is tested with bending and torsion tests and compared to steel. The weight was reduced by 40 %.

1987.prez_name: Resin Infusion/Liquid Composite Molding: Review of  Last 35 Years and Going Forward
1987.symp_name: Shaping and Forming of Composite Materials

1988.prez_name: Voids in Composites: Process Modeling and Mechanical Effects
1988.symp_name: Shaping and Forming of Composite Materials

1989.prez_name: A Finite Element Based Model to Validate Temperature Gradient Measurements in Electrical Insulator and Electrical Conductor Ceramics during Spark Plasma Sintering
1989.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
1989.prez_abstract: Spark plasma sintering (SPS) is capable of precisely controlling material microstructures and achieving non-equilibrium phases due to rapid heating and cooling rates through the simultaneous application of pressure and direct current. Due to these characteristics, SPS is an ideal for processing high temperature ceramics at temperatures greater than 1500°C. However in order to process large and more complex geometries these desired microstructure must be maintained thus, we developed a finite element analysis model to ensure processing conditions result in desired microstructures. Our model is a coupled thermal-electrical finite element analysis model to investigate the effect of tooling, contact resistance, and current density on the resultant processing conditions for an electrical conductor, zirconium diboride (ZrB2), and an electrical insulator, silicon nitride (Si3N4). The model is experimentally verified and material properties are optimized in order to calibrate the model.

1990.prez_name: Accelerated Sintering of Powder Metallurgy Ti-6Al-4V Alloy by Repeated Phase Transformation Induced by Thermal Cycling
1990.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
1990.prez_authors: Pankaj  Kumar, K.S. Ravi  Chandran, Fei  Cao
1990.prez_abstract: The effect of cyclic phase transformation (α+β ↔ β) on sintering of PM Ti-6Al-4V alloy, during the dehydrogenation of TiH<SUB>2</SUB> powder, was studied. Sintering experiments with cyclic temperature change across the phase transition temperature (1010°C) of Ti-6Al-4V alloy were performed. It is found that during cycling, sintering depends on the cyclic temperature amplitude. The density was found to increase with decreasing temperature amplitude, for a given sintering time. A density of 98% of theoretical density, which is similar to literature values obtained at high temperature (> 1200°C), was achieved, when the sintering temperature was exactly at the beta transus temperature. It is shown that cyclic sintered PM Ti-6Al-4V alloy can yield tensile properties similar to the wrought Ti-6Al-4V alloy.

1991.prez_name: Achieving Very High Strength in Powder Metallurgy Ti-6Al-4V Alloy through Accelerated Sintering at β-Transus and Hydrogenation-dehydrogenation Treatment
1991.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
1991.prez_authors: Fei  Cao, K.S. Ravi  Chandran, Pankaj  Kumar
1991.prez_abstract: It is demonstrated that very high strength powder metallurgy Ti-6Al-4V alloy can be achieved by accelerated vacuum sintering of compacted titanium hydride (TiH2) powder and followed by hydrogenation-dehydrogenation treatment. A high density (>99%) in Ti-6Al-4V alloy were achieved by vacuum sintering at the β-tansus temperature, taking advantage of accelerated Ti self-diffusion near the -transus. Hydrogenation-dehydrogenation treatment was subsequently used to transform the coarse lamellar structure resulting from vacuum sintering to super fine widmanstatten microstructure. The tensile properties were 1050 MPa YS, 1130 MPa UTS and 10.5% elongation. Interestingly, the β-transus sintered samples showed a higher ductility compared to that of samples sintered at 1200 ˚C, due to finer prior-β grain and high density resulting from β-transus sintering.

1992.prez_name: Challenges, Progress and Perspectives of Nanosintering
1992.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
1992.prez_authors: Boris  Feigelson, James A Wollmershauser, Kedar  Manandhar
1992.prez_abstract: Sintering nanopowders into monolithic solids while preserving the nanoscale of the initial nanoparticles presents a serious challenge. However, succeeding in such an endeavor opens an avenue to design and make solids with enhanced mechanical and physical properties. In order to realize such a sintering process one should suppress grain growth while creating enough driving force to remove porosity. We developed an Enhanced High Pressure Sintering (EHPS) approach to consolidate oxide, metal, and semiconductor nanoparticles into nanostructured monolithic solids. EHPS incorporates stringent environmental control and utilizes high pressures to break agglomerates while simultaneously exploiting the increased pristine surface potential of nanoparticles for surface-energy-driven densification without microstructural changes. Using this approach, monolithic nanocrystalline transparent ceramics with grain size bellow 30 nm are demonstrated. When used in conjunction with particle atomic layer deposition to created core/shell particle building blocks, EHPS techniques produce nanocomposite ceramics, which demonstrate further increased hardness and toughness.

1993.prez_name: Coarsening, Densification, and Grain Growth during Sintering of Nano-sized Powders:  A Perspective
1993.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
1993.prez_authors: Zhigang Zak Fang, Hongtao  Wang, Vineet  Kumar
1993.prez_abstract: Sintering is one of the main and few approaches for building bulk nano materials from bottom up. One of the main challenges of sintering nanosized powders is to control grain growth while achieving full densification. Considerable literature are now available in searching for unique mechanisms that could give us clues to means for achieving densification with minimum grain growth. It is critical to understand the detailed mechanistic steps in order to design processes that might lead to bulk nano materials with maximum density and minimum grain size. Using experimental data of sintering nanosized tungsten carbide and tungsten powders as well as selected data on other materials in literature, this article articulates a perspective examining the unique characteristics of nano sintering, including the driving force, kinetics, and intertwined processes of neck growth, coarsening, densification, and grain growth.

1994.prez_name: Compacting Nanocrystalline Iron-alloy Powders by High Pressure Torsion and Spark Plasma Sintering
1994.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
1994.prez_authors: Reiner  Kirchheim, Christine  Borchers, Marie  Tiegel, Zenji  Horita, Kaveh  Edalati
1994.prez_abstract: Steel powders obtained by mechanical alloying of iron with graphite, iron with iron-oxide as well as iron with iron-boride were nanocrystalline with grain sizes of about 10 nm. The powders were compacted by spark plasma sintering at 500 <sup>o</sup>C and by high-pressure torsion at room temperature and 500 <sup>o</sup>C. During compaction the mean grain sizes rise from about 10 nm to about 20 nm at room temperature and about 50 nm at 500 <sup>o</sup>C. Vickers hardness reaches values of more than 10 GPa at room temperature and about 5 GPa at 500 <sup>o</sup>C. In a few cases dog-bone shaped samples for tensile testing yield flow stresses as high as 1200 MPa. The results are discussed in terms of strain, strain rate, energy input and deformation mechanisms as well as grain growth.

1995.prez_name: Control Oxide Sintering with and without Grain Growth
1995.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
1995.prez_abstract: Final-stage sintering of oxide ceramics invariably involves the competition of densification and coarsening, which has been the key issue since the development of the first modern ceramic in 1950s. Zirconia related ceramics are particularly instructive because they remain ionic over a large range of populations of cation dopants and oxygen defects. Moreover, like most ceramics they have vastly disparate cation and anion kinetics: In this case cations are typically a trillion-fold slower than anions. Yet it is entirely possible to rationally design the zirconia kinetics so that densification, with and without grain growth, can be achieved at will under suitable pressureless-sintering conditions. The lesson learned here has been further applied to other sintering problems where additional driving forces, such as strain energy and electrically-driven ion current (i.e., ion wind), are present. This knowledge is transferable to other technologically important ceramics and nanoceramics, as will be discussed here.

1996.prez_name: Correlation between Particle Size and Grain Size Distributions in Single/Multiphase Ceramics
1996.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
1996.prez_authors: Keyur  Karandikar, Austin  Travis, Kenta  Ohtaki, Martha  Mecartney, Olivia A. Graeve
1996.prez_abstract: We aim to obtain an improved correlation between powder particle and grain size distributions in ceramics prepared by spark plasma sintering. In our study, sample compositions consisted of yttria-stabilized zirconia, spinel and α-alumina powder mixtures of various nanometer/submicron particle sizes. Powder characterization was performed using dynamic light scattering by using stable colloidal suspensions obtained from ζ-potential mapping.  Powders were sintered to obtain fine-grained homogenous single/multiphase composites.  Scanning electron micrographs of fractured and polished surfaces were used to characterize sintered specimens for grain size and porosity.  Density and crystallite size was also obtained. Sintering curves were formulated to study the complex sintering behavior. The composites were also tested for Vickers hardness with values obtained in the range between 1500 and 2000HV.  Preliminary results include three phase composites with average grain sizes as small as 135 nm and 215 nm for starting particle sizes of 100.0 nm and 132 nm.

1997.prez_name: Densification Behavior of MIM491 Superalloy Prepared by Master Alloy Route
1997.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
1997.prez_authors: Lin  Zhang, Xiaowei  Chen, Xuanhui  Qu
1997.prez_abstract: The MIM491 superalloy was prepared by metal injection molding using master alloy technique. Three kinds of master alloys were designed in order to reveal the densification behavior of the alloy. Microstructural evolution of the superalloys during homogenization treatment was investigated in detail. The relative density of the sintered specimens reaches 96%, and the relative density of above 99.9% was obtained after HIPing treatment. Homogenous microstructure is achieved after solution treatment at 1200°C for 4h. The sphere secondary γ′ phase is about 0.1μm, and it distributes uniformly within the grains. The aging temperature of 750°C is suitable for the MIM491 superalloy due to the slow coarsening rate and non-significant morphology change of γ′ precipitates.

1998.prez_name: Effect of Additives on the Kinetics of Formation of Cordierite via Solid State Reaction
1998.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
1998.prez_abstract: Solid state sintering of cordierite (2MgO.2Al2O3.5SiO2) ceramics exhibit difficulty because of the presence of numerous eutectic and peritectic points which are too close to each other. Furthermore, the formation rate of cordierite via solid state sintering is too slow. Synthesizing and characterization of cordierite has been extensively studied but little is known about the individual effects of different additives on formation rate and thermal properties of cordierite via solid state sintering. The aim of this study is to determine the individual effects of ZrO2, CeO2 and TiO2 on the kinetics of formation and thermal expansion coefficient of cordierite. For this purpose, pressed samples containing 2-5wt.% ZrO2, CeO2 and TiO2 were sintered at 1350°C and held for 10 to 50 hours. Cordierite contents of sintered samples were determined by quantitative x-ray diffraction data using both Rietveld and internal standard methods. The results were correlated with the measured thermal expansion coefficient values.

1999.prez_name: Effect of Powder Size and Sintering Parameters on Spark Plasma Sintering Behavior of TiAl-Nb Alloys
1999.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies

2000.prez_name: Energy Coupled to Matter for Field-assisted Sintering of Materials
2000.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2000.prez_authors: Raymond  Brennan, Brandon  McWilliams, Victoria L. Blair, Jian  Yu, Nicholas   Ku, Michael  Kornecki
2000.prez_abstract: Energy Coupled to Matter (ECM) research has been implemented for field-assisted sintering of materials by utilizing magnetic, electric, microwave, and other fields to enable improved processing temperatures & times, enhanced physical & mechanical properties, and unique phase transformations that cannot be achieved through conventional means. Traditional parameters such as temperature, pressure, composition, and scale are often manipulated to achieve desired properties. However, by utilizing more non-traditional parameters such as the application of high energy external fields through ECM, the ability to achieve unparalleled properties beyond the current state-of-the-art becomes possible. Flash sintering, electric field-assisted sintering, microwave sintering, and thermomagnetic processing have been used on a variety of metals, ceramics, and other materials systems. This has led to successful flash sintering of metals (at 25% lower sintering temperatures), magnetic processing of ceramics (-Al2O3 phase formation at 300oC lower temperatures under 9 Tesla field), and a number of other significant ECM achievements.

2001.prez_name: Enhancement of Diffusion Bonding of Silver Graphite to Copper by Severe Plastic Deformation
2001.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2001.prez_abstract: The conventional press and sinter method for fabrication of bi-layered silver graphite-copper electrical contacts has shown to be challenging process due to the immiscibility of graphite in copper and silver. During sintering of silver graphite-copper compacts, silver diffuses into copper leaving a trace of graphite at the interface. This creates a poor interface between the mating surfaces, thereby decreasing the shear strength of the joint. In this work, severe plastic deformation (SPD) by Equal Channel Angular Processing (ECAP) has been used to enhance diffusion bonding and interface properties of bi-layered silver graphite-copper. Microhardness, electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD), and shear testing, are some of the techniques used to characterize the microstructure of ECAP enhanced parts.

2002.prez_name: FAST Sintering of α-Al2O3, MgAl2O4 and 8 mol% Y2O3 Stabilized ZrO2 Composites
2002.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2002.prez_authors: David  Kok, Shikhar Krishn Jha, Rishi  Raj, Martha  Mecartney
2002.prez_abstract: Three-phase, equal volume α-Al<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>3</SUB>, MgAl<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>4</SUB> spinel and cubic 8 mol% Y2O3-stablized ZrO2 (8YSZ) ceramic composites sinter rapidly with the application of a DC electric field. The temperature for the onset of rapid densification (flash sintering) was measured using a constant heating rate at fields of 50-500 V/cm. The flash temperature drops from 1350°C with 100 V/cm to 1150°C with 500 V/cm. The grain size as characterized by SEM is reduced from 650 nm to 470 nm when the voltage was increased from 50 V to 500 V. Sample densities after sintering range from 90-96% theoretical density. At the highest power density (~600 mW/mm<SUP>3</SUP>), the alumina phase completely reacts with spinel to form a single spinel solid solution, with a significant decrease in the lattice parameter measured by XRD. The composition of the spinel solid solution, measured by EDS, was approximately MgO•3Al<SUB>2</SUB>O<SUB>3</SUB>.

2003.prez_name: FEA of Hot Isostatic Pressing of Steel 316: A Comparative Study of Different Powder Compaction Constitutive Models
2003.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2003.prez_authors: Khamis  Essa, Ali M Abdelhafeez, Moataz M Attallah
2003.prez_abstract: One of the key challenges to the application of netshape Powder Hot isostatic Pressing (HIPping) in large scale structures is the availability of modelling tools that can predict the geometrical changes that occur during the consolidation process in order to design the tooling required. Simulation results are known to be strongly dependent on the choice of the powder consolidation constitutive model. This study investigated FE simulation of powder HIPing of 316L using three different constitutive models namely; Gurson, modified Drucker-Prager, and modified Drucker-Prager with creep. Out of three constitutive models, the modified Drucker-Prayer with creep demonstrated the closest predictions to the experimental trials, with a maximum relative error in geometrical prediction of 4.8%. The advantages and limitations of the three constitutive models are assessed.

2004.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2004.prez_abstract: The essential method of flash sintering, and its application to a wide range of ceramic materials will be reviewed.

2005.prez_name: Flash Sintering: How Does the Flash Start and What Are the Densification Mechanisms and Field Effects?
2005.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2005.prez_authors: Yuanyao  Zhang, Jiuyuan  Nie, Jian  Luo
2005.prez_abstract: A quantitative model has been developed to forecast the thermal runaway conditions and the predictions are in excellent agreements with the observed onset flash temperatures, attesting that the flash starts as a thermal runaway [Acta Mater. 94:87 (2015)]. Using ZnO as a model system, a strong dependence of the onset flash sintering temperature on the atmosphere has been discovered. In the best cases, ZnO specimens have been sintered to >97% relative densities in a just few seconds at furnace temperatures of <120 °C in Ar + 5 mol. % H2 [Scripta Mater. 106:26 (2015)]. Further studies systematically investigate the fast densification mechanisms as well as various electric field/current effects on sintering and microstructural evolution. New flash sintering schemes are also developed.

2006.prez_name: Geometrical and Structural Activity in Sintering of Uniaxially Cold Compacted Metallic Powders
2006.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2006.prez_authors: Alberto  Molinari, Elisa  Torresani, Silvia  Baselli
2006.prez_abstract: The work investigates sintering shrinkage of uniaxially cold compacted iron powders with different green density. Shrinkage kinetics was investigated by dilatometry and results anisotropic, being higher along the compaction direction than in the compaction plane. Such an anisotropy has been correlated to the microstructure of the green parts, where particles are anisotropically packed and deformed. The number and the extension of the interparticle contacts was measured by SEM metallography to quantify the geometrical activity and its anisotropy. Due to plastic deformation, the interparticle contact regions contain a large density of structural defects that enhance bulk diffusivity. This results in a structural activity by deformation that further contributes to anisotropy of shrinkage, being the powder particles inhomogeneously deformed. Both the geometrical and the structural activity depend on green density. The work highlights the contribution of the geometrical and of the structural activity on shrinkage and its anisotropy.

2007.prez_name: Grain Growth of Nano-grained Tungsten Powders during Sintering
2007.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2007.prez_authors: Brady G.  Butler, Jonathan P Ligda, Scott C Middlemas, James D Paramore
2007.prez_abstract: Ultrafine and nano-grained materials offer improved strength and unique deformation properties compared to their coarse-grained counterparts.  One of the key hurdles in producing these materials is the effective minimization of grain growth during sintering.  The grain growth of nanocrystalline materials has been studied extensively over the past several decades.  However, there are still significant questions about the mechanisms for grain growth, particularly during the initial stages of sintering.  This research utilizes high-temperature X-ray diffraction under a controlled atmosphere for in situ measurement of the grain growth of nanocrystalline tungsten powders during sintering.  Grain growth kinetics are studied in the context of established transport mechanisms in an effort to identify and understand the essential factors contributing to the grain growth and densification of nanocrystalline tungsten.

2008.prez_name: High-pressure High-temperature Gasket Material for Polycrystalline Diamond Synthesis
2008.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies

2009.prez_name: High Strength Mg-alloys via Powder Metallurgy: Current Results and Future Opportunities
2009.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2009.prez_abstract: Magnesium alloys are currently a fast-growing class of materials that are being heavily investigated owing to their low density. The majority of research has been focusing on alloy design, casting and wrought processing, however grain refinement to the nanoscale has been much less represented. This lecture will present some recent results on the processing of Mg-alloys into nanostructured powders, their densification, and the resulting properties. The talk will also present the benefits and trade-offs associated with powder processing of Mg-alloys and forecast technical areas of future application.

2010.prez_name: In-situ Neutron Scattering upon Sintering of Titanium Alloy Powder Compacts
2010.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2010.prez_authors: Klaus-Dieter  Liss, Gang  Chen, Peng  Cao
2010.prez_abstract: Penetrating neutron radiation allows to investigate the sintering of powder compacts in-situ. Here we report on the phase evolution of nickel and titanium mixtures, determining the reaction process, intermediate pases, the formation of ordered NiTi and a eutectoid reaction upon cooling. Advanced analysis using the dynamical theory of diffraction reveals the defect kinetics of ordered NiTi at very high temperature, found to remain highly ordered in contrast to previously reported disorder.  As neutrons are particularly sensitive to hydrogen, the presence and kinetics of this element bound in the initial powders is exposed.

2011.prez_name: Influence of TiC and/or ZrC Addition on Densification, Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of TZM Alloys Produced by SPS
2011.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2011.prez_authors: Cansinem  Tüzemen, Onuralp  Yucel, Filiz  Sahin, Gultekin  Goller
2011.prez_abstract: TZM alloy which having Mo-0,5Ti-0,08Zr-0,02C wt% as nominal composition has high melting temperature, high recrystallization temperature, superior creep resistance and provide an advantage in elevated temperature when compare with pure molybdenum. Besides formation of TiC and ZrC carbides in molybdenum matrix, addition of TiC and/or ZrC carbides may inhibite the grain growth and mechanical properties. In this study TZM-TiC, TZM-ZrC, TZM-TiC-ZrC composites having variety amounts of TiC and ZrC as an additive were sintered by spark plasma sintering (SPS). The characterization of prepared composites were carried out in terms of their densification, microstructure and mechanical properties.

2012.prez_name: Investigation the Effect of B4C Addition on Microstructure, Mechanical Properties and Oxidation Behavior of TZM Alloy Prepared by Spark Plasma Sintering
2012.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2012.prez_authors: Baris  Yavas, Onuralp  Yucel, Filiz   Sahin, Gultekin  Goller
2012.prez_abstract: TZM alloy is one of the most important molybdenum (Mo)-based alloy which has a nominal composition containing 0.5–0.8 wt% titanium, 0.08–0.1 wt% zirconium and 0.016–0.02 wt% carbon. It is a possible candidate for high temperature applications in a variety of industries. However, drawback of TZM alloy is oxidation easily at high temperature in air. In this study, TZM alloys with additions of 0-5 wt% B4C were prepared by spark plasma sintering (SPS) at 1420°C under 40 MPa for 5 min. Systematic investigation of the effects of B4C addition on oxidation, densification behavior, microstructure and mechanical properties was performed. The results showed that TZM alloy with addition of 5 wt% B4C exhibited the approximately 66% decrease in mass loss at 1000 °C for 60 min in air and increase in hardness of the alloy from 1.9 GPa to 7.8 GPa.

2013.prez_name: Low-cost Titanium Alloys with Wrought-like Microstructures and Exceptional Mechanical Properties Produced by Hydrogen Sintering and Phase Transformation (HSPT)
2013.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2013.prez_authors: James D. Paramore, Brady G. Butler, Matt  Dunstan, Z. Zak  Fang, Pei  Sun
2013.prez_abstract: Hydrogen sintering and phase transformation (HSPT) is a low-cost process to produce high-performance titanium alloys from blended elemental/master-alloy (BE/MA) powder.  During this process, hydrogenated and/or commercially pure titanium powder is blended with alloying elements and sintered under a dynamically controlled H<SUB>2</SUB> partial pressure.  After sintering, the material is annealed under inert gas or vacuum to remove the residual hydrogen and further transform the microstructure.  HSPT takes advantage of phase transformations in the Ti(alloy)-H alloy systems to produce an ultrafine grain (UFG) microstructure in the as-sintered state.  The as-sintered microstructure may be further evolved to form a range of wrought-like equiaxed, bi-modal, or lamellar microstructures with corresponding application-tailored mechanical properties.  This is achieved without resorting to energy-intensive thermomechanical processing (TMP).  The mechanisms behind the microstructural evolution during sintering and subsequent thermal treatments will be presented.  Additionally, the commercial viability of this process and its industrial implications will be discussed.

2014.prez_name: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of ZrC Ceramics Enhanced by TiC Particles and Graphene
2014.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2014.prez_authors: Burak Cagri Ocak, Onuralp  Yucel, Filiz  Sahin, Gultekin  Goller
2014.prez_abstract: ZrC ceramic is characterized by an excellent combination of properties comprising high melting point, hardness, wear resistance, thermal conductivity, good creep resistance, and excellent chemical stability. However, consolidation difficulties, poor fracture toughness generally restrict the extensive applications of monolithic ZrC. Studies in recent years have indicated that graphene nanoplatelets (GNP) addition can significantly improve the mechanical properties of ceramic matrices. ZrC–TiC–Graphenes composites containing 20 vol.% TiC and in the range of  0.25–2.0 mass % graphene were prepared by spark plasma sintering at temperatures of 1750–1850 °C for 300 s under a pressure of 40 MPa. Fully dense ZrC–TiC–GNP composites with a relative density of more than 98 % were obtained. The sintered composites were then characterized with respect to their densification, microstructure, and mechanical properties change with the combination of TiC and graphene nanoplatelets.

2015.prez_name: Microstructure Evolution and Consolidation Kinetics Prediction in Powder Materials during Field Assisted Sintering Technique
2015.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2015.prez_authors: Sudipta  Biswas, Jogender  Singh, Vikas  Tomar
2015.prez_abstract: Field assisted sintering technology (FAST) is a disruptive manufacturing technique for developing new materials in a cost effective manner. Understanding interface evolution along with densification mechanism and grain growth kinetics during the process is of immense importance. Current work captures the microstructural changes including interface formation between particles and it’s evolution over time as the powder particles compact into a polycrystalline structure. Phase field modeling approach has been adopted with additional contribution of interfacial energy, temperature and elastic loading being incorporated. It has been observed that densification during powder compaction is governed by surface and grain boundary diffusion. It has also been noticed that at initial stage individual grain increases in size until it reaches adjacent grains. Once adjacent grains start interacting with each other, grain boundary diffuses and the grain size starts reducing. Towards the end of the process as two or more grain merge into a single grain.

2016.prez_name:
Microwave Assisted Consolidation
of Titanium and Titanium Alloy Powder Compacts
2016.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2016.prez_authors: Ben Y Rock, M. Ashraf  Imam, Tony F Zahrah
2016.prez_abstract: Titanium is an attractive material for a wide range of applications, includingin the defense and aerospace industries, because of its high specific strength and excellent corrosion resistance. The relatively high cost of titanium is the main barrier to its more widespread adoption in these and other industries.  Consolidation of titanium powder compacts by cold iso-static pressing (CIP) followed by microwave sintering is one approach to increasing the cost effectiveness of titanium and is the subject of this presentation. Green compacts of titanium and titanium alloy powder were made using cold isostatic press. The compacts were sintered with microwave energy at 915 MHz. The chemical, microstructural and mechanical properties of samples processed by these methods will be discussed including our experimental procedures that allow us to     repeatably sinter relatively large samples. We will compare the results with the titanium and titanium alloy produced by different methods.

2017.prez_name: Nanograined Bulk Silicon Steel as a Material for Electric Motor Stators
2017.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2017.prez_authors: Trevor  Clark, Hellen  Jiang, Nicole  Overman, Suveen  Mathaudhu
2017.prez_abstract: There has been a push to develop a magnetic material with minimal core loss for use in electric motors to improve efficiency. Laminated silicon steel has been one of the primary materials of interest because of its high permeability and low conductivity which reduce hysteresis loss. These properties can be further enhanced by tuning the microstructure to increase grain boundary scattering and thus resistivity of the material to reduce the need for the non-magnetic laminates. This talk will discuss the results of high energy ball milling and sintering of silicon doped iron to produce nanograined silicon steels. The microstructure is studied to determine the effects of ball milling and sintering on grain size to determine the effects on resistivity and permeability. These findings will help to advance electric motor technology by improving efficiencies, and have widespread energy impacts.

2018.prez_name: Observation of Enhanced Mechanical Properties in Nanostructured Boron Carbide
2018.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2018.prez_authors: Chris  Haines, Matthew  DeVries, John  Pittari, Kendall   Mills, Ghatu  Subhash
2018.prez_abstract: Boron carbide (B<sub>4</sub>C) is known to exhibit highly localized structural phase transformations, namely amorphous shear bands, under high pressure/high strain rate loading. To assess the effect of grain size on this amorphization phenomenon, nanostructured boron carbide was fabricated, evaluated, and compared to a baseline micro-grained (15 μm carbide. Static and dynamic uniaxial compressive strength and Vickers indentation hardness were determined, and Raman spectroscopy was conducted on indented regions in an attempt to quantify and compare the intensity of amorphization. As compared to the baseline micro-grained sample, the nanostructured boron carbide exhibited significantly higher static & dynamic compressive strength, and higher static & dynamic Vickers hardness. Increases in fracture toughness were also seen. The decrease in hardness from the static to dynamic regimes in nanostructured B<sub>4</sub>C showed only a 4.8% decrease as opposed to 8.6% with conventional B<sub>4</sub>C under similar conditions, suggesting a reduced propensity for amorphization.

2019.prez_name: On the Effect of Electric Field during Spark Plasma Sintering: A “Faraday Cage” Approach
2019.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2019.prez_authors: Anil  Prasad, Somi  Doja, Lukas  Bichler
2019.prez_abstract: Recent advances in spark plasma sintering (SPS) resulted in several investigations on the fundamental mechanism operative during powder consolidation during this powder metallurgy process. Some reports credit the features of SPS to the effect of plasma, some to the electric field and some to both, without a definitive method to distinguish these contributions. In this study an innovative method to investigate the effect of electric field on a material during SPS was carried out. Graphite tooling consisting of copper and alumina layers enabled sintering of pure zinc oxide such that the effect of the electric field on the zinc oxide was minimized. Microstructure analysis and densification kinetics were investigated and related to zinc oxide sintered using traditional SPS approach.

2020.prez_name: Phase Evolution, Microstructure and Properties of Porcelains Using Field Enhanced Sintering
2020.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2020.prez_authors: Wirat  Lerdprom, Eugenio  Zapata-Solvas, Doni D Jayaseelan, William E Lee
2020.prez_abstract: Sintering of porcelains has been studied extensively to understand and improve densification and phase evolution which directly control the physical and mechanical properties of the products. Recently, considerable attention has been drawn to ‘Field Enhanced Sintering (FES)’ to ceramics but only a few have dealt with porcelains. In this study, we report the effect of rapid heating in spark plasma sintering, flash sintering and microwave sintering on a porcelain body. FES-densified samples were characterized using XRD, SEM and microindentation.  The effect of FES on the densification and phase evolution of mullite, glass formation and quartz dissolution will be discussed. For example, densification in porcelains using FES was fast due to rapid glass formation. Different mullite morphologies were observed. SPS produced mullite oriented perpendicular to the compressive plane whilst flash sintered samples contained large amount of glass and dendritic mullite. Microwave produced randomly oriented and fibre-like mullite.

2021.prez_name: Porous Materials by Spark Plasma Sintering Using Different Approaches
2021.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2021.prez_authors: Dina V. Dudina, Vyacheslav I. Mali, Alexander  G. Anisimov, Arina  V.  Ukhina, Andrei E. Brester, Boris B. Bokhonov
2021.prez_abstract: Spark Plasma Sintering (SPS) is usually conducted at an applied pressure to reach high relative densities of the consolidated materials. Recently, attention has been directed to possibilities of SPS in the area of porous materials. In this presentation, we will discuss several approaches to the SPS-assisted production of porous materials: 1) pressureless SPS of single phase materials (iron, copper); 2) pressureless reactive SPS (Fe-Al mixtures); 3) SPS associated with phase transformations (graphitization of nanodiamond); 4) SPS followed/combined with selective dissolution of a phase or an element from a phase (nickel-graphite and Fe3C-Fe composites to produce porous carbon-based materials). During pressureless SPS, microstructural non-uniformities may appear in cases of non-uniform current distribution caused by contact conditions between the punch and the sample or the protective foil and the sample. Studies of the behavior of Fe+Al mixtures during SPS without the upper punch will be presented.

2022.prez_name: Processing and Characterization of Gradient Micro-porous Metals through Blended Elemental Powder Metallurgy
2022.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies

2023.prez_name: Reaction Spark Plasma Sintering of ZrB2-TiB2 Ultra High Temperature Ceramics and Their Solid Solutions
2023.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2023.prez_authors: Karthiselva S N, B S Murty, Srinivasa Rao Bakshi
2023.prez_abstract: In the present study, low temperature synthesis and densification of ZrB2-TiB2 composites by reaction spark plasma sintering has been reported. Elemental powders of Zr and Ti were ball milled with B powder and consolidated by spark plasma sintering to produce dense ultra fine grained ZrB2 and TiB2 compacts as well as ZrB2-25 vol.% TiB2, ZrB2-50 vol.% TiB2, TiB2-25 vol.% ZrB2 composites. The microstructure and phase analysis have been determined using SEM and XRD. Solid solution formation was observed in all the composition. The effect of solid solution formation on the hardness, indentation fracture toughness, oxidation resistance and the coefficient of thermal expansion has been studied. UHTC solid solutions showed improved room temperature compressive strength than the monolithic UHTCs. The reaction sintered samples are compared with samples produced from sintering ZrB2 and TiB2 powder mixtures. The high temperature compressive strength and coefficient of thermal expansion of solid solutions is also presented.

2024.prez_name: Sintering and Characterization of Ge2Sb2Te5 Target by Spark Plasma Sintering
2024.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies

2025.prez_name: Sintering Force behind the Viscous Sintering of Two Particles
2025.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2025.prez_authors: Fumihiro  Wakai, Kota Katsura  , Shun  Kanchika, Yutaka  Shinoda, Takashi  Akatsu, Kazunari  Shinagawa
2025.prez_abstract: The mechanical principles of viscous sintering were analyzed by finite element simulation of a simple model: the coalescence of two identical spheres. The sintering force in the non-equilibrium process of viscous sintering was defined as the difference between the average pressure on the contact area and the surface tension along its circumference. The average strain rate on the contact plane was proportional to the sintering force, so that the sintering force was the thermodynamic driving force for both neck growth and shrinkage. Conversely, a theoretical method was proposed to elicit the sintering force from neck growth curves. The simulation also shows that the tensorevirial equation, which is an alternative method to describe the overall anisotropic deformation of aggregates of particles, is valid for viscous sintering.

2026.prez_name: Sintering in Nanocrystalline Alloys Favoring Grain Boundary Segregation and Second Phase Precipitation
2026.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2026.prez_abstract: Powders containing nanocrystalline internal grain structures are attractive inputs for consolidation of bulk nanocrystalline components.  Their nanoscale structure can offer kinetic advantages such as more rapid mass transport through boundaries, as well as thermodynamic advantages such as grain boundary segregation-based stability.  This talk will summarize our work on nanocrystalline alloys designed to be specifically amenable to powder consolidation while retaining a nanoscale structure.  The role of grain boundary segregation on nanostructure stability will be reviewed, along with so-called “nanoduplex” structures in which grain boundary segregation competes with second phase precipitation. We show how a number of such systems can be consolidated to full density while retaining a nanocrystalline structure, in some cases very rapidly without the need for applied pressure. Finally, possible applications for such bulk consolidated nanocrystalline alloys will be highlighted.

2027.prez_name: Sintering Properties of TiB2 Powders from Carbon Coated Precursors Method with TiCrFeCoNiAl High Entropy Alloy as Sintering Aid
2027.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2027.prez_abstract: Titanium diboride powders with high purity, high surface area, and low cost were synthesized from carbon coated Ti containing precursors utilizing patented carbon coating processes. Using the synthesized nano size TiB<SUB>2</SUB> powders and high entropy alloy (HEA) as sintering additive, novel cermets with outstanding properties were fabricated. Effects of HEA amounts and sintering temperatures on relative densities, microstructures, and mechanical properties were studied and evaluated. TiB<SUB>2</SUB> sintering with Ni were also processed as comparison. Research show that at sintering temperature of 1500°C, samples reached high relative density and had submicron to micron grade grain size. Mechanical behavior testing demonstrated samples featured with excellent combination of high hardness and fracture toughness comparing with samples using Ni as additive.

2028.prez_name: Solid Solutions Formation of Tantalum Carbide-hafnium Carbide by Spark Plasma Sintering
2028.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2028.prez_authors: Cheng  Zhang, Ankur  Gupta, Sudipta  Seal, Benjamin  Boesl, Arvind  Agarwal
2028.prez_abstract: Hafnium carbide and Tantalum carbide are ultrahigh temperature ceramics (UHTC) with superior oxidation resistance in oxygen rich and oxygen deficient environments respectively.  Ta4HfC5 phase is known to have highest melting point in HfC-TaC phase diagram; however very little has been studied about solid solution formation in these UHTCs. This study focuses on synthesis of 5 different compositions (pure HfC, 80 vol.% HfC-20 vol.% TaC, 50 vol.% HfC- 50 vol.% TaC, 20 vol.% HfC- 80 vol.% TaC , and pure TaC) in HfC-TaC system by spark plasma sintering at 1850 degree C, 60 MPa and 10 min holding time. Nearly fully dense samples have been achieved in all compositions. The formation of HfC-TaC solid solution has been investigated and confirmed by XRD and HR-TEM. These findings suggest that highly dense TaC-HfC solid solutions synthesized by spark plasma sintering at relatively low temperature and in short time without sintering aids.

2029.prez_name: Spark Plasma Sintering and Largescale Manufacturability of Nuclear Fuel Pellets
2029.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2029.prez_abstract: Spark plasma sintering (SPS) has been used to fabricate UO2, UO2-Diamond and UO2-SiC composite nuclear fuels. The influence of process parameters and their relationship to microstructure evolution are investigated. Master sintering curves (MSC) were developed in order to model and control the sintering process. The activation energy for UO2 and UO2-SiC composite were found to be 140 KJ/mol and 420 KJ/mol, respectively. The ability and accuracy of the constructed master sintering curves for density prediction and sintering profile design have also been demonstrated. Finally, the ability of SPS process for large scale manufacture of millions of pellets per day have been explored.

2030.prez_name: Spark Plasma Sintering of Tungsten Powder: Densification Mechanism and Mechanical Properties
2030.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2030.prez_authors: Geuntak  Lee, Eugene  Olevsky, Joanna  McKittrick, Eugene  Ivanov
2030.prez_abstract: The dominant densification mechanism of a tungsten powder processed by spark plasma sintering (SPS) is revealed by the continuum theory of sintering-based regression of the experimental data on the powder consolidation carried out at the temperatures from 1600 °C to 1800 °C and the pressure levels of 60 MPa and 120 MPa. It appears that the main mechanism of tungsten powder densification compaction is the grain boundary sliding controlled by dislocation climb with dislocations moving along grain boundaries. The evidence of the superplastic-like behavior of the tungsten powder during SPS is also supported by the Electron Backscatter Diffraction microstructure analysis of the compacted specimens. Based on the experimental data on the processed specimens’ carbonization the diffusion coefficient of carbon in tungsten is obtained. The crystal structure, chemical composition, porosity, grain size, and micro-hardness are evaluated by X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, and Vickers micro-hardness testing.

2031.prez_name: Stability of Intergranular Films in MgO-doped Bayer Alumina
2031.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2031.prez_authors: Tobias  Frueh, Elizabeth  Kupp, Charles  Compson, Joe  Atria, Gary  Messing
2031.prez_abstract: Bayer aluminas are typically 99.0 - 99.9% pure and contain Na2O, SiO2, Fe2O3, and CaO as main impurities. In previous work we showed that Bayer aluminas can densify by liquid phase sintering, which strongly depends on the impurity concentrations and the impurity ratios, e.g. the Na2O/SiO2 ratio. MgO is commonly added to alumina powders since it improves the sintering behavior and microstructure evolution. However, there are no systematic studies available on how the sintering mechanisms in Bayer aluminas change as MgO is added. Our recent TEM and EDS studies showed that SiO2 segregates to the grain boundaries, forming a < 2 nm thin intergranular film, which determines the sintering mechanisms in the alumina. In this work we report how the concentrations and relative ratios of MgO and impurities, i.e. SiO2 and Na2O, influence the grain boundary thickness and chemistry, and analyze how this affects the sintering mechanisms in Bayer alumina.

2032.prez_name: Structural and Functional Materials via Spark Plasma Sintering
2032.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2032.prez_abstract: Spark Plasma Sintering involves much lower temperatures and shorter times than conventional sintering, allowing the desired functional properties to be retained. SPS can also be used to synthesize high temperature materials not conveniently accessible in traditional sintering. We have employed SPS to sinter Bulk Metallic Glasses and ThermoElectric materials. Ultrastrong and tough BMGs based on Ni-W are designed via high-throughput computation. Pressure, temperature, and strain rate effects on densification are studied. TE materials, in particular refractory Half-Heusler alloys, are sintered at high temperatures to promote structural order. Consequently, the carrier mobility increases and carrier density decreases, resulting in higher thermopower and figure of merit ZT.  ZT~1.3-1.5 have been obtained in some Half-Heusler alloys. The efficiency for direct conversion of heat to electricity is calculated to be high at 13%, comparable to that based on current state-of-the-art materials. Half-Heuslers have additional attributes including thermal stability, scalability, and relative non-toxicity and abundance.

2033.prez_name: Study on A Low Temperature Sintering Process for Manufacturing Bulk Ultrafine Grained Tungsten
2033.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2033.prez_authors: Chai  Ren, Z. Zak  Fang, Huan  Zhang, Dean  Buchenauer, Robert  Kolasinski, Mark  Koopman
2033.prez_abstract: With the advent of fusion reactor technology, tungsten has been considered as one of the primary candidates for the plasma facing applications. A novel nano-powder consolidation process has been developed for manufacturing kilogram size bulk tungsten with ultrafine grain structure. Compared to conventional sintering at 1800 to 2000 degree C, near fully densified tungsten with ultrafine grain size can be obtained with sintering temperatures as low as 1100 to 1300 degree C. It has been shown that the Ti-based additives have significant grain growth inhabitation effect on sintering of nano-tungsten powders. Preliminary plasma exposure test shows promising results on plasma resistance of this ultrafine grained tungsten material for fusion reactor applications.

2034.prez_name: Study the Effect of Oxygen on the SPS of B4C by Applying the CALPHAD Approach
2034.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2034.prez_abstract: Boron carbide (B4C), a low-density and extremely hard material, has a variety of applications like abrasive powder, blasting nozzles, and grinding wheels. Different groups have tried various procedures to sinter boron carbide to get the highest density and the best mechanical properties. However, a complete understanding of the reactions and sintering mechanisms can lead to design more accurate experiments to fulfill the requirements for having a desired product. Since the two main impurities in the commercial B4C powder are oxygen and carbon, knowing the effect of these impurities on the properties of sintered B4C is of great importance. In this study, the CALPHAD approach will be applied to predict the effect of oxygen and free carbon on the sintering of B4C. Then, the results of computational thermodynamics will be correlated to the results of experiments to explain the sintering behavior of the commercial B4C powder.

2035.prez_name: The Effect of Sintering Temperature on the Microstructure of Fe-1.4 wt.% C Alloy Prepared by Mechanical Alloying
2035.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies

2036.prez_name: The Effects of Adding CuO and/or SiO2 on Low-temperature Sintering, Microstructural Development and Dielectric Properties of TiO2
2036.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies

2037.prez_name: The Relationship between the Grain Size and Ductility of Ultra-fine Grain Powder Metallurgy Tungsten Alloys.
2037.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2037.prez_authors: Huan  Zhang, Zak  Fang, Mark  Koopman, Chai  Ren, James D Paramore, Scott C Middlemas
2037.prez_abstract: The relationship between the grain size and mechanical properties of tungsten alloys was studied for potential improvement in ductility through minimization of grain size, and for possible modification to the ductile to brittle transition temperature (DBTT) in powder metallurgy produced alloys. In this study, Pure W, and alloys of W with 0.5 wt% and 1 wt% of TiH2, were prepared at several sintering temperatures: 1200°C, 1300°C and 1400°C. Three-point bend tests were used to measure strength and ductility at elevated temperatures, and to determine the DBTT of these tungsten alloys. Correlations are examined between ductility, DBTT and the interrelated aspects of composition and grain size. Samples containing titanium exhibited grain sizes less than half those of pure W samples at all sintering temperatures tested, presumably due to grain boundary pinning by Ti rich phases in the microstructure that deterred grain growth.

2038.prez_name: The Usage of Heat Explosion to Synthesize Intermetallic Compounds and Alloys
2038.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2038.prez_abstract: The study is concerned with certain regularities of self-propagating high-temperature synthesis of intermetallic compounds, in particular in the Ti-Al. It is shown the sunthesis of metallides and alloys on their base may occur conditions of heat explosion. It was shown that the developed formulations of SHS mixtures and technological modes of SHS process, allow to create intermetallic alloys based aluminides titanium. The results of microprobe analysis were used to prove the receipt of γ-TiAl in a two-phase structure of the alloy with intermetallic phase γ-TiAl + α2-Ti3Al.  The possibility of obtaining intermetallic titanium alloys for compressor blades of gas turbine engines based on the method of self-propagating high-temperature synthesis.

2039.prez_name: Zirconium Carbide by Spark Plasma Sintering: Densification Kinetics, Grain Growth and Thermal Properties
2039.symp_name: Sintering and Related Powder Processing Science & Technologies
2039.prez_authors: Xialu  Wei, Eugene  Olevsky, Christina  Back, Oleg  Izhvanov, Christopher  Haines
2039.prez_abstract: Spark plasma sintering (SPS) is employed to consolidate a micron sized zirconium carbide (ZrC) powder. The densification kinetics of ZrC powders subjected to conventional hot pressing and SPS are comparatively studied by applying similar heating and loading profiles. Due to the lack of electric current assistance, the conventional hot pressing appears to impose lower strain rate sensitivity and higher activation energy values than those which correspond to the SPS processing. A finite element simulation is used to analyze the temperature evolution within the volume of ZrC specimens. The grain growth mechanism during the final SPS stage is studied via a recently modified model, in which the grain growth rate dependence on porosity is incorporated. The constant pressure specific heat and thermal conductivity of the SPS processed ZrC are determined to be higher than those reported for the hot pressed ZrC and the benefits of applying SPS are indicated accordingly.

2040.prez_name: Creating High-property Fine/Ultrafine-grained Metallic Materials via Friction Stir Processing
2040.prez_authors: Z.Y.  Ma, Peng  Xue, Bolu  Xiao
2040.prez_abstract: Friction stir processing (FSP), a derivant based on friction stir welding, induces severe plastic deformation and material mixing at high temperature and therefore has been developed to be an unique technique for reconstructing the microstructure of metallic materials. In this study, fine/ultrafine-grain microstructures were created in aluminum alloys, magnesium alloys, copper alloys and steels via FSP. Significantly enhanced mechanical properties and superplasticity were achieved in these fine/ultrafine-grained metallic materials. For example, FSP plain low carbon steel with ultrafine dual-phase structure exhibited a high yield strength of ~1.1 GPa and a uniform elongation of 7%, and FSP fine Mg–Gd–Y–Zn–Zr alloy exhibited a high superplasticity of 3570% at a high strain rate. This indicates that FSP is an effective route for enhancing the mechanical properties of metallic materials. The mechanisms responsible for the microstructural refinement and property enhancement in these FSP materials were analyzed and discussed in detail.

2041.prez_name: Effect of Friction Stir Processing Parameters on Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of Aluminium 6063 Alloy
2041.prez_abstract: Friction stir processing (FSP) is an effective microstructural modification technique. In present work, Aluminium 6063 alloy is FSPed at different combinations of traverse and rotational speeds. The effect of these process parameters on tribological properties is investigated. Wear test was carried out on pin-on-disc configuration using universal tribometer. Microstructure of surface was analyzed using scanning electron microscope (SEM). The results showed that increase in rotational speed increases the wear rate. The increase in rotational speed increases the heat generation in the nugget zone which leads to more softening of the matrix. The high heat generation causes matrix softening which results in increased wear rate. The increase in traverse speed decreases the wear rate due to less residing time for frictional heat generation. Microstructure results showed that FSPed alloy has more refined grain structure as compare to base material which may be resulted in enhancement of hardness and resistance to wear.

2042.prez_name: Equal Channel Angular Extrusion (ECAE) of FeCo-2V Soft Magnetic Alloy
2042.prez_authors: Donald F. Susan, Jeff M Rodelas, Blythe G. Clark, Ibrahim  Karaman, Taymaz  Jozaghi
2042.prez_abstract: The soft magnetic alloy 48Fe-48Co-2V was subjected to equal channel angular extrusion (ECAE), a severe plastic deformation (SPD) process, at Texas A&M University. The ECAE process resulted in dramatic microstructural refinement with grain size of 1-3 microns, compared to conventionally processed bar with grain size >25 microns. Yield strengths of 650-700MPa (94-102ksi) and ultimate tensile strengths of 900-1400MPa (130-200ksi) were achieved, representing a 2 to 3-fold increase in strength compared to conventional bar.  Importantly, the ductility of FeCo-2V was also significantly improved by ECAE, with 15-20% elongation for optimized ECAE samples compared to 4-7% elongation for conventional bar material. After ECAE, samples were heat treated at 838°C for 2 hours in order to increase magnetic performance. The heat treatment improves the magnetic response compared to the as-ECAE condition, but strength and ductility are both reduced after heat treatment. The possibility for tradeoffs between mechanical and magnetic performance will be discussed.

2043.prez_name: Experimental Study of the Effect of Flyer Thickness and Impact Angle on Interface Structure of Impact Welds
2043.prez_authors: Taeseon  Lee, Anupam  Vivek, Glenn  Daehn
2043.prez_abstract: Impact velocity, collision angle, and thicknesses of flyer and target materials have been proposed as contributing factors to the quality of impact welds. In this study, impact weld couples were made using electrically vaporized aluminum foil to accelerate Al 1100 sheets toward AISI 1018 steel plates. The effect of flyer thickness on the weld interface was investigated with target thickness and impact velocity held constant. Flyer thicknesses were varied from 0.0254 to 1.016 millimeters. Simultaneous multi-point velocity measurements were taken via photonic Doppler velocimetry (PDV). PDV data were reconstructed to determine shape evolution of the flyer and the angle when it reached the target. Electron microscopy and analysis assisted in understanding how morphology and intermetallic compounds at the weld interface are affected by impact angle and flyer thickness. A new weldability window was created with respect to flyer condition and energy input.

2044.prez_name: Friction Stir Processing of 304L Stainless Steel
2044.prez_authors: Michael  Miles, Tracy  Nelson, Cameron  Gunter, Fengchao  Liu, Lionel  Fourment
2044.prez_abstract: Friction stir processing (FSP) has potential as a weld repair technique for irradiated stainless steel, because it operates at much lower temperatures than fusion welding, and is therefore less likely to cause cracking in the HAZ. Experimental evidence of the crack repair capability of FSP will be presented. Numerical simulation of the FSP process in 304L stainless steel was performed using both a Lagrangian and an Eulerian finite element approach. Model input required flow stresses for the large range of strain rates and temperatures inherent in the FSP process. Temperature predictions in three locations adjacent to the stir zone were accurate to within 4% of experimentally measure values. The relationship between FSP process conditions and recrystallized grain size in the stir zone was investigated.

2045.prez_name: Hybrid Extrusion-machining Method for Single-stage Processing of Fine-grained Magnesium Alloy Sheet
2045.prez_authors: Dinakar  Sagapuram, Kevin  Trumble, Srinivasan  Chandrasekar
2045.prez_abstract: This talk describes a novel hybrid extrusion-machining method for producing metal sheet and foil in a single deformation step, with application to lightweight magnesium alloys. By utilizing a constraining edge placed directly across from the cutting tool edge, the usual machining process is transformed into a continuous large-strain shear deformation process. The confinement of deformation zone in extrusion-machining and the resultant near-adiabatic heating is particularly suitable for processing poor-workability alloys such as magnesium with minimum pre-heating of the workpiece. Furthermore, the deformation zone parameters such as strain, strain path and strain rate can be independently controlled to induce severe microstructure refinement and engineer crystallographic textures. A detailed application of parametric deformation control to create tilted-basal textures and ultrafine grain sizes in magnesium alloy sheet for enhanced combinations of formability and strength will be presented.

2046.prez_name: Investigation of Process Parameters for Friction Stir Processing (FSP) of Ti-6Al-4V Alloy
2046.prez_authors: Sandip Subhash Chougule, Digvijay  Sheed, Nithyanand  Prabhu, Bhagwati P Kashyap, Kaushal  Jha, Rajkumar  singh
2046.prez_abstract: Friction stir processing of the Ti-6Al-4V alloy was carried out. Various process parameters (tool traverse speed and tool rotation speed) were studied for successful FSP of Ti-6Al-4V. The process parameters were identified using macrostructure observation on the surface of processed plate and microstructure evolution in the stir zone (SZ) of the FSP specimen. The effect of tool traverse speed and tool rotation speed on microstructure evolution in the SZ, thermo-mechanical affected zone and heat affected zone were studied. The microstructure transformation from initial elongated α structure to prior β grains with α layer grain boundary consisting mixture of acicular α’ and very fine lamellar α/β colonies was observed at SZ for all the parameters except for the tool rotation speed of 600 rpm and traverse speed of 60 mm/min and 100 mm/min. Bands of DRX α and transformed β structure observed at SZ of 60 mm/min and 100 mm/min parameters.

2047.prez_name: Microstructural Evolution and High Strain Rate Behavior of Solid State Additive Manufactured Inconel 625
2047.prez_authors: Paul G Allison, Oscar  Rivera, Omar  Rodriguez, Brian  Jordon, Luke  Brewer, Nanci  Hardwick, Jianqing  Su, Greg  Thompson
2047.prez_abstract: The Solid State Additive Manufacturing (SSAM) process referred to as Additive Friction Stir (AFS) provides a new path for coating, joining and additively manufacturing materials such as Inconel 625. SSAM-AFS process differs from traditional friction stir welding since metal powder or solid rod is fed through a non-consumable rotating cylindrical tool generating heat and plastically deforming the feedstock material through controlled pressure from the tool as successive layers are built upon a substrate. In this research, the dynamic recrystallization and grain refinement is characterized for the successive layers in as-deposited samples using Electron Backscattered Diffraction (EBSD). The EBSD results depict grain structures formed by dynamic recrystallization with even finer grain structures forming at the layer interfaces. Tensile behavior of these fine-grained structures at both quasi-static (0.001/s) and high strain rate (1500/s) using electromechanical and a direct tension-Kolsky bar, respectively, show an increase in yield and ultimate strength as rate increases.

2048.prez_name: Microstructural Evolution and Mechanical Properties of Mechanically Alloyed and Sintered Fe-1.4 wt.%C Alloy
2048.prez_authors: Ibrahim Youniss Khalfallah, Alex O. Aning
2048.prez_abstract: Fe-1.4 wt.% C bulk alloy was prepared using powder metallurgy method. Elemental iron and graphite powders were mechanically milled up to 40 h, cold-compacted, and then sintered between 900°C to 1200°C. X-ray diffraction, differential scanning calorimetry, scanning electron microscopy, and micro-hardness tests were used to characterize milled powder and sintered bulk samples. The effect of mechanical alloying milling time on microstructural evolution, density, and  hardness of the alloy were investigated. After milling, only α-Fe peaks were detected, in X-ray data whereas α-Fe and Fe3C peaks were observed after sintering. In sintered samples, Vol. % of Fe3C decreased with milling time. Also, hardness decreased with milling time, regardless of sintering time and temperature.

2049.prez_name: Microstructural Heterogeneity and Texture of As-received, Vacuum Arc-cast, Extruded, and Re-extruded NiTi Shape Memory Alloy

2050.prez_name: Microstructure and Mechanical Properties of Friction Stir Processed Kanthal APMT Alloy
2050.prez_authors: Anumat  Sittiho, Vedavyas  Tungala, Indrajit  Charit, Rajiv S. Mishra
2050.prez_abstract: Kanthal APMT alloy (Fe-22Cr-5Al-3Mo) was developed for use as high temperature furnace elements. This kind of high-Cr ferritic steels is not considered to have good weldability because of a variety of metallurgical issues. Friction stir welding, a solid state welding process, was applied to a Kanthal APMT plate in a bead-on-plate configuration using a PcBN tool with a tool rotation rate of 600 RPM and the transverse speed of 25.4 mm/min.  Microstructure and mechanical properties were evaluated to determine the quality of the weld and evaluate the feasibility of using friction stir welding for this steel. Microstructural characteristics were mainly studied by optical microscopy and transmission electron microscopy.  The stir zone contained equiaxed grain structure with an average grain size of 21 μm. Vickers microhardness profile across the processed zone revealed no significant change in microhardness.

2051.prez_name: Microstructure Evolution and Deformation Mechanisms Responsible for Flow Softening of Ti17 Alloy during Isothermal Compression

2052.prez_name: Some Study on the Milling Parameters Optimization in the Direct Carburization of WO3 by Mechanical Alloying
2052.prez_authors: Véronique  Vitry, Victor Ioan  Stanciu, Fabienne  Delaunois
2052.prez_abstract: The mechanical alloying method allows synthesizing tungsten carbide by carburization of tungsten trioxide. Temperature and pressure have a determined role on the speed of the reaction. The amount of energy developed during grinding depends on the characteristic of the mill.A simplified computational modeling was used to determine that the energy developed during an impact depends on the mass and speed that various sizes of balls attain during the grinding process. To determine the effect of milling parameters on the temperature during a grinding cycle, a temperature monitoring device was installed on the grinding bowl. The tests were carried out with a planetary mill equipped with bowls lined with tungsten carbide and tungsten carbide balls. To follow the carburizing reaction, samples have been investigated by X-ray diffraction. The morphology of the particles was studied by scanning electron microscopy and the particle size was investigated by laser granulometry in liquid medium.
